text: Brown color. Fruity aroma, nice caramel malt tones. Tastes is sweet with some fruity yeast tones, but balanced by a perfect spicy finish. Notes of licorice, caramel, dried fruits, fennel, a bit of clove are evident. Finishes nice and spicy...bit of roast. An incredible dubbel.

Rami Rami is drinking an Abbey Ale by Brewery Ommegang at Powiśle

Bardzo slodowo-owocowo-rodzynkowo-mineralno-przyprawowe. Kolejnosc nieprzypadkowa. A zarazem dosc lekkie w odbiorze. Jak na dubla to wow!
Cork bottle from 2012: Pours a rustic brownish ruby red. Aroma/Taste: figs, dates, raisins and plums. velvety smooth on the palate, with a bitter sweet finish.
Flaska från SB. Rostbröd kulör med vitgrå skumkrona. Doft av torkade fikon och katrinplommon. Frisk och halvsöt munkänsla. Smak av portvin, russin, torkade katrinplommon, choklad och alkohol.
Quite dry palate. Fruity then dark chocolate. Medium bitter. Full bodied. Ruby colour cloudy huge head. Good dubbel, interesting contrast of fruity and chocolate.
Small bottle. Brownish. Raisins, fruity, chocolate. Sweet taste, creamy mouthfeel. Descent dubbel

Clear, dark amber color with tan head. Aroma has sugar and dried fruits, mostly raisins. Taste follows with dried fruits and candi sugar but there is also a metallic note, not really pleasant. Medium body, medium plus carbonation. The metallic note fades after some time but its still a mediocre beer for my taste.
Bottle. HUGE head with an underwhelming aroma. Yeast, citrus (orange), toffee on nose with a full flavor that is slightly sour with a dry finish.

37,5cl bottle from beergium. Dark orange, red, brown. Head is thin to medium beige. Taste is light sweetness, medium bitterness. Medium carbonation and body. Aroma and flavour is caramel, yeast, banana, hazelnuts, raisins, malt, vanilla, whisky, liquorice, honey.

Âmbar escura de leve turbidez, espuma marrom clara de ótima formação e persistência. Chocolate, laranja, passas, complexa. Paladar de médio/alto dulçor sem amargor. Corpo e carbonatação médios. Final adocicado tendendo para o anis e leve picância. Muito boa.

Puszysta, obfita piana, średnio trwała. Barwa miedziana, klarowna. Aromat karmelowo melasowy z całą masą przypraw, suszonych gruszek i rodzynek. W smaku dość słodki, głównie suszone owoce, karmel, melasa, miód, troszkę orzechów, rumu, skórki pomarańczy, pumpernikla, w przeciwieństwie zaś do większości intensywnych, ciemnych piw świątecznych przyprawy są tu delikatnym dodatkiem, uzupełnieniem w aftertejsie. Goryczka niska, herbaciano ziołowa. Wysycenie wysokie, drobniutkie, za wysokie, półpełne, lekko szorstkie w odbiorze.

Całkiem dobry Dubbel, na plus nie dominujący całości wpływ przypraw, aczkolwiek przeszkadza nieco musujące, szampańskie nagazowanie. Do Westmalle Dubbel jednak troszkę brakuje w mojej opinii...

slightly opalescent mahogany-ruby colour, large, dense and stable beige head; aroma of dried sour cherry, dark chocolate, plum jam, caramel biscuit, hints of vanilla, licorice and slight nutmeg; taste of dark chocolate cake with burnt plum jam, bittersweet burnt sugar, licorice and minimal anise; excellent dubbel!

UPDATED: APR 1, 2017 Found at the neighborhood HEB, thank you very much. Tilted into my New Belgium tulip glass it shows a dark ruby red with a glorious long lasting off-white head. It is a nose of great promise, ripe fruit, vanilla and caramel. The taste is quite fine, I get plum, raisin, a slight sweetness and a lingering satisfying bitterness. Not heavy like other Belgians, I can appreciate it both ways, Good time.

33cl bottle at home. Semi-hazy ruby pour wiht a tall tan head with good retention. Notes of caramel, toffee, light licorice, milk chocolate, tons of dried fruit, figs, overripe grapes. Very well balanced, sweet but surprisingly drinkable.

Bottle. Trappist glass. Brownish with light brown, tiny head. Poor head retention and lacing. Moderate to light heavy malty aroma, caramel, candy sugar, toffee, mild no to intense yeasty profile, slightly peachy. Taste is light heavy sweet, candy-like, honey, no really long. Medium body, watery to oily texture, average to lively carbonation, palate is nice and creamy. In overall not really complex, should be more sticky and malty, nicely drinkable. Overrated.

35,5 cl bottle, bottled 2/10/2016, BBE 11/2019. Color is dark ruby with a nicely solid off-white head. Nice aroma of malty sweetness, toffee, sweet bun, Christmas fruits, anise. Taste is similar. Anise seemed very powerful at first, not my favorite that one, but the other flavors start coming through. Gets better as it warms up.

From bottle, pours a dark cherry with tan head which is thick and foamy. Copious amounts of toffee, black cherry, roasted nuts and caramel on the nose. A viscous palate with cherry and malty flavors and dancing carbonation. Well made, just not something I would drink very often.

Bottle (from beergium). Pours dark amber with huge brownish beige head. Aroma is sweeet, malt, dark fruits, candy sugar. Flavor is sweet, dark fruits, spices, malt. Overall: not really complex, and im not sure why its 3rd rated abbey dubbel, but it is ok Belgian Strong Ale...

Bottle from World Beer Market (Sake o Taniguchi). Nice dark roasty nose with brown sugar. Dark ruby/brown color, 1-2cm tan head. Sweetish initial, with dark fruit, caramel. Some licorice, dates, and heavy toffee. Mild alcohol presence. Medium body and a bit warming. Very pleasant dubbel.
Bomber bottle. This is a nearly perfect brew with incredible blends of tasty ingredients. Start here if youre looking for a primer on Belgian dubbels.
Bottle. Pours a cloudy dark brown with an off-white head. Dark fruit and Belgian malt in the taste and aroma. everything great about an Abbey Dubbel without being overbearing. Delicious.

Bottle - pour is cloudy and a dark brown color with very little light penetration. The head is thick and highly carbonated. The aroma is yeast, vanilla and notes of ice cream. The taste is caramel, vanilla and a highly carbonated finish with a little bitter notes.

A fair brew. Not one I would seek out but one I would not turn down. Its good and the aroma is excellent. I may up my rating on this one in the future. I have more to drink and my taste might just be off.
nice malty stone fruit aromas. dark red in color with nice lightly red tinted long lasting head. taste is malty of darker caramel malts, raison, plum, and cherry. finishes clean and smooth.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark copper color with a ton of tan head. Aroma is very mild. Some yeast, fruit, maybe molasses. Flavor has a lot of fruit--dried cherries, apricots, a hint of pear. Some nice malt and just a bit of saltiness. Subdued bitterness in the finish. Medium mouthfeel with mild carbonation. This is a very nice beer with a lot of stuff going on.

Tasting at brewery. Pours deep amber with a medium off-white head. Aroma is malt, licorice, spice, and figs. Taste is sweet malt, dark berries, toffee, anise, and licorice. Full body. Light carbonation. Creamy, heavy, almost syrupy mouthfeel.

Bottle, pours a ruby brown shade with 2 finger head. Smell and taste of dark cherry, dark malt, roast, licorice, and caramel. Rich in the flavor with lots of dark fruits and yeast. Finish is somewhat dry.

Mörkt bärnstensfärgad, disig med medelstort skum. I doften finns massor av torkad frukt, främst russin och mörka plommon,men även lite kryddor. Smaken är stor och fyllig med sötma från torkade frukter, mycket russin i eftersmaken, även lite toffesötma, en fin kryddighet som balanserar sötman och en liten beska på slutet. Munkänslan är stor, mjuk och rund. En riktigt smakrik och välbalanserad dubbel

Smell of hop, malt, toast caramel, anise, cinnamon. Come in dark amber with thin brown crown. Full body taste with hop, malt, and sour caramel. Strong alcohol, somewhat bitter. Smooth but not as balanced due to hindered sourness. Good overall.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2016 I went to Cooperstown NY this week, enjoyed the Hall of Fame and enjoyed this super tasting beer. Really great taste. Nice dark appearance, with a pleasant aroma,  Really great taste with a very good aftertaste. Maybe the best Ommegang brews.

Grand beer! Faint nose of black plums. Mouth is full body coffee and chocolate with dried fruits, plums, apricots, sultanas, a light touch of licorice. Very well balanced with enough acidity to be fresh and not too sweet. Really good!

Aromas of fig, black licorice, raisins and a little spice. Apperance was a deep murky brown, with very small floaters, medium carbonation, and the head was thin and tan. Flavors were similar to the aroma with the licorice being at the forefront, and the caramel and dark fruits lurking in the background. Overall not my favorite from ommegang but still a very solid brew.Originally rated on 10/8/2008.
Bottle from Red Star. Deep mahogany pour. Fruitful aroma with booze, malt, toffee, honey and earth. Flavor is malt, chocolate, licorice and dark fruits and berries.

Out of the bottle, poured light brown, cloudy, with a big rocky persistent tan head. Absolutely beautful in the glass. Malt forward notes of brown raisin bread, molasses, along with fig, cinnamon, and chocolate covered cherries. Rich and complex. Sublime. Loved it.

BOTTLE. Crimson to brown colour with minimal white head.. Berries & plum nose sweetness, malt is hidden.. Sweet malt backbone, dark berry, toffee apple sweetness finishes quickly, wheres the ABV?? Sourced Cape Cellars

For the book. Aroma is caramel, earthy hops, wood, it barely smells like anything. Appearance is brown, light tan head, not clear. Taste is caramel, wood, earthy hops, dirt, dry, some fruit, yep, its a dubbel. Mouthfeel is medium body, light carbonation, woody fruity aftertaste. Overall, this may be the best dubbel Ive had

Pours clear deep mahogany with low light tan head. Aroma of hazelnut, toffee, roasted malt, figs and dates. Taste is sweet and complex, mild bitter finish. Light to medium bodied, smooth, with average carbonation.
Bottle - pours brown with a tan head. Aroma is dried fruit, burnt sugar, rummy. Taste is sweet burnt sugar and fruit, leading to dry sweet boozy finish. Palate is fizzy.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a deep ruby red color with a thick tan head. Aroma is of honey, raisins, yeast and some spice. Full body, lots of carbonation, the taste has a sweet characteristic along with some dried fruit and yeast. Finish is a little dry and just a slight tartness on the sides of the tongue after the swallow. Excellent!

Bottle from World Beer Market. Dark burgundy pour, mahogany up to the light, thick beige head, lots of carbonation. Pleasing well-melded aroma, hints of Belgian yeast, spice, dark fruits, licorice. Subtle flavours of plum and fig, yeast notes, a little booze and a nice spicy finish. Fluffy upfront feel, medium-body, noticeable sweetness and a dry finish. As it warms the licorice pops nicely.

bottle from Wegmans in Fairfax
Aroma: dark fruits, cherries, caramel, Belgian yeast
Appearance: clear amber with a tan head
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: medium body, creamy, average carbonation, dry finish

excellent

750ml bottle. Hazy redish brown with beige head. Aroma is malty with belgo yeast, dried fruits, raisins, figs and slight alcohol. Taste is dry with belgo yeast, sweet malts, dried fruits and slight alcohol warmth. Dry medium mouthfeel, low carbonation and malty dried fruit aftertaste.

Smells of cherry and burbon some sweet Orange peel and rustic finish. Super dark bergondy color with large pillows off white head. Taste is quite complex, with sweet malts starting things off then tons of corriander taste with a bit of Orange peel flavor, some booziness nice smooth finish. Medium body with creamy carbonation. Great beer need to try more from you guys. Nice work!
Smooth malty flavours. Chocolate, toast. Syrupy palate. Long length. Very enjoyable.
Large Format Bottle - poured dark red brown - creamy tan head that lingered through the whole glass - nice balance on the pallet
Bottle. Pours reddish brown. Aroma of licorice, raisin, plums and fruitcake. Malty flavour with licorice and star anise coming though. Some sweetness. Nice rich beer.

At Milanos. Pours dark brown with a malty initial taste. Then a taste of caramel and a subtle difference- someone mentioned liquorice. A creamy smooth finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy
Pours a nice cola colored brown. Aromas of dark malts, fruit, and a touch of spice. Has flavors of chocolate, caramel, and a touch of wood.

Dark ruddy hazy colored pour with thin film of tan bubbles. Aroma is complex - lots of malt as expected with tons of dark fruits, plums, raisins, some cocoa, caramel - almost too much for my sensitive sniffer... but in a good way. Flavor is good but not quite as exciting - still malty with some prune and sweetness. Fairly clean finish. Very good, but a little wacky. Still looking for my ideal dubbel.

Bottled, 355ml, aged 4 yrs, from Stirchley Wines, Birmingham,. Dark brown ruby with cream head. The ageing has worked very nicely with this, smooth and rich malts lead the way, there is a port wine element with a prune like fruitiness. Christmas cake and just a hint of herbiness. True to its style most of the way but perhaps lacking the Belgian yeasty element. Very good.

Bottle gift from EVSJ 160409. 8.5 abv. 
Pours a clear dark mahoganny with lacing espressolike head. 
Sweetish nose with dried fruits, prunes and figs. Sweet first palate with figs, prunes. Dark chocolate. Dry adstringent finish. Excellent Belgian ale style. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Pours a mahogany brown color with off white head. Fruity, plum, malty, yeasty, raisin aromas. Dark fruit, malty, yeasty flavors. Top notch dubbel

Aroma of light grape and metallic. Cooper with a nice head. Malty and sweet with light grape and Belgian yeast. Very nice flavors nice brew. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Amber color with a big frothy biege head. The aroma and flavoring includes orange, coriander, and Belgium yeast esters. Very tasty.

The abbey dubbel I chose for the abbey vertical tasting (after RR Redemption and Chimay Doree). (This includes Abbey Road and the cutest 4 year old, Abbey wager, an inspiration for the tasting!) Pour reddish rust with a caramel beige head. The aroma brings light spice and some sweet Belgian yeast with some sweet malts as well. The flavor has a nice sweet malty profile balanced with the Belgian yeast and just a kiss of the Belgian spice.

Bottle from Beer Cartel 040316. Dark red copper in clout with a solid even layer of foam. Plums and raisins permeate the nose and the flavour is all spiced fruit. Great beer that has a big body and a strong finish.

12oz bottle poured into a tulip. A dark fruit (plums and figs) and sweet spice are most noted with a mild citrus and light, sweet licorice. The beer pours a deep, dark mahogany color with a khaki, foam-cream head that has good retention and mild lace. The taste is a medium / medium high bitter with a medium sweet note. The oily texture has creamy carbonation and a medium body with flavors of prune, fig, and molasses and a finish with a warm bakinh spice and molasses combination, as well as woody notes. The aftertaste is bread crust with a bit of a pumpkin / squash note.
Bottled. Wow. This is really Belgian. Its brown-red, lovely small bubbles. The aroma is like dark bread, the taste is malty and toasted with a lovely alcoholic finish.

Bottle at movie theater in Bethesda, MD. Nice dark amber body with fluffy head. Nose is floral, dark fruits and caramel. Taste is also of fruits, cherries and darker maltier, toffee and caramel. Nice and strong finish.

Bottle. Pours a coppery, brownish body with a frothy light tan top. Complex aroma with leather, honey, caramel, liquorice and a whiff of alcohol. Nice, rounded flavours with a mix of sweet malts and sour/salty liquorice notes. Notes of raisins and wood as well. Light bitterness. Fullbodied with high to medium high levels of co2.

Bottle poured into a Spencer chalice at about 50 degrees F. Cannot find a date on this, but I think it could be quite old. The surprise is that there is no sweetness in it at all. Has a good head, smells yeasty, looks fine, Im getting the dark fruitiness, the complexity, maltiness and spiciness. It has a nice body and a good dry finish. Maybe Im just expecting too much sweetness from this style, but this ale is underwhelming. Will give it another shot at some point.

From the bottle...popped the cork and poured to the chalice from the brewery. Big coffee head with a mix of bubbles, fades like soap. Deep ruby brown in the glass. Light penetrates a little, and appears clear. Fun lightly fruity nose. Dark cherry sweetness on the first taste that rides a mild malty chocolate through the middle. Warm in the throat but not boozy. The beer that got me started revisited years later. Great trip rating this one.

This is a wonderful beer from Ommegang. Havent had it in a while so I figured I dive in. First off, the color is absolutely gorgeous. Rich deep mahogany, not gonna be seeing anything through this. Tastes like a big piece of cherry juice soaked cinnamon raison bread. Big and sweet, lots of richness, this cat will make you purr with happiness. Its really complex, and at the same time simple. I havent had any Ommegang in a while, but Im glad theyre still making some quality beers. Cheers

Bottle to goblet. Look is medium reddish brown, off white, very creamy head. Head is lasting, bubbly legs after every sip. Aroma is Brown bread, yeast, hint of citrus, orange I think, raisin, coriander. Taste is honey, brown sugar, some yeasty Belgian Wang, but not too bad. Little bits of malt and spice. Orange peel. Pretty good Belgian style. Ommegang is always tasty. Thanks to my Wife for a great stocking stuffer.

8.2%ABV. Abbey Dubbel.

18ºSRM.

Formic acid. Dust. Oak. Sandalwood. Sour cherries. 

Graham cracker, walnuts. Pepper, basil spice. Nutmeg. 

Alcoholic finish.

Bottle 0.355l at home, Oulu. Bottled 12/05/12. BBE 12/30/15. Colour is murky brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Dryness, raisins, dry fruits, chocolate, some sweeyness, Belgian yeast and malts. In excellent condition.

Shared 25.4 oz. bottle. Dark brown with thin but long-lasting creamy head. Aromas of caramel, dark fruits, and some alcohol. Yeast, dark fruits, and alcohol flavors. A rather sweet finish. Good, but not earth-shattering.

Aroma: malty, bready, sweet; Appearance: very dark ruby red; creamy, tan head that lingers; good lacing; Taste: malty and yeasty with spicy undertones; Palate: heavy body with long, sweet finish; Overall: can appreciate the quality but too yeasty for my taste.
Dark red. Aroma of vanilla, woody cherry chocolate. Creamy head. Honey toffee caramel, sweet malts licorice, cherry, a little tartness and some dryness in finish.
Bottle. Pours Dark Amber. Aroma is Sweet. Taste is sweet and spicy with hints of licorice and caramel. Finish is sweet and bready.

Great flavor. A great example of a Belgian Dubbel. 

Brown in color, nice tan head that stays around. Not a lot of carbonation after the pour. Sweet sugary caramel aroma. Sweet flavor and a lasting sweet finish. Just enough hops to balance it out.
Bit of a strange bottle - at times more bitter and dry than Id expect/want from a dubbel. Other pours were superb. All in all a good beer.
Pours dark brown, maroon highlights, amber head. Spicy aroma, maybe coriander cumin, definitely banana. Taste is banana, coriander, hints of anise and hops. Dark fruit seems right. My first dubbel.

Abbey Ale is fantastic in the safest way possible. It looks beautiful when its poured, its not offensive to any senses, and it tastes rich while maintaining a smooth finish. I love drinking this because it doesnt really have a weakness. Its just good.

I didn't take any extra notes when I tried this beer for the first time but I'm gonna try it again and update my comments.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a rich caramelly brown from the tap. Nice rounded Belgian style, definitely getting some layers in the sweetness. Heard that someone at the bar was told this is a brown ale. Whoops! Good beer.
Muddy brown pour with a thick brown head. Toffee, chocolate, yeasty, dark fruit aromas. Toffee and fruity flavours, burnt sugar, sweet, a little spicy

Pours murky brown with high copper brown head
Aromas of honey, caramel, liqourize, belgo yeast, 
Taste is round sweet with warming alcohol. Has notes of burned caramel, brown sugar, liqourize, sweet fruits, hints of dried fruits
NIce settling beer, ruby with big light brown head. Sweet fruity aroma and likewise sweet taste. Bit too sweet, but that is normal with this style. (Chicago 201510)
Pours reddish brown with a creamy medium lasting head. Strong aroma of caramel malt. Slightly fizzy carbonation with medium body. Very interesting taste of brown sugar although not too sweet.
Ottle to snifter, Aroma of dark roasted malts, licorice, and a hint of chocolate, taste is similar with some orange that I didnt catch on the aroma, solid
Gr8 Belgian beer kdndndjjdjkekdkjdjdjdjdjjdjsjdijdjdidijdidjdjdikdj via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Où, Quand, Comment :  Bouteille. Mondial de la bière. 


Visuel :  
Couleur : brune-ambrée. 
Apparence : semi-voilée. 


Arôme :  
Levures fruitées (prunes et de raisins), caramel sucré, sucre dorge, légèrement épicé.

Goût :  
Entrée de bouche : levures fruitées (prunes, notes de cerises et de poires) et légèrement épicées.
Un support sucré de caramel, de sucre dorge avec des petites notes de butterscotch avec quelques traces dalcool.

En bouche :  

Corps : moyen.
Effervescence : moyenne.
Texture : moyennement crémeuse.
Finale : moyenne, composée dun goût de levures fruitées avec des notes de houblon floral et dalcool
Linda no copo, com espuma abundante. Baunilha e maltes marcantes. Muito equilibrada. Recomendo.

355ml bottle. Pours a hazy burgundy with a huge, fluffy, long lasting, beige head that laces. Sweet aroma of dried fruit, spices, caramel malt, yeast and alcohol. Sweet flavour of dried fruit, caramel malt, liquorice, yeast, coriander and a hint of chocolate with a dry finish. Medium body with an oily texture and soft carbonation. Nice. Alcohol is hidden well.

bottle. Pours a hazy dark brown with beige head. Lively carbonation. Heavy aromas of caramel malt and toffee. Bit of chocolate in the flavor with some tart fruitiness. Touch of licorice and some bitterness in the finish. Pretty complex.

Bottle poured into my snifter. Pours a deep hazy brown with big vanilla head. Aroma is banana, candied walnuts, dark fruits, and bubblegum. The taste is sweet figs, caramel, toffee, dark fruits like prunes and plums, and leather. Big body, active carbonation. Sweet finish.

From bottle to tulip. Aroma is moderate bakers bread with slight candi. Banana esters and bubblegum appeared as it warmed. Hazy mahogany with a full light brown head. Sweet malt with slight orange peel. An uninspiring faint richness, with a gritty finish on the flavor. Finishes nicely dry.

355ml bottle from Saveur-Biere.fr. Pours deep brown with small beige head. Promising sweet malty aroma. Taste is brown sugar and burnt currants, with spice & a lot of yeast. Smooth and flavoursome dubbel. Not bad.

Pours brown with a low tan head. Aromas of caramel, raisins, toffee, roasted nuts, figs. Taste is caramel, toffee, raisins, roasted nuts, figs and dates. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation.
Good Dubbel. Big malty and yeasty aroma. Biscuit and bready malt flavors with a definite Belgian touch. Soft brown color with a tan foamy head and full weighty palate.
This has a really interesting flavor. It lingers on your tongue long after you swallow.
Awesome especially from US. Fruity nose of grapes and dark dried cherries. Malts come through with mild toast and pumpernickel bread. Thick rich sweetness on palate.

Sample at Giant Eagle Market District. Pours a nice dark rich color with a pleasant fruity aroma. Somewhat thin for a darker beer but it doesnt lack for flavor. A nice mixture of ingredients gives it a full rich taste that is pleasing to the palate. Smooth with little carbonation. Goes down easy. We tried 5 different Belgian beers at the store and bought a bottle of this to bring home.
UPDATED: JAN 19, 2017 well balanced, tasteful beer. i hope someday we could drink it in bars of turkey.
One of my favorites. Total fan of Belgians. Drink it with anything, any time of day. Its what you really wanted, I can guarantee it.

750ml corked bottle, poured in snifter. Pours a nice off white head that has good retention. Deep amber color. Clearly bottle conditioned, and carb level is nice. Big cherry woody aroma, with banana and spice. Smooth for a Dubbel, and quite nice. Alcohol bite at the end, licorice malty but not overbearing. Finish is clean. Tasty.

0.355l bottle. Courtesy of Cristobal37. Thanks! Hazy reddish dark orange body, beige head. Aroma of caramel, toast, orange peel, peach, brown sugar and nutmeg. Taste is really similar to the aroma, but its not that sweet which I like. The finish has some toast and floral hops to it. Very nice.

OMGGANG ABBEYS ALE IS A WONDER FULL BELGIUM. THE SMELL AND THE FLAYVERS IS LIKE FRUITS AND SPICE. THIS IS SPECHAL TOO BELGIUMS. WHAT IS NOT GOOD IS THE BUBBLES. ITS SO BUBBLEY AND IT MADE ME SNEEZE TO. I LIKE TO YOU CAN RELLY FEEL THE CARBONEATION IN YOURE STOMACHE BUT THIS WONE YOU CAN RELLY FEEL THE CARBONEATION IN YOURE EYES AND NOSE. MY ADVISE TO YOU IS PUT A LITTLE SALT IN THE GLASS AND THEN RUB YOURE EARS AND STICK FINGERS INTO THE BEER. THEN IT IS REDY TO DRINK FAST.

Bottle to glass. A nice amber color, ruby red, lots of white head. Aroma is ton of dark fruit, plum, fig, yum. taste is surprisingly light, dry, a bit of tarty fruitiness. A bit of alcohol warmth as it goes down. Really nice easy drinking belgium beer.

draft that poured a medium rich mahogany color with minimal white head. initial aroma was medium to heavy sweet malts with some caramels notes as well as dark red fruits and cherries. the flavor was the sweet malts, caramels and red fruits with a predominant flavor of the cherry. very smooth and flavorful. nice malt backbone start to finish. really really good.

Olfactif: Dattes fraiches, raisins secs, alcool, mélasse, réglisse noire, anis étoilée, ne sont que quelques éléments dun nez extrêmement puissant et complexe. 
Visuel: Brune assez voilée, beau collet généreux et dense, qui sattarde longtemps sur le liquide. Gustatif: Lattaque est très chaleureuse et laisse découvrir des dates, des figues, du raisin, de la mélasse et une toute petite amertume de zeste dorange. Lanis est cependant très (trop) discret. Un superbe exemple du style. On se croirait chez les Belges.
Aroma of raisins, toffee, and brown sugar. Taste is very similar: raisins, brown sugar.

Bottle from Davis Beer Shoppe. Pours dark brown with an attractive tan head and a toffee aroma. There is a dark molasses and plum flavor with a bit of chocolate and a dry finish. Nicely crafted in the Belgian style.
Damn good beer. Sweet dark fruits with some spices. Smooth mouth feel. Only knock would the lack of a strong nose. Delicious none the less.

From a 12 ounce bottle. Pours turbid deep chestnut with a beautiful brown-white head. Toffee nose is prevalent. Taste is sweet but muted, less candied sugar than other Belgians. Finishes smooth and clean. A solid performer.
Very malty. Good overall flavor. No bitterness. No alcohol flavor. Part of a BJs beer pairing.

12 oz pour from refrigerated bottle into sniffer glass. Burgundy and opaque, fizzy carbonation, moderate fizzy head that quickly dissipated. Medium bodied and dry. A bit thin for my taste. Nose is fruity and herbal. Taste is fruity and earthy, a little syrupy and toffee-y. Tangy. Strong Belgian yeast taste.
Pours a deep red with a thick foamy head. Smells of fruit, toffee - rich. Taste is sweet and bitter - a bit tart - fruit, deep malt, caramel, anise.
Deep burgundy color with a big, fluffy head. A little bit alcoholic aroma with sweet bready character and notes of honey, bread and sugar. A little fruity Very drinkable.
Not my favorite. Its pretty malty and smells like an old syrup beer. This is time to try again.

12 oz bottle. Poured a beautiful unfiltered mahogany-amber with a beige head and nice lacing. Sweet taste of caramel, roasted malts, Belgian yeast, brown sugar, toffee with a boozy finish. Avererage carbonation, medium body. Fantastic dubbel!

Can't find a bottling date so impossible to tell how old this is. Pours an opaque dark brown with beige head. Deep, nutty, sherried aroma with hints of dark toffee, baking syrup, malts, lots of dried and preserved fruits, a hint of rhum raisins. Medium+ bodied palate with caramelly maltiness and some sweetness. Medium flavour intensity, good freshness, medium finish. A very good example of the style. Feels like this bottle is a few years old, but sadly there's no way of knowing that with no bottling date on the label.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hazy thick almost brown looking brew with a really nice head that holds. Smells of raisins, brown sugar, licorice. Taste is toffee, raisins, licorice, herbs, and flowers. The more I let it sit the more complex the flavors become making me think it could be too complex and overly done. Thick and hardy but does not leave a coating behind on the back of the tongue.
Aroma of dark fruits and banana. Pours dark mahogany with lacey tan head, Flavor of chocolate malt, figs, and spice with a slight alcohol finish.
This Abbey loves the chocolate chip cookie that I'm eating! The beer is smooth, a little rich, and flavorful.

Pour on tap, dark hazy reddish brown pour with khaki colored head, aroma was full of dark fruit with raisin, plum, some nice caramel, toffee into a bit of yeast, Belgian spices, hints of grass. Taste was a mix of caramel, toffee, dark fruit, slight yeast into a bit of spice, touch of sweet orange, finishing sweet.
Bottle. Pours clear dark ruby with fluffy off white head. Nose and taste is belgian sugar, caramel, toffee, brown sugar. Good.

Bottle. Pours dark mahogany, medium tan head. Toffee and bread aroma. Coffee dried fruit and maybe a little coffee to taste. Enjoyable beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, thanks Eddan. 

Amber with a medium head. Quite a lot of toffee both in the aroma and taste. Also dried fruit, malt and light spices. Vinous and with warming alcohol.
Lovely malty chockately aroma, nice head, great taste with all the complexity and notes that one expects of a Trappist style dubbel. Happy to drink his any time.

Tan head that is two fingers in depth. Beer is a dark red/burgandy color. Tastes of chickory wood and cherries along with some other dark fruits. Very floral aroma. Nice malty taste as well as a medium mouth feel. Leaves a pleaseant aftertaste of cherries.

@ Basunen 15-1-31: ganska tydelig doft av kola. Smaken är ganska len med kola och nötter. Lite torr eftersmak.

---- Soberness not garanteed!

Tap pour into 12 oz tulip glass at Busters. Beautiful full finger or more head on a deep mahogany/plum colored beer. Lacing is strong. Aroma leans on tart fruit with some malty sweetness mixed in. Caramel and toffee with a pleasant but not overpowering sour quality you come to expect from Belgians. Silky, smooth mouthfeel. Definitely a rich beer with a heavy alcohol presence. Enjoyable beer from one of my favorite breweries.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2017 Flaska systembolaget 75 cl. Rödtonat brun kulör. Fruktig doft med russin och knäck. Möjligen lite kaffe också Smaken drar åt plommon, knäck och unga äpplen. Inte så söt som doften antyder.Ganska lätt kropp ändå. Torr avslutning. Rerated 7 maj 17
Incredible dubbel. Sweet caramel and toffee aroma. Taste of caramel, cofee rather sweet. Bittersweet aftertaste.

Not a type al dubbel bit a great Abbey style beer. It has a los of layers. It has a dark ruby color, medium head retention. Caramel and figs aroma and flavor. Kind of crisp, I guess it has some maturation. Cant even taste the alcohol. Like this beer, will drink it again.

12 oz bottle. It pours a reddish brown with a large fairly long lasting head. It has the aroma of caramel, figs & nuts. It tastes like toffee, caramel, bread and fruit with a earthy flavor and some bitterness. Im really enjoying this beer. Id buy it again and have really liked everything Ive had by this brewery.

From pint bottle. Pours a deep red-brown with a fluffy cream coloured head. Aromas of dark toffee, dates, raisins, currants and spice. Taste is all dark fruit at the front end before a gentle roasty bitterness comes in. Chocolate and maybe a little black coffee towards the end. Medium bodied with a lingering spicy aftertaste. Liked this a lot.

750ml bottle in Seattle. Pretty and rich brown, good head. Sweet dubbel, really a terrific aroma that reminds of Belgian browns and old ales. Some tart red fruit, balanced alcohol and leathery notes. One of the better American versions of a Belgian style. Tasty.

Bottle from Drinkmonger. Velvety red body with a thick, lasting beige head. Great lacing. Aroma of toffee, strawberry syrup, wood and creamy malt. Flavour of red apple, salted caramel and yeast. Full body with a creamy mouthfeel. Light carbonation. A brilliant, complex beer.
bottle. Dark ruby colour, large fluffy head. Sweet, fruits and apple, honey, caramel, belgian yeast. Pretty good.

Ommegang really captures that abbey ale essence. It compares nicely to Chimay red. It has all the soft ale-fruit taste, like hints of apple and banana, with a nice moderate hoppiness, and cloudy brown color.

750ml corked and caged. Ruby in colour with fairly strong carbonation. Aromas are of sultanas, toffee, and dried orchard fruit. Strong toffee-ish malt flavor along with red apple, and herbs. Light bodied. On point style wise, but a touch fruity for me.
Pours medium brown with a big fluffy had that dissipates quickly. Nose is dank and musty. Rapidly evolving flavors from honey to fig to toffee. Semi dry finish.

Pours clear amber-brown with one finger of loose light tan head diminishing rapidly to nothing, no lacing. (3/5) Nose is boozy dark fruits - raisins, figs, dates - toffee malt, faint spice. (7/10) Taste is moderate sweet, mild bitter, slight sour. (6/10) Medium body, prickly to moderate sustained carbonation, warming finish. (4/5)

Im a little puzzled by this one - I was expecting something a little more polished. The alcohol, for example, is immediately apparent on the nose, and theres a bit of sour in the finish that Im not entirely sure should be there. The bottle looked a little chewed up, so its possible I ended up with an old or badly-handled one. I may need to re-review this later, possibly from a proper corked 750ml bottle. (11/20)

750 ml bottle. Pours a roan brown color with a medium sized beige head that has fair retention. The aroma is mild with toffee and spiced fruits. The taste was caramel and green apple. The palate was thin and disappointing. Finished short dry. Overall: meh
Big corked bottle from four firkins. Dark mahogany with slightly tan head. Funky sour raisin, sweet date nose. Extremely smooth. Sweet with slight tartness, finishes warm and raisin. Delicious.

Bottle. Opaque brown with thick tan head; a lot of fine carbonation with substantial lacing. Sweet plum and grape aromas with hints of cherry. Sweet fruit--plum, cherry, and raisin--followed by a finish of deeply toasted biscuit with nutty notes along with slight bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance: Its a hazy brown colored body with a thick fluffy creamy khaki head that stands for a long time. Its a very beautiful looking beer in the glass. The head really accents the beer nicely. It doesnt produce much lacing.

Aroma: Alcohol...Its right up front on the nose. The beer is only 8.2% ABV and it doesnt do a very good job of hiding it. There is a light "bakery" scent to it...kind of like cookies...but not sweet or artificial. Its not that strong of a scent. Not much going on in the nose really.

Taste: Alcohol flavor, with some light caramel that coats the tongue and slowly increases the caramel flavor in the mouth as drinking this beer continues. There is a light hint of banana chips in the background, but very light on overall Belgian yeast character.

Mouthfeel: It has a good presence in the mouth. The beer is smooth and the alcohol gives it a faint warming sensation. Good carbonation. Very easy to drink.

Overall: Its a decent enough Dubbel if you have that Belgian Abbey Ale craving, but it doesnt quite meet the mark when it comes to some of the more diverse flavors that are available on the market. I wouldnt say "dont drink it" because is is a lovely beer. It just feels like a beer that was hurried or something.

"deep and complex. intermingling dark fruit and spicy aroma and flavor. one of the better ones ive had within the style. read brewers description...you can actually taste or smell most of those things!"

(Bottle) Dark chestnut body with a bid, tan head that recedes to form stiff peaks. Very little lace. Aroma is heavy with sugar; unidentifiable spice, dark malt, hint of molasses, banana, pear. Light to medium body; chalky mouthfeel. Very nutty, caramel malt flavor; some floral and fruit notes on the tip of the tongue; moderate bitterness. Very sweet, a little cloying.

Bottle. Mahogany brown pour with a nice tall bubbly beige head. Aroma is sweet, caramel, some dark fruit, malt. Full body with a nice complex taste similar to the aroma with more toffee. Soft carbonation.

Dark caramel color with a fizzy tan head from a cork and cage bottle. Aroma of malty caramel. The head dissipated quickly leaving just a few sparkly bubbles rising to the surface. Surprisingly dry with flavors of caramel, a bit of dark fruit, an a harmonious blend of spices. Easy to drink in spite of the alcohol level. Really nice double.

12oz Bottle. Pours a dark mahogany color with a thick tan head that fades slowly to nice lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, dark fruit, and bit of caramel sweetness. Taste of roasted malt, dark fruit, mix of honey and caramel sweetness and bit of chocolate in the background. Subtle bitterness and a dry finish. A good medium nody, smooth and creamy. A well crafted beer that has no hint of the 8.2% ABV. Well worth checking out.

Bottle. Cloudy brown pour with a thick beige head, and classic splotchy lacing. Tons of dark fruit and liquorice in the aroma, sweet with chocolate, bread and candy notes. Flavour has more bitterness, with dark fruit, liquorice, chocolate, caramel, and a touch of citrus. Dry finish. A bit of an off-tasting bitter note at the end that keeps it from being outstanding, in my opinion.

I had to google the word "preheat" to make sure there wasnt a hyphen in there some where. Im older now and Ive drank too much. I drink too much. I forget things like that now. I guess thats what getting old is like. A continuous disconnect from things you once took for granted.
 
Time to preheat the oven for the steaks.

Yeasty, rich Brown sugar, dried fruit, alcohol and yeastiness, very rich, complex and Rewarding. Murky brown/reddish colour, medium beige head. Big sweetness, soft bite, complex and layered, fullbodied, sweet finish. Workd class

Poured from corked bottle into chalice. Dark opaque brown with thick, long lasting light tan head. Smells of wood, dark fruits, spicy Belgian yeast. Taste has more of the same, with some boozy warmth in the finish. Feel is nice and smooth, and medium bodied. Overall, kind of mild for a dubbel, but very pleasant flavor. I really like it.
A fantastic dubbel. Pours a beautiful tawny color. Aromas of sweet dried fruit, bubblegum, and a touch of coffee and anise. Flavors are sweet dried fruit followed by booze. Excellent.

750mL corked botle BB 10/2016
Pours a big beige head atop a hazy deep copper body.
Rich aroma; quite vinous with notes of sultana, red berries & plum, with plenty of woody spice & citrus undertones.
High carbonation, quite dry, somewhat well-attenuated, a bit of creaminess to the texture.
Luscious sort of palate - lots of caramelly/treacley sweetness, touch of date & sultana with plenty of spice following up; anise, clove, pepper, woodiness & earthiness, decent bitterness on a dry finish with a touch of warmth.
Nice enough Dubbel, one the drier end of the spectrum.
Taste and aroma make this brew. Nutty, apples peard and slight burnt caramel. Great flavors, only down part is cloudy brown, and wierd yeaty palate. But the good way outways the bad.

A nice dubbel, a bit one note, but tasty. Pours a muddy red with a thick tan head. Smells great, Apple sauce and caramel, very full smell. Taste has more Apple sauce, with some belgian yeast, and a slightly tart finish. Had in the bottle.

From a bottle at Mondiale de la Biere 2014, Mulhouse. Chestnut coloured with a full tanned head. Smell of malt, honey, nuts and melanoidins. Malty taste, a bit of alcohol is present, honey and red wine. Full body, a bit sweetish with a long lasting taste.

Pours dark with a huge dense tan head. Rich dark bread and yeasty aroma with some spices, not particularly strong. Flavor is earthy raw coco malty sweet and enough bitter. Feel is lively and lush. Solid balanced and enjoyable.

Bottle pour. Dark burgundy with a large tna creamy head. Strong complex aroma with raisins, toffee, licorice, and dark fruits. Creamy full body. Dark fruit flavor with a light spice and licorice aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Habja mintha csak laboratóriumi körülmények között véghezvitt reprodukciója lenne a világhírű dubbeleknek, mennyeien krémes és lágy, áthatolhatatlanul sűrű és puha. Illatai a titokzatosság cseppjeiként hatnak a lenyűgözött szaglószervekre, a tejszínes élesztősség, korianderes pikánsság, gyümölcsös édesség és gyümölcshéjas fanyarság egyszerre van jelen az elegánsan visszafogott karakterben. Bársonyos kortyai - a kezdeti belga sörös benyomásokat idéző- rég nem tapasztalt ízélményt nyújtanak, mindenféle kiugró jellegzetesség nélkül, lágyan krémesek, aszalt gyümölcsös, halványan medvecukros színezetűek. Az a fajta ízvilág, amelyet mindig ismerősként üdvözölünk, megfejteni azonban nemigen tudunk.
UPDATED: SEP 8, 2014 Bottle (750ml): pours a muddy brown with two finger tan head. Medium plus carbonation. Sweet cocoa. Alcohol pretty hidden. Pretty good.

Bottle. Aroma has caramel, malts, licorice and toffee to it. The taste is the same. It actually tastes fairly similar to a Unibroue Maudite, without the alcohol burn. Very smooth for the abv, very tasty. The finish is somewhat dry and chalky. Overall Id say its a very solid beer, worth your time and I can absolutely recommend it! 8.2% alcohol.

Great dubbel style ale! Big billowy head. Complex aroma of malt and raisin and dark fruit and spice. Some sherry/rum notes, vanilla, and spice (licorice?) also in the flavor. Alcohol present, but pleasant. Thoroughly enjoyable.

Pours an opaque rust brown, highly carbonated with a lumpy foam head. Spicy yeast and malt aroma. Sweet and spicy fruit taste, like red apple and cherry. Slight licorice at the end. Moderate sticky mouthfeel with a slight cherry aftertaste.

nose: sweet sherry/port, cookie dough full of raisins, dates. super-ripe oranges.

palate: very sweet but with a nice twinge of acidity/carbonation, tastes like some kind of heavily spiced dark christmas cake chock full of red currants, cherries, figs, decaying oranges. a bit too much for my taste. finish is the best part...dry and smoky and the hops finally show up, along with strong licorice.

should be awesome with the right dessert. otherwise beware

Bottle. Pours deep but translucent brown with two finger head - beige, solid retention. Nose is fruity, caramel, marmalade, mild roasted grain, raisins and just a touch of earthy tartness. Palate is rich and hearty, full of textured caramelized malt sugar notes. Some very rich and nearly indescribable flavors open up right upon the first taste, with some light heat and alcohol as well as a taste that is almost meaty or glutamate. Flavor is a very complex merging of malt ad yeast flavors - cream, vanilla, banana. Some some bitterness and herbal flavors on the finish. A wonderful rendition of a dubbel that is worth revisiting over and over.

750ml bottle pours a very murky copper amber with quite a bit of fluffy, off white head. Nose has loads of yeast character, spice, clove, pepper, lots of bubblegum, some ripe banana, some candy. Flavor follows right along, candy, some white pepper, bready notes come through, some caramel, clove, bubblegum, banana. Full bodied, sticky finish. A bit overdone.

Pours dark brown, cloudy color. Christmas cake, prune on the nose. Rich, dark, cooked fruit on the palate, with the carbonation giving it a kind of Dr. Pepper effervescent overall taste. Overall, a well-balanced professional product but not exactly my taste.

On the aroma, I picked up strong hints of licorice, Christmas fruitcake or panettone, prune, raisins, and other dried fruit, along with the usual caramel and maple syrup I normally associate with this type of brew. The appearance was a simply splendid amber colored beauty with a soft, tan pillowy head. It seems evenly medium-bodied on the tongue with perfect carbonation. The taste up front was slightly sweet and spicy in the licorice sense but then it quickly dries out once it get to the back of your tongue and upon swallowing. Endlessly fascinating. I do enjoy this style and am anxious to compare it to Chimay Rouge.

Nice-looking deep reddish-brown beer with a thick creamy tan head. Sour nose of light balsamic, blood orange, and resin. Flavor is both sweet and sour. It starts with orange blossom honey then moves to mirin before closing with some lightly burnt caramel. Richly effervescent, this is a quaffable abbey ale.

Bona cervesa, és bastant equilibrada i gustosa.

Bottle. Pours brown with thick creme colored head. Smells like a wheat abbey ale and tastes such.

Nice dark burgundy/ruby color and nice head. Not much on the aroma, pick up hints of plum. You can pick up the spices and citrus flavors with a nice malt background on first taste. Very nice, typical Belgian style from Ommegang!
Pours a nice burgundy color. Aroma and taste are caramel, fruits, and spices. Great Dubbel.

On tap. Pours a hazy brown with a tan head and lacing. It has a rich aroma of raisin, apple, some caramel, and toasted malt. The flavor is rich fruit up front with a solid malt backbone and a slightly sweet, slightly dry finish.

Great cork beer. Pours a nice redish brown color with hints of carmel and orange. This is abbey ale fans must. Very enjoyable.
Sweet candy aromas. Nice red clear color. Candy sweet up front with flavors of plum, sweet fruit, raisins. Dry finish with a bitterness that lingers nicely. Strong showing.
Red with tan head. Weak aroma of raisins. Taste of caramel and dried fruit s. Strong alcoholic taste. Fizzy because my beer was shook up.

DATE REVIEWED: July 11, 2014... GLASSWARE: Chimay 125th Anniversary chalice... OCCASION: Cavs welcome the Return of the King... APPEARANCE: as the label suggests, dark burgundy body; thick, stable single-finger off-white head; limited lacing... AROMA: deep plum and floral hops; coriander and citrus heighten the aroma; lilac and honey hover late--delectable... PALATE: big, full-bodied and demanding of attention; creamy and enjoyable (almost like a warm milkshake) with every sip... TASTE: some iron and wine to start; soft plum and coriander; medium hops and solid malts form a balanced flavor profile; some berry accents late--complex and rewarding... OVERALL: first, the LBJ parallels: both are worth the money, both are well-built, comfortably strong (8.2% ABV), agile, and absurdly smooth, both are versatile when pairing with other food/players, and both are winners...I had almost forgotten how good this beer is...

Pours from the bottle a dark, dark brown with a substantial foamy off-white head. Good lacing. Aroma is of dark fruit and malt. Big taste of prunes, plums, spices and sweetness. Medium mouth that coats the tongue well, leaving a nice lingering taste. A wonderful example of the style, and one that Ill have to revisit often.

It certainly has that dubbel appearance down, opaque and dark ruby-red with a giant cappuccino foam head that lasts a really long time. Sweet, spicy, and faintly alcoholic aromas that smell like something you would drink at Christmas. Still sweet but with some bitterness and alcohol heat coming in on the tongue. The flavor is intensely dry, a bit too much for my tastes. Thick and nicely carbed. Good dubbel, especially given how easy it is to find and its reasonably low price.

Pours a rich copper and mahogany color with a fruity and licorice aroma. Taste is sweet, with notes of honey and toffee. The alcohol content is masked well by the sweet flavors and malt. Licorice, is tasted throughout with a dry finish and well hidden spice. An excellent surprise for the style.
Cabeza alta y duradera muy cremosa, color caramelo, sabor y aroma indescriptible, complejidad absoluta... Deliciosa..

Deep burgundy color with a big, fluffy head. Complex fruit aromas with a layered sweetness (honey, then caramel, then toffee) with a hint of licorice and chocolate. A big, rich, abbey-style ale that dries out nicely on the finish.

Appearance was cloudy reddish brown with lasting beige creamy 2 finger head, spotty lacing. Aromas are slight caramel, toffee malts with licorice, anise then soft estery yeasts. Taste are malts forward with sweet toffee, gram cracker, brown sugars midway. Licorice, anise with soft fruits of plum, fig and slightly drying finish. Palate was creamy smooth CO2 with medium-full body, lasting spicy finish. Solid Dubbel, but touch to much spice.
Bottle at home. Pours dark brown, light malty toffee, raisins, fizzy, sweet, liquorice.
Pours a dark burgundy with a foamy, long-lasting white head. Has an aroma of sweet yeast and fruit. Flavor is dark fruit, caramel, and yeast, along with a little bit of an alcohol bite. Delicious.

750 ml corked and caged bottle. Unclear deep ruby, fine creamy tan foam settles and lasts. Aroma of sweet malt, dark fruit and yeast. Taste is not too rich toasty caramel/toffee malt, quite yeasty, darker fruitiness, raisin, fig, plum, some spice, herb and earth. Average carbonation, medium bodied, moderately hopped. Another solid effort from Ommegang. NFL (Not For Lagerboys)

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2016 Poured from a bomber. Pours a dark, burgundy red with an extremely foamy off-white head that sticks around a long time. Pour slowly! Smells of yeast, malt, and dried fruits. Tastes very rich in the abbey ale tradition, yet not too heavy and syrupy as some do. Drink this from a tulip glass and dont rush it. Simply enjoy! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The abbey pours a dark burgundy color with a thick white head. The body is dark and hazy, full of wonderful flavor and aromas. The aroma is filled with caramel malts, fruit and spice, as well as an alcohol kick in the nose. The palate is full and the alcohol has a nice warming quality to it. Favors of sweet caramel, dried dark cherries, prune, and yeast dance on the tongue. These favors mingle for a time and finish slowly.
A dark ruby amber colour with a small head and plenty of sediment. Aroma of dried and fresh red fruits.

sample @ home, thanks veliempojot!
Aroma is sweet with ripe fruits and raisins. Flavour has raisins, some chocolate and ripe fruits. Also some orange peel and spicy notes. Contains some throat-warming alcohol. Quite sweet, but still most likely the best dubbel outside Belgium.

Dégustée (bouteille) le 2 juin 2013 au Mondial de la Bière 2013 à Montréal (D23C4KPPPi). Bière brune foncée. Col mince beige foncé crémeux et persistant. Odeur de sucre et dalcool. Un peu forte, très sucrée, assez amère en finale. Saveur de sucre dorge bien présente, finale un peu sèche. Bien équilibrée, pas trop sirupeuse malgré le côté sucré. Se boit bien, alcool bien caché.

355 ml bottle. Pours a dark ruby amber colour with a small head. Aroma is quite complex with notes of sweet raisins, rowanberries, herbs and caramel. Flavour of sweet malts, some bread, berryish notes, wood and sticky syrupy sweetness. Medium bodied and soft carbonation. Dry, sweet, berryish finish. Elegant.

355 ml bottle.
Pours dark mahogany color with a small head. Aroma of sweet ripe fruits, some wooden notes, sugar, syrup and yeast. Flavor of ripe fruits, caramel, spices, some chocolate and licorice notes and faint yeast. Full-bodied, somewhat sweetish malty feel to it. Very nice.
5335

355ml bottle

Pours dark brown with a smooth head. Aroma of ripe fruits, plums, raisins, honey, sweet syrup and maltiness. Taste is sweet, sugary, syrupy and ripe fruity with some plums, raisins and maltiness. Finish is sweet, slick and ripe fruity with some syrupy and raisiny notes. Quite sweet but balanced dubbel.

This is a great beer! The smell, unsure what comes to mind. Nothing too strong or special. Pours a very dark burgundy with a fluffy off white head that slowly dissipates but so far is not disappearing..I get almost a wine feel for this. Sticky. Sweet. Coats the tongue. Still not heavy. Cannot taste the alcohol but am feeling it. This is by far my favorite Abbey Dubbel that has not come from Belgium. Delicious.

Poured from a tap. Light auburn color, no real head. Syrup and malt aroma. Medium body with a syrup malt and allspice flavor with a nice finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Transfer from BA review conducted 2-17-12 - 
Served on tap in a chalice shaped glass

Appearance  A deep red color with a bit of a haze. The head is off white and nice and billowy. It fades to give some lacing.

Smell  The smell is of sweet malt and some nice yeast. Caramel malt and dark fruits of cherries, and raisins, dominate the aromas. There are also nice notes of yeast cake, banana, and a bit of citrus mixed with spices, that are hard to pin down, but very nice indeed. At the very end of the aroma there is a hint of the alcohol rounding out the sweet aromas quite well.

Taste  The taste is fruity and malty just as the nose let on. Fruit flavors are up front and the most prevalent among the taste. The dark fruit flavors are quite strong and soon mix with a strong bready backbone. The spices slowly work their way in with the alcohol and some caramel and tropical fruit flavors, which collectively finish off the taste, and leave quite a pleasant flavor residing in the mouth. 

Mouthfeel  The body is of moderate complexity with a nice level of carbonation. It coats the mouth but is light and very drinkable. 

Overall  This is a very tasty and enjoyable brew. It has great Belgian style qualities and is one nice Dubbel.

Tap @ Albion NYC. Pours a dark amber with reddish hue with medium off white head. Aroma is raisin, caramel, prunes, cherries, sugary malt. Taste is heavy sweet, sticky, nutty, nice belgian yeast comes through. Great balance, full body.
Nice dubbel. Mahogany pour. Licorice and must on the nose. Taste has caramel, deep malts, and a nice brown sugar presence. Very smooth.

Poured from 750 ml....pours dark red with huge head....crazy complexity....flavors are all over the place...dark berries...chocolate...licorice....orange peel....almost tastes like a fine wine....i have never had a beer like this before...good but very interesting.
Corked bomber poured into a mug. Pours deep reddish brown with huge tan head. Malty, musty, very smooth Very well done.
Really nice nose with a smooth taste. Pours really dark. Licorice is subtle but noticable.
Very tasty ale with caramel and fruit flavors with a hint of coffee. I liked it a lot.

Overall rich complex flavors. Deep gold color with malty overtones. You won't be disappointed.

Tasted on tap at Ommegang with ML. Pours dark brown with tan head. Aroma is dark dried fruit, caramel, and licorice. Flavour follows the nose with notes of spice as well.

I love this beer! I was already an Abby Ale fan, but this beer has the perfect balance of sweet and musty that is Abby Ale.

A touch of alcohol in the nose, sweet bready character with notes of honey, like pumpernickel bread with honey lightly spread on it. A little fruity. Very drinkable for the style. Nice beer in a style I tend to not care for.

bottle. brown with two finger head. sweet malt with caramel and toffee. dark fruit and chocolate. nice solid complexity. very well done.
A big bottle shared with my brother-in-law. Pours with a persistent, fluffy tan head with lacing. Rich red-brown colour. Smells of malts, raisins. Tastes of malts, sweet, and Belgian yeasts.
Huge carb. Hop bitter up front, cherry middle, hoppy bitter finish. Malty molasses nose.

Bottle @home, pours slightly cloudy and red/brown. This has a soft summer fruit nose, with hints of apple and banana, the taste with the banana more to the fore than the apple, a wonderful abbey style beer that i will go back to time and again.

Dark brown pour. Aroma is plum and brown sugar. Taste follows nose. Very good but not in my too 50.

A good looking brew, luxurious brown sugar head on top of a burgundy liquid. The aroma unfolds with several scents, interesting and wine like. The taste is not my thing, with a lot of dried fruit character and some incongruous spice notes. I could not drink a whole bottle of this beer as it does not appeal to me enough.
Tastes like Belgian yeast, brown sugar, a hint of licorice, and red wine. Sweet, but not overly so. Good beer.

Reviewed from notes.
The appearance had a dark brown body yielding a one finger white foamy head that slowly died over a period of five minutes into a film that slowly dissipated into small islands over top the body, really nice to watch.
The smell had lots of fruit up front such as plum, pear and apple. Some light malts enter in along with some super light Belgian yeast.
The taste was really sweet between the previously mentioned flavors adding in a bit of caramel and raisin.
The palate was about a medium to heavy and really sharp on the tongue, not exactly sessionable.
Overall, Id say this is a decent dubbel for its style. Id probably only come back to it on tap.

clean, sweet aroma pouring dark apple cider color and cloudiness with thick light mocha head. Sweet, spicy flavor. a little of the orange, but more of the coriander and cumin come through. The spice lingers on the back of the tongue. Great Dubbel.
Red/brown color , big beige head. Aroma of caramel malt , fruits and spices. Taste following the aroma. Medium body , low carbonated. Very good.

Beer was darker than I expected, pouring a deep tawny color with a caramel head. Nose was abundant, with loads of fruits, berries, chocolate, and malt tones competing for attention. The beers explodes into the same flavors on the tongue. Not an everyday beer for me, but an incredible experience when I'm in the mood for a big Abby ale.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours dark reddish brown with a big beige frothy head that leaves some lacing. Aroma of caramel, malt and sour citrus. Lightly bitter, light to medium sour and medium sweet. Medium body, oily texture, lively carbonation and a brief sweet finish.

Poured on tap into tulip. Pours a slightly hazy ruby brown with a reddish tan head. Aroma is sweet malty goodness, with hints of chocolate and dark stone fruit underneath. Taste is malty, bready, hint of dark malt bitterness, then a touch of yeast and esters at the finish. Darn delicious.

Rich malty aroma. Clear amber ruby colour with good head. Fruity flavours from the malts, glazed cherries and other fruit-cake flavours. Med to heavy body with med carbonation

750 ml bottle. Pours deep red copper, huge frothy brown head. Aroma is plum fruity. Great dubbel flavor, best of style for an american brewery.

Bottle from Microbar, Manchester. Reddish-brown pour with a beige head. Aromas of strawberry, raisin and dark fruit. Flavours of chocolate, raisin and red apple. Quite smooth. Sweet finish. Good stuff.
This really is the perfect example of a belgian style Dubbel Ale. The aroma is all yeasty goodness. One of the most beautiful hues of amber I've seen in a beer. This is one of my standbys...
Deeply caramel flan and a sweet roasted sweetbread backing. Cannot go wrong with this beer, compare with other doubles side by side, youll see. Pair with a taco...really.
Amber brown poured from a tap. Sweet smell and tastes of roasted malts and caramel. Good beer

Deep amber orange with brown hues. Nose of caramel-covered cherry and prune. Flavor is semi-sweet caramel and dark fruits with a trail of toasted, almost roasted malt. Lingering toast and fruit. A touch sweeter than I would have liked.

look: 4.5 smell: 4 taste: 4 feel: 4 overall: 4

Pours a cloudy neutral brown. Thick beige head that lasts a long time and leaves thick, fine lace on the glass.

An undercurrent of slightly soured cherry in the aroma. Light cream. A strong maltiness without the typical Belgian yeast aroma.

Strong alcohol warmth with a deep (dry) malt flavor. A rich brew, but the carbonation provides adequate balance. Big flavor that lasts through the aftertaste.

If you like this style, youll likely love this beer.

Serving type: bottle

Bottled. Pours hazy, deep amber with an average sized, lacing, beige head. Aroma of toasted caramel, yeast, brown sugar and nutty notes. Sweet flavor that ends up dry with bitter notes. Medium bodied, oily text and soft carb. An excellent dubbel.

Small beige head mild carbonation deep burgundy pour with aromas caramel port rich fruit sugar dark fruit toffee honey yeast the flavours raisin plum port wine caramel doughy yeast good touch lovely sweetness toffee liquorice creaminess brown sugar dark fruits stone fruit a fizz bubbly touch red grape sweet superb tasting ale the finish best tastes all round fruit is superb rich malt and alcohol sweetness a big plus first rate beer by the brewers

Bottle at tasting at Beer&Beyond shop. Pours amber brown with a nice off-white head. Aroma - toffee, dark fruits, caramel, spicy with light alcoholic notes. Sweet with fruity and yeasty notes and moderate bitterness. Medium-full bodied. Pretty good.

Appearance: Pours an opaque dark red maroon with light head.

Taste: Dark fruit, light honey, light caramel, faint chocolate.
Palate:Medium body, light lingering aftertaste.
Summary: Pretty nice version of an abbey dubbel. Nice balance.

Pours a dark copper color with a moderate tan head. Smells of dark fruits and some honey and tastes of caramel dark fruits and some malt.

From bottle. Dark copper. Minute head. Nose of dark fruits: raisin, candied cherries. Dense mouthfeel gives taste to mildly sweet burnt caramel snd dsrk fruit balanced with dark malts. Not too bitter, not too sweet. The beer to get someone into Belgians.

A very blueberry and raspberry with hints of leather aroma. Appeareace is a clear dark mahogany with a thin white head near the edge of the glass, no lace. Taste is a very nice and slightly sweet brown sugar and caramel followed by some minor dark chocolate and leather bitterness; the bitterness is stronger than the sweetness, leaving this a little unbalanced, but still very good. Palate is very nice, almost a 5/5, nice fizziness and filling mouth feel without being syrupy. Overall, very nice, if the bitterness didnt overwhelm the sweetness and subtle flavors as much I would have rated this much higher.
My favorite beer by this brewery. The flavor is full of deep reds and malts. So flavorful. Great for conversations over books and philosophy. Pair with Italian foods.

Rating #876 - December 29, 2013 - Live Review - finished with all those extraneous cider reviews as I prepare to go on a bit of a craft cider kick after #beermas - Day 5 - Bought this on the recommendation of @scottyhorizonbeers and it didnt disappoint. Pours a pretty dark ruby/amber - opaque - bubbly white head that recedes to a ring. Complex aromas of butterscotch, black currant, licorice. Palate is more sticky butterscotch, anise/fennel chalk note, chocolate, raisin, pudding - dried out perfectly with some spicy hop and yeast notes. Phenomenal.
Poured a hazy dark brown with a small beige head. Aroma of caramel malt and dark, alcohol soaked fruit. Medium body, flavour as the aroma, some woody notes.

A- poured a deep cloudy ruddy brown with a rich creamy cappuccino head. Great retention and big lacing throughout the beer. S-redolent with dark fruit (raisins and cherry), citrus, and spices. T- this is what a dubbel is supposed to taste like. The amalgamation of the ingredients is incredible, with no one flavor drowning out any one else but all of them harmoniously coexisting like a Belgian Beer commune. Fruit, spices, roasted malts all have a chance to move across your palate. M- full, with a slight slick unctuous character O- an outstanding example of the dubbel style.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured into a Chimay trappist glass. Nice malty, fruity aromas. Very similar to the Chimay red. Very nice head, dark amber to brown malt colored with some lacing. Head dissipates as flavors improve. Somewhat sweet with a bitter aftertaste and reminiscent of the Chimay red. Full body flavor with some mild carbonation but somewhat thick on the tongue. I enjoyed this brew.. Definitely a great version of the Abbey Dubbel. I prefer the Chimay but this matches the Westmalle Dubbel in my book.
Excellent beer tastes like a farmhouse ale without the sugar taste. Caramel + honey like the reviews said.

Pours a deep reddish brown with a thin, off-white head. My nose is stuffy and I almost inhaled beer into my brain but the lingering smell on my nostril is like plums. Flavor is all over the place. Some chocolate and faint fruity sweetness stick out and in true Belgian style, it is pretty prickly on the tongue after it goes down. Ommegang has yet to disappoint me, and as the bottle empties, it seems Im drifting off into some sort of depression. Yeah, this is a good brew.

Bottle @ Deans Winter Shelter Tasting, courtesy of deanso, aged for 10 years! Pours an amber brown beer with a small, off white head on top. Aroma is mostly madeira and port, alongside some very dark ripe fruits. Flavor is rather sweet with sour touches, definitely noticeable age in there. Not really sure that the aging did this beer very much good. It has all faded and blurred into a sweet sour beer. Still enjoyable thought, and you can taste that the original was really good. Nice.

Best by: unk

A: Pours a honey brown ale with good clarity. Three fingers of peanut head falls to a quilt of the same over several minutes. Cobweb lacing.

S: Bananas, coriander, yeast. Pretty sweet and simple nose profile here. Its not really impressive. Pretty simple and sweet.

T: Really alcoholic upfront to me. Then plenty of sweet malts, raisin, copper, and hints of nutty yeast. Again, nothing special. A bit too much sweetness again, really one dimensional. Hints of cardboard (oxidation) in here as well.

M: Medium on thin for the style and relatively high carbonation in the style as well. Nice slick finish.

O: I could really take or leave this one. Its far from the best dubbel Ive had, and it is (IMO) more sweet and one dimensional with the sweetness level.

Serving type: bottle

06-26-2011

Sampled from bottle @ Deans Winter Shelter Tasting. Clear dark red color, small beige head. Smell malts, wood, liquor. Taste malts, wood, liquor, slightly sweet, some caramel. Medium body and carbonation.

10 year old bottle. Hazy brown with a tan lacy, lasting lacy head. Smells of liquorish, caramel, sweet toasted malt, berries, and dark malt. Medium thin body, Tastes of sweet roast with dark malt, fruit and a lasting rip fruit finish.

Bottle at Deans Winter Shelter Tasting @ ABCBeers. 10 years old. Brown pour. Aroma of madeira, aged malts and old beer. Decent and well aged, but should try it fresh again to taste how it should taste.
Pours a bricky color with a nice off white fluffy head. Some fruit and some sweetness. It is well balanced. A rich and delicious abbey ale. Perfect to the finish.
Light on its feet considering the wide variety of aromas and tastes within. Pours beautifully and gives you one more reason to mount an expedition to Cooperstown. Enjoyed from a 12 oz. bottle.
A darker abbey than I was expecting, but a solid beer. Dark caramel and sweet bready malts and a burnt finish make it very good but not my favorite ommegang overall.

Bottle, probably 09 vintage. Bit Hazy deep brown liquid with medium light brown head. Aroma of dried fruit, chocolate, raw sugar, toffee, tangerine, bread, light spices and light port wine. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of toffee, port wine, raw sugar and bread. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Really nice
4/27/2011. From bottle. Red-brown color with a tan head. Malty aromas with sweet, dried fruit, caramel, toffee and spices. Sweet malty flavors with caramel and fruit showing well.

Smells like a nice beer. Non homogenous appearance throughout. Darker in the middle. Taste is complex. Multiple tastes required to put words to this delicate beauty. Palate similarly complex. On tap at Barrels & Bottles. Reddish-brown appearance with a tan head. Aroma and flavor of caramel, chocolate, candy sugar, dark fruity esters, earthy hops, yeast and light spices. Medium plus sweetness and light bitterness. Average body with a smooth creamy feel. Pretty good, Im not crazy about it though.
nice burgundy/maroon color..fruity aroma..dry/malty..an excellent example of a dubbel

The ommegang abbey is a deep red brown with a huge head that eventually dissipates to a nice lacing. This beer hold true to the abbey style with that belgian maltyness and flavors of chocolate, brown sugar, and finishes with caramel and toffee. Awesome complex flavor!!! Creamy but not overly sweet. Though it is a 8.5% this beer is not overpowered and is more of a dubbel than a strong-ale drinkability. One of the best bargains on the market, great beer from a great brewery! Great job ommegang!!
Excellent brew! Omegang rarely puts out a brew I dont like. Crisp head. A bit raisiny, but quite tasty. Sweet wash down. Easy, simple but complex. Hard to put this one down.

Poured from corked 750ml bottle into a goblet. 

A: Very malty, with a hint of dark fruit, rasins, spices, and a faint oatmeal note.
A: Pours a dark dirty reddish color with a nice head that falls at a good pace leaving a thin layer on top and decent lacing. 
T: Big bready flavors off the bat. Slight sourness intermingles, and then the fruits kick in. Some interesting hints of grape and raisin. Finishes quite dry and very bready, much like the scent. 
P: Medium body that looks thicker than it is. A bit creamy and very nicely balanced carbonation. 
O: A complex, outstanding beer. An initial stroke of lightness fades to slowly let in a wave of darkness; it takes a special kind of brewer to achieve something like that. Quite simply, this dubbel is really one of the best out there.
Dirty dark red-brown colour with a big foamy off-white head. Aroma of toffee malt, some spices, earthy hops. Sweet, well balanced, medium duration. Oily texture, medium carbonation. Pretty good.

Bardzo dobre klasztorne w stylu piwo amerykanskie z belgijskim akcentem i dusza. Piekny wyglad od piany wysokiej po kolor rubinowo czerwono brazowy. Wysycenie i dymek spore, ze az z kielicha sie dymilo. W smaku miod, figi i sliwki. Slodki finisz, marmoladowo-owocowy. Pysznosc godna poleceniu.

GCB: Great at the price. There are not many good belgian style brew for the $.
