Bottle from kris wines, london. Hazy reddish brown color, small beige head. Sweet balanced malty aroma with fruits, apples, yeast, hint of alcohol. Medium bodied, belgian malty sweetness, some yeast, some hops, short finish. Aroma was good, taste little disappointment.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2013 Dark ruby color leaning to brown. Fruity and malty aroma with a touch of roasted barley and fruit: apple and pineapple came to mind. Chocolaty and malty flavor with some sourness and a roasted finish resembling dried fruit. Medium carbonation and a medium full body. Surprisingly easily drinkable. Little to no hop flavor. A nice subtle sweet malty nutty aftertaste.

I begin by confessing that I am an unabashed and unrepentant beer snob. That said, this is a fine beer. The issue is that I had something in mind when I purchased it and this ale is a bit different. Having been introduced to Trappist ales and cheese by a friend from Belgium, I have a little bias. This friend also introduced me to home brewing about 30 years ago. Comparing this Dubbel to my reference standard, Chimay Dubbel, is not a fair contest. Chimay is the Ferrari of Belgium Ales. I liked the design and choice of bottles. Thats a great start. The color and head were nice too. But the body is less malty and complex, and this is definitely a lower gravity brew than what I expected. It also lacks the phenols and esters characteristic of European Trappist and similar ales. The characteristic flavor imparted by Trappist yeast is barely discernable. My guess is the brewmaster has chosen a milder ale yeast or has chosen a lower temperature fermentation and has lost the benefit of having used a Trappist ale yeast, or both. The flavors we expect from this style of beer are produced by specific yeast strains working on wert at warmer fermentation temperatures. I have brewed several Trappist style Dubbels and Tripels, as well as some high gravity ales using German wheat beer yeast, such as Weihenstephen yeast. I am surprised how similar the Weihenstephen yeast is to the Trappist yeasts and experiments using this German wheat beer yeast come out very much like sme of my favorite Trappist ales. Having now finished two glasses I must say that some fruity (perhaps cherry) flavors have finally emerged from this brew. I think they could alter the recipe by supplementing the mash with 25 to 35% more malt, add in some Carmel malts and perhaps Belgium rock candy often used to bump up the gravity of this style of beer. Changing the variety of yeast and or temperature of fermentation would likely impart some of the wilder favors and aromas of this style. However, my opinion is mine alone. I will go back to purchasing Chimay. This is a fine brew, but is not what I expected. The enemy of good is perfect. Chimay is perfection. This is very good.
Bottle. Color is a dark ruby brown. Aroma is pineapple and other tropical fruits. Taste is pineapple and brown sugar. Smooth with a nice balance of sweetness and carbonation. Excellent dubbel!
Dark almost burgundy, head sticks around. Smells almost sweet, almost taste tangy with a really short aftertaste. Would get again.

Bottle @ Malmö Brygghus Hamnmästaren. Hazy dark reddish brown with a lasting beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, dark fruit and yeasty. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Sweet and moderate bitter finish. 240713
UPDATED: NOV 8, 2014 Nice and sweet with a healthily bodacious bod. Around $9 for a hearty bottle.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2013 Bottle to glass. Pours reddish brown with nice tan head. Aroma of yeast, carmelized sugar, malts. Notes of carmelized sugar and malts. Lively full bodied on the palate. Nice finish.

750mL bottle. Pours a deep reddish-copper with a monumental off-white head, unparalleled retention and wicked lacing. Nose is malty, brown sugar, toffee, some mild yeasty funk. Mouth follows nose... caramelly malts,dried fruit, yeasty spice, toasted bread, hint of licorice on the fadeaway. Delicious.

355ml bottle. Pours a colour that is somewhere between copper and prune - with a brown sediment and a generous head The nose has toffee, apple and prunes. A taste of raisins, prunes, stewed apples . A very nice palate that is rich and full bodied

Poured from a bottle, San Diego. Deep reddish-brown with a strong head and lively carbonation. Distinct aroma of sourness, sweet caramel malt, and some yeastiness. Some fruitiness to the flavor, with a rather light body and some mild bite. A bit of sourness, and the sweetness of the malts. Not a world wrecker, but a good dubbel with some warmth at the end.

Cloudy and dark honey-colored with a thick, active head. Fruity nose with cherry notes. Malty intro with a moderately-carbonated mouthfeel, and finishing with cherry, honey, caramel, and milk chocolate.

Ommegang is one of my favorite breweries. I always find consistency in their brews, but this isnt their best in my opinion. I didnt get as much fruit as expected in the taste, very yeasty. Still good, but not the best for the style or Ommegang.

Dark amber/brown color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of sweet malt, yeast, dark fruit, & spice; Flavor of sweet malt, yeast, caramel, dark fruit (notably plums), raisons, and spice; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Solid dubbel.
Out of the bottle at home. Taste is good but nothing special and not memorable. I think Ommegang has several beers I would rather have ahead of this.

750ml bottle, 11C. Clear dark reddish brown with a large lasting pale beige head. Gentle aroma of prunes and raisins, caramel, bread, light spices, maybe a touch of chocolate. All those are there in the taste along with an unfortunate metallic tinge. Either the malt side of things is not as luscious as it came across in the aroma or it dries out too quickly and too much. Alcohol sticks out a bit. Metal there at the finish too. Looks great though.

This beer has a cloudy dark auburn color with a large khaki head, and the aroma combines the scents of toffee, dough yeast, and toasted malts. The taste is exquisitely balanced with its combines of quite sour, slightly sweet, and a touch of umami flavors; furthermore, the palate combines a long finish, average carbonation, medium body, and a thick texture.

355ml Bottle from The Cave, Glasgow:
Deep & complex with dark fruits coming through initially including some dates, cherries, apricot and a strong orange peel aroma. There is also some sweetness and a nice helping of caramel with some lighter malts and apple,.

Reddish brown colour with a two fingers sized, foamy head that is a creamy white colour and holds well.

Apricot and dark fruits to kick off. There is an initial alcohol kick as well plus some apples, a helping of orange from the nose and some sweet malts, not to mention some raisin, dates, fig and prunes all fighting to be noticed around the middle.

Medium & sweet with a lot of sugar and sweetness from the fruits plus a strongly carbonated middle on top of a fairly dry and alcohol laced finish.

Great combination of darker fruits and sweet malts with a lot more going on besides. Both the smell and the taste, particularly the smell, are wonderfully complex and very good from start to finish.

12 oz bottle pours reddish brown color with a thick brown head that leaves great lacing. Smells of chocolate, banana, caramel, and toffee. Tastes of all the same things in the smell. Mouthfeel is medium, creamy, and oily with good carbonation. Overall this is a pretty good dubbel, pairs well with cheese. It also has a lot of flavor Definitely more affordable in 12 oz bottles I can get 4 different kinds of Ommagang for the price of one 750ML bottle. Good beer.

Bottle from The Bottle Shop Canterbury. Dark brown colour, lasting beige head. Like the Rare Vos, this has a metallic twang to the peppery hop finish. Less estery than the Vos, this is more like a strong brown beer. Hides the alcohol well. Some dubbel characteristics after a time. OK.
750 ml bottle, vintage 2008. Dark amber brown with orange head. Aroma amazing, caramel, plums, leather, wine and toffee. Taste is toffee, caramel, wine, leather, alcohol and pears.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2013 Rating = 1/5 = Good, but I would not seek this out again - Moderate aggressive pour.  Nice 2.5 finger head of a root beer color.  Tons of huge bubbles in the head.  Very thick and frothy.  Nice lacing which is long lasting.  Beautiful alcohol legs.  Aroma has lots of sweet fruit, mostly dark cherry with a somewhat artificial or syrup taste.  Very wet on the palate with a slight creaminess.  Carbonation gets in the way of the taste.  First sip is light fig and cherry flavor with some alcohol presence.  Mid sip shows some malt character, but not very robust.  Malt character is more pronounced in the mid sip and in the finish.  Finish is somewhat long lasting and mostly reminds of rum soaked cherry with a plesant creaminess.  Overall, I had many nicer dubbels, but this is on par with similar american versions of the style. Wouldja - No

Bottle.  Pours clear brown with ample off-white head.  Aroma is big on stone fruit, with loads of sweet malty aromas that blend into each other.  Taste is sweet, bready, some toffee and fruit, finishes somewhat dry.  Medium body, slick texture, average carbonation.  Nice overall.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy dark brown. Thick eggy head with medium retention and lacing. Smells of medium caramel, malt, yeast. Tastes of weak caramel, toasted malt, slight bitter hop. Crisp to silky finish. Top notch brown ale.
Draft. Pours deep clear brown with a creamy tan head. Smells sweet like raisins and caramel. Tastes like alcohol, molasses, dried fruit, and light hops. Dry feel. Medium body and low carbonation.
caramel, earthy aroma. Deep red colour, sparkling with medium head.medium sweetness, medium bitterness, medium sourness, full body, thick feel, lively, long finish,

Tap. Pours deep, mahogany brown with creamy, beige head. Aroma is caramel and cookie malts, figs, plums, floral hops, sweetbread, and molasses. Flavor is sweet, bready malts, dark fruit esters, light hops, toast, and faint booze; dry finish. Medium/full body and low carbonation.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2013 Bottle from the Bottle Shop, Cardiff. Dark ruby red, cloudy from the yummy yeast, frothy cream head which lingers. Red fruits on the nose, banana bread, some spiciness. Really superb dubbel.

Bottle. Sweet dark fruit, toasty caramle malt, and yeasty aroma. Deep cloudy amber with a moderate beige head. Sweet fruity caramel malt, toast, and spicy flavor. Medium body and moderate carbonation.
Bottle at flemings .. briwn hazy pour.. big ass off white head... strong fruiyty aroma.. taste is all over the place... fruit caramel..sour sweet... pretty awesome...

Bottle at Flemings. Dark amber. Smells fruits/sweet. Lighter taste than I expected. Good stuff. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Chilled bottle, poured into a tulip.  Ruby red, big head endures.  High level of carbonation.  Caramel smell.  Taste follows.  Yeasty, slightly watery finish.  Not bad.  Ive had a lot better for a lot cheaper though.

12 ounce bottle into signature tulip glass, bottled on 10/10/2012.  Pours very hazy and cloudy deep ruby red color with a nice 2-3 finger dense and fluffy khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers.  Nice foamy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation retaining the head.  Aromas of big raisin, prune, apple, fig, molasses, banana, brown bread, clove, light pepper, floral, candi sugar, and yeast earthiness.  Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of malt and fruity/spicy yeast notes; with good strength.  Taste of raisin, apple, prune, fig, molasses, toast, banana, candi sugar, clove, floral, light pepper, light chocolate, bread, and yeast earthiness.  Lingering notes of light and dark fruits, molasses, toast, banana, candi sugar, light clove, floral, bread, and yeast earthiness on the finish for a good bit.  Fantastic balance and complexity of fruity/spicy yeast ester flavors; with moderate malt balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish.  Medium-high carbonation and medium bodied; with a creamy and fairly slick mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly any warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is a highly excellent  Dubbel style.  Great balance and complexity of fruity/spicy ester notes with malt balance; and very smooth to drink.  A highly enjoyable offering.
Bottle.  Honey, peach, and toffee malt aroma.  Brown with moderate head.  Semi-sweet fruity toffee malt, hay and mildly bitter herbal flavor.  Body on the lighter side.
Aroma of Belgian yeast and dark fruit. Taste follows. Nice level of complexity makes for a very enjoyable beer.

Bottle.  Reddish brown beer with a strong light brown head.  The aroma is yeasty and I get the honey.  The flavour has a fair degree of bitterness amongst the malts, sweetness and vinous qualities.  Overall a good take on the Belgian dubbel style but not as good as the originals.
36cl, at 8.2%Vol, American brew, from Beers of Europe Setchey, complex brew, malty/spicy and slightly fruity/sweet, balanced, hazy, rocky head, good brew, yet expensive!
A solid thick quad. Fruity notes and a frothy mouthfeel. Pours a dark amber with very present candy flavors. Great booze finish.

From notes: Poured hazy chestnut brown with a pillowy 4-finger bone-colored head.  Sweet aroma of candied stone fruit with a mild earthiness underneath.  Full body, very slightly syrupy, with a light astringency to the finish.  Flavor of candied fruit up front giving way to nutty malt with an earthy note beneath.  As it warms, the sweetness subsides a bit and the nutty malt becomes more pronounced.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2015 Appearance is a deep brown with slight cloudiness and a thick tan head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is dark fruit, raisin, licorice, and burnt sugar.  Taste is deep and complex with caramel, molasses, dark fruit, licorice, and brown sugar.  Mouthfeel is relatively thick, almost syrupy. Finishes with a deep rich malt flavor and alcohol warmth. Overall great dubbel.
Fermented cans of spiced cherries, plums and other ancient dark and dank fruity malts unearthed from George Clintons Patriotic Pantry. Saddened by the lack of Sir Loyalist Licorice.
180513. Bottle at home. Pours clear deep ruby with a nice head. Aroma licorice, caramel, toffee. Some spices. Nice balance. Should age really nicely. Not Bad.

355ml bottle from Appellation Wines. Pours a colour that is somewhere between copper and prune - the head is generous and typically Belgian. The nose has toffee, apple and prunes. The taste has raisins, prunes, stewed apples and just a hint of toffee. The palate is rich and full bodied with a big creamy yet tangy texture and the finish still has a degree of elegance despite having a lot of sweetness. Overall, a really complex beer which engages the brain with its layers of flavour.

Bottle, from BOE, split at JFs, 20/04/13.
Hazed dark amber with a thin beige head.
Nose is toffee, dark malts, brown sugar, light booze.
Taste comprises toffee, yeast notes, dark malts, cocoa, dates, brown sugar, a little booze.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, touch of bitterness in the finish allied to booze.
Decent enough dubbel, whilst the booze was evident it was never all encompassing.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
A - 2 fingers of cream colored foamy head that takes forever to melt and leaves blankets of tight knit lacing. Body is Dark ruby/garnet.

S - A huge mix of fruit, cantaloupe, red grapes, apples, tart cherries and raspberries, mango, some muted under-ripened bananas, creamsicle, some faint oak notes, hints of chocolate and fruity alcohol.

T - A very complex blend of fruit, pick the fruit and you can taste it, lots of papaya and cantaloupe when chilled. A mix of soft spice and brown sugar, yeast is dark fruit dominates as it warms.

M - Full creamy body with lush mouthfeel.

In the top running for the American made Dubbel. Very complex fruit aromas and flavors. Excellent mouthfeel as well. A go to Dubbel for sure.

Serving type: bottle

07-14-2011

Deep copper from bottle at Dylan's Chicago. Sweet doesn't describe this. Chocolate and cherries take over then smooth out with a long mouth feel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This score is from my backlog at a different site. Full reviews written for all new beers tasted.

[330ml bottle, The BeerHive, Edinburgh] Lots going on in this one  light brown, slightly hazy pour with a small, thin white head. The aroma is liquorice, on top of other tingling spice, some raisins, sweet stone fruit and alcohol. On the taste, again, the liquorice comes out on top overall, but there some woody, tannin flavours at first. The aftertaste is where the cumin comes out, which is something of a shame (despite loving cumin). Maybe theres just one too many ingredients here, that ends up spoiling what could have been a great twist on the classic Belgian-style abbey beer [25042013]

Tasty beer; just expected a lot more based on the breweries reputation.  Smells great, tastes ok; just a little too carbonated.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Sweet fruity smell.  Pours thick brown with burgundy hints.  Great flavor, complex mixtures with a long finish.

On draught at Todd English Las Vegas - pours dark cloudy brown.  Medium off white foamy head.  Nose of clove, malt, caramel.  Taste of toffee, fig, and cloves.  Smooth mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle shared from Jmgreenuk.  Pours amber brown with an off white head.  Aroma caramel, plums, fruit.  Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter.  Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Purchased at the Hunger Moutain Coop in Montpeliet, VT. Slightly haze copper colour with a frothy off-white head, average retention, but not much lacing. Big fruit nose with apples, plums, dates and some nuts. Slick mouthfeel with well-hidden alcohol. Loads of dark fruit, fresh wood in the finish. A nice Dubbel that is refreshing, full of fruits that gives you a different twist on the Belgian style. Well done.

On tap at Todd English pub in Las Vegas.  Some sourness present. Fruity notes with a bit of toffee and chocolate

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Rich, dark nutty flavor that stays. The aftertaste is the best part. As an earlier reviewer stated it takes you through several different flavors in turn. The more drinks i took the more i liked it.

Nice American version. Smells fruity, almost wine like. Apples. Pours brown orange with a small head. The taste was slightly complex. Candied fruits and hints of chocolate. A bit of whiskey. Can taste the alcohol. Finishes tart. A good beer, but there are better choices at this price point.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark mahogany color with a thick khaki head.  Aroma of oak, dark cherries, dark fruits, honey and caramel.   Taste is of dark fruits, caramel, old wood, and loads of dark cherries.  A nice dark taste that is balanced by sweet caramel and honey. A lingering dry finish. Very enjoyable.

A faint fruity aroma - raspberries stick out. An a nice amber pour with heave white head and a lot of carbonation. Not one of the better Abbey Ales Ive had in terms of taste. Distinct Belgian body with a fruity flavor, prune and  cherries sticking out the most.
Bottle pour from a bud who came over to the house to let the dogs tear around together.  Awesome dubbel that warms very nicely.

Bottle, 75cl - Hazy red beer with a large head. Aroma is fruity with notes of caramel, dried fruit, dried raspberries, strawberries, oxidized notes and yeast. Flavor is fruity with notes of caramel, red berries, cherries, dried fruit and yeast. Fantastic beer 5 years into aging, a real cherry bomb in the after taste.

On draught at Leopolds Gasthof in San Francisco.  Served into an Ommegang chalice.  Deep brown with a great head on it.  Caramel, hint of sweet, but good body.  Excellent.  The aroma is attractive but a little faint.

Semi hazy/semi-clear ruby, roughly the same color as the beers label, under a pillowy off-white head.  Fruity aroma of pear and plum, with a touch dusty caramel and honey.  Flavor is fruity and semi-sweet until an appropriate dry finish.  Starts with a touch of cherries and raisins, then a bit of belgian yeast dust comes in, with a bit of toffee and a little honey and a wee touch of licorice, then a quiet, slightly fruity dryness that rounds out the swallow.
Drank this after a glass of Pyramid Heffeweizen, and the flavor kicked my ass. Smells like liquor, but tastes very sweet and then tangy.

Poured a cloudy brownish red color from a 12 oz bottle. A huge foamy head that stuck around for quite a while and left lots of lacing. Light carbonation. Aroma was yeasty and something else I cant figure out, maybe the coriander or star anise.Taste was lightly sweet with a dry finish.
My favorite brew of the night.  Good looking beer, with an overall solid taste.  Considered  a "dubbel". I will look into this style now.

12 oz bottle - Pours deep red to brown and develops an enormous light beige head. The aroma is fruity. The taste tends to caramel, but with with little sugary sweetness. This ale was a very accompaniment to a roast beef dinner. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clearing backlog. No comments. Apologies, future ratings will have detail. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours reddish brown with tall fluffy, beige head. A light aroma of licorice. The taste is dominated by roasted malt with notes of prunes, raisins, licorice, booze. Mouth feel is creamy. A carbonation bite and a little bitter at the finish prevents any cloying presence and makes for crisp, drinkability. Excellent.

Caramel. fruit...fig, raisin,date maybe...Good. at 7 bucks. A steal actually. Super for a Trappist style Dubbel from the good ole USA. Nice pour and head and color. a little metallic on the nose but I drank it from a Burgundy glass. Recommended.

Bottle. Pours a deep, opaque red-brown with two fingers of fine white head. Pillowy, good rerention, significant thick lacing. Aroma is sweet, fruity, caramel, malty. Flavor is fruity, stone fruit, apple, caramel, mild alcohol in finish with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Finish seems slightly rough. Moderate carbonation, medium body, crisp texture, and mildly dry finish. A very tasty, sweet, fruity, smooth abbey ale.

This is a tremendous dubbel from Ommegang.  Im happy that I can get it in 12oz bottles, for a while there it was only 750s, which is just annoying.  This beer, I think, is a great alternative to the costly Trappist ales.

750ml->trappist.  Auburn with frothy tan head.  Aroma has raisins, dark fruit, yeast, sweet malt.  Taste is sweet, with caramel, raisins, orange peel, yeast.  Lots going on here.  Gets cloying after a while.

Djahsjdndndndnd nd d d d d d d d s d d s s d d d d d d dndnsndnsnsnsjsksnsmsnsmsnsmsnsnsnsnsnsnsnsn

 via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at WOB. Pours a red brown with a beige head and sweet, fruity aroma. Taste is of yeast, dried fruits, roasted malt, and woody notes with a medium finish.

Pours a dark brown color with a dam all head. Nose is fruity with currants and raisins. Taste is typical Belgian yeast, with fruit and spices. Finishes in the same notes. On tap at WOB, Coconut Creek, Fla. Quaff Score 7 / 10

The fact that this dubbel is made where and how it is (not to mention in the U.S.) makes it special. Check out the brewery if you are ever in NY state. Delicious sweet rich flavor. Filling and satisfying. A real treat.

Enjoyed this beer with pizza in little Italy at Toby's Public House. On tap it was slightly cloudy. Head disappeared quickly. Generous delicious hops were well balanced with a thick creamy mouth feel and a nice finish. 

F Avey---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Deep reddish brown, a bit cloudy from the yeast. Fruit and caramel in the aroma. Rich and sweet with notes of caramel, toffee and dark fruit. Well balanced, but a little more caramel then I personally prefer.
Shared a 750 ml bottle.  Prune, plum, vinous, chocolate, malty, caramel, coffee, leather. Very nice. Aged very well.

(From Notes) 
A 750ml bottle. Dark brown in color, carbonation evident through the dark color. Small cream colored head which fades somewhat quickly. Minimal lacing. Aroma is a rush of fruits and sweet malt. Very syrupy taste, like maple. Not bad but not what I was expecting. Smooth finish. Not very drinkable, one is more than enough to be sipped over an extended time frame. Almost tastes like cough syrup after awhile

Deep reddish bronze, thick cushion of pillowy foam. Clear if you dont pour the yeast, foggy if you do.  Aroma/taste is delicious. Brown sugar, toffee, molasses, raisin, licorice. Dry sweetness, balanced by the yeasty funk and a touch of tartness. Really light on the palate, but rich as can be. Alcohol wonderfully hidden. Really good.

Poured from a bottle into ommegang goblet. Extremely dark ruby pour with an off white thick head that retains its body well. Yeast, dark fruits, caramel, toffee, brown sugar hit the nose. Tastes smooth with all of those fruits hitting in the middle of the tongue, supported by the caramel body. Great dubbel for a great price point.

Appearance: dark rich amber color, smaller tan head, no lacing, bits of yeast at the bottom Aroma: molasses, plum, sweet, smells good Taste: plum, molasses, slightest bit of chocolate, hop bitterness is there but very faint Palate: feels thick on the tongue, not overly carbonated, slightest hop aftertaste, frothy Overall: a very good Trappist type beer, has some subtle complexities behind the plum and molasses ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma of sour fruit and chocolate. Pours a cloudy amber colour. Certainly a sour fruity flavour with a sweetness that is almost chocolatey. Goes down with a nice bite. Fantastic beer!

Wow, this beer is amazing. I can recommend this to stand toe to toe with any Trappist brewed abbey ale, but this one will only cost you about half as much. Aroma is of figs and plums, fruity, yet dark and spicy with a stong smell of belgian yeast. Appearance is crimson in color and it pours with a thick, fluffy, cream colored head. Taste is amazing, dark fruits and figs shine through, as well as the familiar and friendly bite of the Belgian yeast, this is a sweet beer. Palate is thick and leaves you wanting for more, this is a very easy to drink beer, but be warned, this is not a session beer, and will sneak up on you very quickly, this is a sneaky beer! Overall, this is one of my favorites. If you love abbey ales, then you must try Ommegang!
Home Run. Hall of Famer. "Tripel play". How many more of these ridiculous puns before I reach the character count.
This beer has a really smooth and pleasing flavor, its well balanced and has a great color.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2016 Ommegang Abbey Ale served from a fresh 22 oz bottle. Revised lightly and mostly upwards in Feb. 2016 with an aged (BB 8-2013) 12 oz bottle. 

Pours a clear mahogany color with a near perfect head. The enticing aroma is mostly malts but has some spicy and dark fruit elements. 
Flavor: Enjoyable and compelling taste with good balance. Features sweet malt, dark bread and dark fruit notes. 

Medium body and medium+ carbonation.

Recommended.

Deep mahogany pour with a dense lasting tan head. Aroma is sweet raisin bread, banana, caramel, and sticky dates. Taste is raisin, molasses, and spices. A bit acidic. Prickly carbonation. Really nice.

Nice color, just enough dark fruit taste w a very nice smooth punch at the end. Overall, fantastic!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Reminds me of judgement day. It is drinkable, but doesnt really stand out on its own. I actually think this was mistakenly bottled as three philosophers.

Full tasting with huge fruit profile. Rich dark fruits - raisins, figs, plum - ripe and dried, Belgian yeast spice and some caramel and chocolate. Smell is subtle, sweet and slightly spicey - champaign like in its way. Feels medium/full and chewy. Really nice

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 bomber to goblet.  Pours a hazy brownish red with a quickly disappearing head.  Aroma is fruity with a hint of anise and toffee.  Taste is the same with some chocolate.  Good carbonation and dry at the finish.  Good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a murky ice tea brown with ruby highlights.  A finger of head white head with good lacing.  Smell fruit and chocolate in aroma with a hint of licorice.  Caramel and fruit taste with a bit of bread and a slight burnt aftertaste.  Full mouthfeel that finishes semi dry.  Very nice Belgian dubbel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bouquet rich with brown sugar, root vegetables, and soy sauce.  The flavor mostly on the salty and umami spectrum with some bitterness on the edges.  A bit of  fizz on the palate with an astringent finish.  Pours a rich dark cloudy brown with a thick pink head.

Bottle poured into tulip. Brown in color with a reddish tint and a huge tan head, leaving a lot of lacing as it dissipates. Sweet, bread-y, caramel scent with hints of dark fruits. The taste is all fruit and bread with caramel and complex malt. Fairly light carbonation gives it a great feel. A very good abbey ale, strong without tasting of alcohol.

12 oz. bottle into trappist glass. Nice chocolate/caramel scent. A sweet, almost brandy-ish taste did not pare well with my food (salmon salad with bleu cheese crumbles), but seems like it would be a great dubbel otherwise on a cold night.

2nd October 2011Hazy dark red brown beer, good cream - tan head coloured head. Crispy dry palate. Malt led with a nice dark toffee streak. Mild minerals. Thins out a bit toward the dry finish. A bit one dimensional.
33cl bottle at local Belgian bar. Wonderful burgundy color with thick white head. Complex fruit notes with some candy/toffee/malt notes as well. Big flavors, a very nice abbey dubbel.
Brown with thick foam head, fruit aromas, followed by malt sweetness. Flavor is malty and sweet with some chocolate. Not too thick, very good.

Pours a mahogany brown with huge beige head and think lacing. Aromas of sweet malts, toffee and subtle dark fruits. Taste is rich bready and earthy tones with dark fruits, cinnamon, and all spice. Finish is a little hot with a sweetness that persists.

Pours a crystal clear ruby brown with a huge tightly bubbled beige head that persists forever. The aroma holds sweet malts of caramel and toffee with a huge expression of what a Belgian yeast strain can bring to a beer. Bubble gum, bready,  Vegemite, with a hint of pepper round out the nose nicely. The flavor is sweet malts up front with brown sugar, toffee, and a hint of honey. Light dark fruits with all the yeastiness provides a great balance to the sweet malt. Medium body with a spirited level of carbonation and a sweet bubbly mouthfeel. This is a very nice brew, Im glad I picked it up the other day.

The Abbey Ale pours a handsome dark copper and has a sweet malty nose with a pleasant bursting of citrus.  Its loosely carbonated and has 2 fingers head with excellent retention.  Lots of foam hugging the glass, lingering sweetness on the palate.  This beer has full body and a hint of chocolate. . Ommegang does this dubbel perfectly.

Ruby brown. Nose is of sweetness and some alcohol. Taste is of rich maltiness. Full bodied. Carmel, alcohol orange peel and raisons. Aftertaste has light bitterness. Fizzy carbonation. Delicious and filling.

This dark Belgian Ale taste like nuts, toffee, raisins, many other dark fruits, and apple cider. Pours with a nice frothy two inch head, very dark brown in appearance, you will enjoy every sip of this delight from Ommegang.

Draft at PD. Cloudy amber pour with a short off-white head with excellent retention. Nose is nut and medium roast Belgian malt. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Banana, moderate dark fruit, caramel, apple butter, chocolate and light pine hops. Finish is drier than expected and nicely balanced. A very Belgian BA, which you dont often see from an American brewer. Age this one for a bit and I reckon the integration will improve.

31 Dev 2012, bottle. pinkish brown and slightly hazy, thick foamy head. nose is sweet white raisins, alcohol, maybe a bit of champaign. thin body and fizzy.  tastes of white grape juice, fruit cake, some oakiness. not much noticeable alcohol. decent.
Poured from bomber, a very cloudy, rich amber with a fine head. Overpowering on the toffee/nut/caramel...sometimes you feel like a nut, sometimes you dont.

Was poured from the bottle at Legals leaving Logan International for Laguardia which was only 10 to 15 feet from my gate. Its a deeply-hued magenta crimson with a handsome, amiable off-tan head which had showed incredible promise for lace. Smells delicately of peanut brittle, Trappist yeast, almond butter, smoked caramel, lobster grease, noble hops and peppercorn. Tastes mostly of caramel, sweat, Belgian yeast, salted butter, sweet malts and cloves. Ends with notes of cornstarch, russet potatoes, lavender and refined. Bittersweet at swallow. Keyword here: fluffy.

Pours deep red-brown with nice off-white head.  Aroma of cinnamon and spice.  Slightly sweet and robust spicy flavor with string alcohol.  Finish is long and sweet and spivey.  Overall, good strong beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Shared by jayhawk73. Thanks Jeff.

The beer is crimson colored with an inch of lasting beige head. The aroma brings toffee, fruit, cherries, yeast, malt. The flavor offers a sweet, fruity, yeasty character with cherries atop a malty base. The beer is medium bodied and really smooth on the palate. Overall, a very good example of the style.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-13-2012

Look: Iced tea brown body, nice frothy beige head. Smell: Figs, cherries, wild berries, toasted candied nuts, spices, yeasty dough, very sweet aroma. Taste: Follows the aroma, toasted malts, spices, yeast, mild bitter hops round out the sweetness nicely, toasted nuts, dry finish that aches for another sip. Feel: Medium body, lively carbonation. This is a very good brew. Solid Dubbel that has no off flavors, well balanced. This is a tasty treat, recommended.
Great dubbel that you can find in most locations.  If you havent tried it you need to go out and get some.

Bomber bottle poured a hazy brown w/ a large frothy tan head slowly diminishing to a thin cap w/ excellent lacing. Big sweet aromas of molasses, caramel, roasted straw, and nutty malts. Initial flavor is moderate sweet w/ a light acidic finish. Tastes are a complex blend of dark dried fruits, citrus, molasses, caramel, toffee, pineapple, port wine, and licorice. Medium to full bodied, creamy texture, lively carbonation, and a dry alcoholic finish.
from bottle to glass. beautiful, but rusty metallic like taste. not as sweet or full bodied as i wanted it to be.  perhaps, dry instead.

Bottle sample.
Hazy mahogany with a nice beige head.
Yeasty nose, with dark fruits, caramel candy, faint egg aroma and floral hops.
Tart fruity flavors (cherries and raspberries), low bitterness and some earth.
Gassy, med-full body, creamy and interesting though not malty enough.
Bottle. Pours a very hazy and very dark brown color with an extremely thick off-white head. Nose has some sweet and caramel notes. Taste is sweet, yet very dirty. Meh.

Deep red pour, off white head.  Belgian yeast and dark fruits in the nose. Sweet on the tongue (malt heaven).  Cherries, burnt sugar, plums, hearty bread, and carbonation in the middle.  Long, sweet, roasted malt finish.  Yes.

Bottle, nose luscious velvety malt, chocolate and heavy raisin and plum, some sugars, great depth!  Touch of cherry, berry.  Pours a cloudy dark (chestnut) brown with a rocky beige head.  Taste is sweet with sharp mineral character and a little air, brown sugar and a touch of berry but most of the fruit is backed off.  Low bitterness with a touch of rubbery yeast, sparkling medium-full body.  Classy, classy drink, one of the best American Dubbels.

Russet brown pour with a mountain of beige froth. Toffee apple, brown sugar, doughy malts, hints of dark fruits, and damp leaves. A very sweet, warming, autumnal beer. Fizzy but soft carbonation, medium body, and a somewhat short finish.

Caramel color with a creamy head the provides continuous lacing.  The aroma is subdued.  Theres slight alcohol behind a subtle malt and fruit tones.  The flavor is rich and warm, with a woody malt and some apple.

750ml bottle.
Amber brown pour with some off-white head.  Aromas of dark fruit, honey sweetness, and caramel.  A great american brewed dubbel - spices and dark fruit.
Meeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeh! Not that great. It taste a bit like medicine if u ask me... But glad I had it.

Bottle poured into pint glass. I was fortunate to try this beer at a bar I was gigging at. Really complex flavors of honey, dark fruits, licorice and mocha. While most dubbels are muddy and chalky, this is crisp and dry. Surprisingly very easy to drink. Another great beer from Ommegang.
Good, not great, but a nice dubbel.  flavor doesnt last through the sip, head is a little thick, solid but three philosophers is miles better

New Yorks Brewery Ommegang brews authentic Belgian style beers exclusively, but manages to make them a bit more drinker-friendly all around. Their Abbey Ale is their flagship beer and for good reason - it has all the makings of a Belgian dubbel but without the acquired taste you often need to drink and appreciate a beer of this type.

I poured a 12oz bottle dated 27 June 2012 into a chalice (I left the yeast in the bottle).

Appearance: Beautiful dark chestnut mahogany hue thats almost dark purple. Forms a large, fluffy, tan foaming head which is slow to dissipate and leaves a continuous coating of head and minor lacing on the glass.

Smell: Dark fruits, especially prunes or raisins with hints of spices, but still mild.

Taste: Ommegang Abbey Ale describes was inspired by the Trappist dubbel style and one sip into it you can tell this is true. Much like a Chimay Red or a Rochefort 6 its a soft, but complex palate of dark fruits and light bitterness. What makes this brew unique and (for lack of a better word), Americanized, is its use of spices: coriander, sweet orange peel, star anise, licorice root, and cumin. Youd think that would make for a spice bomb, but this beer is surprisingly calm in its delivery. 

Light malty sweetness up front with a taste of dark fruits, but also bready at the same time (fruitcake?). Dry bitterness through the middle which then finishes with a gentle alcohol warmth and even sweeter fruity taste on the finish. The spices are not individually distinguishable, though thats fine because I think this beer is meant to be about the homogenization effect and they all blend well together. Strong enough to create for an interesting, delectable palate, but still calm enough not to make it liquid potpourri. This is an ideal starter Belgian-style beer, yet good enough to be appreciated by connoisseurs.

Drinkability: When I first poured the bottle it created a large amount of foam which had me concerned it would be a carbonation explosion in the mouth. I was pleasantly surprised to find it was a soft, gentle mouthfeel that was very smooth going down. It does leave a somewhat dry, pasty aftertaste, but its easily tolerable. At 8.2% ABV Ommegang Abbey Ale would seem pretty hefty, but its nothing close to a weighty, obese brew. The subtle alcohol warmth is welcoming here.

Sour smelling and tasting, a little sweet. Ruddy brown in color. Much fizzier than I expected, with a long finish - carbonation overpowers the flavor a bit.  Bitter in the back of the throat, but not overwhelmingly so.

Strong flavours in keeping with its roots.  Slightly harsh tones.  Good mouthfeel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Smells like spicy cherries if that makes sense. Garnet-colored with fine off-white head. Lightly sweet, dark fruit, some booze, finishes dry which is nice for a dubbel. My favorite dubbel.

Deep amber, light copper, cloudy, very tall head. 
Full body, low alcohol warmth but the 8.5% abv shows on the palate. Texture is dominated by very high carbonation. 
Off dry, low bitterness, from beginning to finish. 
Very delicate, complex and subtle flavors, which are nonetheless well delineated. Malty, molasses, raisins, hint of cloves
Pleasant, elegant not a blockbuster.

Pours dark reddish brown with a couple fingers of khaki head that left some lines of soapy lacing.  The aroma was of dark fruit and licorice.  The taste started out with licorice and some spices and a hint of dark cherry came out as it warmed.  Overall it had a slight bitterness to it that lingered.  Some light fizzy carbonation gave it a slightly creamy texture.
Bottle. Reddish brown colour, spongy tan head with small retention, citrusy aroma, slightly sour malt taste, mild carbonation, medium body and long finish. Nice one.
Frigging excellent. Huge molasses/honey scent and taste, licorice and alcohol finish. Slight dark fruit aroma as well. Quite complex, creamy mouthfeel, wish I could afford more.

I dont know if I had a bad taste or what...it didnt taste skunked, though.  Its the worst abbey Dubbel Ive had, notwithstanding.  Id try it again to make sure, but I wouldnt pay the $15/bottle theyre asking.  Bitter taste instead of malty, thinner than Im used to - neither big or rich.  Dull brown color, not really burgundy.

malty aroma with a sour and citrusy quality,pine and grape..a cloudy reddish brown with billowing head which dissipates to a beige coating..tastes of sweet lollipop like flavor swith the hops coming in at the end to cleanse your palate and make it tingle,almost like a barleywine..medium bodied slightly sticky and some dryness at the end..i usually dont go for most of the popular belgian styles but this one is good

This is the best New York Abbey Dubbel that I've had.  Actually you wouldn't even know it was from New York unless you read the bottle.  I'm not usually a fan of dubbels but this one was good.  Looked good in the glass and tasted good in my mouth.  I would drink again.

- check out more at www.beeriam.com

Pretty light on the first sip for a dubbel, but gets better as it warms up. I definitely smell the cumin and coriander. Anise comes out in a little herby bitter flavor if anything. Pours brownish with a little lacing and some head. Bottle I hustled into the make-yer-own-six at wegmans. Word.
Feels strange to write how I love this beer, yet its not a Belgium brewery.  Its to style and in fact I would consider this to be the reference to this beer style.... Great Beer
Pours a very nice deep brown with a couple of fingers of tan head. Some bread aromas with just am undercurrent of honey. Get lots of chocolate coming through especially at the end.

On tap at Judge's Bench in Ellicott City, MD.

Clear, red brown with a light tan head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of bready malt, honey, toffee, dates, figs, plums and yeast.

Taste of bready malt, caramel, honey, toffee, raisins, dates, figs and yeast.

Medium body and low/medium carbonation.

This is one of the best beers ommegang makes. The commercial description is perfect from start to finsh. If you like abbey ales this is a must try.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2015 Pours dark opaque brown with a thick lingering tan head with sheeting. Nose is caramel and dates. Palate is an unctuous caramel with an understated hops. 12 oz bottle in the eight bottle variety pack enjoyed in the Ommegang BPA glass.

0.33l bottle. Served in a trappist glass. Appearance: Opaque dark brown, fine beige head. Aroma: banana, raisins, hay, orange, coriander. Palate: Fizzy, medium bodied, smooth. Taste: Very sweet. Notes of toffee, caramel. Pretty good.

bottle shared with mathieuc, tom10101 minderbinder and others. thanks to all. pours almost clear dark reddish with a vefy nice off-white head, good retention/lacing. roasted and chocolate malts blend in with smooth and dry caramel malts, some smokiness, cherries, woodiness, hint of sweetness, some burnt notes. soft carbonation, fine bubbles, medium body, warming alcohol, very nice yeasty, peppery and grassy finish. best dubbel to date.

Bottle 750ml.
Pours mahogany with medium beige head. High lacing. Aroma is of bread, dark fruits, alcohol, red licorice, caramel. Taste is of bread, red licorice, alcohol, sligth acidity. Palate: medium body. Overall: Drinkable. A bit thin on body.

Bottle (750 ml). Shared by Claudia, thanks! Hazy light brown with a small long lasting beige head and nice lacing. Aroma is of intense caramel, dark fruits, red licorice and brown sugar. Taste is sweet and about the same as aroma, but less powerful. Very rich beer, decadent. My favorite dubbel to date.

Thank you Claudia for bringing this fine dubbel! Nice aroma with lots of caramel and candi. Mouthfeel is full and creamy. Taste is malty sweet, more than your usual dubbel. I really enjoyed this one too, in fact, I really enjoyed them all. Having nice beers in nice company is all I ask for!
Pours a dark copper with nice carbonation. Aroma is dark fruit and caranel. Taste is complex and some alcohol. Good beer.

Pours a burgundy like the description says, with a good sized burgundy/white head. Aroma is slightly sweet and like a Belgium ale, but light. Taste is sweet and raisin like with a grainy and light Belgian yeast edge. Palate is smooth and light but a bit stale.

burgundy, reddish brown pour with a huge foam tan head.. lots of carbonation.  aroma of malty sweetness, fruit... same on the tongue along with some caramel, toffee and a slightly tart, sour finish.  delicious beer

Bottle from Stirchley wines and spirits Birmingham. A little bit of Belgium in  New York. Rich yeasty malty aroma with a typically trappist Belgian smooth malty flavour with a hint of fruit. The first few sips had a little life which enhanced the flavour somewhat, but that carbonation rapidly disappeared and so did that gorgeous flavour. An excellent ale, but there are many similar beers in Belgium for a lot less money.
Poured from a 12 oz bottle shared at a private tasting. Dark amber pour with a quickly dissipating head leaving no lacing. Golden raisins in the nose. Red currant and caramel. Bitter finish.

35cl bottle courtesy of jmgreenuk.
Thin white head.  Hazy burgundy pour.  A lovely brew.

A: Pours a dark brown color with a little haze going on. Big billowy cap with excellent retention

S: Spicy, peppery, candyish, sugar, molasses. Big yeast aromas going on above all else. You do pick up on the malts though.

T: Similar to the nose, more spices (light clove), toffee, caramel, wintergreen, and candy. Sweet in general, also a bit peppery

MF/O: Creamy feel to it despite the big carbonation prickle, easy drinker, a bit sweet. Overall, a refreshing beer if you are in the mood for some big time Belgian yeast

First off the pour is really surprising, in a great way, you can tell you are in for a treat! This has the mouth feel of a great beer, full and lively without being too heavy for the style, almost silky on the aftertaste. Nice depth of flavor with active bubbles to tingle the tounge while you sip your way through. Overall, this is a real highlight to the dubbel style because it accentuates all the great attributes while keeping them in balance.

beautiful dark color with a hint of red.  the aroma is of cherries, rich maltiness and hints of belgian yeast.  the flavor is slightly sweet with more of the rich malt, caramel, more cherries and the yeasty/spiceyness continues. the finish is mildly dry and hints of sweet with richness and hints of alcohol.  Good stuff.
Pours cloudy reddish brown with a light brown head. Aroma is caramel, bread, honey and maybe cherries? Taste is sweet and slightly bitter.

12 oz bottle, poured into my Chimay goblet. Dark, hazy brick-red with half-finger tan foam. Lively, audible carbonation. Nose is cherry/raspberry, with hints of caramel and chocolate malt. Subtle fennel on the taste, but again, the chocolate and dark fruits dominate. Quick kiss of particularly sour cherry on a dry finish. Crazy this is as available as it is. As perfect a beer as Ive had, truly.

750 ml bottle. 2012 vintage. Used a snifter. Pours reddish brown with big fluffy, long lasting white head. Nose has light notes of yeast, complex fruit and sweet honey with caramel. Taste mirrors the aroma. No bitterness in this brew but does have a peppery spice in the finish. Complex. 
Rich flavors are sweet but without being syrupy or otherwise heavy.  Medium-bodied, smooth and a finish that is dry and spicy. If you tried this in a blind taste test, you would think this beer was from Belgium. Ommegang comes through with yet another top notch beer!

reddish/brown, pour, aroma of caramel and  fruity, interesting complex taste of fruits, malty backbone of licorice/chocalate, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, medium to heavy sourness,. medium body, average carbonation, clean dry finish.
from draft. Pours cloudy brown with red tones, small tan head. Lots of dark fruits, cherry, strawberry, spices, and alcohol. Well balanced. a solid abbey, though not the most memorable Ive had.

On draught at Nob Hill Bar & Grille. Pours a dense dark amber without any head. Rich malty and slightly estery aromas. Medium body with full mouthfeel. Complex malty flavors with slight early hop bitterness. Nice job of matching malts with complex yeast characteristics.

A-- Poured a crimson red color with a half inch of head. Well carbonated with some floaties in the pour. Head died away very quickly.

S-- Tart cherries, bread and sweet fruits in this

T-- Cherries, bread and sweet fruits in this. A little sweet but I like it though. A little acidic but good.

M-- well carbonated in mouth. Lively and a bit tart. A little sweet but that is ok in this beer. It is not candied sugar like Belgian beers are. More of a tart sugar to me.

D-- Very nice beer. Very dinkable and the ABV is well hidden. Still I really like the smell of this beer. Very easy to drink and enjoy a few of these. An Excellent US version of a Belgian style

12 ounce bottle.  Ruby red and aromatic release of honey and prunes.  Taste was the same, sweet and some chocolate maltiness mixed in.  Not very carbonated.  This was very smooth stuff, given the 8.5% abv.  Complex and still enjoyable, Id rank this as higher than average in a style category I normally dont like much.

Maroon in color with fluffy light tan head.  Really thought I was going to enjoy this, but I didnt.  The sweetness that it is said to have, came through more as tart for me.  The malts didnt seem so great either.  Disappointing...

Im more of an IPA guy, but need to venture out occasionally to the malty side of things. This did the trick - this is a SUPERB beer. Big bread, molasses, and caramel notes. Lots of fruit and the Alcohol is not overpowering though fairly high. A huge head and tons of lacing. A quality beer that is surely one of the best of its type worldwide

Deep burgandy color and rocky tan head. Strong fruity aromas and flavors lay nicely over a malty backbone. Alcohol is subtle for such a big beer but is nicely warming. Definitely a slow drinker but would go well with a meal. Good beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Its amazing! Not merely the strength and potency gives it its formidable quality, but the everflowing flavor! Ranks among the finest brews ever brewed, alongside every trappists monks secret concoction. Hail to thee, Ommegang! Once again, you knocked my every sock off!

Had a fun side-by-side tasting of two vintages, a brand-new 2012 and a properly cellared 2006. They both poured a hazy dark orangish brown color with moussy beige foam and lots of Belgian lace. The 2006 was a bit darker, the 2012 was a bit redder with better head retention. Both had true-to-style Abbey Dubbel aromas and flavors: loads of caramel, apricot, plum, fig, fruit cake, brown bread, toffee pudding, extremely rich malt sweetness with a tangy and perfumey noble hops balance, pepper and clove yeast phenols. Medium body and carbonation, well-concealed alcohol, lingering fruity and caramelly aftertaste. The 2006, while more complex with some beneficial oxidation, was not as purely enjoyable. It had low notes of vinegar and soy sauce, and probably peaked a year or two ago. Good stuff, nonetheless, both of them.

On tap at Southern New Hampshire Brewers Fest. Enjoyed in a 2 ounce glass. dark amber appearance, 2 finger head of tan appearance. Tight bubbles. Scent is burnt caramel, cream and sugar. Cream soda with bread and raisins. Similar taste of dark fruits, caramel and licorice. Cherries as well with an oaky finish. Very bready. Carbonation is 80% carbonation, medium body.

Ommegang Abbey Ale has an extremely thick, creamy, fluffy, beige head and a semi-opaque, bubbly, amber appearance, with lots of lacing left behind. There is a huge amount of sediment floating about the beer. Aroma is of fruit, citrus, spice, sugar, malt, and caramel. Taste is of spicy yeast, fruit, citrus, lemon, spice, bitterness, sugar, barley malt, bread, and alcohol. Mouthfeel is medium, and Ommegang Abbey Ale finishes sweet, boozy, and surprisingly easy drinking. Overall, this is a wonderful, outstanding beer. One of the best out there. RJT

A carmelly-brown cloudy ale with a light brown bubbly head.  Thick complex notes of sugar cane hits the nose with a crispness.  The beer is complex yet has very little linger and leaves the mouth feeling clean.  A solid beer.
Darker brown and amber color with big foamy tan head.  MAlty fruity yeasty aroma.  Caramel malt flavor with fruity notes and some hop finish.
I like this beer. The carmel flavors remind me of darker, thicker beers. Had it with a piece of cold pizza which made the pizza not taste like ass.

Dark caramel color. Thin Lacey head.  Very cloudy. Fruity esters. Citrusy aroma. Crisp. Sweet. Mild hop bitterness at the finish.

A disappointment for me. Poured from bottle into a Trappist glass, it looked nice deep reddish brown with a nice head which lasted a long time, the aroma was sweet and fruity, taste of carmel, raisins and molasses, the carbonation was too sharp and the taste of alcohol a little too pronounced.

Pours a dark reddish brown with a two finger beige head. The aroma is dark fruit, raisins, and spicy Belgian yeast. The taste is much like the nose with medium sweetness and spicy throughout. Good stuff.

My favorite beer ever! But at times a but difficult to find locally. Perfect beer for the fall and winter. Slightly sweet and slightly bitter but that is what makes this Abbey perfect!

Pours a deep copper red with a huge foamy tan head.  Smells like a drunken fruit cake.  Tastes like toffee.

The head is a dark khaki, about 2 fingers, and leaves delicate lacing.  The nose of this beer is the highlight of this experience.  It is full of red licorice, cherries, roasted malts, and toffee.  I spent almost twenty full minutes just smelling the beer.  The mouthful was very full with a dry aftertaste that really clears off the palate.  The tast was again lots of cherry and toffee, very fruity estery, and complex.  Absolutely a beer to experience.

Pours a reddish  murky cola like color with a course tan head and nice lacing.  Aroma is of dark fruits, sweet candied malts, honey, caramel, toffee, licorice, an some coco notes. Has medium-full body with a creamy mouthfeel and a dry, warming finish.  overall, a very nice Abbey Dubbel.

Smells very caramel like.  Dark color.  Semi sweet and easily drinkable.  A favorite of mine.

Smell is amazing. Smells like cinnamon, pumpkin pie spice, and banana. Poured a cloudy dark brown with a big beige head. Taste is a lot like the smell with an interesting raisin like finish. Feels full bodied with a creamy texture.
Poured from bottle dark brown color with tan head. Taste was rich with a touch of cherry and chocolate. Rich and malty.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy copper, with a thick head.  Sweet aroma of caramel malt, yeast, and a hint of cherryish fruit.  The flavor is powerfully yeasty - the yeast character could really pass for a real-life Belgian ale, pretty uncommon for American beers.  The malt flavors of caramel and brown sugar are more understated, but quite nice.  A little bit sour on the finish (in a good way), with a nice mouthfeel.  A very nice beer.

Really good. The aromas are carmel, a little burnt, some dark fruit in the raisin and cherry range, and a touch of  spice maybe licorice. The beer is a cloudy deep ruby brown with a long, long lasting tan froth. The head leaves lace rings all the way to an empty glass. The beer tastes of caramel with a little nuttiness with notes of dark fruit and yeast spice. The bitterness comes at the end to provide just enough snap to prepare you for another sip. Full bodied, rich, and velvety smooth with a nice warming alcohol presence makes the beer a delight. Great with spice, cream, and caramel based desserts or withbarbeque with a sweet and maybe smoky sauce.

Bottle - Spicey, burnt caramel and a yeast alcholhol finish in the aroma.  Cloudy rich burgandy with a brown light head.  Exeptionally smooth taste with a rich mouthfeel.  Caramel notes with a ever so slight bite of biterness.  I am not normally a fan of this yeast profile, but it is so well balanced I can only say wow.  A fantastic after dinner beer.
This is a dubbel.  Well done and tasty.  Rich dark fruits and nuts dominate and a nice spicy yeast finish.  Medium sweet and rich.  Well done.
Bottle is a year and a half old. Tons of cherries, tastes like a cherry chocolate pie. Rich and malty, much better than an average dubbel.
12 oz bottle. Dark copper pour with rich head. Wonderfully rich and delicious.  The best heavy beer out there
Rich dark brown colour with tan head. Fruity complex hard to pick specifics. Tasty dubbel
Moderately complex Belgian. Not overly sweet, maybe lacking in the more deeply complex flavors, but still a good Belgian ale.

It poured a golden brown color with a tan head. The aroma was of dark fruits, caramel, a little yeast, with some apple and a hint of licorice. The taste was sweet & sour, caramel, sour apple and a touch of oak.

750ml brown bottle, corked. Pours out dark brown and fairly clear even after pouring 3/4 of the bottle into the glass. Thick and very creamy beige foam on top. Decent spotty lace. Nose is fruity, raisins, brown sugar, chocolate, trace of banana and alcohol deep in back. Malty taste, chocolate, sponge toffee, boozy raisins, mild red wine, black cherries and other dark red fruits. Great yeast profile in the finish, very drying with a trace spice, a bit of dark grains and a bit of warming alcohol also show. Medium body, good carbonation, soft mouthfeel. Ease of drinking is high, Ive consumed two thirds of the bottle while composing this rate. Good complexity, loving the richness mid-palate and then the dryness in the finish. This beer is now on my radar officially.
Bottle at Ale Yeah! in Decatur, GA. Creamy, tan head, wine colored. Fairly thick. Malty, complex sweetness. Definite alcohol at the end.

The beer pours a dark amber color with a large head and nice lacing. Aroma of rich fruits and sweet malits. I really liked the taste. Very smooth with some caramel first and then a slow teansition to a mild bite of alcohol. The finish is very good with some roasted fruits. Good beer.

Pours a nice dark brown out of the bottle, with a decent head and light lacing. Sweet smell, mostly of the caramel malts, with a little bit of roasty lingering. The taste was great, very complex and smooth for the alcohol content. My favorite of the Ommegang beers.
UPDATED: APR 30, 2012 Aroma of fruit and caramel.  Pours dark brown with a nice head.  Taste is sweet and malty.  Great dubbel.
UPDATED: SEP 6, 2013 Beautiful pour, appearance, and palate...not a huge fan of the flavor but pretty decent. On tap at Commons Ale HOuse Santa Monica.

May 2010: On tap in the Burger Bar (las Vegas), poured into a chalice.

I like and know Belgian dubbels fairly well, and thought this one fitted in nicely with what I am used too, if a little sweeter than some.

Deep amber in colour, not as dark as most dubbels, but decent enough. The head was thin, a tan colour, leaving next to no lacing as I drank.

The nose was malty, malt molasses gave it a sweet smell, the alcohol also seemed to get into the aroma.

The taste was all sweetened malts, caramel with hints of dried fruits (mixed peel, raisins, sultanas, etc). The alcohol was, like in the smell, very conspicuous again.

Glad I only had the one, but glad I had the one, to compare it with others.
Tap at brewery. Sweet all through dark fruit and maybe some lighter chocolate. Medium to light carbonation. Alcohol well hidden. Beautiful beer.

[bottle, several years old maybe 2009]
Nice cereal grain aroma with raisins, black currents, and other dried fruits, probably some hops too. Hazy red-brown under a lasting, reddish, light brown flannel blanket. Almost pumpernickel cereal grain barleywine flavour with some raisins, plums, and even some vinous notes. Full body, moderate carbonation, sweet grainy finish.
Bottle. Pours a reddish amber colour with a nice head. Some vanilla in the aroma. A very good Abbey Ale.

Dark reddish amber pour with medium sized tan head. Aroma of caramel, yeast and fruit. Taste of caramel, toffee, red fruit and bread. Nice carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. Slight dryness on the aftertaste. Very good beer.
Pours reddish brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma is spicy, dark fruits and toffee/chocolate.  Taste is sweet with some tang.  Smooth and very deceptive as it does not drink like an 8.5%

UPDATED: APR 30, 2012 Toffee, fruit cake, nougat, prunes, nuts, and dark grain in the aroma. Sweet and cozy, although for some reason the alcohol confers it an artificial feel (and I know theres nothing "artificial" about it). The taste is sweet and minimally bitter, with toffee, fruits, honey, and a strange finish of nougat. The palate is medium and slightly fizzy. Not my dubbel of preference, but great beer nonetheless.

355ml bottle. Reddish amber with a fluffy head. Hints of vanilla, rum and a little cough syrup in the aroma. Pretty thick, creamy palate, with a slight boozy kick but alcohol well hidden. Intensely bready, caramelly and featuring heaps of liquorice. Not enough to topple the best Belgian examples but not too far away.

Hazy medium brown pour with lively light tan head. Fruity aroma with some caramel, spice and light nuttiness. Taste is caramel, raisin and molasses. Also has some moderate apple notes as well. Medium mouthfeel and carbonation, somewhat dry finish. Very nice complexity of flavors and aromas in this dubbel. A winner.
750 ml. Bottle pour.  Brownish color with a thick tan head.  dark fruit, caramel, toffee and spice.

Lightly hazy dark amber, tan head light retention... Dark fruit aroma, belg yeast lightly nutty, limited sweetness in the aroma... Flavor is more sweet with belgian yeast fruitiness and dark fruits dominating subtle sweet notes... Lightly lively, medium to medium full body dry finish...

Bottle shared at a tasting at Dagans place. Pours an hazy red to brown with a huge beige head, aroma of dried fruits, cherries, vanilla and toffee, flavor of malt acids, dried fruits, alcohol warmth, nice bitterness, medium to full bodied, nice.
Belgian beer is not my thing, but this is a solid Dubbel.  The dry finish helps keep the beer from being a sticky sweet mess.
Dark reddish brown. Off white head with a powerful chocolate/cherry nose. Full bodied, but lively in the mouth with a balanced mix of red fruit and brooding dark flavors. Endless finish.

Finally to try this beer! The body had a very nice and hazy, rusty body with a plush head. With aromas full of nutmeg, clove, cinnamon and dried berries it was all very inviting. The flavor was thick and complex; Lots of herbs and yeast with smooth notes of cherries, molasses, plum and chocolate. Youll get lost in the layers of complex flavors sip after sip... and forget that it is somehow 8.5% abv.
Pours dark red with great lacing.  Aroma and taste are complex.  Aroma of honey, dark fruit, and red wine.  Taste is figs, carmel, soy sauce, and alcohol.  Great dubbel.

The Rochefort chalice gets pulled out again. Unreal lacing. The white layer covers the top all the way down. Heavily raisins, figs, some roast. Caramel. Highly carbonated. Barely touched the cork and it flew across the room. Complexity and depth is great. A great example of a great style.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Dagans place. Thanks zvikar. Hazy dark amber with a big yellowish head. Heavy aroma - honey and fruit, sweet taste, slightly bitter and somewhat metallic. Full body, medium carbonation, long finish.

This came on a recommendation to me from someone, and I saw the high praise made me decide I had to try it :) Dark rich color, relatively frothy head (poured in a snifter) that dissipated (I felt) a bit too quickly. The aroma was my favorite part of this beer: heavy fruits, with a hint of dates and caramel. Taste was rich and a bit hoppy, but I didn't taste a lot of complexity. Bright, lingering finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nice thick tan head. Solid brown Belgian ale with a sense of apple. Moderately thick mouthfeel, best when cold.

Bottle. A beautiful bottle, actually. Pours amber/brown. Fruity body. A bit too sweet for my taste. Lambic-land. I dont visit there very often. The complexity of this brew confuses my redneck palate. I respect the Belgian ales, I do. Its just not my thang, I guess. Tastes like liquid raisins.

2010 bottle pours reddish brown with a off white head. Aromas of caramel, burnt sugar and raisin. Tastes of caramel, raisin and dates.  Body is medium with average carbonation. Overall, a nice dubbel that holds up to Belgiums finest.

11.2oz bottle pours a reddish copper with a thick khaki head. Aromas of sweet calmer toffee malts yeast candied sugar and honey. Flavor starts sweet with honey then is cut with some hop and bready cereal flavors. Body is full and finish leaves a bit of candy sugar
UPDATED: MAR 31, 2012 The ending is a bit dry and bitter for me but the first sip is malty and sweet with honey and caramel profiles.
750 ml pours hazy amber with a off white head.  Aroma is sweet, malt and spices.  Taste is of sweet fruit, spice and a subtle bitterness.

Draft. Pour is murky ruby/brown with a small beige head, little retention/some lace. Aroma of chocolate, toffee, raisin, brown sugar, fruity esters. Taste is very malty sweet, belgo yeast, fig, brown sugar, toffee. Palate is soft, creamy, slightly sticky, dry sweet finish.

I did not detect as much aroma as some of the raters, but it was very pleasent and inviting , nontheless. Perfect color , like cherry wood cabinets. Great clarity, no sediment in my jumbo bottle. Big head at first , then settled in my chalice glass. Mouthfeel is sticky , clingy, mossy. Tatste is currents, raisans, fig, and roast caramel. Sweetness in waves of overlap , flavor levels, then the warmth burn alcholol. Felt pretty good after the big bottle.  A + This is a beer to be shared and discussed amongst  fellow brew nerds like me. You also get a bit of cloves smell and taste throughout, would be great paired up with a picnic pit ham, some fruit and bread, and some aged brick cheese.

dark brown with some orange / reddish hues around the edges. The head is large and light tan in color. Aroma is supper sweet, candied bananas, sugar and has a slight alcohol presence. The flavor is of raisin, malt and alcohol. Al title bit of cherries and other fruit is also there as well. Mouth feel is medium bodied.

750ml bottle, best before 5/03/14. Hazy burgundy color, big foamy khaki head. Lots of sheety lace. Carbonation is sharper and more pronounced. Some spicy, warm texture at first doesnt make it the most drinkable brew, but this gets substantially smoother and richer as it sits for an hour or more and warms up a bit. Spicy, dark fruit aroma, funky yeast. Interesting spiced sweet taste, with some booze warmth.
Pours a cloudy clear nutty brown with tan tinged frothy head. Aroma caramel brown sugar, hazelnut, raisin, almond. Flavor is raisin, baked bread, caramel is medium with active carbonation.

Pours a dark amber with filament clouds drifting through it (perhaps sediment?).  Good ivory head and even lacing.  Taste is a big roasted caramel malt with yeast, toffee and spices.  It turns over to a nice alcoholic bitterness at the finish, which lingers for several moments (particularly the alcohol warmth.  An excellent sipping beer for a chilly evening with a firplace and good book.

pours maroon-red/brown, 1-inch foamy head, sticky lacing, long retention, ultra-active fast moving CO2 streams. A bit of malt on the nose, muted. Initial creamy mouthfeel, predominantly 6/10 sweet red fruit (cassis), quickly transitions in to a dark fruit fig and 4/10 bitter dryness that is soft at first but grows stronger. Medium-high complexity, med-high depth, long length, excellent transitions, full-bodied, great carry, excellent drinkability. Overall very smooth and drinkable, gets you buzzed quite fast.

On tap at Bier Markt, poured into snifter

A: light amber almost purple color, nice head with retention, ends in a cap

S; clean smell of sweat malt, spice, and alcohol

T; nice clean taste, dark fruit, slighlty sweat front. Ends dry with alcohol

M&d: decent mouthfeel and drinkability..

Dark reddish brown color with a medium-sized, even head. Sweet caramel aroma with some estery notes. Sugary malt taste, followed by a somewhat bitter aftertaste and just a little bit of alcohol to it. Mouthfeel is at once mellow and refreshing.

Right off the bat I get an overpowering cheery like citrus smell. Pours a dark red non-translucent color. Abbey ales maintain that consistent carbonation and this one keeps the reputation. What I particularly like is the lingering nature of this beer. It leaves you craving another taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

S: brown, slightly opaque, rusty

A: light Belgian smell, not too strong, but a little of that euro funk, sour caramel apple

T: mild, slightly tart, good initial taste, but finishes quick and as good as the start

O: decent beer, easy to drink, but not incredible, Im not a big Belgian fan and this stays true to my tastes

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma indicates plum, cinnamon, and raisin. The flavor is complex offering caramel malt notes supported by toffee, licorice, and spiced cake. Love this beer.

Served on draft in a tall pilsener glass at a froo-froo steakhouse.  I believe that the glassware faux pas severely limited the aroma, but what I could get was enjoyable.  Burnt caramel, chocolate, and sweet cherries all came through on the nose.  The flavor was nice and sweet with the slightest vinuous dry quality.  As the beer warmed, the mouthfeel improved, linearly adding a nice smooth creamy texture.  Id certainy be happy to drink this again.
Tap into a chalice. Dark reddish-brown pour with a small head.  Big aromas and flavors of red apples, yeast, and a hint of metal.  Not usually a fan of dubbels, but this one is excellent.

Bottle pours a redish color nice head that all ommegang seem to have. Smells tastes of caramel, bread, honey licorice, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, full body, lively, slick feel, great beer one that you can enjoy almost year round and still want more.

33cl bottle Euston Tap. Nose of black olive and blue stilton, mellowing into salted caramel and candi sugar. Tastes biscuity, almost of wholegrain continental wheat bread dipped in quality schnapps. Not much hop character, but well rounded and appropriate for style.
Love Ommegangs Abbey Ale. Such a full bodied ale with a great aroma, will definitely be a surprise for your tastebuds, it is one of the more unique flavorings out there.
My first try at a belgium style. It was a good flavor but a little better than I like.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a cherry caramel color. Smell is a light and wafting mixture of light yeast, complex fruit (elements of fig, grape, and cherry), and sweet honey and caramel. Notable for its complete lack of banana character. Flavor is a rich, complex layering of fruit, sweet sugars, and hints of candied licorice and chocolate with weaving traces of yeast notes. There is initially a caramel honey malt base, which is followed by gradual injections of fruit notes before arriving at the fruity belly full of deep fig, date, and cherry. This follows through into a rich finish with hints of assorted sweets -- candied fruit, toffee, chocolate, and licorice. Palate is thick and moderately sticky with a brisk champagne-like initial carbonation. An exceptional brew.

Sweet candied and ripe fruit aroma rising off a slightly murky red/orange body with a quickly dissipating light tan head.   Bing cherries and ripe plum flavors hit first followed by a caramel and toffee sweetness.  The body gets creamy as the sip progresses giving it an almost milky texture and flavor.  There is some earthy bitterness to balance all this sweetness along with a light Belgian yeast character.  The alcohol finally shows itself ever so slightly near the end, but even then the 8.5% ABV doesnt seem possible its so well hidden.  An aftertaste of candied fruit is left along with a surprising light taste of buttered popcorn.  A delicious and well made Belgian style beer.
Medium brown in the glass. Nice notes of dried fruit, caramel, toast, and bready malt. Smooth mouthfeel. Great abbey dubbel.
dark deep reddish color that pours with thick creamy head , smells fruity like raisins , and tastes mildly chocolate , slightly sweet honeylike and smooth mouthfeel with a pleasant aftertaste

Poured into a shaker glass on tap at the House of Brews in Turnersville, NJ.

A: Hazy brown with a 1 finger pillowy tan head.

S: Dark druits and some apples picked up with sugar and some other sweetness coming through, couldnt really pick it out though.

T: Lots of fruit and some tart to it with lots of sweetness throughout, sugar I mostly picked up.

M: Full-bodied and lightly carbonated.

O: Very flavorful and easy to drink despite the slightly high alcohol content.

Rich, burgundy-wine aroma, the alcohol definitely there. Raspberry-red color (a little like a nice scotch) and medium-low head. Strong honey sweetness on the nose, alcohol rather smooth & muted. Burnt caramel, a bit of raspberry fruitiness, richness lingers on the tongue. Opens up a lot more with warming. Definitely a solid dubbel!

UPDATED: APR 12, 2012 Pretty sure this was an old bottle. Appearance was basically headless with a very deep burgundy. Aroma was very sweet like wine. Taste was tart and sweet similar to a red wine and plenty of alcohol. Overall not really my style even considering the potential age.

Refrigerated 750 mL bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours clear crimson with three finger fluffy beige head.  Very little lacing, light body, smooth texture, highly carbonated, and very little aroma.  Taste is fruit (mostly plum, some apple, and a hint of fig) and honey.  Easier to drink than many dubbels.
Poured brown with huge head smelled weak but tasted sweet yeasty and breach good beer

On tap at The Gingerman Plano.  Pours a deep red with a large tan head,  the aromas are dates, raisins, plums.  The mouthfeel is dry, sweet, has a lively carbonation and a medium to heavy body.  Nice beer.  Cheers!

355ml bottle. Clear dark brown-red with yellowish off-white very fine pored head. Dark berry fruit aroma with alcoholic vestiges. Gingerbread, dark fruit, anise. Wow! What a conglomeration of fine and according tastes. Passing a number of Belgian origin Dubbels.

750 mL bottle.  Dark, chestnut brown with a fluffy, light brown head.  Aroma of toasted caramel, spice, dried fruit, and a touch of milk chocolate.  Maybe a little anise as well.  Flavour is very nice - many or the same flavours, with the addition of a herbal note in the finish.  No alcohol.  Good body.  Very nice beer.

Pours a reddish amber with a full head of tan foam. Nose is of nuts and malt. Very creamy to the palate, the taste is sweet caramel and malt with a touch of dryness on the finish. Very flavorful and at 8.5% ABV, very powerful. An excellent Abbey style beer that stands alone as a dessert beer or can be paired with nuts and/or cheese.
A dark brownish red beer with a medium beige head.  The aroma is fruity, caramel, and a bit of alcohol.  The flavor is caramel and nutty, with woody, slightly bitter finish.

750 ml bottle....pours a dark amber color with a fluffy light tan head. Cherries, plums, dough and yeast aroma. Creamy mouthful with the 8.5% hidden well. Very much a easy drinking dubbel, very smooth and very complex. Excellent beer, highly recommended!

Big bomber with ned.   medium brown color.  Aroma of light brown sugar, cherry, toffee, honey.   Spicy, belgian yeast, sweet caramel malts, brown sugar, light honey.  Hard hitting without the alcohol presence.   Quite good.

Golden brown with a large tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma is dark fruits, caramel, yeast, apple, hint of licorice. Good body, creamy mouthfeel, slightly sour finish. Taste is sweet & sour, caramel, sour apple, touch of oak. Very enjoyable.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep amber brown with a thick creamy light beige head. Aroma is malty with a lot of dark fruits, prune, a light spiciness, toffee and caramel candy sweetness, a touch candied nuts. Flavor starts with a dark fruity character, slowly picking up some of the sweet candy character, toffee and a doughiness before a more grainy and a bit of a sharp fruity note. Medium body and a crisp carbonation. Decent dubbel
December 20, 2011 bottle from Zipps.  Opaque brown pour with huge head and some lacing.  Fruity aroma that slaps you across the face.  Taste didnt quite pull through, but still pretty good.

Pours a two-finger cream head that fades very slowly leaving a good lace.  Opaque deep brown color. Good carbonation and medium bodied. Malty nose and flavor is sweetish candy and slightly medicinal.  Higher ABV is hidden. Caged and corked 750ml bottle from Madden Beverage Saco, Me.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2012 Bottle. Dark Reddish Brown Color. Fuffy white head. Fruit floral nose, and malty accents. Fruit and hop flavors, with some spice and candy. Clean bitter, but also dark fruit and creamy finsh. Very nice. Loved it!

Pours a beautiful deep garnet with a huge semi-creamy head. Nose is chocolate and candied sugar-plums and acai with some nuttiness and dark dehydrated fruit. Flavor is rich sweet fruit cake with rum and cocoa. A medium to big bodied beer that borders on cloying without sucking. Absolutely grabs your attention, this is a big beer and I like it.

Pours wonderfully dark (particularly for a dubbel), with a thick, rich head.  Plenty of Brussels lace runs up the sides.  Nice caramel and liqorice aroma.   Flavor is sweet, with a tad of bitterness on the finish.  Overall, I really like it!

Pours dark brown with reddish hue and foamy head (in the right glass).  Smooth and crisp with a slight bitter finish. Fruity at first, pepper undertones, then finishes with a sour citrus aftertaste. Very complex and enjoyable beer.

This is the beer that started it all for me. Id highly recomend enjoying it as it warms up to about 55-60. At 6.99 a bottle its the best value for my money and truly and outstanding experiance. A treat if you appreciate all the ever changing nuances of a finley crafted beverage.
