Mörkt magohnyfärgad och stor skum som långsamt lägger sig lämnar rester på glaset. Fantastisk doft av marsipan, dumlekola och honung. Dessa återkommer i smaken som är lätt vinös, små lätta bubblor, komplex smakbild, väl dolda 8,5% och torr avslutning. Otroligt välbalanserad. Den ästa dubbeln jag någonsin druckit. Hittar ingen datummärkning på flaskan men jag gissar att den börjar närma sig utgångsdatum eftersom denna beställningsvara hade hamnat på Hansas systemhylla. Ser du den så köp.

The color is spot on for a Dubbel. Deep ruby with a fluffy off white head. The familiar sweet malt and sour fruits fill the nose. The flavor is quite close, too. Sweet malt, fruit, lots of spice and black pepper. Maybe some anise, too. Full and creamy in the mouth with a pleasant alcohol warmth on the way down.

If there is any drawback, Im getting an overly salty soy sauce flavor.

Overall, its outstanding, but I would put it a notch below similar offerings from true Trappist breweries.

Bottle. Deep red, amber brown color. Thick head tat doesnt dissapear. Smells and tastes of toffee, carmel, chocolate and maple syrup. ABV not as present, but tastes great and easy to drink. Excellent beer.
Pours a cloudy amber with ample tan head. Aroma of fruit and malt. Taste is strong, malt and belgian sugars. Good kick, pronounced alcohol. Fairly smooth, this is a really nice Belgian. Thumbs up.
Sweet malty nose...toffee and honey.  Reddish with a thick foamy tan head.  Very sweet, no bitterness apparent.  Honey taste throughout with moderate carbonation.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2015 At Red Lion. Really this is quite good. Quite dark brown in color. Rich texture, not too syrupy but big in your mouth. Peppery maybe with bitter chocolate and malt. Serving: Bottle

12oz bottle poured a medium-dark cloudy brown with thick, frothy head that laces nicely. Smells malty and strong, though muted by its thick, persistent head.  Sharp, thin-medium warming, body.  Maybe some very subtle fruity hops, zero bitterness with tons of thick, chocolatey malts.  Mild aftertaste with very light alcohol and very crisp finish.  Goes down smooth.  About halfway through the glass theres a distinct caramel sweetness in the nose that begins to come out in the finish.  Tough to taste the 8.5% ABV but certainly notice it in the head on an empty stomach, eat something first!  Seems like it should be overpowering, but a great experience.  Highly recommended!

Bomber. Pours a honey brown with ample head. Fruity, with slightly floral aroma. Taste is a tangy citrus blend with slight alcohol warming. This a very good to great dubbel. If you see this at your liquor store, pick it up!
Great beer. Had some fresh from the brewery. Either fresh or aged a little its still amazing!
Ommegang is one of the best brewery outside of belgium beers, great taste, body, taste and aroma. Three philosophers beer is another from the brewer that i admire.
Maybe the best abbey ale brewed outside of Belgium.  Deep amber, low carbonation, spicy (cloves present).  9/1/2008

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2011 Deep burgundy with a big off white head. The aroma is of dried fruit, yeast, candy sugar. Sparkling carbonation, with a sweet maltiness and complex yeast flavor. A good deal of dark fruits, chocolate, and a faint alcohol throughout. The finish is nicely balanced with a slight bitterness. OK dubbel.

Bottle. Long time rating coming...fluffy eggshell head on a deep murky ruby brown. Toffee, candy sugar, sweet maltiness for the aroma.  Very much the same for the flavor with some plums, dark sugar and fruits.  Medium body with vibrant carbonation.
On tap @ Petrol Station. Aroma and flavor are predominantly caramel malt plus clove, raisin and yeast.
On tap at Blind Tiger.  Pours a brown color with an off white foam head.  Aroma of caramel and slight vanilla.  Sweet caramel taste with some chalkiness and vanilla notes.  Very tasty.  Nice dubbel.
pours a dark brown caramel color with a creamy head. Has flavors of citrus, herbs, caramel malts and a toastyness. The spice lingers on the pallet. Overall one of my favorite beers.
Bottle. Brown with a medium head.Malty with some fruitiness and low carbonation, A full bodied brown ale that is worth checking out.

Bottle 75cl from Mondial de la bière, a clear amber beer with huge head and good lacing. Nose is nice, fruity, porto like, spicy. Aroma is on caramel and burnt caramel. Some vinous notes, body is medium, expected something more complex.

bottle thx frank. A: licorice, caramel App: clear darkish brown beige lasting head. T/P : light body finish is bitter and medium long. some warmness from the alcohol. O: nice like the mouthfeel on that one.
Bottle - big foamy head, hazy dark amber/light brown color, fruity sour apple aroma and flavor - very good
Bottle; dark brown to red with large beige head; aroma-sweet, caramel, Raisins, wood, spice, black licorice; taste- light sweetness, medium bitterness and carbonation. Complex aroma, ok taste.

Pours a cloudy deep amber with a smooth head. Spicier than most dubbels - clove and allspice in with the usual sweet fruity malts. Brown sugar and caramel, with a great nuttiness. Spiciness lingers, and the flavor is a bit more dilute than I imagined it would be... very good, though.

750ml bottle from Brewery Creek in Vancouver. Pours a deep, dark mahogany with a huge, frothy beige head that endures. Aroma is caramel, raisins, toast, plums, red wine and mild Belgian yeast. Taste mirrors this with the yeast, sweet and bitter flavours proving well balanced. Alcohol is well hidden. Medium bodied with smooth carbonation, a creamy texture, and a dry, bitter finish. Solid.

12oz single from Beers of the World, East Henrietta.  Pours a ruby red with a tan head that starts off large but eventually fades.  I get cooked green beans, toffee and alcohol in the nose.  Tastes of wheat, licorice and alcohol.  I dont know, I just cant get into this beer.  Not as good as I was expecting.  Not Ommegangs best by any stretch.

Bottle Stirchley Wines, Birmingham. Clear amberish brown pour. Nose was dark fruit, spices, sugar and booze. The flavour was sweet and had caramel malts, yeast and more dark fruit notes, but a bit thin. Bit of a chore to chug through really. Ok at a push, but rather overrated. Surely there are more worthy beers to ship over the pond.

This was from notes roughly three years ago: Port notes in a brown beer with a soft, pillowy head. Aromas of crystallised fruit, Belgian yeasty notes and firm dry cocoa powder. Taste and plenty of it that dwells mainly in chocolate and sherried christmas cake fruits. A finish that sits and stays for an age. A good ruminative beer for a cold Autumnal evening.

bottle at home ... deep brown ... thin tan head ... soft dark roast ... yeast .. dark sugers ... nose ... thick body ... heavy dark fruits ... roast sugers ... hint of honey ... again some yeast... Quite heavy going
Bottle shared with northropfye. Sweet aroma of prunes, raisins, and yeast. Tasted of prunes and raisins as well with a deeper liquorice note. I like it a lot.
Bottle in tulip glass. Nice fruity aroma. Dark brown colour with off white head. Taste is prunes, caramel, some dark chocolate. Not my favourite dubbel, but a decent one.

One of my favorites. Ommegang never disappoints. Pours dark rusty brown, with a hearty tan dead that lasts and great lace. Slightly cloudy with an active bubble. Aromas of caramel, fruit, figs. A nice earthy spice from the yeast. Palate is rich and starts out sweet and fruity, and finishes crisp and quite dry. Fairly carbonated, and a bit of warmth from the alcohol. Ill take one of these any time.
Plum wine and cinnamon nose, rich and semi-sweet initially, with apple notes coming through, and ending dry and spicy. Superb.

17/09/2011 12 Fl. Oz. bottle @ Ginger Man NYC (2011-450) 
Little cloudy purple to dark brown beer, yellow to beige creamy head, very stable, fairly adhesive. Aroma: sweet, caramel, mocha, milk chocolate, dried fruits, cherries, coffee, bit of tobacco. MF: a bit too much carbon, medium body. Taste: fruity and a bit tart in the beginning, ripe cherries, grapefruit, some alcohol, dried fruits, dried orange peel, spices (liquorice and a dash of cloves), hop bitters with some citrus. Aftertaste: carbon sour, some hop bitters with citrus, peppery.

Tasted from a 12oz bottle in early 2011.  Pours cloudy amber-orange with an average white head that slowly recedes to thin, even lace.  The nose is spicy Belgian yeast with tons of brown sugar and caramel malt.  The flavor is the same spicy yeast from the nose, along with caramel, burnt brown sugar, bread, and light bitterness.  The body is medium with average carbonation and a long caramel and lightly bitter finish.

Bomber.  Reddish-brown with fluffy yellowish head.  Wonderful lacing.  Aroma big raisins and figs.  Taste more dark fruits, plums, caramel, bread.  Finish brief with bread and a little alcohol burn especially with warming.  Palate a bit fizzy, full but not thick..
Good dubbel from Ommegang.

Ar: Raisins, figs, dark caramel and a touch of moss.
Ap: Very deep rust red - clear - large tan head with very good retention and a thick lacing made of fine bubbles.
T: Rich dark caramel dominate up front - follows with raisin, pear, and a clean rum-like alcohol warmth - medium-sweet up front, but dries out with a lingering slightly tannic fruity and earthy finish.
P: Medium-full bodied with high carbonation - rich without being cloying at all, and the finish is quite dry.
O: This is a beautiful beer - a picture in the glass, enticing aroma, wonderful caramel and dark fruit flavors, and a rich palate.

Dubbels are just an amazing ale and this brew doesnt fall short of greatness!  This brew poured up a deep, dark copper-colored body topped off with one hearty, bubbly (tiny bubbles) head with a retention and lacing effects like nothing I have ever experienced!  I was still licking up foam when the liquid was completely gone! Aromas of sweet roasted malts, caramel, toffee, honeycomb, dark fruits (grapes, figs), and cloves along with other spices. The flavors are so complex that you must truly enjoy this brew on your own to gain a true understanding of what I try to describe.  Medium-bodied, smooth and a finish that is dry and spicy. Truly worthy of induction into my all-time favorites list!
Bottle.  Pours reddish brown with big fluffy long last white head.  Nice aroma of sweet dried fruits and honey. Nice dry flavor.  Taste of roasted malts.  Biting carbonation.

big raisin, prune, and fig flavors.  yeast spice, tight sturdy head.  spicy hops and burnt brown sugar.  slightly boozy and a lot of caronation make this a little hard to drink much of.  but incredible flavors.

Draught at BoHo.
Clear redbrown with a beige head. Aroma heavy malty (brown sugar, dark fruits, dark chocolate notes), moderate hoppy. Flavor moderate+ sweet, well balanced bitterness. Almost full body. Like Chimay Bleue with American hops. Mums.
pours a deep dark mahogany red with a nice full head that laces beautifully. Nose and taste is of dark fruits, and deep malts. A very enjoyable beer on a cool fall or spring evening.

This beer is HUUUUGGGEE.  Aroma of lots of chocolate malts with caramel notes, definitely some roastyness as well.  Pours with a gorgeous chocolate dark brown color with a fitting caramel fluffly, pillowy head.  Tastes of god himself, chocolate malts, espresso, caramel, little bit of booze but it warms you in the proper manner a beer should.  Wonderfully crafted beer from a quickly growing in stature brewery in my opinion. Solid, delicious beer

dark mahogany brown with nice ruby highlights and no haze. Good carbonation in the glass and a fluffy pillowy soft yellowish white head. Some ridiculous lacing ensues. On the nose, there is a honey sweetness with caramel and bready malts. A pronounced dark fruit note and mild alcohol pungency. The middle has the honey sweetness and caramel malts with a grape juice and sugary taste. The finish is surprisingly hoppy and dry with a light alcohol presence. Medium bodied with moderate carbonation and a smooth creamy taste. Overall, this is a fantastic dubbel. Right up there with the Trappist dubbels.

750ml corked bottle poured a deep amber-brown color with huge tan head and nice thick lacing.  Aromas of some spice and yeast and toasty malts.  Taste is quite sweet with some spices and a hint of yeast and caramel finishing with a mild bitterness.  Nice mouthfeel provided by full carbonation and a modest body.  Overall, this is a nice robust flavorful abbey dubbel style brew.

750ml from Picks poured into a Trappist glass. Pours a dark brown with about 1 finger of thick tan head. Aroma of baking spices(cinnamon and nutmeg), caramel and roasty coffee. Light sweet on the start and medium bitter on the finish. Taste of caramel and chocolate. Full bodied with a thick and creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, its a pretty good beer. Not my favorite style but something to enjoy nonetheless. I suggest splitting with a friend.

Kicking off the start of the Packers season with a big beer.  Deep mahogany brown color with a thick, foamy tan head.  Everything you expect in an excellent dubbel; sweet malt and spicy yeast aroma, Creamy malt flavor with sweet dark fruits and spice throughout.  Full bodied and creamy with a tingle of carbonation.  Excellent beer.
Another excellent beer from Ommegang.  This has a nice Belgian flavor with a slightly sour flavor that I was not expecting.  Id highly recommend this beer to fans of the style.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle in Snifter.

Appearance: Cloudy orangish-brown with sustained thin tan head.

Aroma: Pungent combination of plums, figs and a strong mustiness. Some light banana and clove.

Taste: Very malty and musty with plum, figs, raisins and a good earthy undercurrent. Ends more spicy and clove-like.

Palate: Moderate carbonation, medium to full body that simply feels Belgian (not sure how to describe that), semi-dry finish.

Overall: This is the best Dubbel I have had, with a strong complex aroma and taste. However, I have never found this to be the easiest to drink style; even Quads are more drinkable for me.

A nice cloudy brown with a lasting tan head on the pour. Aroma of sweet caramel malt, some dark fruit, raisins, plums, dates. Taste is sweet malt, raisins, dark plums, dates and light hops. A nice medium body, good carbonation and a nice smooth mouth feel on the palate. Finish is sweet malt some yeast, dark fruit plums, a light toffee, raisins and dates with some light hops for balance. Overall a very nice, tasty and flavorful brew.

355ml bottle.  Pours a dark, burnt orange with a large head.  Aroma is heavy raisin malt and sweet caramel.  Taste has raisin to start.  Bitter, burnt caramel in the finish.  Touch of alcohol.  High carbonation.

Bottle, mybrewerytap.com. Richa nd full bodied ruby red ale. Sweet and vineous, some vegetable anfd soy sauce in the aroma. Lingers on the palate. A good heavy ale, with a subtle punch, warming and satisfying.

Poured from 750ml bottle.  Pours dark brown with just a bit of red around the edges with a creamy beige head.  Aromas are dried fruit, toffee and belgian yeast.  Taste follows the nose.  I good representation of the style.

The beer pours a slightly hazy brown color with a large off-white head. The aroma is heavy on the toffee and caramel with a little bit of dark fruit mixed in. The beer smells about like a I expect a dubbel to smell. The flavor is more of the same. I get some dark fruit (mainly cherries and plums) as well some Belgian yeast and some brown, candy sugar notes. There is a little bit of alcohol noticeable but the beer is still easy to drink. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A very nice American-made dubbel.

Raisins with a complex caramel/sugar component. Great color and refreshing with a pleasant alcohol finish.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a reddish mahogany color with a fizzy, pinkish-beige head that is thin despite a vigorous pour. The aroma has a wonderfully fragrant combination of wine grapes, candied plums, and dark brown sugar. The flavor is likewise rich and complex, with notes of leather, rum-soaked cherries, raisins, brown sugar, and some deep underlying earthiness. The fine, active carbonation creates a texture that is both prickly and creamy. Overall, this is a wonderful beer that features rich flavors without being syrupy or otherwise heavy.

Bottle, from trade. First beer from Ommegang up for rating! :-) Pours a fantastic-looking deep brown body with a big, creamy caramel-hued crown. In my trappist chalice, this beer looks just beautiful! Aroma is smooth raisiny dark fruit tones with lots of dark malts in the back. Taste is raisins, salty licorice (nice combo!) dark fruits and hints of red grape peel and dark candy sugars. A very lush and solid Abbey Dubbel blend from Ommegang; this is definitely up there with classic dubbels that serves as the source of inspiration - top stuff for sure.
Excellence.  Caramel, prune, and currant.  Best Dubbel Ive ever had.  Burgundian.   Another great product from this company; and a few bucks cheaper than many of the belgian counterparts.

Pretty good. Not as big a beer as I usually like, but seemed pretty well-balanced. A little harder in the mouth than I expected. First time Id had this beer- getting off a little early did enhance my enjoyment of it!

Pours a dark brown amber with a tall head which fades fast.  The aroma has a fresh sweetness, like cotton candy and cherry.  The flavor is sweet but mild.  The brew is medium-bodied, finishes clean and is smooth going down.  This is a great sipping beer for after dinner!
Tap at Eureka. Rating #1615. Hazy dark amber color with a tan head. Sweet toffee aroma, sweet spices are in there as well. Flavor is similar to the aroma, real nice after dinner beer. (1805)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: bottle pours a dark, murky red / brown color with light brown head, sustaining with good lacing.  Aroma of spiced raisin, a note of clove, prune, banana, guava.  Smells like a blend of dark fruits and tropical fruits, with a touch of burnt sugar.  Flavor has aspects of caramel, toffee, and fruit, with a long, lingering finish that features a progression on fruits, raisin, prune, fig, honey glaze, pear.  Alcohol has a small presence.  Pretty nice.

On tap at the Flying Saucer in Nashville. Pours a dark reddish brown. Not much head, lacing all aound the glass. Medium mouthfeel, medum carbonation, huge tastes of brown sugar, molasses. Fantastic Belgian style beer. Very drinkable.

If I didnt know what it was, I would swear it was from Belgium. Pours dark chocolate brown with a strong head that laces the glass through the drink.

Aroma is perfect for an Abbey Dubbel.

Tase is pleasant. Perfect for the style. Great balance of malt and fig. Just enough sweet and just enough fizz.

Surprisingly wonderful. Ive only tried their Tripel previously. This is really good. I will get it again.
Over the top carbonation, good amonts of bready sweet caramel malts. No hops to be found. There is an odd metallic flavor that dominates the finish with a bitterness that seems to be out of place.

Appearance - Pours a dark amber color into a snifter. A lot of carbonation with this beer compared with other quadrupels. About one and a half fingers of head. Heavy stickage to the side of the glass as it is swirled around.

Smell - Malty and slightly sweet smell. Some dried fruit and earthy notes. 

Taste - Not as impressed as with some quadrupels I have had. Maybe it is because I have tried several quadrupels now (and am not used to Dubbels), but I feel as if this beer is just attempting to copy the other (better) quadrupels out there. I taste heavy malt taste that is not very sweet as all (despite the fact that my mouth and glass lip are sticky by the end of the tasting). Also in there are some dried fruits and earthy notes. Maybe some star of anise as well.

Mouthfeel - Not too heavily bodied as to be overpowering. Despite there being a lot of carbonation on the pour you cannot taste too much of it in your mouth (a good thing for me). 

Overall - What can I say? Maybe I have become a quadrupel snob with the likes of Westvleteren 12 and Rochefort, but I like a sense of sweetness and fruit in my beer. This just feels like a semi-good imitation beer. Really cannot tell the big difference between a Quadrupel and Dubbel.

Deep, dark mahogany with a huge, frothy beige head that lasts forever. Aroma of caramel, raisins, toast, plums, red wine and mild Belgian yeast. Yeast, sweet and bitter flavors are well balanced, though they do seem to be a bit weak. Alcohol is well hidden. Medium bodied with smooth carbonation, a creamy texture, and a dry, bitter finish.
Brown cocacolaish with nice head. Aroma malty, fruity (plum), chocolate. Taste sweet fruit (plum), malt. Medium body, text smooth, average carb, alcohol hidden, finish long sweetnees.

12 oz bottle.  Dark amber/burgundy pour with 1 finger head, some retention and nice lacing.  Good looking beer.  Nose is all over the dark fruit, honey, toffee, and malt.  Taste follows the nose and has an additional subtle extra sweetness.  There is also a back end bitterness to this that I am not too sure about.  Carbonation is a little too high for my liking as well.  Overall a good dubbel.

has to be the best mass marketed micro Belgian style double from a US brewer. when it comes to mass marketed micros, I find if I stick with the big boys(Rogue/ORE, Sierra Nevada/CAL, New Belgium/COL, Ommegang/NY, Unibroue/CAN), I tend to have better luck in finding a favorite than fishing some of the smaller ponds. 
Great stuff, thanks from Texas!
Bottle:  Pours amber with medium foamy head.  Aroma of fruits.  Full palate with flavor of fruits.  Very good.

Bottle; Pour is a slightly clear mahogany hue with a beige head that retains fairly well; average lacing in this glass ; the nose is dark fruit, crackers, caramel, and port; the flavor profile is on the sweet side; caramel, toffee really; perhaps a hint of cocoa, a bit of bitterness from the hop profile. Dark fruits are fairly strong in this brew - This one feels like a good american version of a dubbel to me.

Pours deep mahogany/auburn with a creamy finger and a half tan head. Smells malty and fruity, with hints of burgundy that comes out more as it warms. Tastes fruity, with a wine character and some caramel/toffee notes underneath. Medium-bodied with a smooth texture and soft, but present, mouth-carbonation, Ommegang Abbey Ale finishes with sweet fruit notes.

Dark brown body with beige head. Arom ahas strong malty backbone. Some sweetness, berries and chocolate. Flavour has little plums and bitterness. There is definitely good amount of flavour. Something portwine like.

12oz bottle in a Duvel glass. Deep amber pour with tan head that has an almost pinkish hue and it sticks around and laces nicely. Fruit driven nose with a nice little smoked quality. Very fruit forward on the palate with a high level of carbonation. Finishes bitter sweet with more fruit.

Hazy mahogany, thick light tan head. Aroma of ripe fruit, cherry, raisin, plum, fig, toffee, brown sugar. Taste is nice and sweet with lots of fruit again, light roast, bitter, doughy, well balanced. Medium body, more bitter finish than expected, medium high carbonation, some medicinal qualities but not to the point that its bad.

Rater #1600! Yeah Me! Tasted 5/31/11. 750ml cork and cage bottle. The first pour is heady with a creamy colored hue. Filtered with lively body. Dark amber hue. Aromas of dark fruits, piedras, and cocoa dust. Green apples and raisins. Very well rounded olfactory! Full bodied and just as tasty as I remember. I know Ive had this a hundred times, I just never took the time to tick. Full and sweet. Bitter and tangy. Nice mix of citrus and chocolate. A very sticky and spicy. Subtle flavors of cola and spicy pepper. Medium dark toast and brown sugar. Dark fruit and dark chocolate wafers. This is a standard for a reason!

On tap in a pint glass - this might be a really good or bad idea. Super dark amber and opaque. Aroma is fruity and earthy. Prune-y or some other lightly tart fruit. Lingering aftertaste with thin feel. Would pair very well with fruitcake or a berry pie of sorts. Overall, goes down dangerously easily considering how strong it is alcohol-wise.
no aroma... maybe a little yeast. lovely dark pour with big brown frothy head. many flavours, raising, toffee, caramel a little yeast.

20-MAY-2011, bottle @Marielyst sommerhus with Morten, from "Whole Foods".
Brown with beige head.
Typical belgian with yeasty fruity notes. Quite sweet and alcohol barely present on the nose - and none on the palate.
Fine high carbonation and a very fine creamy mouthfeel.
Nice brew brought back from New York by Marianne:-)

Great aroma with lots to unravel.  Definite sweetness with lots of malt.  Appearance is good with a pleasing dark dark amber.  Taste is right there with malty sweetness, but balanced with the alcohol.  Overall a very enjoyable beer.

750ml bottle. Pours a plum color with a 2 finger foamy beige head. Head recedes slowly leaving nice lace behind. Dark fruit aroma along with Belgian yeast.  Complex taste blending several fruits, plum, cherry, banana, along with a brown sugar sweetness, balanced with a mid hop profile. Soft, moderate body with aggressive carbonation.
A very sweet and heavy abbey ale. Not my usualy style, but highly drinkable and complex.
Pours a lasting ring of tan head with a ruby-brown body.  Aromas of coffee and red fruit.  Flavor is much the same but with some dates.  Finish is sweet, fruit, and lasting.
A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again for sure, probably my favorite dubbel, lots of depth in candi sugars and malts.
Solid in the malts and decent amount of fruitiness from the yeasts, this was good, although slightly subdued.

750mL bottle, pours dark reddish brown with a big beige head that takes a while to settle. Nose is candied sugar, caramel malt and light dried fruits. Flavour of caramel, candied sugar and lots of yeast. Highly carbonated. Very nice - its like a toned version of Three Philosophers.

Beautiful dark ruby colour, firm creamy beige head. Decent carbonation. This beer certainly is a looker.
Sweet aroma, caramel with notes of fruit and prunes, with a rather overpowering metallic iron smell.
The flavour is of caramel, malts, yeast notes, but rather thinner than expected. The finish is very short. Not nearly as balanced as its Belgian counterparts. I expected more of this beer.
(from 75cL bottle, thanks to RM for sharing)

Sampled from a bottle. Poured a hazy brown with an amber hue with a light brown head that lasted and laced nicely. Aroma had a bit of citrus and fruit with some sweet bread, coriander and a hint of caramel. Flavor was similar with a combination of light fruit, coriander, slight spice and a smooth caramel finish.

Poured from a bomber into a tulip glass. Appearance is a dark, hazy mahogany with a huge beige head that lingers for a long while. Aroma is prunes and green apple up front fading away into a red wine esque aroma. Taste is prunes and fig with a nearly tart finish. Smooth creamy mouthfeel with just a slight bubble from the carbonation. Good beer but not all that memorable in my book.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2011 Like a toned down version of Three Philosophers really. Good, but not as good as the Belgians. Dark cherry flavor. Must be aged a bit because Im not getting a lot of sweetness or alcohol.
12oz snifter. Yeasty aroma. Dont get much other than the yeast and hint of alcohol.

ON THE TOP OF THIS DEEP RED/BROWN BREW SITS THE THICKEST HEAD YOUVE EVER SEEN, DOWN TO THE BOTTOM OF THE GLASS IT NEVER GOES AWAY. FOR NO TRUE REASON I AVOIDED THIS ONE FOR AWHILE AND LIKE A FEW OTHER BEERS IVE AVOIDED I WONDER WTF  I WAS THINKING. THE AROMA IS THAT OF SWEET CHERRIES AND CARAMEL THE FLAVOR IS ROBUST HONEY AND LICORICE, THIS IS A VERY SWEET BEER REMINISCENT TO A BARLEY WINE OR A SUGAR CANE RUM. VERY NICELY DONE GANG!

The color of this beer is of the most beautiful hue of mahogany. The nose is full of dark fruit; dates, currants, with a hint of sour acidity. Given a chance to warm, and the flavor fills the whole mouth with a galactic spectrum of every cured fruit imaginable. Finish is long enough to pause for many seconds to ponder the rich, broad profile of the beer.

12oz bottle.  Recent delivery, should be relatively fresh.  Served at cellar temperature.
Pours murky reddish brown with a billowing tan head that holds well, recedes to an island and ring, leaves some large spots of lacing behind.
Aroma is yeast and fruity esters, toast, golden raisins, plums, brown sugar, yeast, bread, caramel, toffee, apples and pears.  Good to very good strength.
Flavor is toffee, caramel, dark fruits such as dates, figs, and raisins, bread, toast, and yeast, some molasses, brown sugar, fairly sweet, minimal alcohol.
Mouthfeel is medium, creamy, foamy, medium+ carbonation.
Very tasty Dubbel, one of the best North American versions Ive had.  Rich and robust.  Good value too as I can get a 4-pack for the price of an imported 750ml and this is just as good.  Had this a number of time in the past, just never reviewed, and is a top candidate anytime Im craving a Belgian-style beer.

Single bottle purchased from a Price Chopper in Lake Placid, NY on 03/28/2011. Colour: Medium to dark brown colour with light brown puffy and big head. Nose: Fruit blast, apple and pear to be exact, some foot sweat and egg as it opens up, then dark cherries and graham crackers late. Lots of layers and deeply complex. Taste: Medium-high sweet, medium sour, light bitter.  Cookie dough, vanilla, more cherry. Dreamy ingredients if ordering desert from a restaurant, of which this was not. Too much carbonation. World class nose and look, but the taste and palate need work....in my opinion.

750 ml bottle from Trader Joes. 2010 vintage. Pours a clear, rich amber color that is more gold on the edges and brown in the middle with a massive, rocky off-white head. Aroma of mixed fruits (plums, apricots, raisins), caramel malts, Belgian yeast, candi sugar, and licorice. Flavor of caramel malts, Belgian yeast, candi sugar, more fruits, chocolate, and licorice. Medium-bodied, with abundant but soft carbonation and a fruity, malty mouthfeel. Really nice dubbel, and cant believe I havent had this before.

12oz bottle. Pours a dark amber color. The beer has a sweet, malty aroma, with a touch of spice. The beverage was relatively easy to drink, with a nice malt and caramel characters. Honey, tinge of toffee.

Poured into a snifter. The Abbey Ale pours a beautiful rich mahogany color, with a tan head that drops slowly and leaves great lacing. Wonderful rich malty aroma, slight coffee hints and caramel hints in the nose. Rich flavors on the palate, strong alcohol notes, and good coffee finish. So much malty goodness, the palate goes crazy. Mouthfeel is outstanding, high carbonation and complex flavors make this a very drinkable beer.
Just a very nice beer overall.  Brown pour with a frothy head.  Lots of dark fruits, malt, and caramel aroma and taste.  Hops help balance the end.

One of my old favorites that I keep forgetting to rate.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Smells of rich, dark malt, dark fruit, cherry hints, spicy, nutty.  Tastes of honey, caramel, molasses, some dark fruit, some spicy elements on the finish.  Great beer.

12 oz. pour meduim brown with a red tint through out my glass a wonderful 1" thick tanish head that is determined to stay. I pick complex aromas of caramel, fruit, and honey.The taste is also very complex honey, chocolate, raisin, licorice, vanilla, with a nice touch of alcohol in the short finish. I think this dubbel is superb!

Pours a solid ruby brown, with a khaki head.  Aroma of fruits, malt, and alcohol.  Flavor is fruit with some spices.  There are also some hints of chocolate and alcohol in the finish.  Very nicely done!

Bottle pours red/brown with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of caramel, honey, cocoa powder, and dried fruits.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of roasted malt, oak, and alcohol.  Overall body
is moderate, soft and finishes with light bitterness and a touch of warming alcohol.

750 ml bottle, pours a cranberry honey w/ a dense rosy head, aroma is rum, dried fruit, and some light esters, flavor is burnt sugar, heavy orange rind, and finishes with a tactful carbonate bite, some alcohol warmth, pleasant but not exceptional

Pours reddish brown. Sweet smelling fruits, a little alcoholic punch.  
Delicious chocolate, cherry and dark fruit taste. Medium body.

Bottle from Knightly Spirits. Aroma consisted of fruits, notably raisin/plum and malt. Very aromatic. Appearance is a dark golden brown with a slight reddish hue. Flavor consists of raisin and prune and a nice caramel-like malt that comes through in the aftertaste. The flavor itself is quite nice and not overly complex. I like it.
Its got the right stuff, but the flavor is a bit blunt, it isnt as smoothe and intoxicating as other dubbels.

Rich, full, head.  Solid ruby color.  Taste is a perfect medly of dark cherries, red wine, and burgundy.  Tart at the tip of the tounge, goes down sideways as the tartness leaves you guessing->is this a beer or a wine?

Bottle. Poured into a DFH tulip glass a clear, dark reddish brown color with a very lively and think light tan head that is slow to settles. As it the head settles it leaves a nice sticky lace on the glass. The aroma is on the rather light side with notes of dark fruit and very slight booze. Dark fruit, caramel, and a subtle spice all play in the flavor. Light/medium mouthfeel with a pretty lively level of carbonation. Overall, I lke this enough to drink again but it isnt anything Id go running out to grab all that often. Ends with a lingering slight spiciness and mild bitterness.
absolutely delicious, why did I wait so long to try this?!? one of those beers that you cant stop sipping. this is one for the wall.

A - Pours a nice rich brown color with very nice amount of off-white head that retains fairly well. There is also some nice lacing left behind.

S - Rich and assertive fruit aroma, very sweet. Also a touch of sweet malts breaks through.

T - The immediate taste is the sweet fruit and maltiness that is in the smell. This is followed by a bit of mellowing malt flavor. There barely any noticeable bitterness or bite here, the flavors are well extremely well balanced.

M - Medium bodied and fairly creamy, but smooth and just the right amount of tingling carbonation.

D - A complex beer flavor wise and even mouthfeel-wise, but the flavors are well balanced and the beer stays fairly drinkable for its 8.50% APV.

Appearance:  reddish cola pour with a light foamy head.  Aroma:  caramel, strawberry (?), toasted spicy grains.  Taste:  sweet, rich and malty, with a light crisp bitterness and a hint of warm dark fruit (plum, raisin?).  Finish:  short and clean, with  a beautiful balance of tart,fruity hops and sweet, malty caramel; then comes a scotch-like warming of the belly.  Notes:  Beautifully balanced and rich.  Great mouthfeel, with a good blast of carbonation to aid the flavors right off the bat.

Dark red amber with a nice whitish foam. Nose is all on the cherry side. Medium to full body, lively carbonation, feels like swallowing a« forêt noire » cake. Long cherry cocoa aftertaste. Lovely beer.

Bottleshare. Deep rich reddish brown with a tinge of brown on the edges. a mix of light fruits and richer figs with a bit of molasses and biscuit to balance the sweet and the earthy. Great balance of flavours in a rich and complex brew.

Reviewed from notes.

Pours a moderately dark brown with some reddish hues. Off white head and some good lacing. Nose brings forward raisins, molasses, caramel, brown sugar, and dark fruits. The taste doesnt quite meld everything together, with some sugars and dark fruits coming through in the end. Moderate, creamy mouthfeel with lowish carbonation. Drinks pretty well, but not my favorite from them.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 10-19-2010

Bottle. Poured into a DFH tulip glass a clear, dark reddish brown color with a very lively and think light tan head that is slow to settles. As it the head settles it leaves a nice sticky lace on the glass. The aroma is on the rather light side with notes of dark fruit and very slight booze. Dark fruit, caramel, and a subtle spice all play in the flavor. Light/medium mouthfeel with a pretty lively level of carbonation. Overall, I lke this enough to drink again but it isnt anything Id go running out to grab all that often. Ends with a lingering slight spiciness and mild bitterness.
Bottle.  Deep red, cloudy, foamy tan head.  Fruit aroma but not sweet.  Medium body, smooth, flavorful.  Sweet finish.

Maudite glass. Classic, big-time Belgian pour--as good as they get. Dark brown with a touch of red; almost opaque-looking. Light brown head taking up 40% of the glasss height, and a bit over the rim. Not going anywhere. Aroma is sweet, beautiful Belgian yeast. Smooth mouthfeel, light carbonation plays on the tongue as alcohol notes come through. This is a very delicate beer. Outstanding overall balance and drinking experience. This is when I say "its just good" (meaning, SIMPLY good, not MERELY good!).

750 ml bottle shared by a friend.  Pours a deep reddish copper color with a large rocky off white head.  The aroma is sweeter with caramel and honey and a splash of berry fruitiness.  The flavor has more honey and caramel malt sweetness, just a touch of raisin, light notes of Belgian chocolate and a vinous alcohol note.  Medium to medium plus bodied and quite easy to drink.  This is a solid readily available beer.
On tap at Zenos. Amber with a medium cream head. Aroma is yeast and raisins. Flavor is raisin, plum, honey and toffee. Delicious.

Brownish with  amber red color in chalice style glass.  Thick off white head.  Smells of apple, toast, fig, and yeast.  Taste is much of the same with fruity sweetness, apple cider, fig and bread toast flavor.  Also a little boozy sourness comes through on the back-end.  Very good dubbel.

Shared at Nashville Beer Summit 1.0. Pours dark brown with a khaki head. Aroma of Belgian ale esters and yeast. Medium bodied with a soft texture, and fine spritzy carbonation. Flavor of dark Belglian malts, raisen, berries, candi sugar, and yeast. Solid stuff

12 oz. bottle. Pours a dark, opaque orangish-red with a large tan head. The aroma is figs, apricots, butterscotch, molasses, and a biscuit dough yeast smell. The flavor is sweet with a sharp citrus tartness. The palate is surprisingly light and smooth, and slightly astringent. The finish is a little clingy and bitter, and the abv shows through with a light warming feel.  Overall, an amazing brew. Smooth and drinkable, yet very flavorful and complex.

Bottle: pours a hazy amber, cinnamon, fluffy head that recedes. lively carbonation. fermented fruit, raspberry, cereal malts, herbal hops. quite light mouthfeel and a bit dry. short finish. pretty good

Aroma: Lots going on here--raisin, chocolate, caramel, licorice. Nothing too overpowering or singled out, all put together in a pleasant, sweet perfume.
Appearance: Clear dark reddish brown with a thick, frothy tan head.
Taste: Medium sweetness, light sourness.
Palate: Full body, creamy texture, lively carbonation, long finish
Overall: A bit too fruity for me, but still a very solid beer. I could see this pairing well with a hearty stew or French Onion soup, or possibly a roasted duck. Theres a lot happening here, and its all working well.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2014 I loved this beer. Such a sweet sugary, liquor smell to it with a nice, dark amber body. To start off with it, has a huge head on it and the first taste is sweet caramel taste,  malty with some chocolate tons to it. I loved licorice taste and hints of vanilla are in there. very complex with hints of vanilla, roasted malts, chocolate but most of all you get that caramel taste to it. It hits on all notes for me as the my pallet loved the mix of beer and liquor taste.

On tap poured a dark brown color with a medium head.The taste was medium sweetness  It had a medium body,  with a soft carbonation. The finish was clean on the palate. I also tasted what i thought was brown sugar cane.
Brown pour with some light  tan head. Sweet candied sugars, yeast and light fruit notes in the aroma. Flavor of sweet malt and sugars, yeast , light licorice, and a touch of fruity warmth.

This is one of the highest rated beers for a reason.  Such a great taste.  Stronger then your common run-of-the-mill beer weeds out the binge drinkers.  This is not a chugging beer and should be enjoyed with no rush. 
Also, its slightly better on tap.

Bottle. Pours deep burgundy/brown with big off white head. Aroma is of dark fruit and a bit of apple cider. The taste is sweet and malty dark fruit but with a definite cider undertone, followed by herbal hop bitterness which lingers on the finish. The cider note is very long lasting in the aftertaste. A bit too much hops compared to many of the Belgian Dubbels I think but good overall.

750ml Cork and Cage. Deep ruby red in color with a thick, long lasting, white head. Fruit cake, licorice, and slight caramel notes in the aroma. Very smooth, slightly malty pallet. Well balanced fruity (slight cherry) with toffee notes  and very drinkable for 8.5%. Finishes a bit dry and malty but very well balanced. Great American Dubbel.

750 mL bottle from Total Wine, served in a tulip. Pours hazy mahogany with a huge frothy tan head. The head remains and leaves copious lace. The nose has notes of candied fruit, caramel, honey, toasted malts with hints of flowers and chocolate. The flavour is dominated by complex malty sweetness, with notes of raisins, caramel and candied fruit. It becomes a bit drier towards the end. The finish is lingering toasted malts with a hint of fruit. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, milky texture and lively carbonation. Overall, this is a phenomenal dubbel with a huge complex fruity sweetness. It is beautifully assembled, complex and satisfying. A very introspective beer great for sipping next to the fire. Another great brew from Ommegang! 2010-12-30

Poured a brownish color, cloudy.  Medium head.  Aroma of sweet sugers and honey and malt.  Lighter aroma.  Bigger taste.  Taste was med sweetness. Palate was med bodied, creamy texture.  Tatse is nice malty sweet flavor.  Raisons and malts. Fairly complex.  Would get a case of this.

12 oz bottle, brown color, minimal head, hazy. Aroma is sweet and fruity, with raisins, citrus, and sweet roastiness present. Flavor is very sweet with some spicyness. Palate is very full, nice beer but flavor is a bit over the top. Good to sample, but definitely not a session beer.

Bomber.  Poured a nice reddish/amber color with huge fluffy white head.  Nice aroma of fruit and hops.  Taste is really good with coffee, caramel, and honey all being prevelant.  Really good abbey double.  Highly recommended and the price was on sale for 5.99.  Great beer at that price.

Aroma is overwhelmingly sweet, of undistinguishable dried fruit. Pours a cloudy reddish brown, with a foamy, resilient tan head. Taste is far too sweet for me; raisins and dates are clear, along with a bit of alcohol. I dont get any of the subtle coffee I had heard others mention. After swallowing, an unpleasant sticky fills my mouth like I had just swallowed cough syrup and I was tasting its coating.

Belgian bliss.  Dark copper color with an off-white frothy head. Rich fruity aroma with no one fruit dominating is perfectly balance by a malty backbone. Spices are subtle but evident. Lighter in color than the typical dubbel yet fruitier.

Aroma- dark fruit, caramel and overall a rich maltiness. Pours a dark coffee color with a rocky tan head that leaves a nice lacing behind. More maltiness in the flavor with a hint of sweet caramel. Finishes dry with a well balanced bitterness. Overall a nice belgian ale with plenty of character.
Aroma is very fruity with a distinct Belgian beer smell. It tastes even better than its aroma with hints of caramel and balanced malt and hops. This is one of my favorite beers from Duvel
Hazy candied apple color. Vanilla head with little lacing. Medium candied aroma with a slight sour aroma. Beer has a slightly sweet palate with a tangy finish.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2011 Appearance: Dark brown, hazy. Nice amount of creamy, light tan head.
Aroma: Sweet, dark malt. Caramel.
Taste: Some sweetness, dark malt and fruit. Vinous. Slight alcohol. Enjoyable.
Info: 750ml bottle, 17/11-2010, 209/300, 224/500

Beer poured a coffee color. Cloudy with a tall stiff tan-colored head. Aroma was earthy with an alcohol profile sort of like a red wine. A subtle wet dog aroma in here as well. Taste was strange. Peat, wet leaves, fruity,with rich malts, umami on the mid-taste morphing into a funky, tangy aftertaste. Mouthfeel was medium carbonation. Medium texture and body. Sharper rather than syrupy. Overall a unique brew. It is hard to pin down into a familiar style.

Tasted from a bottle at the Parade of Darks in Denver, Colorado. Red/brown with a reddish head. Belgian ale aroma with some candy sugar. Body is fairly sweet with a pretty good Dubble-style flavor. Finish is not surprisingly sweet. Overall a pretty good beer but too sweet in my opinion.

12 oz. bottle.  Bought the sampler pack to see if I could work any Ommegang onto my beer menu...  Definitely a lot more "beer" than my regulars can handle.  Dark amber pour.  Moderate head.  Great flavor profile.  Not your everyday happy hour beer.  More like a nice sit down dinner with good friends kind of beer.

Really impressive.  A wonderful mixture of Belgian ingredients and American brewing.  It has a slight, fruity aroma and a beautiful, dark burgundy color that sparkles deep marron when held to the light.  Thick, fluffy head that leaves a good film.  Flavor is malty and fruity, almost whiskey-like.  The palate is crisp and clean with overtones of the malt.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a hazy dark brown with a nice foamy, long lasting head.  Aroma of caramel, dark fruit and some florals.  Tastes rich, with dark fruit, sweet malt, chocolate and a bit of alcohol.  Excellent.

Bottle - poured a clear reddish brown with a nice, lasting head and substancial lacing. Aromas of dark fruit, molasses and faint floral scents. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of spices, molasses, and some fruitiness with a smooth, lingering sweet finish. Very nice - just bought another bottle to share with my dad since he enjoyed this one so much a while back and I am trying to keep him away from the bud light!
Nice dubbel, this is becoming one of my favour styles and this one does not disappoint. This one is a dark dubbel but it is recommended
Tried it on tap and bottled, excellant either way, but better draft. Sweetish with hints of coffee and alcohol.

75cl cork/cage trade while eating homemade Liege waffles. Probably about 1.5-2 years old.  Pours a murky brown like you would expect with a small tan head and no lacing. Sweet(er) aroma of dark fruit, sugar and caramel malt. Flavor was true-to-form but a little hot in the finish.
perfect texture, great malty balance, and wine flavors make this a luxurious beer
Bottle to chilled mug.  Light yellow head, with nice lacing.  Dark amber color, cloudy.  Musky scent.  Lots of thick malt flavors.  Sweet and delicious.

Enjoyed at the monthly beer dinner at The Holy Grail in Plano, TX.  Pours a dark, hazy amber with a medium head. Aroma is dark fruits and malt.  Taste is raisins, black cherries and malt.  Alcohol is well masked, making this easy to drink (too easy!).  Neutral finish.  Really good stuff here.

Bottle, caged and corked.  Poured dark brown with a nice head.  The aroma is sweet and sugary.  The beer drinks with the distinct farmhouse character of many Belgian standards, rich with toffee and brown sugar.  Not a girlie beer by any means!  Excellent.  (#4014, 11/11/2010)

12 ounce. Poured into Ommegang glass. Pours rich, dark mahogany color. Creamy head dissipates relatively quickly to form only a thin layer. Aromas of Belgian yeast, spiciness, chocolate, roasted malts. Subtle hints of cooper.  Cooper (penny) taste on back of palate. Roasted malt flavor on front palate. Mouth feel has nice carbonation on the front palate for a dark Belgian ale. Smooth feel on back palate.
Dark brown with a nice tan head. Good dark fruit aroma with some caramel malts and light chocolate notes. Medium bodied and very smooth, high alcohol is hidden well. Very complex and enjoyable.

Clear burgundy pour light off white tan head  ..... sweet dark fruity belgian yeast and caramel malts in the aroma .... decent lacing starts off with light chocolate and toffee flavor then a fruity and rich belgian yeast lightly bitter and caramel malts with a dry bitter finish .... full bodied and awesome dubbel flavors come together so well in this beer

Pours darkish brown with a subtle red tint and a large off-white head that lasts for about half of the tasting. Aroma is very heavy on the fruits and includes notes of plums, raisins, caramel, and alcohol. Flavor is not as heavy on the fruit as the aroma would have hinted at but its there along with a subtle spicy flavor and a hint of alcohol. Finish is pretty heavy on the carbonation and alcohol.

opaque brown, big dense tan head, creamy full body, bubbly medium-high carbonation.

aroma: dark fruit, red wine alcohol, sweet roasted malt, dark fruit, milk chocolate, toffee, bready yeast, and a hint of licorice.

taste: belgian yeast esters, dark candy sugar (or unsweet brown sugar), burnt toffee, a touch of tartness, balancing notes of alcohol and stale hops, and some warming alcohol in the finish with lingering toffee notes. 

Very complex and great aroma, but not a notable amount of dark candy sugar, stale hops, or minerality -all of which are my least favorite elements of this style. Taste is equally complex, but mostly a different set of flavors, making for a hugely flavorful and complex whole. A little too sweet to drink much by itself, but a great pairing beer.

Deep brown pour with hints of red. Large brownish head that disappears as you drink.  Wonderful smell, dark fruits and caramel with an alcoholy scent for me. Although I must say that after every smell I found it more difficult to describe.  Tasted (obviously) like a definite Belgian for me. Caramel and alcohol up front. Lingers of fruit tastes after, grape or cherry.  The more I drank it, the more it grew on me. This is the first Dubbel I have had, as I normally stick with Trippels, but this could change that.

Poured a hazy reddish-brown with a thin off-white head.  Aroma is very fruity and sweet with caramel malts, raisins, and brown sugar.  Taste is quite fruity with yeasty flavors.  Alcohol is slightly noticeable.  Bread and caramel are also present which balances it out.  Finish is sweet and fruity.  Maybe a little too much carbonation.  Overall a very nice beer.

Bottled. A dark amber beer with a good lacing beige head. Aroma is sweet, malty and belgian yeast. Notes of caramel and dry fruits. Aroma is also sweet and malty. Strong belgian yeast character, burning alcohol and spicy finish. Nice mouthfeel and caramel notes

Pours a cloudy leathery brown color with a foamy caramel colored head.  Basic dried fruit aroma and some alcohol notes mixed in.  Flavor is not a sweet as I expected it to me.  Very dry with a bitter toasty malt aftertaste.  Highly carbonated on the palate.  Overall, Im not sure about this one.  Maybe I got a bad bottle as I had higher expectations.   May have to re-rate...

Pours deep amber with quite a bit of carbonation that disapears quickly. Aroma of dark fruits, yeast, bread and bubblegum?  Lots of things going on here with the taste, first off very intense palate. Toffee, caramel, dark fruits (raisin,plums,figs) and sugar all ending with a nice dryness. Well done and tasty.

On draft at the Southampton Beer Store. Pours a deep burgundy with thin off-white head. Aroma of dried fruits, malts and yeast. Flavor was a great blend of dried fruits, malts, dough, toffee, and a hoppy finish. This beer was delicious all the way through, from the initial sweetness to the finish. Excellent.
Bottle. Dark amber color with off-white, almost tan head.  Thick yeasy aroma with lots of nutty malt. Flavor matches nose perfectly. This is a regular in my glass.

Dark amber, good off white (almost brown) head.  Bread malt mixed with light fruit aromatics - apricot comes to mind.  Taste is more of dark fruit though - prunes or figs, along with some sweetness.  Sorry - but I just dont taste the chocolate in there - more fruity than anything.  Its a really nice beer.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a Chimay goblet. 

Appearance: Pours a dark mahogany brown with a 1-2 finger foamy tan head. Nice lacing.

Smell: Dried fruit, caramel malt, spices and a hint of alcohol.

Taste: Sweet dried fruit up front followed by caramel malt in the middle and ending with mild phenols and a slightly bitter metallic taste.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a high amount of carbonation. Nice tingle from the carbonation up front. Alcohol warmth comes through as you drink it.

Drinkability: High drinkability although having more than a couple could spell trouble.

Overall: Very solid beer overall. Great representation of the style. Definitely worth giving a shot.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2010 Foamy tan head over a dark brown body. Aroma not as sweet as expected. Malts, dry, earth. Smooth and a bit sticky; makes a good drink. Sweetness comes later - too late. Very interesting although I wouldnt call it authentic Belgian. (On my FL trip.) My 100th rating! :)
I had this for the first time today.  Very rich without being overly heavy.  It has a slight bitterness that tapers off just right at the end.  Highly recommended.

This beer was delightful. Spicy banana bread & toffee aroma. Additionally at times I thought I smelled something a little like soy sauce. Amber color with a dark tan head. The taste has the sweet bread and toffee that was detected in the aroma. Very yummy taste. Thick oily mouthfeel.

Appearance is dark amber, with a hazy layer of yeast settled at the bottom of the bottle. Thick, creamy head. Aroma is malty and sweet. Taste is well balanced. Hints of smokiness, fruit, and sugar. Sweet finish and palate feel. A bit sticky in the mouth. Exceptional beer.

Pours deep yet dull amber with semi loose dark tan head. The aroma is pretty rich with ripe plum, figs and dates along with modest amounts of yeasty spices in the background. The taste has the same dark fruity sweetness as noted in the nose and then slowly gets more and more prickly and bright with spiciness, spiced red apple, raisins, nutmeg and then picking up softer yeasty notes into the finish.
brown sugar, dates, great mouthfeel.  smells like syrup.  tastes a bit alcoholic, but it is pretty drinkable.

(750ml bottle) opaque rich amber-ruby, very Long lasting tan head with great lacing. Nose of banana, brown sugar, honey, Belgian yeast, mild spicy alcohol. Taste of Belgian yeast, spicy hop bite, dark fruits, banana, alcohol, brown sugar and caramel. Very dry finish.

Poured into a tulip glass from 12oz bottle, thick creamy head and pours a rich deep red. The aroma is over sweet, caramel, maybe some fruit, cherry, maybe toffee. First sip is different, alcohol taste is near non-existant for a 8.5 beer, a very backloaded taste, truly Im ambigious about it, it has some weird qualities Im not sure I like. There are better examples out there from American breweries.

750ml bottle from Winooski shared with friends at home.

Appearance : Deep mahogany with a big creamy and foamy brown head. Light gusher. Not much lacing.

Aroma : Sugary and nutty. Slightly earthy and mineral. Light toffee and licorice. Light hints of bananas. Sugary candy on nose.

Taste : Sugary and nutty with some caramel. Finish is a bit mineral and earthy. Mineral profile fades away with time. Spicy and a bit bitter. Carbonation quite fizzy.

Overall : NIce nose, nice caramel and sugar. Nice nutty profile. Mineral profile is a bit distubring at first but fades away after some time. Nice sugar on taste. Very nice belgian beer. Nothing really outstanding but well made.

Poured from bottle, pours a cloudy dark amber with a soapy white head, aroma is sweet with hints of raisin and bread notes, the taste is full bodied with a nice sweet finish of brown sugar with a hint of booze in the flavor, enjoyed this brew

24-09-10 Bouteille dans un verre westmalle: Brune foncée, quasi rouge. Belle petite mousse crème tournant vers le beige qui disparait asser rapidement, mais laissant un léger filet. Légère effervescence.  Aromes de fruits rouges, de caramel, de patisserie fraiche. En bouche, elle est douce, légèrement sucrée, avec une petite touche surette. Elle a une texture crémeuse et enrobante laissant la bouche un peu sèche, mais prete a en recevoir plus. Tres bonne biere bien balancée.
Dark amber with slight foamy head. Strong madeira and port aromas.. bready and sweet with a malty finish. very vinous and grapey in nature. Nice dubbel.

Bottle. Thanks to my friend Rachel for bringing this back from Washington for me. Pours medium brown, 2-finger, pale tan head that is moderately persistent, lacing is ropey, at best. Nose is rather boozy, notes of spice, raisins, brandy, honeyed malt, ginger, plums. Flavours are rich and nutty, lovely Belgian yeast character; notes of dark fruits, spice, solid tart malty finish. Warming, but not heavy. Tasty.

Pours medium brown with a moderate light brown head and a touch of sediment. Nose is delicious and smells of a deep brown sugary malt and a little yeast. Flavor is rich and layered with caramel, both brown and white sugars, abbey yeast, a little alcohol, light hops and spice, and an unidentified (by me, anyway) last flavor that adds more depth. Very drinkable. Finish is a little sticky and mostly sweet. One of the best beers I have ever had.
Cloudy dark brown with medium head.  Aroma sugary yeast.  Full body without noticable alcohol.  Pretty sweet with some fruitiness and brown sugar, slight dry finish.  Good stuff.
Amazing beer had this in a bottle at Lartusi in NYC tastes very similiar to a delirium tremons but not as much bite. this could be a wonderful session beer when going out
Dark with medium, dissipating head. Aroma is faint, but interesting... hard to place. Like a mellow quad with a bite, I guess. Flavor is rich and funk-free, but does have a bit of acid/harshness.

Draft.  Pours a clear dark mahogany with ruby highlights and decent near white head and spotty lacing. Nose of light cherry and light nutmeg spice which becomes more pronounced in the flavor.  Notes of anise, dark fruits, belgian yeast, but not biscuity or bready.  This is pretty good.  Classic for the dubbel style I would say, but definitely not my fave for the style.

Bouteille de 750 ml partagée avec mon vieux pote Steph pour nos 37 ans.  Nasdrovia!  Le liquide est rouge sale et la mousse se transforme en un petit anneau.  Le nez est plein de confiture (prunes, figues, cerises), de caramel, de levure épicée, de malt doux et de sucre dorge.  Lalcool se manifeste sous un aspect poivré.  Enfin, beaucoup de complexité dans les parfums.  Au goût, le liquide est tout autant riche avec un profil caramélisé, fruité et épicé.  En bouche, le liquide a une rondeur agréable avec un corps moyen et une effervescence qui me semble juste à point. Sa texture douce et crémeuse invite rapidement à une autre gorgée.  La finale est peu surprenante : des fruits épicés avec un alcool qui cherche à réchauffer.
Bottled pours a cloudy cherry color, lasting amber  head, easy carbonation, spice and fruits in the aromas and burgundy in the flavor with fruit notes and an alcohol finish.

Bottle. Pours a dark and cloudy brown with thin tan head.  Aroma is very sweet, hinting of fruit, nuts, and alcohol, maybe similar to fruitcake.  Flavor is dominated by a sweet maltiness with the fruit and spice components in the background.  A bit cloying.  Pleasantly lively carbonation on the palate.

Pours hazy, red/amber.  Off-white dense head carries a yeasty/sweet bouquet with a touch of banana/fruit.  The liquor is tart and sweet with caramel malt dominant with an underlying backdrop of alcohol.  Belgian lace persists to the end.
Good, but not great. Didnt live up to the hype. Check my full review: http://beerhatesme.blogspot.com/2010/08/ommegang-a
Bottle pours a hazy deep red/brown beer with a large tan head. Scent is sweet fruit, yeast. Taste is sweet malt with yeast. High carbonation.

Very deep red with a fluffy tan head. Aroma of toffee, caramel, dark fruits, and nuts. Sweet flavor of roasty caramel malts, followed by a rush of dark fruit, possibly some plums and figs. Slight alcohol flavor that fades quickly after the first few sips, after which the 8.5% is hidden very well. Medium to full bodied ale whose complex character tastes markedly different between drinking vessels. I actually preferred the taste in a pint glass to that in a trappist glass. Do yourself a favor and let it warm up a bit after you take it out of the fridge!

Serving: 750 ml. bottle from Wegmans Leesburg. 
Aroma: The nose is ripe with fruit, toffee, dark caramel, fruit cake, and dark bread. Delicious! 
Appearance: It pours a dark, tea like color with a very foamy tan head.  Be forewarned!  This one may pour out of the top once you pop the cork!  The head settles down to to a foamy ring around the edge of the glass. 
Taste: Sweet with dried fruit, raisins, dried apples, molasses, caramel, tobacco, and a bit of Belgian yeast.  I forgot how much I really love this brew. 
Palate: Light to medium on the palate with large bubbles of high carbonation leading to a sweet, dried fruit finish.  Quite nice. 
Overall: This brew reminds me of why Ommegang is so good.  An American classic if you will.  Definitely worth trying.  Repeatedly.

Bottle.

A - Hazy chestnut, copper color with with a decent to smaller sized, foamy beige head. Disappears pretty fast with a ring of lace around the edge.

S - Dark spicy fruit with cherry, date and raisin with a lot of rum soaked aroma. Some licorice, some burnt brown sugar, yeast and some bubblegum like aroma.

T - Similar to the aroma with lots of spiced dark fruit with a bit of a rum soaked taste and burnt candi sugar. Some yeasty taste comes out. Fair amount of apple and orange as well. Caramel and burnt toffee malt. Some cinnamon, pepper and clove along.

M - Medium body with a good amount of carbonation. Pretty smooth and slick.

D - Decently drinkable. A bit on the spicy and burnt to really want to drink a lot. Alcohol is fairly well hidden.

Notes: Overall a decent beer, pretty big flavors with a good amount of spice, burnt and rum flavors that make it a bit strong. Not my favorite for the style, but not a bad beer overall.
This has everything I like about Abbey Dubbels.  Very well crafted, but the alcohol is too noticeable for my taste, impinging on the flavor. I much prefer the Chimay Rouge.

Cloudy dark orange-amber color with a light-brown head.  A delicious, syrupy honey and malt characteristic.  Very smooth, tasty and fruity with a neat sweetness thats a little puckery in the finish.  Dark sweetness with a hint of licorice.  A great Abbey!

medium brown with large white head.  medium carbonation for the style.  nose of sweet malt and fruity esters.  little bitterness before fruity esters and a nice candi-sugar like sweetness.  the fall of this beer is the residual sweetness, which is too great, not allowing the yeast to open up the beer.  the brewery suggests 3-5 years of storage before sampling, which would likely cure this problem, but is too extensive of a waiting period

Pours a deep nut brown with a small beige head. The aroma is of toffee, dark fruit, caramel, yeast, and candied sugar. The flavor is similar, with some added plum and dates, and faint anise. Nice abrupt finish with a light mouthfeel and fine Belgian carbonation. Very well crafted dubbel.

This beer has some very good qualities. I quite enjoyed the strong aroma of yeast and fruit. The initial strike to the palate is its biggest weakness - being it is very light, but mostly pleasant. Overall, the beer is very light with nice carbonation. The backend of the beer is a high point, leaving a refreshing aftertaste.

Poured into a brandy snifter, it still has only a subtle aroma, toffee and raisons. But the flavor is not so subtle; rich and complex with sweet burnt sugar malts playing with dark fruits (plums) and yeasty esters (clove, a little banana). The aroma becomes a little more intense as it warms and you swirl away all that nasty carbonation.
Pours a nice burgundy/ brown color. Smell is of sweet fruit, Carmel, toffee, and raisin notes. very full bodied mouth feel, the taste is carmel, raisins and brown sugar. Very good beer.

This is a good beer.
Very nice mouthfeel, those little belgian bubbles.  Very nice.  Beautiful color.  Very ice soft head, like a pillow.  Malty, hoppy, spicy, very good...

First, let me say this is my First beer rating here and I Do Not like this style of beer.  The bottle says is a "rich, fruity, aromatic, burgundian brew."  Id agree with that, but the problem is, if I wanted burgundy, Id buy a bottle of WINE, no t this.  I had a few sips of it and started using it for cooking.  I can imagine some of you now laughing at me, but I dont care.  Thats all its good for, except for one thing: more than any other beer Ive tried, it goes well with pasta and tomato sauce.  Most beer drinkers should take caution when considering this one. Cheers!

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho.
probably my favorite dubbel, lots of depth in candi sugars and malts.

12oz bottle holy head sweet head large and fluffy pours dark brown slight amber in color. Aroma of raisin, apricot, toffee. Taste of soy sauce, fig, caramel, floral, meaty, metallic. Not one of my favorite styles but a decent beer.

I will spare the description and will get to the point! This Abbey punches you in the face right after it gives you a hug that says, "Here, I got you this puppy?" Its like listening to Al Green then Metallica then Kenny G at the end.....nighty night as you start sucking your thumb like a baby!!! WARNING! This brew may make you give away your significant other and make you think you hit the LOTTO! Please drink responsibly and give your friend one!!
Pours a dark amber color. Smells of sweet brown sugar, sweet pears, apples, figs, and a pinch of honey. Tastes of sweet sugar with a slight bitter finish. Could have been colder. Oops

Bottle. poured a deep brown color with big head.  big aroma of dried fruit and caramel aroma. big robust roasted flavor at the beginning with sweet licorice  and big toffee flavor coming through at the end.

Very pleasant, strong fruity aroma. Big frothy tan  and nice brown, cloudy color. Light carbonation and good weight on the palate. And the taste ... Excellent. Im a fan a beers with a strong flavor and a lot of body like this beer has.

Poured into a McDonalds super sized cup and drank through a silly straw.
Billowy head with an amber hue. Aroma is subtle and complex with a hint of anise. This ale starts out sweet and finishes dry with great balance. The palate is quite nice being full-bodied and creamy with an unctuous texture that dissipates into a somewhat astringent after taste. Truly a great ale from the Leather Stocking Region of New York state.

From bottle 75 cl. Yesterday @ gouvernementsplace Antwerp.  Thx to ABC beerclub.
This was my first Ommegang beer. 
Nice label.  Redbrwon color, with a large beige head. 
Aroma dryed fruits, some light roasted malts. 
Medium body.
Taste sweet start, fruits, nutty touch, caramel, roasted malts, bit alcoholic.

Ommegang
Abbey Ale
Pours orange/brown with a thick cream colored head. Lots of retention. Aroma is sharp fruity cloves with yeast and some alcohol. Light raisins on the nose. Flavor is malty stone fruits with a slight pleasing funk. Not much alcohol. Nice brew with some mild hop bitterness on the finish.

Pours ruby red with a cascading pillowlike foamy head.  Aroma is fruit, yeast, spice and a hint of alcohol.  Taste is more of the same with a little bit of a dry snappy finish.  No Chimay, but a quality brew.

750ml bottle in a Trappist glass.  Pours dark ruby/brown with a thick beige head.  Aroma of spicy Belgian yeast, fruit, and caramel/toffee.  Flavor of some dough, fruits, and caramel.  Has a nice finish with notes of alcohol.  Thick for a dubbel.  One of the best dubbels Ive had, but Im still not that big of a fan of this style of beer.

Beautiful amber/reddish color with ample head that really stays when served at the right temperature.  Nose is both sweet and sour  with bright citrus notes and dates or dried fruit.   Taste is sweet (more of a honey taste than a sugary taste) and floral with slight maltiness.  Overall excellent.  Not bitter and while the alcohol is present, it really balances nicely. 

Terrific.

From The Hopster beer club pick.  Poured into trappist glass.  Dark ruby red color with huge frothy head that diminishes quickly and leaves impressive lacing. Notes of caramel, spice, banana. Lush mouth feel. Very nice.
12 ounce bottle-a hazy brown pour tan head-aroma and taste of rich sweet fruit-smooth creamy sweet finish

(25.4 oz bottle)  My beer club pick.  Aroma is yeasty and malty.  Poured a rich dark amber color with a light tan head.  Very little lasing.  Taste is rich with caramel, toffee and malt and hoppy finish.  More enjoyable once the unique taste is acquired.

Bottle. Poured a hazy brown with a large tan rocky head and had good lacing. The aroma was of sweet toasted malts, dried fruit, a leathery yeast and had a moderate alcohol scent. It tasted slightly sweet yet acidic in the beginning and finished about the same with a mild alcohol flavor. Mouthfeel was light to medium in body with the texture being quite creamy. Overall an assume brew and quite satisfying to drink.
Good frothy head, aroma and taste of grapefruit, crisp mouth feel, hazy appearance.  Overall refreshing.
Excellent beer. Pours a burgundy flavor with a big frothy head. Aroma is malty with a sweet alcohol aroma. Taste is sweet with a Belgian tartness. Fantastic abbey. one of my favorites.

Bottle.  Pours dark, hazy amber, nearly brown, with a medium beige head.  Aroma of lots of dark fruits (cherries, raisins, prunes); some malty sweetness.  Lots of fruit and sweet caramel malt in the flavor.  Theres some earthiness, yeast, banana, and sourness, but less than Id expected.  Complex, long flavors.  Creamy palate, but not overly thick.  Alcohol is muted.  Delicious and dangerously drinkable.
Bottle.  Medium brown pour with a nice tan head.  Sweet bread, spice, flower, banana, and nuts.  Nice aroma.  A good beer worth drinking.

Alot of foam as I poured into trappist glass........but got under control in time.  Tastes of ginger and rye..........and very dry finish.   My first Dubbel and definitely want to try more.      Well worth a try.
A good but not great beer.  Smooth mouth feel with a steady taste.  Hops were well balanced I thought.  I was new to the style when I tried this beer so please take this rating with a grain of salt.
Nice amber copper colour with loads of begie head and lacing. Fruity sour aroma. Fruity, sour, malt flavour. This is a nice beer!

Pours dark ruby red with a thick two finger head light caramel color. Smell is dusty barnyard, with caramel and bread undertones, and plum. Taste is fruity with a definite malt and lasting caramel flavor. Mouthfeel is creamy and coats the tongue nicely. A rich and filling Abbey with a nice complex taste. A wonderful sipping beer.

Pours a dark red and a thick creamy head forms.  The aroma is of rich plums and dates as well as yeast.  The rich dark fruits are strong and dominating.  There might be some chocolate too.  It just has a nice thick malty aroma to it.  Very raisiny, loads of sweet dark fruits, and minimal hop character.  The body is a little full, more of a medium to full.  The finish is medium in length and rather sweet.
Nice dark brown/reddish color. Nose and taste is a little too sweet and doesnt mask alcohol content as well as other breweries. Rated 3/1/03

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2015 Pours a muddy apple cider with a healthy dusty tan head.  Good retention.  Every time I try this ale it comes across a bit different.  Aroma is apple pie, brown sugar, cherry, old bread.  Taste is spicy, fruit cake, bread, raisin, with a nice touch at the end.  Very dry and attenuated.  This brew is what sold me in the beer hobby, so its fitting for rating number 100.  Recommended to anyone, thank you Ommegang!

Draft at redlight redlight.  pours a very pretty opaque amber with a tan head and decent lace.  solid nose thats strong on the malt characteristics, not half bad notes that almost resemble saurkraut, fairly perfumy.  rich flavor that is very sweet and actually just a tiny bit tart.  features flavors of candied raisins and prunes.  Very good belgian style ale.

Pours dark redbrown with lightly tanned head. Sweet malts, fruits and hints of hops. Crisp, acidly freshvfruits and malty sweetness. Nicely balanced on palate with a short acidly bitter- sweet finish.

Poured dark amber, with bubbly slowly dissipating head.  Aroma is fruity (cherries perhaps?).  Taste is very fruity: apricots, raisins.  Dry finish.  Interesting beer, but definitely not for everyday drinking.

Ommegang Brewery--Ommegang Belgian-Style Abbey Ale--rich, fruity, aromatic, burgundian brew--2004 25.4 oz. Bottle.  8.50% ABV.  10-IBUs?  (4.0 / 5.0)  Belgian Ale--Dubbel.  2 @ $5.99 Each.  Lacy tan mild tight head.  Clear deep dark ruby red color.  Rich aromatic plum fig no hop front.  Mild sweet fruit ester complex toffee cherry chocolate plum licorice honey rich body.  Huge BC sediment clouds & mellows sharp flavors creamy.  Smooth end.  Nice.  Sampled 12/20/2008.

Thick and gorgeous pour. Awesome color of dark roasty brown. Huge flavor that has fig, toffee and wonderful belgian yeast flavor and a great coating texture all over my mouth. I cant believe I have not had this, or at least not rated this before, a great abbey beer.

This is an outstanding version of an abbey ale.  Big, bold flavor - sweet fruitiness, a solid caramel malt presence.  Finishes very dry and hides the high ABV quite well.  Definitely worth picking up if you see a bottle.

Bottle at Göteborg beer festival, 2010-04-23 Göteborg
creme brulee, fruits, chocolate, malts, toffee, figs

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2013 Corked & Caged 750 ml Bottle. Appearance is dark reddish brown with some pulpy particles at the bottom and a thick layer of light brown head that never dissipates. Aroma is brown sugar, candied figs and spiced bread. The flavor begins with toasted malts and caramel followed by toffee, dates, doughy yeast, raisins and rum. Mouthfeel is full-bodied and silky smooth with medium carbonation. Finish is dry and sugary with a strong alcohol kick at the end. The candied fruit and dark sugar flavors blend nicely with the yeast and the malt.

A- Murky medium brownish red body that pours with thick creamy light tan head. Head eventually fades to 1/2 finger and has perfect retention. Little to no lacing is left behind in the glass because it seems to heavy to stick to the sides. When held up to the light the red in this brew shimmers through its dense fogginess.

S- Licorice, subtle spice (mostly clove), fig, caramel, toffee, alcohol, and hints of cinnamon and dark fruit. Interesting and complex combination that seems to mold well together.

T- The cinnamon and clove fight with sweet plum and caramel malt for dominance upfront. A hint of toffee can be detected also. A big dose of licorice and hops arise for the finish and add to the complexity of the flavor that is already present. Lots of cinnamon lingers along with hints of caramel malt and a blanket of alcohol warmth.

P- Medium carbonation with a medium weight body that is smooth, creamy, soft, and easy to swallow.

O- This is an excellent and complex brew by Ommegang. It has sour, sweet, smooth, and spicy characteristics that blend together very well. The 8.5% is not hidden here-and my 12 oz bottle was plenty for one sitting. I will have this one again-as Ommegang has become one of my favorite breweries. I still have a bomber 3 Philosophers left in my fridge and I am looking forward to trying it. Then I shall move on to Chocolate Indulgence.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-19-2007 17:29:22
The foam head really exploded once I  poured it into a glass, so beware. The aroma is fruity and has notes of honey and chocolate. The taste is somewhat heavy, but not too overpowering.
Big rich head with dark bronze/amber color. Fruity nose with a bit of sweetness that dries out on the back of your tongue. Rich on the pallet with a smooth aftertaste. A very nice beer.

Pretty good. This was my first abbey dubbel. If this is what abbey dubbels typically taste like then Id say Im much more of a fan of the abbey tripel. Looked great. The aroma threw me off a little bit. Smelled like sour fruits. The taste was pretty good though. Flavors of fruits and caramel. Slightly nutty. The silky smooth texture and moderately high amount of carbonation made for a pretty good mouthfeel. Overall it was a good beer but I probably wouldnt buy it again.

The beer looks great. Its got a big head and a thick dark brown look that definitely appealed to me. Once I smelled this beer, I knew something was wrong. There are certainly some interesting elements to it and I fully believe that there is a good beer lurking within, but to my nose, it smelled like strong stout with a shot of vodka dropped in, like the horror that is a boilermaker.  The taste is really great for the first half second or so, but there isnt even enough time to swallow before the alcohol kicks in. The mouthfeel is fine. Theres good carbonation, and the beer seems well-constructed.  Will re-review in the future.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2012 $6 / 25.4 oz bottle - On re-rate two years later...Would not change my initial rating, but have a different appreciation for this double.  Fruit-forward and yeasty--some fruit cake characteristics.  Dry on finish.  Good value.

I was honestly a little disappointed by this brew, to much weak dubbel and not enough belgian strong, if you will .. . a murky slow poke brown .. lacing was average .. . goes down easy but the flavours dont quite meld together .. . Ill try it on tap, but in the bottle i had, i didnt like it too much ... I am speechless, i literally have nothing to say, i dont know what youre waiting for..
Red pour. Smells of fruits. Sweet and complex taste with raisins, caramel, malts.
Pours a dark amber brown with light lacing and a fine head. Aroma is malty and sweet. Taste is complex and malty with a light hop balance.

Draft at the Haze.  Thick, deep brown-amber color underneath a massive rusty beige head.  Very true to style, displays lots of Belgian nuances.  Yeasty plum and dark fruit tastes, pungent raisin.
