Smooth and sweet at first, a citric bitterness of lemon and grapefruit refreshes in the finish and brings me back for more. Up front are the dark fruits I smelled in her nose with prunes, dried cherries, and raisins being the predominant flavors in my Abbey Ale’s palate. A light layer coats my mouth and lingers long after each quaff. Already well balanced, there isn’t too much change in her overall temperament as she warms. If anything, a bit more malty and rich with the citric hop twang fading a bit further into the finish.

As rich as my Ommegang Abbey Ale sounds, she is actually very well-balanced with just the prefect amount of delicate sweetness which relies on her natural fruit flavors. Not artificially cloying or overpowering. An excellent abbey ale from Ommegang and a good started Belgian ale for those who are curious, but not ready for some of the darker richer Belgians such as a dubbel or a quadrupel.

Poured clear burgundy in color with a bubbly light brown head.  Aromas of caramel malts, alcohol and black cherries.  Complex flavor - mostly honey, black cherries, maybe a little chocolate, more alcohol than I prefer.  Finish is slightly dry.

Reddish brown body with a good sized light brown head.  Fruit, spice, malts and some alcohol in the aroma.  Complex flavor.  Starts off sweet  and then you taste the spice and malts followed by a lighly astringent warming alcohol finish. Pretty well balanced.

Pours a really tan head and a dark reddish brown body. Strong fruity aroma with some burnt sugar thrown into the mix. Heavy thick and dark fruit taste. Has some notes of oak and there are a bunch of subtle hops. Spices and malts abound. The palate is a little syrupy and there is a sweet sugary finish, but not excessively so. Taste sticks to your mouth afterward. This was a really tasty dubbel.
750ml bottle purchased at Total Wine Pembroke Pines, FL for $4.99 Very good.
Pours Mahagonny - cherry aroma - hits with some carbonation - good alcohol.

Pours a very deep maroon with voluminous head that quickly dissipates, yet never disappears entirely. Current bottle has been aged approximately 9 months since purchase, due to the over-whelming spiciness of this brew fresh. Aroma is still of heavy spice, of dark fruit, belgian funk, as well as faint cherry tartness and licorice. Taste is very deep and much more well-balanced than when fresh. The effervescent carbonation really helps to scrub the palate from the heavy dubbel taste, which makes it even more satisfying. This time around was much better than previous experiences. For people who are not fond of heavy spicing, I would definitely recommend aging it awhile to let some of that drop out.

Pours a deep red with thin beige head.  Aroma of cherries and yeast, almost smells like a cognac.  Malt and fruit to start, finishes with a flat kind of sourness which sticks around.  Medium carbonation, leaves a bit of stickiness to it.  Solid beer

The aroam is dark fruits, yeasty, slight alcohol.  Very pleasing.  Very attractive amber/chestnut color as well, persistent white head.  The flavor is malty, fruity sweetness, caramel.  A little spicyness is thrown in as well.  Strong carbonation.  The finish is clean, sweetness with a some spicyness on the palate.  Excellent beer.
From bottle.  Pours reddish brown with huge tan head.  Aromas of yeast, honey and spice.  Complex flavours of hops, spice and toffee with long finish.  This bottle was cave aged.

Opaque deep ruddy brown pour with a layer of a tan head that lingers and leaves a veil all the way down the glass as it recedes. Really a beautiful thing. The nose is dried fruits, some sugars and a hint of funk. The flavor has those influences that blend nicely, with the addition of cocoa like a chocolate covered cherry and a touch of licorice. Very enjoyable.

Malt and brett notes dominate smell and taste.  Layers of malt and cherries in this rich and dark brew.  The yeast layer was packed  down into a brick like layer in the bottom of the bottle (worth mentioning).  Great carb with a bubbly sour finish.  Was really surprised this came out of NY and upon reading the bottle, it didn’t, it came from Belgium, which sounds right.  A great dubble but slightly too sweet overall.  A great brew.

Brown bottle, 12 ounces, purchased at Beers of the world (Rochester), via Karl Probst on Elvis’s death 2008, savoured on Sepetember 24 2008; eye: copper, clear, average effervescence, voluminous beige head that falls and turns into a tiny ring; no lacing; nose: molasses, candied fruits, liquorice, alcohol, light smoke, malt; mouth: molasses, candied fruits, alcohol warmth, malt remains present throughout the sip, spices, hops makes a surprise appearance just prior to the finale, juniper, velvety finale in caramel malt with a good presence of molasses and juniper, medium-full body, lightly sweet and bitter, creamy, foamy; overall: quite likable

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 12 onces, achetée chez Beers of the world (Rochester), via Karl Probst	à la mort d’Elvis 2008, savourée le 24 septembre 2008; œil : cuivrée, claire, effervescence moyenne, mousse beige abondante qui tombe et se transforme en un petit anneau, pas de dentelle; nez : mélasse, fruits confits, réglisse, alcool, léger fumé, malt; bouche : mélasse, fruits confits, chaleur d’alcool, malt demeure toujours présent durant toute la gorgée, épices, houblon fait une apparition surprise juste avant la finale, genièvre, finale velouté en malt caramel avec une bonne présence de mélasse et genièvre, corps moyen-corsé, légèrement sucrée et amère, crémeuse, mousseuse; en résumé : bien aimé
Poured a reddish light brown color with an off white head. Aroma was of sweet candy sugar and some spices. Flavor was really sweet and spicey, very complex for a belgian

Sweetness in the aroma, mild molasses and heavy caramel aroma.  Huge tan head tops this reddish brown ale.  Nutty caramel flavors mingle with dates, black currants, and dark fruits with a spicy finish.  Complex malt flavor bittered just enough for balance.  Clean sweet finish and full mouth feel.  Wonderful beer, a flavor explosion, addictive, nothing bad to say here!

More like a fine wine than a great beer (though equally a great beer) the novelty of my first corked beer is what turned me on and I was impressed.  Pours a dark purple/brown with a great fluffy head.  Aromas of wine with that deep alcohol taste that all beer should have.  Complex flavor that was hard to place but vinous, sweet with a hint of dark chocolate, and velvety on the finish.  Good Americanized Belgian.
Last had at Ommefest.  Just as I remember it being such a great all around beer, great color and aroma.  Plenty of spices and slightly sweeter aromas with nice dry finsh, so good.
Pours opaque golden brown with medium white head. Bannana and carmel yeasty aroma. Dry yeast, tobacco, caramel. Not as much complexity as I have expected.

This beer is so good especially when considering the price...it pours a very attractive red copper color, full tan head with good retention, complicated aroma, a layered and complex taste: fruits, raison, hints of chocolate, spice, smoke; a clean neat finish - if it was slightly smoother with a stronger finish it would have been a perfect score for me

Gorgeous deep, almost opaque, red mahogany color, tan light effervescent head with orange highlights, thin, tiny bubbles, good retention and lacing... aromas of sweet, candied fruits, vinous wine grapes, dark raisins, yeast esters and fresh bread. So smooth! Complex flavors of toffee, floral hops, light and dark fruits, chocolate covered raisins and a long finish that ends on a caramel note - truly a layered beer, as iit warms the ambiance changes and the beer reimagines itself, iImpressive example of the Belgian style being made by an American company and a very satisfying experience.

Dark body with a moderate diminishing head.  Strong, attractive aroma with a fruity sweetness and a hint of malt.  Smells like candy almost.  The nose is deceptively thin with a lot of carbonation, but the flavor comes out after that.  Lots of malt on the flavor, although its not my favorite malt profile.  There are just enough notes of various fruits to make this a rather complex brew; you get a different flavor on each swig.  This is a great beer, although I think they could tone the carbonation down a bit so that the nose is not dominated so much by fizz.  Otherwise, this is a near perfect beer.

Absolutely delicious. Very large tan head, pours hazy brown. Unique aroma, dark and fruity, like licorice and chocolate. Dark fruit flavor comes out in the taste, with a noticeable edge of hops. The alcohol blends in well also, but it’s noticeable. Great dubbel, one of the best I’ve tried.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2008 really, really enjoyed this beer.  I have considered chimay rouge my go to beer if I want a tasty beer that is also easy drinking.  This is my new standard for a dubbel.  I has a much richer colour than the chimay.  I has more of a fruitiness both on the nose and the palate..  Carbonation is quite minimal which gives it a nice mouthfeel.  I could drink this ofter.  Very good beer.

12 oz bottle.  Pours crimson with a nice tan head.  Aromas of dark fruit and tart apple and banana.  Flavors are bready, yeasty, with elements of dark fruit and hops.  Nice flavor, a little weak on the palate, but pretty good stuff.
Pours amber brown with a tan colored head.  Big malty aroma with some yeasty notes as well.  Very malty and delicious.  A fine dubbel.

12 oz. bottle: pours heady with good lacing and a nice light brown color, aroma is of roasted malts and some caramel, flavor is much lighter than an actual Belgian brewed Abbey ale, good clean beer though brewed for "American tastes"

Bottle. Berries, nuts with a slight smoked aroma. Mahogany in colour with a decent off white head. Fruity, red berry flavour. A little spicy with liquorice. Very tasty ale. Bitter and strong liquorice finish. Lovely tasty ale.

12 oz bottle from premier gourmet. pours hazy dark amber with a lovely tan head that is thick and luxurious throughout your drinking experience. the aroma is of dark fruit, pale malts and belgian yeast (loses one point for noticeable alcohol). caramelized rum soaked raisons. the flavours are similar but they are accompanied by a soft comforting mouthfeel that in my mind is perfect for a dubble. my bottle was fresh but a little age on this would make it almost impossible to beat. very good brew that i wish i could purchase regularily.

Bottle, 8.5%. Yeasty, slightly funky aroma. The flavour starts off very malty with some malt syrup, melassis. Ends on a citric note that lifts the beer a bit. Has a little cardboard to it, but it does not matter much.

On tap at Stone 12th, but I’ve tried this many times over the years.  After learning about  red beers, then Chimay red, I stumbled upon this and I like it better than Chimay Red.  My standards are narrower now, but at one time this was one of my favorite beers.  Tasting this after such a long delay, reminds me of why I liked it:  Lots and lots of sweet long boil melanoidins and caramelization.  I see this flavor also in many IPAs and a few English beers.  I like it.  Much better than Ommegedon yuckiness.

Bottle from Plano Beverage in Plano, TX.
Pours an orange/red with beige head. Nice floral ,spicey, malty aroma aroma. Flavor is medium sweet, nice caramel, black licorice notes, spicy hops. Palate is medium mouth feel with champaign like qualities, carbonation wise. Over all, I enjoyed this.

Another solid brew from Ommegang!  Pours a deep amber color with off-white head. Sweet, dark fruit aroma with candy yeast notes,  Complex taste of fruit and candy.  Sweet finish, that lingers for a while.
Gracias casyta desde nyc hasta el salvador. Me gusto porque esta rica rica rica. En realidad esta buena

Tasted somewhere along my trip through the States.
Brown colored brew. Sweet chocolate, brown sugary aroma. Flavor is fruity and yeasty, sweet malts and somewhat dry.

Very nice in appearance with a full tan head and the romantic reddish /brown color. Traditional smell of Dubbel including, caramel, malt and sweet candy. Complex enough to complement the yeast strains. Very well done.
caramel, coffee, herbs, earthy, brown, cloudy, frothy, tan foam, medium sweetness, chocolate & caramel flavorsfull body, soft carbonation, smooth palate.

Murky brown with a thick tan head.Smells like rasins, spices, and alcohol. Very sweet and not very strong.Heavy on the sweet dark fruits and alcohol in the beginning. Has a slightly bitter and warm alcohol finish.Kind of slick in the mouth with high carbonation.Overall it is a gteat beer.
Murky brown with a bubbly tan head. The lacing slid down the glass quickly. Smells like sticky, sweet molasses/brown sugar/toffee and alcohol. Somewhat bitter finish, but sweetness prevails.

Bottle shared by SWOLF3, aka Bossman! Thanks wolf! Poured a brown color, decent head. Aroma of fruits. Flavor was a spicy fruity taste. Texture was easy to drink, light carbonation. Sweet taste overall. Good brew that I would buy. Thanks again wolf!

LET THIS ONE WARM UP. Refrigerator temperature is much much too cold for this creation.

A bit too carbonated for my personal taste, but that may have been partially due to too cold a temperature.  Nice exhuberant head which rapidly deflates, minimal lacing, pleasant color, nice rich malty nose with great malt in the mouth. Sweet with multiple layers of flavor. Good stuff!!!

Wow!  I wish I’d tried this one much sooner.  Very complex.  Not for beginners, but, a beginner will love this.  A dark beauty with head.  Fresh fruit smells.  Taste of fresh goodness with a lot of love, smooth and rich and lite bitterness.  This is what Tears For Fears would taste like if TFF was a beer.
Plain and simple, I’m Head Over Heals about this one and I have to Shout!

Pours a nice amber color with a great big off-white head that quickly disappears.  Aroma is roast malt and caramel.

Flavor is more of the same.  A little on the sweet side with some nice toffee undertones.  Perfectly decent beer.

Amber pour with sizeable cream head.  Roast malts and nuts, some toffee and slight hints of fruit.  A little sweet but the lasting carbonation evens it out a little.  Slightly sticky, but a pretty clean finish.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: pours a bownish red with a nice foamy "Fluffy" off white head. a sweet start with a bit of a bitter ending on the plalate. sorta stale aroma

12 oz. bottle.  Pour was nice as expected, 2 fingers of caramel cream head, deep dark red, almost black in some light, some lacing,  head stays for the most part.  Aroma overall is refreshing, not overpowering, strawberry shortcake with toffee bread, sweet caramel hard candy, maybe I’m a little nuts with that description but it was that good. Mouthfeel is pretty close to perfect as well, creamy and fluffy, in the middle it feels like almost nothing is in my mouth , then there is a minor bite right at the end.  Sadly, the actual flavor is the weakest experience of this beer if you can say that, very sweet, malt dominated flavor, caramel toasted marshmallow maintains throughout.  This beer was fantastic, though just maybe too onesided on the sweet side for me, but still... good stuff.
(Bottle).  Aroma of spices, slightly medicinal.  Pours dark reddish brown.  Medium head.  Flavor sweet, with orange.  Smooth through the finish.  Pleasant enough, but not overly impressive.

I’d call the color mahogany/reddish. Brownish head. Nose is woody and spicy. Feels great on the tongue. Taste is complex, with hints of spiciness and fruit but well balanced with the malts. I really like this beer.

*******MY 100TH*******
Bottle listed as 1pt 9.4 ounces-  poured out a brilliant amber, clear with a giant cola-colored head.  The head itself was incredibly bitter.  The aroma was mildly fruity and sweet.  The taste was rich with hints of malt, yeast and citrus.  Palate was excellent, very smooth.  Not bad at all.
12oz 2k7 bottle.  Poured dark brown with a huge brown head.  Dissipated very quickly.  Great beer!
2k7 bottle. Pours a perfect dark brown with a huge but dissipational head. Aroma is caramel raisin and yeast, taste is similar w/malts and a nicely accentuated bit of hops.  Well regarded.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a ruby red, with a pillowy head.  The aroma is of pure sweetness and fruits.  It has a full mouthfeel, a well balanced flavor profile of fruits, caramel and some spice, and has a clean dry finish.  Another quality ale from Ommegang.

Very nice appearance deep caramel red color nice tan head very good retention. Strong alchohol presence rich fruity tones good caramel and toffee aroma, some hints of chocolate malt in the roastiness. Fruity finish definitely dates, figs maybe some plum did not pick up the anise that others seem to have. Very nice belgian style Ommegang is good at what they do for sure. Making a trip to central NY this fall plan to take a tour. If you like Belgians you’ll appreciate this one.
Bottle 2007. Pours amber with a big brownish head.Aroma is fruity. Flavour is fresh and fruity with sweet toffee, ryebread and some oak.

Pours a nice burgundy cloudy color with a light brown head.  Mild aroma of sweetness and hints of berries.  Creamy texture with sweet flavor.  Fruity with rich maltiness.  Notable alcohol presence.  Tasty dubbel.
Enjoy this beer alot, had a very good taste, very enjoyable, highly recommend trying this out, split it between 2 other friends, so about 1 glass per person, good amount of alchohol.
Bottle Pours out a dark copper topped with a nice off white head. Aroma of pit fruit all over this one. Tast more of the sweet fruit. Along with some yeast.

Pours a deep caramel color with a full head.  Smells of dark fruit, perhaps plum and has a strong licorice taste.  Been a while since I have had this style and remember why I enjoy it.  Chewy feel and a nice finish.

750ml bottle from BevMo Mission Valley.  Pours dark brown with a slight ruby hue.  A big beige head with good carbonation left great lacing.  Tons of sweetened dark fruits on the nose with some Belgian yeast and light hops.  A fairly sweet finish with (again) some Belgian yeast, another great one from Ommegang.

750 mL bottle from Whole Foods Charlottesville. Reddish brown with a medium frothy head. Very fruity aroma... dates, banana, brown sugar. Anise comes through strongly in the taste, with some malty sweetness and fruitiness. Interesting, but this anise is a bit too strong for my taste.

This is complex.  Its fruity, but I could not quite pin down the fruit.  Definitely some fig, date, plum kind of stuff going on, but I could swear I sensed some pear.  Nice finish with a little fig aftertaste, but not sweet. Their is no discernible alcohol flavor in this higher gravity brew.

Bottle.  Dark copper pour with generous pillowy off-white head.  Very sweet smell- malt, caramel, burnt sugar, cotton candy, and dates.  A hint of sour wood on the nose, and also sometimes metallic notes.  I swear this beer alternated between a few different distinct smells every third time I sniffed it, and occasionally the smell hit me as unpleasant.  Similar on the palate.  Sometimes it hit right, but sometimes it just felt too sweet or metallic.  Haven’t had a double in awhile, and I know they’re not typically very yeasty, but I just kept wanting something to funk it up just a bit.  A very nice beer, though.
a swirling deep red pour with a head so light it was like peaks of marshmellow. sweet anise and dried dates smell. malty smooth taste, great with the level of abv. long finish
This is an interesting beer.  All beer, but fininshes like a dry red wine. Goes very well with a Rhubarb crisp!

Reddish-brown and hazy. Frothy tan head. Prominent vinous nose of plums, malt, rye bread and licorice. Notes of chocolate, raisens, caramel and lights you right up too. Lingering finish that dances on the tongue. Daddy wuvs you, Abbey Ale.

This beer pours a deep red-brown with ample head that leaves behind fine belgian lace.  The aroma is fruity and malty.  I find dark fruits in the aroma along the lines of cherries and plums.  The flavor is very similar with no noticeable alcohol, which is surprising. The body is medium with the carbonation.  Ive never been disappointed by Ommegang.

Bottle. Huge dense light tan head. Very big nose filled with fruity sweet doughiness. Taste is thick, dark sweet like over ripe plum or fig. Malty with a hint of tannins at the end and clean lingering bitter finish. not session beer imo, but a good after dinner sipping beer.
Large pillowy and lasting head with a red-amber pour.  Rich fruit and dark fruit notes finish with a little alcohol.  Very nice from an American brewery.

Bottle, corkd and caged. Lots of people have been to Europe, and have attempted to bring the quality and honesty, back to the states. Ommegang scores big with a photographic tongue! A true delight from New York. Enjoy reasonably kids!

Huge 4-finger almond-hued head tops a slightly-hazed burgundy pour... nice retention that leaves a thick cap all the way down the glass.  Yeasty dough and fruity notes to the nose.  Nice start of sweet fruits and Candi Sugar, an "ester-take" on heavy malts.  This leads to a yeasty bread mid-palate, with a touch of alcohol following a lightly bitter finish.  Mingling around are more notes of complexity... some wooden earth, unripened bananas (from many different layers of yeast).  Soft carbonation levels and a medium (to medium-light) embodiment tend toward an oily mouthfeel.  Nice abby dubbel, and a classic example of the style.  Would be nice paired with food.  This only gets better as it warms... nice and rounder, with lots going on; livelier carbonation levels provide more character at slightly warmer temperatures.  (Honestly, this isnt my first "style" of choice, but its an appreciated offering; a very good brew, staying true to the Trappist style.)  Good stuff.  On the next bottle, Ill let it sit for a bit before partaking.
Outstanding take on a Trappist...er...Abbey style beer.  Deep, dark fruit tones underpin the medium-bodied malt flavor.  Finish is alcohol and yeast.  Tremendously enjoyable.
A huge light brown head that disappeared quickly. Very sweet and thick with lots of yeast floating in the glass. Toffee and malt with a little bite. Smooth lingering finish.
Here is another great abby.  I was surprised at how much I liked it.  Nice sour yeasty and fruity scent hints at the flavor to come.  Well balanced witha tinge of alcohol and a lont finish.

Nice beer that is a bit yeasty with subdued apple sour fruitiness. I didnt find much of the sugars like everyone else did, but that could be because my bottle was a 12oz and not a 75cl? Still a nice beer that tastes like boozy apple and grape skins with lots of spices.
750ml bottle served in a trappist glass. Pours deep garnet-brown with a tan head. Smells sweet and spicy. Taste is candi sugar, &cinnamon. Finishes with a touch of brett funkiness. Very good.

Talk about a bang for the buck.  I got this beer in a 750 mL bottle and only paid $5.  Great abbey that has notes of chocolate, coffee and a finish of sweet honey.  Absolutely delicious.  I would recommend it to anyone.

(Bottle at Pikkulintu on 2008-06-04) Deep red wine colour. Small white head. Yeasty and bit sour nose. Lots of carbonation in full and dry palate. Chocolate, bitterness, fruitiness, liquorice and malts in taste.

Dark copper/maroon, cloudy and opaque with a generaous head that had excellent retention and nice lacing. Malts and dark fruits evident on the nose, as well as some brown sugar. Flavors of dark fruits - figs and cherries, some cloves and spices, and caramelized sugar, like "grandmas candy dish". Very soft on the palate, lively carbonation, and a smooth, dry finish.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark reddish brown color with a small brown head.  Strong fruit aroma plums, raisins, apples.  Alot of malt flavors in the taste, mildly toasted chocolate and caramel.  A nice complex beer.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 A dark red-brown beer with a small whitish head that doesnt stick around. Aroma is dark fruit and toasty malt notes. The flavor is dominated by roast barley, with some hints of oak and prune, fig, raisin and sweetness. Perhaps some toffee and molasses. Very carbonated mouthfeel.

The beer pours a hazy red brown color with a fine lightly brown head. The nose is a sweet mix of berries, yeast oak and malts. The taste is a sweetness mixed with alcohol dark fruits, wood, sweet berries. The mouth feel is very prickly due to the high carbonation the finish is a thick feeling in the sides of the mouth mixed with sweetness that is long-lasting.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2008 Thanks to jrob_21 for this 750. Pours a cloudy dark brown with a thick beige head. The aroma was fruit, alcohol, metallic and yeast notes. The taste was dominated by a nice fruity body with a surprisingly bitter aspect. There is a ton of yeast and some toffee, malts. Quite good, a brewery I really enjoy.

Bottle. 75cl. Clear medium brown color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light beige head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy malty, roasted, caramel, light to moderate yeasty, brown sugar, light alcohol. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is light alcoholic. (180408)

Pours a brownish amber with a big fluffy head. Aroma of dried fruits, bananas, alcohol, malt, brown sugar, and yeast. Taste is similar, fruits, malt, brown sugar. Its a little lighter in taste than i expected, but still excellent.

Love getting around to beers Ive had quite a few times but not gotten my lazy ass to rate. Light brown w/ large head. Aroma of dark fruit and belgian yeast. Textbook taste for a dubbel. Dark fruit, light caramel sweetness and sharp belgian yeast with a slightly dry and lighly bitter finish. Love it. One of the best values around for a 750ml. Fantastic and versatile beer for pairing with food.
Pours red with a thick, fine-foamed head.  Aroma of raisins, citrus, alcohol.  It isnt as forward on the flavor as I like in a Dubbel.  The alcohol flavor is most prominent.  Good, but not great.

wonderful reproduction of an abbey dubbel.  malt clobbers the hops with subdued raisins and a thick dark red apperance. aroma is surprisingly stifled despite its hefty color.  the typical dubbel flavors are present but dulled compared to others in the style. still, this is far from falling short -- booze factor is minimum on the palate but maximum on the brain, immediate relaxation takes places after a few swallows.  in the end, ill stick with a pater 8 or something similiar, but for the price this cant be beat. another very strong showing for ommegang!

Pours red mahogany with a rich white head. Aroma of banana, raisins, slight citrus, and alcohol. Flavor is strong malts with fruit and alcohol. The palate reflects more alcohol. The beer is nicely balanced despite strong alcohol presence.
Deep red pour, with a solid head. Pretty sweet, fruit aroma. Flavor is very nice - plums, toffee, vanilla, spice, licorice. Decent carbonation, pretty full bodied, solid mouthfeel. Good beer.

Reddish brown in color with an off-white foamy head. Sweet fruit aroma. Malty sweet taste with dark fruit (cherry and plum) and yeast, ending with some sourness, spice, and bitter hops. Nice carbonation and medium mouthfeel. This has always been a very sloid beer over the years.
Red brown coloured. Fruitiness and maybe some soap in the nose. Average carbonation. Mild hoppiness. A little bit sourness in the end. Not too sweet.

Bottled. Tasting @ Kolding Bryglaug. Lovely, very fruity aroma with dark fruits, toffee ,alts, plums. Hazy, dark red coloured with a beige head. Taste is sweet, has toffee maltiness, rye, plums and yeast. Quite complex Dry finish. Really nice.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2008 First rating(75 cl bottle from Systembolaget)On May 24, 2008Dark red color, tan head. Sweet licorice scent, also toffee and phenoles. Phenolci sweet taste. Spritzy mouthfeel, low bitterness.7/4/7/3/13=3.4Second rating(Bottle at Café 3 Små Rum)On June 13, 2008Clear copper color, tan head. Sweet, spicy, lactic and alcohol scent. Sweet, spicy, phenolic and yeasty taste. Sweet licorice aftertaste. Moussy mouthfeel, low bitterness.6/4/6/3/12=3.1

Big bottle shared w/ Simon.  This was a lot better than expected.  This has been cellared for at least 8 months...forgot about this guy.  Nose was a soothing mix of brown sugars, belgian yeast, dark senuous malts, sweet fruits.  Flavor was much the same with a delicate mouthfeel, smooth and soft on the palate.  This almost sheds some similarity to a mini-Rochefort 10 - mouthfeel and flavors and on par...just a smaller scale.  With that said - I dug this.  Nothing mind blowing, but just a solid beer and one I would welcome revisiting.

750ml Bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki)- Brown in colour with some red tinges. Fruity aroma with some plums and a hint of cherry cake along with some raisins.  The taste is rather fruity with raisins, cherry cake and a bit of caramel featuring. Fairly nice but not overly impressive.

I really really liked this beer. Bottle from Capitol Convenience. Pours dark red-brown, slightly cloudy and tea-like. Not much head to speak of. Beautiful bouquet of cherries, honey, floral notes, and bread. Taste is awesome, with cherry notes, caramel, candy, a bit of yeastiness, calm hop character and smooth malt complexion.  So smooth, tasty, sweet, but not overdone. Complex. This is one of my new favorites.
Bottle @ thewolf-and-his-flock-of-sheep tasting session. Red color, thick off-white head. Aroma of soft fruit, oak chips. Dry taste, slight sour, bit sweet, oak wood. Quite nice.

Bottle. Pours a haze red-brown colour with a nice big beige head leaving a good lacing. Sweet aroma of dark fruits, caramel and some spice. Great mouthfeel. The flavour is sweet with well toasted malt, dried raisins and prunes, spices, toasted malt, bitter hops and yeast. Tasty brew indeed!

750 ml bottle. cloudy brown, fluffy head. aroma of fruits. honey at first sip, with some dryness at the finish. i keep going back to the aroma as it warms a little, finding something different, like a little spice thats comes out in the taste too.

750 ml. bottle. Poured into a trappist glass. Rich mahogany pour, beige head that didnt last too long. Aroma is fruity/sweet and floral. A bit of sugar up front, raisins, plum, some citrus but not too hoppy-very nice balance. Medium body, a bit fizzy. Despite the ABV and style, I found the alcohol character to be burried. Very good beer.
cloudy brown beer with a lasting tan head. Aroma has caramel alongside prunes and cherries. Dry and earthy flavour, some caramel.

Bottle:  Poured a dark brown color with a nice amount of head.  The aroma was sweet caramel malts with a tiny bit of spice.  The flavor was smooth and malty with just a bit of bitterness and tartness.  Overall, this was an excellent beer from on of my favorite breweries.

750ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki, Bitter and Sour 2008)
Dark brown, very tight wispy head. Yeasty blue cheese aroma. Quite lively in the mouth. Full-bodied, but not as full as I would hope and expect from a dubbel, which it claims to be. On swallowing it fills out a little. Decent grainy taste, but spoilt by slightly too prominent alcohol. A very good simulacrum of Belgian brews, but not a patch on their best.

Bottle @ thewolfs pre-festival tasting, Kolding.
[thank you, drmatt]
Pours deep red with a giant frothy/creamy beige-brown head. Aroma has loads of caramel and dried, ripe fruits. Some light yeasty tartness with toffee and dry grassy hops. Lovely creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is wonderful, light tart, very dry, some plums and toffee. Really nice brew.

Bottle pours a dark reddish brown with a thin tan head.  Mild aroma is mostly yeast and dried fruits.  Lots of different flavors going on here...malt, yeast, spices, brown sugar, dried fruit, and even caramel.   Very carbonated mouthfeel.  Nice aftertaste with a slight bitterness.

3/26/08 notes:  12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a two finger tan head.  Smell of soft malts, butterscotch, and some spices.  Flavor is a robust combination of coriander, clove, some orange peel and a smooth blend of hops and malts.  What really impresses me about this beer is its combination of well-blended spices and a very tasty mildly sweet hoppy finish.  The carbonation is a little on the fizzy side, I wonder if this might mellow with age.  Overall, I am a huge fan of this brew, and it is one of Ommegangs top offerings.
Amber color with a slight head. Earthy, yeasty candi sugar smell. Rich, full bodied flavors mirror the aroma with spicy yeast, toasted earthy malt with a sugar honey sweetness. Not too bad.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle from Liquor Barn in Redding, CA.  Poured dark with malt and dark fruit nose.  I felt that the flavors overpowered this brew, but it may have been too cold as it smoothed as it warmed.  Drink at 55.

Wicked tastey brew. Pours a deep dark brown colour with a full sized head. fairly sweet and heavily carbonated. Prevalent nutty character, milk chocolate, caramel, and raisin on the palate. Aroma is fruity, ginger-bread cookies, cinnamon and brown sugar on the nose.
Bottle. Nice head with excellent duration. Color is brown. Aroma and taste are rich with fruits, malt and spices.

bottle,deep, reddish purple pour with a HUGE offwhite head. Very fruity bouquet. Deep rich taste of fruit and caramel, slight alcohol aftertaste which makes sense for the ABV. Very good would buy again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: 750 mL bottle. Pours dark rust color with large beige head. The aroma is fruity, with banana, prune, tamarind, and some spicy clove hints. The flavor is sweet dark fruits with a sharp yeasty spiciness. The finish is dull chocolate, alcohol, and a little bit of licorice. Pretty easy to drink, even if a little bit uninspired.

Bottle from the Liquor Barn in Redding, CA. Poured a very dark amber and smelled of toffee and carmel. This is a full-bodied brew with hints of carmel . The rich flavors came out even more and the beer warmed up a little. Great brew.

[bottle] Poured at a blind tasting at the Cellars. Yeasty, funky aroma. Pours amber gold with a large tan head. Flavor is brown sugar, caramel, dark fruits, yeast, and a pleasant tartness that creeps in. Pretty good stuff.

Bomber on 5/5//2008. Ruby brown pour with a foamy medium head settling to a thin ring in a few minutes. Fruity aroma of raisins and plums over a backdrop of caramel and spice. Medium/full body with very lively effervescence, leaving the palate fairly clean. Maltiness dominates  the flavor, providing a sweet backbone, but substantial spicy bitterness comes on quickly for a welcome, if surprising, dry finish.

Pours a dark brown with a solid head. Pretty tastey but i find it a bit less complex than three philosophers.  A generally solid brew that is very drinkable.  I will likely buy another bottle of this at some point
I could drink this stuff forever. Some malt, but not as much as some. Im tasting hops and caramel. Lots of alcohol, but in a good way. Nice fluffy head and a great brown color. WONDERFUL!
Nice Strong Ale.  Pours dark, with a lot of thick head.  Strong aroma of honey and caramel.  A thicker beer, but very delicious and complex.  A good beer for after dinner.

The commercial description here is pretty dead-on. Dark red-brown with a thick head. Fruity aroma, I think that citrus dominates here; lime and lemon, with a nice sweetness (perhaps apricot?) to balance it out. Flavor is caramely and buttery with more fruit. Aftertaste is pleasant and hardly bitter at all. One of the best beers I have had in a while.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2008 More malt than I am used too in a belgium, but it is nice. Smokey. Its like the cheeze and cracker together. Well done. Nice Smooth aftertaste. Not bitter and not too sweet..  Smooth ...Im enjoying this experience...writing as I drink... hmmm...nutty and even..Its like  dark chocolate. Not too sweet ,not too nutty...all the tastes are in the right place.

Im not a huge fan of the dubbel, but for some reason I keep coming back to it. Perhaps I just respect the style. Well, the Ommegang offering is as good as anything else Ive had (Chimay, Allagash, Rochefort). I cant find any fault with it. For the price ($5.99 in MA), if I was a dubbel fanatic Id come back to this again.

750ml bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Florida). Pours a dark chocolate brown with a thick and frothy tan head. Aroma: some sweetness, caramel and honey laced with an earthy overtone, grass and straw. Faint hints of spices. Taste is much of the same: earthy, malty with a slight sweetness. Some hints of honey and caramel, but an earthy overtone throughout.

Bottle... Poured a cloudy ruby with a great light brown head.  Aroma of spices and figs.  Roasted malt lend way to raisins or prune-like flavors.  Alcohol was hardly present in the flavors making it very easy to drink.  Hops are subtle but create a warming balance.

Date and raisin nose. Clear ochre, with a thick tan head. Flavor is dark roasted malt, dates, and smoke. Finishes with a nice smoke and subtle charred bell pepper. Not my favorite, but distinctive. Would pair well with any cheese.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2008 Burnt molasses with some roasted nuts.  Deep reddish amber with a massive frothy head that lasted forever.  Roasted sweetness, with some sourness, not much hop bitterness. Some slight spiciness, mild complexity, a little licorice present.  Was a  bit boozy, but gets more well-rounded as it warms up. Expected a little more, but still tasty.

12oz bottle. pours hazy brown and with  copious head. Intense mouth-feel; carbonation is very present, but doesnt detract from the beers enjoyment. Many layers of flavor, ranging from toffee to cherries, and finishing with a not too strong alcohol presence. Personally, this is one of my favorite beers that I have tasted. Ill be sure to pick up another, next time!

These Yankees have been paying attention.  Big burgundian brew with all the bells and whistles.  Rich, ruby pour.  Nose of cocoa, cinnamon, dried fruit, alcohol.  More balanced than expected on the palate with just enough hops to prevent a cloying effect.  Chocolate-covered cherries, licorice, and spice on a warm alcohol finish.  Delicious.  May I have another?
Pours a bit hazy, which I suspect is acceptable for the style. Notes of toffee and possibly banana. Finish is mildly bitter and dry. An excellent beer, but could stand a little less carbonation.
Bottle pours a red / brown. Huge fluffy cloud like head. Good toffee flavor, but I was expecting a bit more something from this. Overall not bad, but not Ommegangs best.
Cloudy brown with medium off-white head.  Aroma of licorice, caramel and fruit.  Taste is sweet  caramel, licorice, fruit and overly malty.  Mild sourness on the finish but overall a quality brew.

75 cL bottle. Pours hazy amber/deep orange to brown with a huge light tan head. Light spiced, mild fruity and yeasty aroma. Flavour is sweet fruity with a light caramel and mild yeasty note following. Nicely spiced to provide some dryness and light acidic touch to the otherwise rather sweet dubbel brew. Light estery finish. Goes fantastic with barbequed chicken and turkish potatoes.

Pours deep, murky mahogany. Nose deeply sweet, plums, sugars, port, and grapes. Flavor is nicely sweet, some molasses and plums, lots of candy sugar. Hints of nuts and mild toasty bitterness, pleasingly fruity and rich, lovely kiss of chocolate at the end. Full and chewy, nice mouthfeel.  Nice easy beer for the beginner.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: An excellent abbey ale from an outstanding brewery. It pours a dark burgundy color with a thick white head. The body is dark and hazy, full of wonderful flavor and aromas. The aroma is filled with caramel malts, fruit and spice, as well as an alcohol kick in the nose. The palate is full and the alcohol has a nice warming quality to it. Favors of sweet caramel, dried dark cherries, prune, and yeast dance on the tongue. These favors mingle for a time and finish slowly. Ommegang is grate as it is and could be even better with cellaring.
Smagt 17/4 2008 hjemme. Den lever op til forventningerne kraftige aroma og blide brus minder den i stil om chimays

A hazy deep red-brown beer with a nice brown head. The aroma is sweet with primary notes of berries, but also lighter notes of yeast and wood. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of yeast, but also notes of wood, prunes, and berries, as well as hints of the alcohol. It is very sparkling on the tongue due to the carbonation, and it ends of with a slight alcohol burn.
Last of several beers of the night... i claimed it was the best but all i wrote was "Robust taste, Balance, Uber".  So a rerate might need to happen.
Bottle. Hazy red with large white head. Sweet, fruit, malty aroma. Well balanced. Short aftertaste.
I liked this beer.  A reddish beer with a nice aroma.  Has a long lasting head on it.
pours brownish red, big fuzzy beige head.  dark fruit aroma.  begins sweet and fruity, gets a little dry and alcoholic in the finish which is unpleasant

beer pours a reddish mahogany with visible carbonation,  a beautiful frothy head and nice lacing. aroma of figs, raisins, prunes, malt, traces of alcohol- very smooth upon first sniff. gorgeous flavor- nice mouthfeel, tastes similar to aroma, absolutely delicious. my favorite style, and i really love this beer.

Deep amber color topped with a thick long lasting tan head. Roasted malt aroma, with hints of fruits mixed in. Taste is burned, blackened, roasted malts, and a little sweet cherry flavor then on to a candy like tangy finish. Full bodied and rich. 8.5% alcohol content does generate a rush of alcohol and a tart, somewhat burned mouthfeel. A very solid brew.

Bottle.  Hazy medium brown ale with dense tan head.  Definitely some fruit and clove aroma.  Flavor is full with and slightly sweet.  Chocolate notes, not very sour at all.  Dry finish.  Better than most Belgian dubbels Ive tried.

My first impression was the smell of garbage, I believe the one i picked out may have been contaminated in the bottling process but I drank it anyway. It poured a dark copper color with a thick head that dissapated slowly. Slightly fruity flavor, with hints of spice and prunes?.  The alcohol was a little too prevalant in this one. A sipper

Bottled. Poured clear, brown, with a foamy tan head, which left a decent amount of lace on the glass. Nose was raisins, molasses, plum, and brown bread. Flavor was very complex with hints of raisins, cherries, wood, candy sugar and alcohol and vinous tones. Mouthfeel was medium and nicely carbonated. A dry finish without being astringent with a warm alcohol undertone.

Dark reddish brown color with a medium, beige head. Aroma is mostly carmel and sweet. Flavor is toffee and licorice, caramel, fresh bread, tobacco leaves, figs and plantains. Finish is tobacco and dry chocolate.

spicy and nutty aroma as it pours creating a lite lacy head. dark red color. malty and thick spread across the palette. some figgyness and nuttiness strong on the caramel overtones. alcohol is evenly balanced whatever temperature it is. all in all a good abbey style ale.

Very enjoyable Belgian strong ale. Similar in feel and scope to the Lost Abbey 10 Commandments with less raisin notes. But fine malt forward balance without overemphasizing the sweetness. Hint of spice on the finish. Fruit is darker with more depth and less tang. Prune or dark rum flavor finish. Enjoyable and expertly made. Still missing that spark that a Chimay Blue seems to retain.
Great head retention/pour.  Very well balanced between malts, yeast and aromatic fruits.  The taste belies the color a bit, could be stronger.
Dark red-brown pour with good sized head that has great lacing. Nose is darker pitted fruits, nuts, yeast with a sweetness as well. Flavor is caramel, cherry, spice and some raisins.

Poured into a Chimay goblet.  Dark red color with a dense tan head that leaves good lacing.  Aroma is fruity with cherry and prune.  Flavor is much the same, kind of like Three Philosophers junior.  Cherry and dark fruits make up the esters while yeast creates a doughy underpinning.  Malt is sweet and chewy.  Dry finish to a rich palate.  Average drinkability.
Hazelnutty earthy flavors, candi sugar, yeast, prunes; reddish copper color; a little on the boozy side; not really for me.
Dark redish brown with a medium off-white head. Sweet malty tones with some fruit.Sweet fruits, roasted with hints of pices. Full body with a dry finish.
Dark and musky.  Looks can be deceiving to the tongue.  A great start, peak, and finish.  Deep aroma and subtle vapors.

Bottle. Labeled as Abbey Ale. Large light brown creamy head that mostly lasted. Hazy amber  brown color. Good display of lacework. Thick and complex aroma of yeast, fruit, toffee, toasted malt, nutty, dried fruit, spice. Full bodied with an average carbonation and thick light alcoholic texture. Moderated sweet flavor with hint of acidic and bitterness. Sweet toffee lingering finish. Quit nice.
I have enjoyed this beer a few times in the past.  Sweetness is nice and not overpowering.  It pours a dark amber color with a nice head.  This beer would be perfect after visiting the Hall of Fame!

THOUGHTS: Had this a few time, but forgot I never rated it. This small bottle of it didnt seem as good as the big bottles Ive had in the past, but It was still pretty good, so I dont think it was skunked but something was off.
TECHNICAL: Small bottle. Poured a medium, reddish brown with a small, off-white head that mostly diminished but left fair lacing. The aroma was moderate to heavy caramel malt with red wine, brown sugar, spices and slight fruitiness from dark fruit and maybe just a note of skunk that usually isnt there. The initial flavor was moderately to heavily sweet and sour, while the finish was havily sweet, lightly acidic and bitter and sour with and average duration. The flavor was caramel malt and some fruitiness (apple and cherry) and a little spiciness with some honey and even a little coffee and cola. The medium body was syrupy with fizzy carbonation.
Deep red color with a creamy tan head. Aroma is caramel and malt. Very earthy taste. Nice sweet raisin flavor but i get some kind of unripend fruit flavor that i dont enjoy very much.

Deep copper color with a decent sized cream colored head. Light yeast aromas with brown sugar, raisins and dates. Grapes and raisins in the taste as well as caramel. Slight hop bitterness in the finish.
Amber to red in color.  Smell is sweet, you can smell the alcohol, malts, and some fruits.  Medium body.  Taste is sweet with some fruitness.  Dry finish.

Pours a dark reddish-brown color with a big fizzy tan head and good lacing.  Sweet aroma of dark cherries, yeast, and spicy maltiness.  Flavor is similar, sweet with dark fruits and malt.  Nice dry finish.  This is a very solid brew, but I didnt enjoy it as much as some of the other Belgian Ales I have sampled.

12 oz. bottle...Poured a toffee brown mized w/ some shades of molasses. It had a fizzy off white head w/ considerable amount of lacing. Nose of banana, yeast, caramel, and apples. Tastes like raisins, candied dark fruits, a tad of banana, and some malts. Fizzy mouthfeel, w/ a dry sweet finish. Very solid beer...

Bottled. Ruby/brown
Nutty, chewy, sweet fruit .
Fine Belgian style sourish edge. Great beer.

Poured from a 750ml caged and corked bottle and served in a tulip.  This beer poured an attractive mahogany brown with a few ruby highlights and a thick, fizzy head of tan foam.  Excellent retention and a fair amount of slippery lacing.  The aroma of the beer was made up of dates, ripe dark fruit, chocolate, graham cracker, and a bit of bready yeast.  The flavor included notes of dried dark fruits floating on a nice backbone of honey graham cracker maltiness.  Just a touch of warming alcohol shows up as the beer reaches the back of your tongue.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied with a moderate amount of very soft carbonation.  An inviting aroma and a tasty, complex flavor make this a memorable beer everytime.  Very nicely done!
750ml bottle. red-mahagony brown, tastes of sweet malts and some cherry. very good with the roast beef my friend cooked

Pours a deep ruby color with a full lacey head. Spicey sweet aroma. Sweet spiced malty flavor. This is my one of my favorites in the beers Ive sampled. But I havent had the Unibroue Trois Pistoles yet.
Bottle. Picked this up in Asheville, NC. Smell was fruity. Taste was that of a good traditional Belgian ale, but not great. Unibroue Trois Pistoles was much better. Its worth a try though.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown reddish color with an off-white head. Spicy fruity malty and yeasty aroma with hints of dark fruit. Sweet yeasty spicy and slightly alcoholic flavor with dark fruit hints. Has a sweet malty spicy finish with some yeasty hints.

Poured an attractive dark burgundy color with a pillowy white head that hung around a while.  Aroma is quite fruity and sweet with a touch of chocolate.  Flavor is very much the same as the aroma with the taste of dark fruits and a nice dry finish.  Nice beer that I would definitely explore again.
Bottle, 75cl (parts of the label carefully masked for some reason). Fruity, vinous aroma. Taste is dark fruits with notes of yeast.

Its very beautiful, dark, red mahogany with a huge, nice and creamy head. The aroma has sweetness, dark fruits, spice, yeast and alcohol. The flavour is just like the aroma complex and vinous; sweetness, malt, caramel, dark fruits, raisin and figs dominate, alcohol, spice and hints of licorice.

75 cl bottle. Dark amber color, offwhite head. Malty, bready aroma, fruity, pine apple and some trpoical fruit, caramel, mint notes, really fresh. Malty, fruity, caramel flavor, a bit vinous and citric, some lather, some hops. Malty sweetish finish with some alcohol notes.
Has a nice Belgian sour aroma. Nice dark copper appearance. Very malty flavor, backed up with some leather and sour notes. A good beer overall.

Aroma: yummy, wort, julmust, soy, rowan, caramel, some hops, cocoa butter, roasted, sourish, funky yeast. 
Flavour: nice, caramel, berryish sweetness, slightly burnt aftertaste, roasted barley, sourish yeast, very peculiar and VERY Belgian. 
Appearance: red, murcky brown with yellowish, creamy head. Very special appearance indeed. 
Palate: fluffy, soft, lathery.
Hazy dark amber with tiny head. Sweet fruity aroma with yeast, caramel and light roasted malt notes. Sweet yeasty flavor with roasted malt, caramel and overripe fruits. Ends rather sweet.
Bottle. Dark brown pour, decent head. Little lasting carbonation. Still feels slightly rougher than the Belgians, even tasting blind.
Pours dark copper/red with a thick head.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, and teast.  Flavor of toffee and dark fruits. Moderately bitter finish.  Very complex beer.

Poured a deep reddish color with a light tan head. Aromas of sweet dark fruits, figs, licorice. Malt flavor with hints of raisins and cherries ond some metallic taste. Medium body with a creamy texture, lively carbonation and a dry, bitter finish. Not bad.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2008 Poured using a Trappist glass.  A rich dark burgundy pour like port wine with a nice foamy head.  Different mix of aromas that carries into the pallet.  Fruits, smoky caramel toffee and chocolate notes.  Rich and creamy, strong and complex.  There is a bit of alcohol bite throughout.  Nice dry aftertaste nothing really bitter or overly sweet.  Really great strong ale from New York no less.
Bottle. This is awesome. Pours a rich burgundy-brown. Billowy head gives way to a delicate lace. Candi on the nose. I love the complexity. Caramel, spice and a nice carbonation. Gots to have more.

Bottle. Poured into a large snifter. Fruit arouma and a beautiful reddish brown body with a dark tan head. Very complex flavors. The carmel malts seem to dominate and like others have said its a bit to sweet. A little more hop would be good. Not quite in leaque with Rochfort , but not far off either.

Bottle. Dark fruity smell of plum and raisins. Some roasted malt and caramel. Dark malt reminiscent of rye. 
Big body. Sweet. A bit too sweet for my taste. Some bitter astringency, again reminding of rye. Slightly vinous and oaky. Nice. The alcohol comes through and finishes slightly bitter. 

I like the sour and oaky notes, but it is slightly bitter from hops, grains and yeast, and a bit too sweet in the finish.

Pours a beautiful deep mahogany.  Two finger white creamy head with great lacing and lasting power.  Aroma is bready, yeasty and sweet malt.  Sweet dark fruit like cherry and plum.  Medium body with a nice chewiness.  As far as I am concerned the epitome of the style (although I have not had all the belgians yet).  Excellent beer.
bread, dough, licorice, red, hazy, frothy, medium sweetness, lightly sour,

Poured into a tumbler with a big head that settled nicely but quickly. A really nice chocolate and cigar box like smell. Very full bodied that finished with a bit of a kick at the end. A very good beer.
nice big pillow head ... sweet malt and molasses aroma ... starts sweet with alcohol in the middle ...cleaner than expected finish ....slight alcohol in the aftertaste..... its good

Bottle. Brown-red hazy body. Begie head. Aroma is little starnge... Brings burnt sugar, rubber, candy and raisin. Flavor brings malt, sweet burnt sugar, candy, rubber, sirup. Palate is watery and has to much Co2.

Bottle(75cl) Clear deep red/amber colour, with a nice creamy head. Aroma was citrus, choclate, caramel, metalic, yeasty, fruity and has rasin. Flavor was almost the same, smouth creamy mouth feeling. Medium body,and medium rasin/fruity finish. Nice

75 cl corked bottle Reddish brown colour, somewhat hazy. Big, fluffy, collapsing head. Toffee, caramel and chocolate on the nose. Flavour is sweet, fruity toffee. Quite pleasant but might get a little bit too sweet in the long run.
A sweet, rich beer that is definitely right up my alley. I sandwiched it in between two great Unibroues though, and I think maybe it would stand up better on its own. Yummy yum though!

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2009 
(Bottle) Pours a light hazy dark reddish brown colour with and off white to light brown head. The aroma is fantastic and fat with clear tones of, malt, caramel, toffee, sugar, honey, doughy yeast, dark fruits like resins, figs and plums, lighter fruits like apples, sweet oranges and pineapples. Sweet but also a bit sourish. In addition, some berry notes of grapes and cherries. Undertones of tobacco and liquorice. The nose is more like an English BW than a Belgian strong. The flavour is sweet malty, sugary and dark fruity but also a bit tart and sourish. Vinous tart with grape sand cherries. The caramel and toffee tones are more laidback in the flavour.  Finish is dry and spicy with a touch of chocolate/cocoa and anise. The mouthfeel is quite rich, warming, round and creamy with a champagne carbonation that dies out pretty fast. Light bitter. The sourish orange notes plays well with the sweetness and make the beer less cloying. Medium to full bodied. This is a very special example of the style and in my book a better example than many of the beer in the same category.

After fighting with the cork for a while- Pours a flakey bronze into a stemmed tulip glass. Small bubbles of carbonation make up the great tan head. Very aromatic musty oak and flowery with hints of caramel. Tastes of sweet caramel and fruit dance on the tongue while the slight alcohol burn is surprising for only being 8%. Higher in alcohol percent and mouthfeel, but still a very drinkable beer.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a beige head. Sweet and fruity malt aroma with notes of caramel and raisin. Medium body. Flavor is sweet, dark fruit, and yeast. Notes of dark fruit, berry, caramel, and bread. Finish is a little bit alcoholy. A pretty good beer, good to share with friends.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2008 Despite the drama of the lacey head and the robust copper presentation, the taste here is a bit too chocolatey for me.  Sure, it feels great from the moment it touches the lips through the swallow, but its just a bit too heavy for me preferences.  Upon further consideration, that’s all good!

Bottle. Opaque dark ruby, medium head. Fresh, fruity aroma with some alcohol sting. Taste is like a less full quadruple, with a dry finish. There is some sourness in it as well. Quite interesting on the whole.
One of the better Belgian styles done in the US. And here in Missouri, one of our better places to eat keeps it on the beer list. Malty. Dark. Brown. Very nice.

Bottle (75 cl) from Systembolaget. Hazy ruby/mahogny with a medium beige head. Fruity. earthy. spicy and fudgy with notes of clove and orange peels. Medium bodoed and smooth, good balance, ok strong belgian but nothing special.
UPDATED: JUL 8, 2008 A dark reddish brown beer with a tan head that fades quickly.  Light fresh bread aroma.   Pleasant blend of yeast, malt sweetness, and sour.  Good but not outrageous.
750 ml bottle in tulip glass, has a lot of carbonation which I liked, amber color with spice, caramel and hops, nice head with medium body and strong finish
Bottle at ØLbaren. Cloudy red/brown - white head. Berries, fruity, yeasty, nutty, sweetness, madium carbonation. OK - but typical belgian style !!

Bottle.   Pours a light brown color with a rocky tan colored head.   Aroma is caramel, spices, light roast, some dried fruits.   Flavor is again caramel, light roast, raisin, spice.   palate is medium bodied, medium carbonation, finished on the sweet side.   Good stuff, great price!

It pours deep reddish brown, with a lingering rough tan foam. The aroma is dominated by a rich spicy raisiny caramel, with an interplay of sweetness and roasted notes blended with elements of pear and dried dark fruits. Upon tasting, one is struck by the vigorous carbonation. As it subsides, the caramel takes center stage with the fruit and spiciness, making a gorgeous display of flavors. Toward the end, the spicy peppery element transitions into a streak of mild bitterness, leaving behind spice, caramel, and bitterness in the final notes with a licorice like association.

750 ml bottle:  Aroma is sweet fruit and a nice roasted malt scent.  Caramel, Raisins, roasted malts, and a nice fruity overtone that makes this a nice aromatic brew.  Pours a semi opaque reddish brown with a thick tan head that lingers.  Taste is nice caramel malt  overtone with a nicely spiced note.  Somewhat alcoholic but not over the top.  Overall,  a pretty nice drinkable ale.  Im glad I brought my bottles back and got this brew.
my favorite, priced right, so smooth with molasses flavor, cofee, and hops, great for the palate, infinitely better than any wine , great w/ cheese

750 courtesy/split with Naka.  Pours brown w/ amber hues.  Caramel, puffy head, long lasting.  Sweet caramel nose with hints of fruit; apple and raisin.  Tastes of brown sugar, molassass and caramel, Pear and apple fruity notes, alcohol warmth, with a slight bitterness at the endthat lingers into the after.  Some fruit and alcohol there too.  This is a very drinkable Belgian that is priced very competitively.

Dark Burnt caramel color with a decent light tan head.  Some light fruitiness with some sour yeasty notes and a little bit of spice.  There is a light fruitty flavor kind of like over ripe apples and spicy caramel.  There is a sour metallic hint, but not really in a bad way.  Not very heavily carbonated, but has a very bright spritz giving it a decent body.
Caramel head.  First I smell plum and dates.  Taste creamy sweet dark fruits and a skightly metalic finish over all a good beer.

750 ml bottle - Pours a cloudy dark amber color with medium sized creamy light tan head. Aroma is creamy, fair amount of caramel, light chewy malts, notes of cherry, raisen. Flavor is malty, chewy, fair amount of caramel, raisen, dates, figs, with a balanced, dry finish. Nicely done overall.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2010 Bottle.  Has a nice deep brown pour with a champagne like head.  Aroma of strong toffee, chocolate, and roast. Flavors were very complex with some dark fruit, roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, and some wood characters. Very smooth and delightful. Great beer.

750ml-A cloudy hazy dark brown with a huge tan head which emots an aroma of roasted malt, caramel, yeast, hops, and slight alcohol.  Taste of this full bodied brew comes across with a taste of the same with a bit of sourness and sweetness.  A great tasting brew.

hazy, dark reddish brown.  decent small, off white head.  very fruity aroma, apricot, white grapes, hint of pumpkin spice.  not as much "punch" as a normal belgian strong ale as it hides a bit of the alchohol and is a little smoother.  fruity taste.  i get sugary malt and spices.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2009 Re-rate: Just had a tap of the 2009 version, it was so full of Diacytel (butterscotch bomb)  that I declined ot drink it. What happened?

Pours a dark ruby brown color with a large pillowy head and disappearing lacing. Aroma of sweet sugars, dates, some dough as well as pineapple and spice.The flavor is spicey, candy sugar sweet, caramel, almonds, and bananas. Medium bodied, dry bitter finish. I need to start paying more attention to Ommegang!

Sweet caramel and bready malt.  A mild acidity provides some slight sourness.  A good amount of cherry, a little plum.  Flavor washes out a bit in the finish.  Pretty clean yeast doesnt leave a ton of esters.  Not bad, but pretty generic for the style.

Aroma: Malty sweet (moderately), honey, raisiny, vinegar, and, uh, brussel sprouts. Taste: raisins mix in w/ sweetness, but are kept in check by a slight sourness. Fairly good, but not all that inviting.
Great beer.  Tastes much like the Chimays, but substantially less expensive.  Good color, aroma, head and finish.  I really like this beer....it also packs a pretty good punch!
Great belgian strong. Tastes more alcoholic than it really is.  Doesnt finish as nicely as the description suggests.

Poured an orange tinted light brown with a tall foamy tan head. There was a sweet aroma with a undertone of hops. The taste was creamy with a little citrus flavor followed by a mild sweetness of caramel. There was a nice hoppy bitter finish, but not to overpowering. There was alot of mingled flavors in this beer, which to me makes it good when its hard to put a finger on the various flavors. The alcohol was hidden pretty well.

Bottle, 75cl corked. (RBNAG 07) Pours a hazy, orange-brown body, with a dense, beige head. Sweetish, roasted, slightly oxidized aroma and flavor. A bit too oxidized flavor I think. Full-bodied, slightly sourish in the mouth, and quite sticky. A nice beer, but considering it being quite fresh, it shouldnt taste as oxidized as a twenty year old beer. (071103)

750ml bottle. Pours a chestnut brown body with a towering khaki colored head. Measures at least 3 1/2 fingers thick with incredible retention and lacing. Nose of cherry pie, caramel candy, raisins, plums, candied sugars, funky yeasts and tropical fruity esters. Also maybe some brown sugar at the very end of the aroma. Flavor is semi-sweet chocolate, raisins, prunes, plums, candied sugars and yeast. Back end of the sip produces some more fruity esters and a drying bitterness. Medium bodied, slightly sticky but far from cloying. Finish is lengthy, chocolate, cherries, caramel and tropical fruits carry on to the end. When they say the finish dries out, they arent kidding. Not a favorite of mine, but this is a good beer.

Thick head, dark beer, very sweet smell or dark chocolate and Cherries. This was given to me from a friend for New Years 2007/2008. Taste is Caramel and dark chocolate. Alcohol is present but not in a bad way. My Wife hated it which automatically makes it a good tasting beer. Delicious!

Bottled 
Muddy brown color, small beige head. Chocolaty and a bit fruity, propably some notes of oxidation. First impression: anise ... then some licorice, caramel backed with malts. Short finish, alcohol is very well hidden. Very interesting, something similar to Gouden Carolus Christmas. Fabulously balanced.

Bottled (thanks Degarth). Brownish amber colour with mediumsized beige head. Aroma is alcohol, spices and herbs. Flavour is spices and licorice. Slight notes of some caramel and candyish sweetness. I think this could do with some "heavier meaty foods" better than its without.

[745-20071008] 750mL (w/ jerc, tuqueboy). Toasted chocolate aroma with some alcohol and anise. Hazy, dark brown red body with a long-lasting foamy light tan head. Toasted Belgian yeast flavour has some chocolate notes and licorice anise. Medium-full body. Very nice, goes well with yummy pork roast.

I cant believe I have not rated this.
Had a side by side of 2 year old versions of the NY and Belgian.  
The NY won by a wide margin.
Whereas the fresh version is sweet caramel and finishes dry, the NY version after two years drops a lot of the sweetness and gains a slight soda-like characteristic, but still carries most of the flavors that are present in the fresh version.
I still think the optimal aging for this beer would be around a year to 18 months, but at the same time, I think its still pretty solid.
Lots of caramel,  red apple, and fruitiness, but also the soda water taste and over-carbonation that is generally present in Ommegang beers- and a lot of belgians.
has a nice sweet almost sugary taste to it.  A nice body, good balance, has a slight hop hint mixed in with the sweet taste.

Nice Aroma--smells sweet and fruity at the same time; dark reddish brown color; tastes wonderful with nice aftertaste although alcohol taste comes through often and takes away from flavor.  Nice--will recommend and drink often.

4-pack from Brewers World, Dumont, NJ...bottle pours reddish-brown with a light beige head...aroma is quite busy, sweet, dark fruits, plum, raisin, fig, molasses...flavor is rich with much of the same, some alcohol in the aftertaste...the only thing Id take away from this beer is that its a bit too carbonated, otherwise very good.

Bottle. High creamy and long lasting off-white head. Hazy orange read body. Powerful barley malt aroma with a good deal of alcohol, grassy notes and a faint hint of cocoa. Sweet caramel  coffee flavor made less sweet by a good deal of alcohol and a bit of bitterness. Low carbonation. Short aftertaste. Interesting and hard to describe.

Awesome brew.  Dark, lots of flavors throughout the drink.  I split one bottle with a friend (cause I didnt think hed handle it not being bud or miller)  and we ended up finishing all four.  Im going to try more belgians.
burgundy with a fluffy khaki head. spicy malt aroma with a chocolate orange note. medium bodied. toasted caramel with oranges and cherries and an alcohol note.
Thanks to Ramenen. Bottle: Bread dough with a heavy malt presence. Red fruits and lots of spices (cinamon), alcohol leverl well hidden.
Thanks to my parents who brought all the way from Clearwater, Fl.  Pours in nicely into a deep, red and brown color.with a tan head.  Malty and spivy with a long finish
Bottle at RBNAG 07. Mahogny colour with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, malt, alcohol. Flavour is sweet, caramel, cellar notes, hop, alcohol. nice beer.

Bottle. Pours cloudy brown with some red highlights. Thick foamy head. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Flavor is fruity with some spice, licorice, caramel, even some chocolate as it warms. Medium bodied and smooth.

750 ml bottle.  Poured a cloudy ruby-brown with a fluffy off-white head.  Aroma was medium bodied and had a nice fruity/floral/yeast blend.  Taste was distinct--a burnt prune juice flavor.  Slightly flat and not as complex as I would have preferred.  The finish is smooth and warm but slightly disappointing--there is simply not enough complexity to enjoy the finish much.  Giid but nothing spectacular.
Mahogany with thick tan head, lacing the glass all the way till the end.  Aroma is slightly toasty/nutty with some fruit.  Taste is sweet up-front with light roasted notes and finishes quite dry.

12 oz Bottle-Poured a Cloudy golden color w/a fair sized white head. Crisp, hoppy, floral/citrus inital flavor w/some yeast to it. Had a spicy flavor mid palate w/a lot of carbonation; reminded me of a Duvel-It seems Ommegang is the American arm of Moortgat according to the bottle which mentioned Duvel. Kind of a thin mouthfeel w/a dry finish; Alcohol is well hidden. Nice light summer brew. Original rating was done 7/1/07 but accidently entered under the wrong beer (Ommegang Ommegeddon). Just noticed my error. Deleated that rating & copyed it to here.

Pours a dark ruby red with a creamy, slight beige head.  Lots of yeast floating in the bottom of the glass.  Aroma of cherry, yeast, alcohol and spice.  A nice amount of carbonation of front with a tart herry flavor.  Very spicy with hints of cherry, honey, and lcorice with a slightly dry finish.

Pours a cloudy, dark brownish-red color with a nice off-white head.  Awesome aroma; yeasty, a little spiced, cinnamon, cloves, figs, and an underlying sweetness.  Smooth, but crisp mouthfeel reveals a spiced, bready delight.  Yeasty notes, dark fruits, just a great sweetness to it.  An old standard.

tasty brew - started with a deep amber color - no head really.  - malty taste dont notice too much carbonation, high alc % isnt very evident - great wintery beer - probably one of the best Ommegang (or Belgian strong ales) for the $$- i can find a 750ml for $4.50 whilst some of its brothers and sistes sel for 12.00 at the same store.  definite stand by

I think this is the best beer I have ever had that I can purchase absolutely anywhere I shop for beer.  As many times as I have walked by this, I only tried it today, and boy am I glad I did.  I have a new standard beer.  A really rich and darkish Belgian with a very complex-but-soft flavor.  I can taste roasted fig (?!), caramel, red grapes and only comfortable bitterness.  A very ethereal and vaporous quality makes this like a darker meade -- truly beautiful.

Pours amber brown with a light brown fluffy head. Aroma is straight Belgian! Caramel dipped over ripened strawberries, caramel chocolates, and alcohol hit the nose. Taste is of toffee, bits of roasted malt, candy malts, Belgian yeast, dried fruits, and hops that break through the sweetness; all topped off with a dose of booze. Good carbonation for the style, but wish there was less. Great brew that finshes off somewhat dry and sticky!  (Coming down with a cold, re-rate is definitely in order).

Is there no section for the cave-aged?

Bottle - Memphis. Poured a burnt ruby color, tranparent with thick white head head, good head retention.  HEED THE SERVING TEMP LISTED ON THE BOTTLE!! The toffee and chocalate really came to light as the beer warmed a bit.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2008 re-rated:
7/4/7/4/16 - 3.8

pours cloudy brown with a maroon tint, large creamy tan head, and excellent lacing.

smell is sweet, maple syrup, roasted pecans, some cocoa, prunes, caramel, and spice.

taste is smooth, prunes, raisins, touch of cherry, some cocoa, burnt toffee, some malt, ends thick, somewhat bitter, and tangy on the tongue.
UPDATED: OCT 9, 2010 bottle. deep mahogany.  Alcoholic tasting. Taste is also roasted malt. Some fruit as well.
Pours a reddish brown with a lovely creamy head, surprisingly light on the palate and easy to drink considering the alcohol content. Actually didnt find this to sweet, it had quite a dry finish.

Huge beer, dark belgian style that was a bit too fruity for my tastes. I dont know if it was too complex for me or if I was too complex for it, but something was far too complex for my likeing. Better as it warmed, the second glass revealed some better flavors. Alcohol more prevalent with the second glass and after the 750mL corked bottle, it was easy to see (or feel) that this one is serious. Good, but not my favorite offering from Ommegang.

750ml bottle @ RBNAG07. Clear mahogany body with a medium beige head. Aroma of sweet caramel malt and alcohol. Flavor is sweet, caramel malt, dry fruit, candy sugar and alcohol. Quite complex and typical sweet ale in Belgium style.

This is a really nice ale with rich flavors.  Another success from the gang at Ommegang.  I saw that the price of this almost doubled recently.  Too bad because at its previous price I would buy this a lot.

750ml bottle, great carbonation, not getting much on the aroma.  Kicks in sweet but doesnt stay that way (which is good).  Almost a mead-like initial taste, but finishes dry with a nice burn (carbonation or alcohol?).  Would buy again.

Pours a murky, unfiltered, layered black cherry burgundy. Yellowish-off-white head with nice lacing and a gentle carbonation stemming from the center of my consendonk tulip.  Nose is full with dark fruits- especially cherries,  belgian yeast, and candied and brown sugars. Flavor begins sweet and fruity with more cherries and a little raisin, prune, and plum. Finishes more earthy and clean with a smooth cocoa bitterness and a bit of (pleasant) cough syrup.

750 ml. bottle.  Pours a dark copper to brown with a substantial frothy almond colored head.  Big fruit in the aroma--cherries, plums, currants, raisin, with maybe some peach and apricot.  Toffee malt underneath, with some wafts of yeast.  Rich toffee malt flavor with raisinettes and some licorice throughout, with some dried fruit notes and yeast.  Warming finish with a touch of chocolate.  Solid signature/flagship beer from the Cooperstown Moortgats.

nice deep chestnut body with a tan head, cloudy. Malty aroma with some spice present. Rich malth flavor with raisons, dates and plum flavors. Medium mouth feel. Semi sweet chocolate finish. Very complex
Fuck me sideways...this is always great. Really flavorful...with the right amount of alcohol...a little cloudy tooo...sort of like an opaque cream soda

Really good beer. Thick head on the pour, leaves a thick lace but its still opaque. Smells sweet and citrus fruity. Taste is almost of caramel and orange. Crisp mouth feel. Smooth finish. Its worth a try even at 5 bucks a beer.
Big light brownish head, dark fruity taste and very smooth.  Great carbonation.  Excellent brew.

My favorite beer from Ommegang and a really good belgian strong ale. Dark and sweet fruity flavor and aroma of prunes and plums. Full bodied and complex. Does not have much alcohol presence despite the strength. Lightly dry finish.

Bottle. Poured a very dark brown with a good but, not huge head of light brown. Aroma of plum and raisin. Flavor of dark fruit with a cola undertone. Good mouthfeel with a slightly dry finish. A very good strong ale.
bottle, poured a dark murky color. Sweet smell, light head. Malty at first with slight fruity flavor to it, good body. Not overly impressed for my tastes but what a unique beer.
pours dark amber,nice frothy off white head.sweet carmel nose.carmel fruity slow slight bitter finish,med body average.
Sampled bottle, RBNAG 2007 in Grimstad. ABV was 8.5%. Beautiful copper to ruby colour, decent head. Intense oaky, malty and vinous aroma and flavour.

Pours an amber colour with a tan frothy medium head. Aroma is slight metallic, dark fruits, and cherry. Initial taste has a fizzy mouthfeel with dark fruits, cherry, cocoa, and funky metallic notes. Finishing with a mild bitter hop. Slight lacing of the glass. Medium body.

Medium yellowish brown head. Deep hazy brown mahogany body. Malty egg aroma with banana notes over a cinnamon background. Dry vinuous cinnamon licorice soapy peppery taste with banana notes. Dry caramelly afttertaste with cardboard notes. Liked this less than I expected. (0.75l bottle at RBNAG07.)
Smells sweet and strong like a typical Belgian strong.  Looks dark brown and opaque, curious.   Thin consistent head.  Tastes fruity, honey with a caramel style aftertaste.

Pours dark amber with fluffy tan-white head.  Aroma is sweet and nutty, with notes of maple, dark fruit, caramel and honey.  Flavor is sweet: apple, anise, berry, balanced with light yeast, toffee, chocolate, and molasses.  Nice dry palate.

A dense  lasting tan head over a burgund colored body. Pleasant and complex aromas. Belgo-yeast and a range of inviting fruits; mainly sweet apples, plums and berries. Whiffs of caramel and flowers. Taste is fruity-sweet, malty, light yeasty and very well rounded. Medium to full body. Mild bitterness and warming alcohol in the finish. Excellent. (750 ml bottle @ RBNAG07)
75 cl bottle. Dark brown color, medium beige head. Caramell, dark malt, fruity and floral. Nice bitter finish. (RBNAG07 in Grimstad Nov. 3th.)
Moderate foamy head, heavy lacing, strong, tofee, light floral flavor. Not very sweet for an abbey ale. Bitter, strong alcohol finish.

750 ml bottle into trappist glass.  Pours a dark ruby brown with a few fingers of tan head.  Toffee and caramel malt aroma.  A hint of liquorice and chocolate in the flavor, with a nice sweet toffee aftertaste.  A good Belgium strong ale for the price.

Bottle from some ale house in New York.  This was a solid and enjoyable brew.  The dark fruits and chocolatey Belgian malt were the star of the show.  The alcohol was hidden, or at least it was by that time of night.  Good mouthfeel.  Good beer.

Very big beer.  Aroma is big and full of belgium malts and sweet crystal.  Nice apple cider like red amber hue.  Flavor is very complex with yeast and Belgian malt.  Nice bitter finish.  Good mouth feel for such a big brew, feels light but medium body and soft.  Good for a Belgian strong ale.
bottle pours mahogany thin off white head aromas of grapes and yeast . Mediun body light carbonation Nice flavors of fruit and malt with a distinct hopps bitter

Cask of dry-hopped version at the Blind Tiger.  The aroma was fruit, clove, belgian malt, and pine.  The flavor was similar with the belgian malt taking a back seat to the fruit, clove and pine hop finish.  I wasnt sure what to expect with this one because I disliked the Urthel hopped belgian, but this was really quite good.  Great mouthfeel on cask, and the typical yeast found in belgians wasnt really there (which was probably a good thing).
Sampled at the Newtown Brewfest 07 with Stegosaurus. Brownish/red pour with tan head. Spicy sweet aroma. Bready fruit flavor with a blended smooth finish. WELL DONE

Sampled @ GDBTF. Pours a dark ruby with tannish head. spicy nose, cinnamon, nutmeg, toffee. Pretty rich on the palate but not too heavy; strong caramel, faint grassy hops, licorice bitterness, very yeasty dry finish.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2017 Bottle (small). Malt and yeast dominate the aromas of this beer. Moderate notes of caramel, nutty, a little cereal, and dough, with light herbs and grass for the hops. Dates and a little alcohol are in the background. Head is fizzy with big bubbles, off white, with fair lacing and is fully diminishing. Color is a murky brown. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, between watery and creamy and carbonation is fizzy. It finishes lightly alcoholic and a little dry. A bit fizzy and the taste been bold. A very enjoyable Abbey Dubbel.
