12 oz bottle.  pours mahogany shimmering hue.  thin, yet substantial creamy head. aromas of toffee, sugar, slight smokage, raisin-esque as well.  also - a tail end of ginger and clove, more or less mulling spices.  flavor is of dark, bitter fruits and perhaps some bitter anise.  its nothing wonderful, but some can get into the espresso bean finish and flavor.  interesting.  a re-taste is in store.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2008 Pours a very dark amber-brown with a nice head that lasts a while. The aroma is true to the style... yeasts and bread notes dominate. Some beers in this style have a deadness in the aroma, but this one has a lot of refreshing qualities. Flavor has tons of malts and some dry, bitter hops. The body is medium to heavy, with a nice smoothness after the spiciness up front. Hints of dark fruits come out on the finish, rounding out a very nice beer. Not terribly complex, but whoever called beer liquid bread could have been referring to Ommegang. For the money, Ill be returning to this one time after time.
Not a big begian fan but this one is pretty smooth and has a nice finish to it. Fruity with a some nice spice tones to it.
Smells very yeasty. Pours a dark deep brown with a large tan head. Tastes yeasty and faintly of toffee. Very nice
Pours a brownish color. Lots and lots of head. Smells like raisons (to me), caramel, and strong alcohol. Bitter, spicy on the lips finish. Dry.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: bottle.  an average belgian strong.  the thing that hurts this one the most is the finish... it just stops very abruptly.  Overall, it is pretty good... but could be much better.  Nice caramel notes...  pours a deep red/amber.  Spicy / carbonated on the top of the tongue.  Not bad.

Pours a deep red with a light brown fluffy heads.  Smells of malt and dark fruit.  This is pretty good with a dark over ripe plum taste with alot of carbonation.  Plenty of malt with a good hint of hops to balance. There is a nice shot of bitterness at the end.
bottle. amber-brown, with off-white head, minimal lacing. aroma of fruits and chocolate, flavor of chocolate, dark fruits, toffee, malt and some bitterness. Quite good.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2007 Bottle.  Dark brown ale, with a small beige head.  Aroma is sweet with hints of berries and a little yeast.  Flavor is quite dry and bubbly with sweet tones and notes of wood, berries and a strong finish of alcohol.  Nice ale.

Pours a clear dark ruby brown with a thick small bead tan head that stays forever.  Aroma is vinous with dark fruit and mapley chocolate.  Taste is sweet dark roasted malts with caramel and a bit of a dry merlot wine element.  This stuff is superb!  A Belgian better than a Belgian!  I dont offer many high ratings but this is unavoidable.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2007 Im not a fan of Belgians, but I really liked this one.  Flavor is slightly tart, but with a solid yeasty-malt bread backbone.  Nicely spiced, with sweetness of caramel and toffee.  Finish is pleasant and dry.  Very drinkable, alcohol well hidden.  I will get this again, its restored my faith in Belgians.

Wow, havent rated a beer for a while. Huge head with spicey molassesy notes. Smells very sweet. Too much for me perhaps. On the mouth the molasses is thick, am I actually drinking molasses??? With toffee and licorice notes. There are some Belgian Strong Ales that I love and covet, and others that go over the top for me. This is in the latter category. Thanks to my dad, for bringing this beer to Panama from Cleveland. I kept in the fridge for 10 months, might have affected the taste, but not sure based on other reviews.
This ale sets a high standard for Belgian style brewing. It has an intense and dark taste with hints spice.

Beautiful swirling dark hypnotizing pour from gunk on bottom of bottle. A tempest in a mug. Really sweet aroma, nearly sickening sweet, attractive in its own way. Taste impact is burned caramel. Very strong, near whiskey bulldozer. Creamy carbonation but its hidden in the misandry  of repulse. A magniloquent example of the style. Finish is just plain anti- amicable.  In your face danno. The aroma and appearance save this selection.  Im not good enough for this brew. Very difficult to enjoy.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: pours a dark ruby red with a nice one finger stiff brown head. aroma is dark fruits, yeast, and a touch of candy sugar and alcohol. has a medium to full body with good lacing and carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma but a bit stronger. another good one from ommegang! as it warms it is a little more aromatic and the flavor smooths out a bit. there is also some wood aroma and flavor that show up. there is also a tart aftertaste and is a touch dry.
Dark red color.  Fruity nose and very malty.  A little earty flavors come through as the beer warms.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2008 good but not great. Interesting color. Fruit, yeast nose. Dark, deep Brown amber, beige head. Heavily spiced carbonation, followed by plums, dark malt, alcohol present on back end. Cloudy and unfiltered looking. Not great.

750 mL bottle.  Poured deep red/brown, much darker than I expected, with a nice white head.  Aroma is sweet, filled with fruits and berries as well as some caramel.  Flavor is sweet and malty, with fruity/nutty notes.  Its almost oily as it coats the tongue, but very smooth, finally ending in a nice alcoholic kick.  A great brew.
dark ruby with a guge head. sweet raison and rum bread aroma. caramel and dark fruit flavor. nice carbonation with a medium mouthfeel and nice finish. balanced very well.

A frothy brown pour with a nice tan head. An aroma of dried fruit. A hint of dates and brown sugar with some abv. A solid palate. All round a good beer that is just solid top to bottom. I hate I had to drink the whole 750.

Rated while drinking: Pours a rich mahogany with a gorgeous off-white head. As soon as it came out of the bottle, I knew it was gonna look amazing. Complex aroma; chocolate covered fruits, licorice, very rich. Flavor is everything the aroma hints at, but with thick malt all over the tongue, while fruit and chocolate hits the back of the throat. Lush. Smooth all the way down, with just a tiny bit of alcohol burn at the end, but definitely a sipper. Amazing beer. Definitely one of the best Ive had in a while.
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.

750 ml bottle:  Pours a dark brown/amber with a massive, foamy cream  head.  Dark malt based aroma with some fruit and dough aspects.  Has a subtle hay note in the background.  A bit dry and perfectly carbonated, the malt dominates the flavor.  Again, the dark fruit flavors are prominent which helps accentuate the big maltiness throughout.  A damn fine brew.

Hazy burgundy brown, just as the bottle says, with a towering tan head that demands you take time through the pour. Rich toffee, chocolate, banana aroma. Same flavours fill the palate, sweet dates come to mind also. Warming alcoholic finish.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Cave Aged version. Very, very dark brown. Nice fluffy head retains well. Sweet malty delicious aroma. Some candy gummies and sweedish fish aroma. Very well balanced taste with rich malts and mild hop flavor. Hints of plum and raisins engrained in some mellow boubon oak. Nice smooth almost heavy body but goes down easily.

750 ml bottle.  Pours a beautiful burgundy with a tan, thick fluffy head.  Aroma is fruity and sweet.  Flavor is awesome, and it gets better with each sip.  Dark fruits and cherries dominate and sweet caramel.  Balanced and very smooth.  Medium to full mouthfeel and a dry crisp finish.  I cant believe it took me so long to try this beer and it has lived up to the hipe.

Had this beer on 4/29/2007.  Aroma is a sweet rich malt scent with caramel tones.  Color is a deep purple amber with low carbonation but a nice tight head.  Taste is light and sweet.  Starting with a full/medium body it goes down with a crisp bubbly feel and a roasted sweetness coming on.  Finish pulls from the sweet malt flavor with a nice fruity and yet spicy flavor that must come from the yeast and ends with a mellow bitterness. This is one of the best Belgium brews I have had and is far better then I was expecting.
Bottle. Reddish brown with a long-lasting tan head. Sweet caramel aroma with some dark fruit. Flavour of more dark fruit with some chocolate. Very enjoyable.

pours with a nice full caramel head and a reddish amber color.  smells like strawberries well more like a fruit salad (one that is just different fruits).  very easy on the palate and tastes quite well.  the alcohol doesnt overpower the beer either.  great beer.

Pours a very deep brownish red with a tan head. Quite a bit of lacing on the way down. Nose is extremely sweet with tones of old cherry skins. Flavor is smooth, rich, and deep. Robust malted flavors with a slight cherry tone to it. Caramel tones present as well. Feel is excellent. Perfect combination of bubble and rich, thick flavor coating your tongue. Extremely drinkable. A heavy hitter, but so rounded that you cant help but keep going and going and going. Awesome offering from Ommegang. A Belgian styled jewel right out of America.

Huge tan head with a deep reddish coloring that retreats slowly.  Good fruity smell and taste.  12 oz. capped bottle... wish I had gotten the larger corked bottle that is pictured.  Good alcohol content;  the alcohol doesnt burn through and disrupt the taste of the beer like in some other strong ales.
Deep red color, not sure what to compare the taste too, very good beer, nice alcohol content at 8.5%, Definitely  will add to my list of good beers, picked up a 4 pack at Top Shelf in Brandon, Fl.

This is interesting beer but it tastes a lot like my home brew.  This is kind of like reading the book then watching the movie...always a disappointment.   This is exactly my point but Im pretty sure its the style that Im not crazy about versus this particular style.  Obviously many folks like it due to the ratings.  I know this isnt the normal way to rate beer but I did a clone brew of this beer and it surprisingly tastes very similar.  The bummer is that Ive never really been a fan of that particular batch of beer.  Im convinced now that its the style.

Wow! what a great beer. Fruity earthy aroma that is complemented by the taste. Lots of flavors come through in layers starting with fruit and moving through to chocolate and a little bit of alcohol. Complemented the cappucino cheesecake my wife made perfectly.

God this beer was godly.  I live in a college dorm and i didnt have a glass available (my friend has a tendency of knocking over and breaking glasses) so i had it out of a plastic cup and it was still amazing!  i can only think of a few beers that i like better then this, and thats because i prefer stouts

one of my favorite beers. i feel like i should just copy and paste the commercial description...because its pretty accurate. i didnt get the licorice flavor it describes, but everything else is on point with maybe a little extra fruitiness in the flavor to match the aroma. this is like the beer equivalent of a nice jammy syrah. goes fantastic with dark chocolate too for dessert.

Large bottle.  Malt and fruit aroma with notes of dried fruit and spices.  Deep amber with a frothy tan head.  Flavors of roasted malt, figs and rasins.  Some caramel and chocolate notes.  Strong and lively carbonation with a creamy palate and dryish finish.  This beer is like a mild version of a quadruple.  Not overly alcoholic or strong.  Easy to drink but rich and well balanced. Very good.

12 ounce bottle in Duvel glass.  Deep dark red color with dense lasting beige head and lace.  Earthy, fruity cherryish aroma with yeast and slight alcohol.  Fruity ripe cherry/rasin flavor with slight tobacco bitterness and slight tart finish.  Medium-full bodied medium carbonation.  Absolutely excellent.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2009 
Date: November 04, 1999
Mode: Bottle
Source: Ale Atlanta
Appearance: brown, frothy tan head
Aroma: rich malty aroma, sliqhtly alcoholic, touch of chocolate
Flavor: rich malt flavor, warming, balanced, lot like an octoberfest

Date: July 27, 2002
rich fig aroma, very rich with lots of fruity character, 

Date: December 27, 2006
Mode: bottle
Source: taco mac woodstock
lots of the rich ripe fruit aroma and flavor, no sign of the alcohol

Date: November 20, 2009
Mode: draft
Source: brick store
Appearance: clear dark brown with ruby edges, big dense beige head, drippy streaks of lace
Aroma: sweet fruity aroma, dark fruit esters, light spicyness
Flavor: sweet fruity flavor, rich ripe dark fruits, spicyness continues to grow as it warms

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.7/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4

Bottle. 750ML. Pours extremely dark brown with light redish tint and the head is creamy and a red tinted tan. Aroma is light and fruity, with some yeast and malt. Fairly faint aroma overall or my smeller isnt working right today. Body is light with abundant, light, and very active carbonation. Flavor is moderately to highly sweet, with a pronounced yeastiness, hint of toffee, wood, and light berry tartness. Finish is fairly heavy with alcohol and lightly bitter. Good stuff, slightly out of balance and missing in complexity though.

Great richness and carbonation with berry-like flavor. Good tartness and acidity which are married with the creamy nutty flavors, making this a very good Belgian. It was better than I remembered it when I tasted it a year ago and an economical choice too. Great color.

Pours a very deep red mahoganny color with a nice dark tan bubbly head.  Aroma is of candy and wine.  Sweet assertive flavor indicative of belgians, tastes nice at room temperature.  Alcohol flavor is pronounced but only adds to the appeal of this brew.  Has a tart raisin flavor that gives way to the dry warming alcohol flavor.

Ommegang... Oh, what a head.  A huge, melted styrofoam, creamy head.  The beer itself is the darkest shade of magenta I could imagine.  Dark, but not obscure in hue.  Its really turbulent and cloudy.  Its a candidate for best head ever along with Hennepin.  Head and lacing are so tenacious.  The aroma is of deep grain, alcohol, grass, hay, plum, black cough drops-- all soft.  Its dank, like a basement.  It has a medium to heavy body.  Its soft and syrupy with an acidic flick at the end.  It lingers.  The flavor is like wood with tarragon, fig, plum, fennel, tamarind and brazil nuts.  Its very complex and very boozy with an aftertaste like scotch.  It actually tastes stronger than 8.5% ABV.  Great beer.

12 oz bottle purchased at the brewery. Poured a murky brown with a large off white frothy head. Aroma was complex with the standard yeastiness of a Belgian style but also had a ton of fruit including raisins, plums, prunes, banana tied in with a light maltiness. For some reason on my initial sip I got a mouthful of a metalic flavor but after that first sip it disappeared. Flavor was dark fruit, yeast and candy sugar. This beer was far better then I remembered it and was a nice suprise on a rainy day off from work.

First of all, any beer with a cork already gets cool points. Ommegangs (1 pt. 9.4 oz. bottle) pour is beautiful, a deep, dark, ruby-tinted brown with a lasting cream-colored head. And, the taste aint no slouch either. Immediately after the pour, I smelled some dark fruits, or raisin, which later developed into a fuller sensation with strawberry or raspberry. The taste which followed the sniff was obviously fruity, with some sweets and some sours, and underscored by a decent balance of roast and bitter. The finish is a little bitter (and you definitely know youre getting the 8.5% alcohol), and it really seems somewhere between grape juice and wine. Ommegang is definitely one of my faves.

Pours mahogany with frothy head.  Strong nutty scent.  Surprisingly smooth flavor, great rich taste tat doesnt have an overly hoppy aftertaste.  Dark but not overpowering, an all around excellent, slow drinking beer.
12oz bottle from puzzl, thanks Andy! lightly hazed cheery brown with a huge beige head; nose of cloves, caramel, figs, and nuts; flavor has caramel, raisins, spices, and some light bitterness.

Aroma resembles burgandy wine, with dark fruits like raisin and prune. Deep mahogany color with a beige head that flattened quickly. Medium bodied, with near fizzy carbonation (real ale). The flavor is caramel, toffee, raisin, prune, and some chocolate. The mild sweetness dissipates, and the finish is relatively dry. There is arguably some bitter, and likely some anise. Complex ale.

An excellent beer.  Pours black with a billowy white head, which doesnt seem to dissipate.  The aroma is of malt and strong fruit.  The flavor is a creamy, balanced and very sweet.  Sweetness dominates but a subtle note of toffee, raisins, and caramel provides a very delicate and complex taste.  I would recommend it with any sort of rich game such as duck or lamb, or even with very sweet pork ribs.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2007 Dark malt aroma with a slight banana yeast smell. Clear amber color with a initially large brown head that dies down with time. Starts with moderate malt taste finishing sweet. Thick creamy mouth feel.

Very beautiful pour...huge head that seemed to last forever. Ive had seasonal allergy attacks, so who knows about the aroma...but it tasted nice. Fruity but not overly so...not quite as refreshing (a bit heavier tasting) as the Hennepin, but still very nice.
Taster at the Mondial de la Biere 07. The color is dark amber with a thick beige head  It has sweet malte flavor, with some fruit taste also. It is a very good exemple of a Belgium stong ale.
Freakishly big bubbles in a matrix. One of the best Beligan ales Ive tried so far. Great complexity and balance.  Not acidic or cloying like many beligans.
Decent brew. I had it at the recommended temp and it was very flavorful. A little heavy on the alcohol. Otherwise excellent.

Bottle. Hazy brown color with red hues and a large dirty brown head. Aroma seemed fairly weak but had a lot going on - mainly malty but also fruits with plums and hints of pineaple. Taste was not good - It was absolutely nothing except watered down rubbing alcohol. You could take a shot of vodka and itd be the same. Screwed up batch maybe but I didnt like their Three philosophers either. So far they have a tendency to taste like bad grape cough medicine.

From a 750 ml bottle. Dark burgundy color with tan head that lasts. Aroma of dark fruits (plum?) and chocolate. Medium body with moderate carbonation. Malty taste, somewhat fruity, possibly figs and raisin. Theres a lot going on here.
Pours reddish brown, small brown head.  Sweet fruity aroma and flavor.  Nice beer.

Cloudy, dark chestnut body with a nearly uniform off-white head.  After about one minute, the head dissipates to a thin film.  The lacing is spotty and sudsy looking.  There is an appealing aroma of caramel, candy sugar, dark fruits, apples, root beer, and a faint bit of alcohol.  The flavor blends all of these aromatic elements together into a sweet, creamy, fruity caramel concoction.  The taste is really, really good.  I would classify the body as medium and very smooth.  Its sweet but not overly sticky.  Alcohol is apparent, but not excessively so.  Very nice brew.  Probably my favorite out of the standard Ommegangs.

Brown pour with tan head. Somewhat fruity odor with yeast as well. Complex and smooth has some currant, toffee, fruit and honey, which all work together wonderfully. nice finish with a bit of a warm bite. a wonderful beer.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2010 good caramel and toffee flavor. good after taste. smooth and balanced. overall a very good beer but not too fruity. K7 -- Re-rate (1/30/09): Dark brown pour with a big frothy light tan head and sheets of lacing.  Aroma of dark fruits - cherry and alcohol.  Sweet malts, prunes and caramel in the taste.  Slick thin texture.  Finishes bitter and slightly dry.
Pours brown with a light brown, frothy head. Aroma is yeasty with caramel, fruit, refreshing and lightly spicy. Solid mouth feel with a fruity, spicy complex flavor.

Rich brown with a creamy tan head; some lacing.  The initial nose is very fruity.  Flavors of cherries, raisins, plums.  Smooth  finish.  This bottle says "Brewed and Bottled in Belgium".  Whats up with that?  I know Duval bought the brewery.  Have they closed it down?

Pours a dark brown with shades of red and a tan head. Leaves some lace. Nose is yeasty with the same sort of dark fruit aromas Id expect from ales like this. The first to come to mind is raisin, but one could find others in there, too. There is also a bit of caramel and the slightest hint of alcohol, but it is mostly fruity. The taste has the same sort of fruitiness as the nose. Again, I found raisins most prominently, but I also thought there was a bit of ripe plum in there, too. Under this is a mild, but noticeable backdrop of caramel and toffee. The finish is dark and dry. The caramel (somewhat toasty/roasty, I think) malts mostly come through here, as the prominent fruitiness fades, and there is a slight alcohol warmth as the beer goes down. The mouth feel is medium and a little creamy. I think Ive experienced this same set of flavors in a certain quad. That one punched me in the mouth with Trappist goodness, but this one is more forgiving. I like the other more, but this one is still very good.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2011 Damn if this isnt a lot fruitier than I remember. My recollection is of a more caramel-heavy, darker Belgian strong. And while this brew certainly has those qualities to some degree, its given a distinctive character - and balance! - by this complex fruit character, with a bit of McIntosh apple, a smidge of toffee, a hint of tangerine even, and finishing with a warm malty feel. Very nice, and just a bit out of the ordinary.

The 12 ounce bottle poured a beautifully clear reddish amber colored beverage with a modest creamy off-white head that lasted well and left good lacing on the glass. The aroma contained notes of caramel and dark dried fruits along with just a hint of Belgian candi sugar. The body was moderately full with soft carbonation and a thick, creamy mouthfeel. The flavor starts out moderately sweet and stays that way through the long finish. There is a nice alcohol warmth at the end as well.
Dark amber body with a faint head.  Spice and caramel aroma.  Caramel body and light yeasty finish.

Pours a dark red/bron with a small light tan head.  Smells of dark fruits and rich caramel malts.  Very Belgian.  The taste was much the saem.  Alot of dark fruit and malty, syrupy flavors.  Pretty sweet actually, left a profound sugary sweetness on the palate in the finish and the aftertaste.  Just a typical belgian dark abbey ale.  Cant get much closer than this for an American style of this beer.  Rich, sweet, fruity, malty, with a nice little alcohol kick at the end.  Solid job here.

(bottle) Pours a dark red with a large light tan head.  Aroma contained a wine-like quality, with some spice and fruit as well.  Taste is very sweet at first then gives way to some caramel.  The finish was almost tasted like fresh bread, and it lasted for quite a long time. Overall a pretty good beer.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2012 [Bottle] Pours dark red with a towering tan head that leaves nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of pears and white wine.  Pretty high carbonation with a taste that is hard to describe--a little spicy, a little fruity, some other things there too...  Medium body.  This is a beer that I could drink quite a bit of, very nice. Old rating: 8/4/7/4/17 = 4.0Re-rate:  Reddish-brown with a good tan head. Aroma is very fruity--pear, apple, and blackberry.  After awhile, the sweetness really comes out, with lots of caramel. A little hot, lots of yeast, which provides a metallic taste at times which is the only downside. Big malt backbone. Lots of fruit again, with the same character as in the aroma, especially apple. Medium mouthfeel, good finish length. Just a little too sweet for me at times, and the metallic notes did detract a bit. Still, Im only going to drop it a couple of tenths.

Pours a muddy brown, reddish color with a good beige head. Smell is somewhat fruity, yet rich and creamy with a hint of the clovey hefeweizen yeast smell.  Taste is very unique and somewhat highly carbonated.  Some spiced sweetness at 1st along with some roasted slightly bitter tastes and some flat licorice like taste in the finish.  After drinking half of it, I still hardly know what to think.  After it warmed a bit I like it less and am not crazy about finishing it.  Definitely drinkable, but not something I particularly care for.  This is obviously liked by many, but it is not my style of beer.

Deep mahogany red with dark orange/tan cumulus cloudy head. Large craters appear in mounds of head in glass. Fruity sweet aroma. Flavor is best described as complex. Bitter and sweet at the same time, light and heavy at the same time. Mouthfeel is very very solid for a beer of this nature. Like other Belgian Strongs, this is an acquired taste, but is probably considered near nirvana for a beer geek. Really as classy a beer as youll find, this beer is perfect for introducing to a wine or scotch snob to change their views toward beer.

Pours dark brown/ruby with pillowy head, very nice lacing.  Fruity aromas, caramel, toffe, toasted malts.  The taste is a little rounded with berry, pear,  a little raosted caramel/chocolate with a light sour drying finish.  The high abv is masked quite well.  Good mouthfeel, good brew.
Coupled this with the Three Philosophers tonight; dark ruby red with white head; sweet aromas are much more mild w/ more hops than the 3P; much less bite to the flavors as well; mmmm....beer

pours a dark nutty brown in color with a nice full one finger head. loads of tiny bubbles, smells of prunes, honey and apple sweetness, with some light yeast. taste is full of carbination, some dark fruits and a dry finish for sure, there is a slight tartness pushed by the carbination that mellows quickly on the back of the tongue. nice beer but not too complex at all. worth noting there is no alcohol taste at all for a 8.5% beer.

Poured a deep burgundy color with a thin head that dissipated quickly. Smelled of dark fruits, caramel, with a bit of chocolate in there as well. At first the beer was cold and it had a lot fo carbonation and spicyness from some hops I think. As it started to warm up the flavors all came out of fruits, caramel, and toffee. Was much better as it got warmer. Had a full, creamy mouthfeel that finished off nicely and left a sweet aftertaste. Pretty good brew.

Strangely clear amber-mahogany pour.  Nose of mulled wine, christmas spices, red apples with cinnamon.  A woody bitterness, followed by an odd fruit lipstick taste.  Black licorice, plum skin, tannins.  Dry texture with a sweet, false aftereffect.  Unadventurous and rather a bore.
Pours dark brown/ruby with a nice dark tan head.  Aroma of dark fruit, lightly spiced malt. Taste is a lightly sweet fruit with caramel with just a bit of light citrus hop.  Very well balanced.

Pours a dark brown red with orange highlights and a beige foam.  Aroma of cloves and banana at first, then a nice whiff of malty cinnemon, some leaves and light caramel.  Taste is earthy and yeasty with some caramel and  dry roast flavors.  Finishes dry and toasty with a surprising citrus element.  Lingering earthy aftertaste.  Medium body with fairly high carbonation, and unremarkable texture.  Pretty good overall.
Pours a dark mahogoney color. Small acidic bubbly head. Tastes of licorice and spice. Last acidic finish. Not my favorite abbey ale.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2008 Bottle. Pours mahogany-red with a large head that dissipates fairly quickly to a small cap. Bubblegum, wheat, brown sugar and spice aroma, with maybe some Thai fish sauce. Bubblegum-wheat, salty and malty molasses flavor is pretty well balanced, but really too salty and kind of bland for my taste. Palate is medium-bodied, mostly smooth and has some alcohol. Not overly complex and definitely overrated. The dubbel is one of my favorite styles and this one is just average.

750 ml bottle.  ommegangs take on the trappist strong ale.  a great brewery but imo they miss the mark on this one. had it next to chimay and it was definitely not on the same level.  pours opaque red.  aroma is strong molasses.  burnt molasses and plum flavors with tight but fizzy carbonation.  became increasingly smooth as it warmed.  compared to the chimay, the molasses is overpowering and overly bitter.  rather than complement the flavor the carbonation distracted as well.  not a bad beer by any means but i expected more from the omme gang.

Pours a deep red and a nice off-white head.  The aroma mostly favors spices and grains.  The flavor is very smooth, with barely-noticeable notes (they blend together very well).  This is a very smooth but non-complex beer.

Pours dark ruby red with a fizzy, tan head.  Aromas of syrup, toffee, and toasted grain.  Big flavors of cocoa, molasses, vanilla.  Full body and long finish.  Balanced but somewhat flat; flavors could pop a bit more.
xxx what a great beer, i felt like i was eating the thing, it was such a solid, well brewed beer
wonderful beer with a toasty caramel color. sweet like cherries and honey. a little cloying so a little goes a long way!

Bottle. Deep maroonish red, pours with a big head that quickly disappears. Aroma of roasting nuts, caramel, and alcohol. Wonderfully complex taste. Sweet malts, honey, and a touch of berries with a solid malty/alcohol finish. This one has a lot going on and its all good.
A wonderful, complex beer with caramel, chocolate and malt flavors.  A bit of a weird aftertaste, though.  Not bad, but different.

Pours a dark copper color with a light tan head.  Aroma is of caramel, figs, toasted malts, chocolate, cherry, and a little alcohol.  Light on the palate with the figs, cherries, and sweet malts up front giving way to the toasted malts, chocolate, and a slight hint of some tartness on the finish.  Pretty delicious brew, probably not my favorite from Ommegang but all their brews are amazing.
This is a smooth drinking strong ale. Wonderful aroma and flavor is nice given the 8.5% alcohol content. An enjoyable brew!
UPDATED: AUG 8, 2007 Bottle...beautiful burgundy color -- one of the best Ive seen. Full flavor with complex sweetness and a touch of bitterness. One of the best beers Ive tasted.

This beer poured a nice reddish color with a mild head to it. There was a ncie smell of earth and hops. as you drink it you could taste some earthy flavors with hints of cherry and peat. There was a very nice cherry after taste that stuck around for a while in the back of your mouth.
Fruity, oak aroma.  Brown, with lasting lite brown head.  Hops, alcohol, carmel, and cough syrup flavour notes.  Full body with bitter finish.

Pours a deep wine-red with some brownish hues and a medium foaming beige head. Aromas flit between dark and chocolatey to must to figs, dates, and caramel.

The beer has lively carbonation, which made me burp more than any abbey ale Ive ever tried and is not as full bodied as I expected. Its definitely malty but not overly sweet, and its got a smattering of acidity and bitterness. But the thing you definitely wont mistake is the alcohol, which is very forward, perhaps overly so. 

This was not the first time I had this one and Im wondering if this bottle had suffered from improper care.

Pours an excellent dark amber with a small tight head.  The lacing is there, but thin.  I smelled raisins, malt, coffee beans and some carmel.  The taste was very complex with a definite layering effect on the palate.  I tasted some sweetness up front, with fruity notes coming through, the middle was very malty with some coffee and carmel and the finish was very clean with the alcohol coming into play.  Very nice strong ale.

Deep red color with medium tan head that lasts.  Complex, mildly fruity and malty nose.  Burnt sugar and alcohol flavors on top of chocolate/black patent malts.  Mildly scotchy continuing as aftertaste.  Ok, but makes me sneeze (dont ask).  No WOW factor for me.

25 ounce bottle. Chalice. Mahogany with a tan head. Aroma was of dark fruit and malt. Taste was sweet with notes of dark fruit and licorace. Alcohol becomes more apparent as it warms. A solid Belgian, but lags behind some of the better ones.
Pours a deep dark brown with a thin tan head. Aroma of rasin and dark fruit. Tastes of honey, carmel, fruit, rich. A very nice finish

12 oz bottle poured into a Trappist glass.  Pours redish brown with a average size fizzy head that diminishes rather quickly leaving no lacing.  It is bottle conditioned with medium size particles floating around.  The aroma is very complex and very good.  It is fruity with caramel, molasses and a hint of alcohol.  The taste, this is very complex also.  As the discription says, you start out with a sweetness that reminds you of honey followed by caramel and then after that is some toffee.  There is a very slight hint of licorice, along with a slight sourness, and as the beer warms up the sourness stands out a little more.  The body is medium with a dry and creamy texture and soft carbonation.  Over all this is a very good and very complex beer.  I enjoyed it alot and will be getting more of it.
On draft at the brewery. A great piece of work after a nice tour! Fruity and sweet, bubbly good. Youll run into some yeast on the way to a spicy dry finish.

Robe rouge aux reflets bruns légèrement voilée surmontée dune mousse beige épaisse en dentelle qui persiste. Arômes de levures, de pain, de caramel et dalcool. Saveurs de cerises, de levures, dalcool et de caramel.

12 oz. bottle in pilsner glass.  Pleasant light bouquet, floral and fruity aroma.  Extremely attractive golden deep red.  Lots of layered sweetness as described with a very fizzy belgian ale mouthfeel.  A little dry on finish, a decent bitterness, overall very enjoyable.

Pours rich brown with amber highlights. Slightly soapy aroma (a hint of phenols). Some candied fruits. Sweet toffee and malt. Spicy too: clove and nutmeg. Lively carbonation. Spicy and dry on the palate. Notes of clove and some dry yeast. Finishes quite dry.

750 ml- Wills front porch.  Poured a caramel / coffee color, with fine head.  Smooth throughout, with a lot of complexity and even a little chocolate at the finish.  I wish I had made this last longer.  Paired with a great burger ~ what a start to a holiday weekend.

Popped the cork off and there was very little aroma, but it makes that up for that with its nice deep dark reddish appearance. The head is beige in color that lingers around for a bit. The taste has licorice-fruit notes with a touch of spice. A noticeable alcohol present is there but not too offensive. The finish is abit strong, but doesnt hang around to long. Well done Ommegang...

Reddish-brown color with beige head. Pretty! Pruney, slightly malty aroma. Flavor has lots of dark fruit, mild bittrness and noticeable alcohol. Some parallels here with Rochefort 8. Then booze gets bigger on the finish. A touch out of balance, but a fruity, warming ale for cracking a good book before bedtime.
Pours a deep redish brown with a thick head that hangs around.  Taste is of fruit and toffee with a nice spicy finish.   Very carbonated. Anice all around Belgian ale.

Slightly sour, raspberry aroma when poured, which reminded me of Rodenbach.  Pours a very dark red, with a thin head that slowly fades to a thick lacing.  The flavor is an interesting one, hints of fruit, black licorice, and spice.  The beer is noticeably carbonated when tasting it, and various flavors dance across the tongue while tasting it.  A decent beer, but one Id have to be in the mood for to go after.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2007 Mahogny brown hue with light brown creamy head, decent lacing, when pouren from corked bottle produces much, much head, have to pour very slowly not to overrun the cup, smells like brown sugar and dired fruits, hints of chocolate or caramel taste,, medium to full body, light carbonation, syrupy texture as it warmed the honey really out as did a bit of a spicey aftertaste, very nice Belgian Strong Ale.
I bougth a bottle in Philladelphia in 2001 and tasted it in 2003 in Belgium. A very nice and complex beer

Rated 4/30/06:  Mild complexity is the best way that I can try to sum up this bountiful brew. Pours a deep rich burgandy color with more than ample head that never leaves, there is considerable amounts of lacing rounding out a wonderful appearance. The aroma is a bouquet of dark fruits and spices. Plums, raisins, figs perhaps swirled around some cinnamon and cloves. Mouthfeel is slightly thinner than I was expecting but adequate. The flavor is a toned down version of the aroma, lots of intricate flavors come together to form a very appealing taste. Finish is smooth with a slight alcohol warming, nicely done.

750ml. thanks to holdenn for offering and i finally rate this beer ive had countless times but probably not for the past year. pours hazy reddish brown with off white head. nose is very red fruits, plums, with hints of caramel. flavor is very red fruity, plums, pears, some caramel, yeasty, malty. flavor seems weak and watery to me. ive never thought that about this beer before. mouthfeel is low to medium. carbination is a tad high. a decent belgian beer.

750 ml.  So after passing this up on the shelves so many times, i figured it was time to try this.  Pours an amber brown like browning fruit with a tall beige head.  Nose is red apples, yeast spice, carmel, toffee, and some other dark fruits.  Over carbonated on the tongue but the flavors come out similar to the nose red fruit, dried fruit, yeast, toasted, hints of toffee and chocolate with a carmel backbone. Finishes dry due to the extra carbonation and alcohol.  A decent beer especially for its decent price.  Just what I was in the mood for.
Bottle @ MrGoodbar GBC. Deep maroon with sweet dried fruit, chocolate, licorice. Big full body & Very good
Dark hazy brown with fluffy tan head.  Sweet fruity aroma.  Tangy, sticky palate.  Caramel and fruity taste finishing slightly sour.
Very nice pour with a long lasting off=white head. Taste is fruity with hints of honey. Smell is very fruity. A really good beer

No date.  Beautiful pour, head and body; body is deep, dark brown with ruby highlights and accents.  Head is full, creamy, tight, and a tan-beige color with excellent lasting ability and nice consistant lacing.  Nose is very delicate and somewhat complex; floral hops over the top with plenty of rich malt tones of toffee, caramel, light honey, light yeast, and a bit of date.  Flavor is nice but nothing compared to the nose; not as fruity as I would have thought.  Honey and chocolate are dominant with lighter notes of yeast, toffee, anise, and faint toast note; decent bitterness and dryness  to go along with a minimal fruit note, apricot maybe.  Palate is decent, just over medium, round, creamy, and lively.  Finishes all dry and somewhat short with toasty notes, chocolate, and anise.  Nice American-made Belgian with a wonderful pour, and nice nse.  A bit more fruit in the flavor and less dryness and this would have been great.

Cloudy reddish brown, thick tan frothy head.  Thick aroma of honey, old fruit, and some toffee.  Flavor is more mild, caramel and some spiced fruit.  A bit too fizzy, but otherwise smooth.  Warm, though a bit thin.  Slightly week alcohol finish.

Pours a dark brown color with a thin white head. Has a some lacing. A lot of carbonation. Has hints of dark sweet fruits, and spices. Finishes sweet on the tongue. Alcohol is not masked whatsoever with this brew.
UPDATED: FEB 5, 2008 Wow, this beer is a great deal for a little over $5.  Classic dark fruits, figs and raisin, nice carbonation.  All comes together in a nice finish.  This is a go to beer for me.
Bottle. Dark brown, long lasting tan head. Plum, raisin sweet. Very good Warming, notes of sherry. Smooth drinking. Somewaht dry finish.
UPDATED: MAY 9, 2007 A nice brewski.  A nice belg.  Not overpowering yeast..., a bit on the dark side. $40 a case is definately questionable.
From a bottle pours dark amber color with Lots of light brown head.  Nice strong flavor, with a very mellow finish.

12oz bottle.  Pours dark red/brown with a small white head.  Aroma is sweet, candy, fruit, malty, figs, honey.  Smooth, belgian taste, sweet, fruity, very dry with an odd aftertaste.  This is pretty good.  There is a sweetness/other taste in there that turns me off a little but this is still nice.

bottle.  mahogony pour with nice thin creamy tan head.  nutty, floral hops, oak, apricot and raison,  yeast, musky malt aroma.  dark fruits, medium body, smooth.  some lively carbonation.  nutty, peppery bitter finish.  slight tartness throughout.  a bit of cardboard.
Trappist glass.  Dark brown/mahogeny/black with thick brown head.  Aroma of a flooded basement.  Prune, raisin, caramel, sweet malt flavor with a hint of hops at the end.  Nice soft mouthfeel.
I like it! Remindes me of Duvel But made in the states. Straw and  smokey nice head fades out at a slow medium rate. Banana bread scent and taste. a rweal winner!

I wasnt very impressed with this beer, but I still enjoy it. The apperance is great. You know you are about to drink a beer with a great palate after looking at this one. Dark brown, dare I say black in color. The taste is fruity, with a lot of caramel. I dont feel that the flavor(s) pop out at me. I am trying so hard to taste these flavors, but I am having a hard time picking out the flavors; slowly but surely they are coming to tastebuds. The caramel notes took a while but I am beginning to taste them. I love the color, I think that the palate is great but the flavor just wasnt all the way there. Deent brew nothing to go crazy over. Cheers!

This beer has been one of my top 5 for the last 3 years now... Its rich and chewy, with the slightest hint of cane sugar to finish off an amazing combination of licorice, dark chocolate, and orange rind. Its an excellent beer for the holiday season, as well. LLLOVE IT!

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2007 drank out of the wrong glass, wanna fight about it? vinous. flavors of malt and burnt sugar with some dried figs.  its got a light alcohol burn and a bourbon/scotch flavor.  great all around beer. for just $4.39...

Nothing spectacular going on here. Pour was a dark brown with a puffy white head. Aroma of malt and dark fruit. Taste is dark fruit and honey with a caramel and malt aftertaste. Thick chewy mouthfeel. A little too sweet for my taste.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: I have a lot of respect for this brewery, but this one is just sorta plain jane, imho. Nice rocky head and a pleasent enough taste profile- maybe the style is just getting done too much.

750 ml. bottle. Poured a dark brown, almost cola like. Aroma is sweet, figs, chocolate. Taste is sweet, carmel, slight fruits. Better as it warms up. Alcohol is well hidden as it makes a very slight appearance in the finish.
Poured plum black body, with a nice white head to it.  The aroma was sweet, almost vegetable smell.  Taste was a lot better than the nose.  Very good relaxing beer especially for the price.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2009 bought the beer to drink on easter sunday2006. bought along  the rare vos as well. drank them both. couldnt get anything good out of the flavor.vegetable broth. on tap at shortys nyc this tapped omme was much better.

Bottle. 12 FL. OZ. Cloudy, dark brown with a light shade of red and a tan head with good lacing.  Medium to full bodied.  A smooth, balanced palate.  Aromas of dried fruit, malts, and light chocolate and  sweet flavor that gets better with every sip.

Date: 4/06/2007
Serving: 750 mL bottle (8.5% ABV).  Thanks Matt!
Event: Weekly Friday night tasting.
Location: Rivers Bend Wine & Spirits.
Tasting Notes
Aroma: Sweet berries, caramelized fruit, and brown sugar.
Appearance: Dark ruby copper with a dense, rocky, dark beige/light tan colored head.
Flavor: Mellow British maltiness (caramel, toffee, light butterscoth flavors), figs, and some sort of red wine depth.  The alcohol strength is controlled and is quite mellow as compared to the Ommegang Hennepin (even though the alchohol content is higher in this beer).  The flavor seems to flatten out some as the beer warms.
Palate: Medium to medium-full body.  Smooth on the palate with a bit of creamy feeling as well.
Overall: This beer is complex, interesting, and very easy and enjoyable to drink.  Ommegang makes some really good beers at a great price (750 mL bottle for only $4.99+tax!).  .
750mm bottle.  Pours a dark burgundy with a thick pillowy head.  Excellent lacing.  Rich fruity tones with hints of cherry, rasberry and choclocate.  Smooth lingering finish.  Most excellent.
Pours very brown and beautiful.  Lasting head is tannish yellow. Smells of fruit and honey.  Deep caramel flavor, wow. Deep and dark.  So malty.  Not much hops at all, but enjoyable.

75cl botle.  Pours a deep red with a fine dense tan head that leave little lacing.  Plums and raisin flowed by tofee are the scent that enthrawl my nasal passages as I ready myself.  Ummm!  Ommegang!
Thats good S%$T!
12 oz- Pours a nice dark reddish-brown with a nice tan head. Scents of dark fruits with hints of chocolate malts. Tastes are of the same with a nutty,woodsy flavor. Decent.
maroon purple color.  had this one the same night as the allagash dubbel reserve and like the allagash much better.  chocolaty with a rich woody taste.  nuts and grains nuts and grains

750ml bottle pours a deep dark red, with a nice thick tan head, that disappated very slowly. This was my first brew from Ommegang, and I was plesently suprised how much I liked it. Next up, Three Philosophers.

The 4-pack box this is packaged with recommends drinking it with a heavy meal  something like pot roast.  I couldnt agree more.  This beer has an interesting mix of dark fruit flavors with just enough citrus on top to keep it refreshing.  A touch of sweetness keeps you coming back for sip after sip.

Aroma of sweet malt, grape, raisin, plum, slight alcohol.  Appearance, pours a large, frothy head that is light brown in color, good amount of head is lasting, clear body, amber hue.  Initial fruit flavor, finish of slight alcohol, dryness, average duration.  Creamy texture, medium bodied, average carbonation.  You cant beat a bottle of this for $5.00!

Bottle Dark brown pour with great microbubble creamy head that lasts the whole beer and has good lacing. Aroma of sweet malts, fruits and esters. Similar flavor, maybe some cherry and rasberry. Smooth mouthfeel, overall great brew.

Has all the elements of a great beer. But i dont know about this one. Similar to other belgium strongs cherry, caramel, bite but unenpressive or unique in any way. It was kind of like sex with your ex girlfriend. Sure it will get you off. But you alredy know what to expect anf there are no surprises. Same goes with this brew. i was very dissapointed. But it did still get me off.

From a 750mL Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy, brilliant sunset ruddy fire with a tall layer of frothy off-white head.  Big, fruity aroma with some notes of raspberry licorice, toffee, and sherried green raisins.  Marachino cherry, caramel, and a subtle touch of clove spice.  Not too much phenolic spice in the nose; the fruity dimensions are the clear focal point.  Medium bodied, heavily carbonated texture that lightens up the palate weight enough to make it remarkably easy to drink.  Huge flavors, however.  Rustic, well toasted pumpernickel bread crust, mild chocolate licorice, and prune flesh create an intense flavor layer.  Behind the dark malts, some spicy yeast chracters follow closely.  A little bit of plum and dark toffee linger into the final smack, before finishing cleanly with a smidgen of minty herbal hops.

750mL, 48 F, pours a hazy deep amber with a mamouth, microbuble light brown head that resembles chocolate whipped cream. Smells of malt, dark fruits, and toffee. The mouthfeel is extremely rich and smooth with an active fizzyness. The finish is long and ends dry. I can chew on this a glass for while. Caramel sweetness and fruits are overwhelming. Cherries, plum, and other fruits I cant identify. This stuff is better than a lot of belgian abbeys.
UPDATED: APR 6, 2007 Dark burgundy color (close to brown) with lots of head. Malty aroma. Nice abbey ale. Ommegang is definitely a company I will be looking to try more of their different styles

Fills the glass as a dark brown with foamy head. Rich in its aroma of sweet malt and spicey yeast. Flavor reflects the very same with nice tocuhes of sugar and caramel. A real treat that i had been sleeping on for the longest time.

Drank 750 ml bottle, 10 celcius, aged 1 1/2 year imported from US. Strange musroom like aroma, almost thought it was corked! Dark amber opalescent pour with extremely rich yellow foam head. Very complex malty flavour with notes of dates, dark cherries and partly refined dark sugar. Exceptional maltiness. Full thick palate with lively fizz and long finish. Buy it and forget it in a closet for a year, its well worth it!

Maybe I am wrong but I always thought of this as the benchmark for all other dubbels. Licorice, figs and plums and outstanding even nicer with some age on it. Page 345 of Michael Jacksons Great Beer Guide and only 305 out of his 500 Classic Brews to go.

This beer was great and all but just didnt tickle me right, Big head that stays for a while, malty taste with some spice in there, so many flavors in this beer, very complex in a good way. Good intro to Belgians for me.

This brew pours a clear but dark brown, with a marshmallowy tan head.  Aroma is strong of spicy malt and alcohol.  The flavor is sweet, raisiny and brown sugar, with a drier finish.  Of thee beers from this brewer, this fits right in.  Definitely tasty.

Ginger Man, NYC. Hazy ruby brown coloured, brown head. Malty, nuts, brown sugar and warming alcohol. Tastes like a good Belgian Strong, although the mouthfeel is not as great. Might age very well i think.
This American brewery has it as close as it can get to a Belgian Ale.  It is strong and flavorful, rich and golden.  Tasty blend of hops to create a smooth Belgian style ale.  Recommended!

The aroma was malty with dark caramel and some dark fruit presence. A candy aroma was prevalent with a nice peppery spice. The fruity presence had cherries, raisins and some slight prune. The beer was crystal clear amber brown into the chalice and had a fleeting yellowish head which lasted just enough to lace. The flavor was malty with dark caramel, chocolate and more of the dark fruit presence than was promised by the aroma. The dark fruits were prunes, raisins and this time black cherries in the background. The caramel presence was strong but the beer quickly dried on the palate with a peppery spice and decent level of earthy bittering. The body was medium and the beer had a fairly high level of carbonation despite the fleeting head. This one has aged very well. The other cave aged bottle just was not very interesting, its amazing what another two and a half to three years can achieve! Cave aged from March 4, 2004 - September 30, 2004. 750 ml corked and bailed bottle.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: My rating could be skewed based on the fact that my Ommegang was five years old and aged in a 12 ounce bottle.  It was very thick, almost like a dark apple cider in color, and somewhat vinegary in flavor.  I think that I definitely need to try a fresher one to give this beer an honest appraisal.

Deep red in color wih a bid frothy head. Sweet, fruity, spicy aroma with cocoa, caramel, fig, plum. Big punch of flavors, spicy and carbonated, with cola, cocoa, caramel, a bit of licorice. This one pulls a trick, feeling big bodied but remaining dry. Nice.

Pleasant caramel, fig, dried bananna, esther flavor. Smooth, drinkable...too drinkable. For the price, a wonderful Abbey. Compared to much more expensive dubbels, though, this brew seems woefully simple.
Normally I do not like anything from New York, but Ill make an exception for Cooperstown. A very nice beer with lasting flavor. Pours very smoothly and has a taste that lasts, in a good way.

pours a creamy ruby brown with a full light brown staying head. Has a sweet rich aroma with caramel and fruit. Very pleasant taste with chocolate and some banana...and I actually do get a hint of licorice in the end. very enjoyable
Rich and full in color, aroma, and flavor. Tastes of some faint fruit behind caramel and other sweet flavors.

Beautiful deep reddish brown in color, with massive full light brown head. Pleasant fruit aroma.  The fruit aroma carried over with a crisp fruit flavor, followed by some spiciness.  Very well balanced.  The alcohol content is apparent, but not overpowering.   Very drinkable.  I spent $4.50 on a 25 oz. bottle.  Well worth it.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2007 Cloudy mahogany with with big, foamy tan head / Light nose of banana and malt / Medium body with good finish / Flavors of toffee, banana, raisins, and black pepper /  Not spectacular but very good.

750 ml. bottle- color of redish mahogany , with a thick light brown head - nose of malts , citrus hops  , red cherries , deep red fruit , and is bright and clean  taste of malts , deep red fruit , hopps , and red cherries - body silky with a little bite , and it has medium carbonation  aftertaste of fresh dark red fruit , and bitter sweet thing gong on

The color was a beautiful clear, dark ruby color.  The head was creamy and light beige.  The aroma had hints of caramel malt, sweet, nutty, and alcohol. The flavor roasty, dark, slightly bitter, and a very light salty element.  The palate was lively, with a medium body.  The finish was warm.

Aroma:  Dark fruits and alcohol.  Lovely aroma that jumps out of the glass.  Very complex.  

Appearance:  Brownish with hints of red.  

Flavor:  Sweetish malt balance, with alcohol evident, but not overbearing, in the finish.  A little medicinal, and more straightforward than the aroma.

Palate:  Medium body, no astringency or fusel hotness, but a little alcohol warmth.

Overall:  Enjoyable, solid beer.

Bottle. Spicy aroma with hints of licorice, dried fruit and caramel. Bigbubble tan head and very clear chestnut. Sticky palate with good carbonation. Bitter aftertaste with chocolate and licorice kicking in. Finishes with alcohol warmth. Very nice Belgian style ale with good bitterness.
Light tan colored head. Fruity and spicy flavor. Sweet and hearty. Smooth clean finish. A favorite Abbey.
Pours a dark red brown with a with a tan head. The head dies early. I get a hint of some spice and dark fruits in the taste. Full mouth full. Great beer overall

Pours very dark ruby/amber, with hints of brown, and a thin white head. The aroma is of yeast, sweet malts, and spices (cloves, coriander). The flavor starts sweet and spicey and has some fruitiness. The middle has more yeast and more fruit - like candied pears or other soft fruit. There is some caramel and toffee sweetness from the malts. The finish is crisp and a little sweet. Overall, very nice.
wonderful nice amber/ruby red, decnet head, nice rich fruit, citrusy with a great mouth feel, dry finish , slightly creamy
[Bottle, January 2007] Nice light brown head atop this deep burgundy brew. Cherry and wood aroma. Flavor is cherry, smoked oak, and honey. Finish is nice and crisp. Delicious.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of yeast, fruit, and blue cheese.  Poured brown with a hint of orange.  I guess you can all it burgundy.  Big foamy head.  Very good lacing.  Opaque.  Sparkling.  Flavor is complex.  Hard to discern different tastes.  Medium sweet and lightly bitter.  Malty!  Kind of is what it is.  Medium to full body.  Lively carbonation.  Dry finish.  Overall, I dont like Belgian Ales, so take my rating with a grain of salt, but it is drinkable.

Dark brown with reddish tint with a thick head. Very inviting maly and fruits aroma. Ommegangs description is right on the money "layered sweetness (honey, then caramel, then toffee)". I has an aftertaste of raisins. A very good beer and a bargan at $4.99

A dark brown malty carmely beer with a big head and a big taste. There are instructions on the bottle label as to how to pour it. Probably a good idea. Exhibits a pretty alcoholic taste which is not a bad thing. A little too malty for my taste but a good beer non the less.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2007 Ommegang is pretty hefty name for a beer, let alone a brewery. The visual appearance of the label (Serif fonts, the crest) just screams serious beer. Well it is a seriously great example of the Belgium abbey ales.  The commercial description says big, fluffy head and when you pour an Ommegang it does exposes the visual characteristics of great ale; the sort you imagine some bald, chubby Belgium monk pouring into a goblet.  The taste is malty and smooth. Overall, the beer was quite enjoyable and a solid take on the style. Cheers to Ommegang!!!

This is a very exciting beer.  The aroma is very sharp but lingers like dusty rum.  You can smell the high alcohol content very easily.  It pours beautifully into a glass with a thick, fluffy head that doesnt dissapate too quickly.  It tasted much smoother than it smelled, and wasnt inredibly filling like its appearance would lead you to believe.  I thoroughly enjoyed this beverage and am eager to try others by this company.
12oz. bottle.  Large tan head with nice lacing which leads to the brownish ruby.  Aroma is malty, with honey, and some caramel notes.  Full bodied flavor with a light bitter finish.

750mL:  Pours a dark red/brown/black.  Tannish white head, very fine bubbles, creamy looking.  Good lacing.  Very lasting.  Very flowery, alcoholy, surypy sweet.  Strong floral taste.  Dark fruits like plum, and a walnutty taste.  Nutty aftertasty.  Not very alcoholy, which is good.  Not as hoppy or floral a taste.  More malty.  More tempered as it warms up.

Oof, I opened this bottle to celebrate the day we brought my new son home from the hospital, but am finding Im too knackered to do a decent review!  Pours a dirty brown with reasonable head.  Nice beer, complex flavours.  Good for a celebration.  The 8.5% alcohol and sleep deprivation should work well in, oh, about 10 minutes.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2009 A 750 ml bottle priced at $5.85 from the Northcoast Coop in Eureka, California. Deep rich mahogany color with a light brown head, and good lacing.  Nose is very complex, with malts, yeast, honey  apricot, berries, prunes, caramel and chocolate. Flavor is much like the aroma but even more intense. Mouthfeel is rich and somewhat oily.  Dry and nicely bitter finish.   Excellent overall balance. This is pretty inexpensive, and this is really an excellent Belgian Strong Ale.

750ml from Knightly Spirits, Orlando FL. Mahogany pour with a two finger light brown head, good retention. Ratings from combined notes of bottles produced at Ommegang and at Duvel, 04 and 05 vintages, respectively. Aroma is a little sweet, with yeast, wood, apricot, berries, prunes, caramel and chocolate. Flavor is slightly vinous with more concentrated components eluded to by the aroma. Big raspberries, dusty cocoa, prunes galore. Additions include raisin bread and distinct Belgian yeast. Palate is warm and somewhat syrupy. Finish is somewhat dry with some good bitterness forcing its way through. This is a very good strong ale, this breweries best offering, to me. Only noted differences between the two bottles were what seemed tired yeast and less hops from the Belgian originating version. Both were consumed very fresh. Good balanced beer.
Dark red, clear brew with huge foamy head very fruity aroma, a bit grainy and sweet malt. Alcohol taste is previlant, with a burn and a fruity malt flavor. Very dry.

Pours a deep an ruddy brown with a thin film of foam. No lacing. Sweet aroma, with some mild fruit, cork, and a faint scent of port wine. 

The initial sip is a bit on the dry side, with lightly toasted grain and, whats this? Tequila? Yup tequila. Then caramel malt kicks in, and then it is full of stone fruit like cherry and dried plum. It finishes moderately spicy and sweet. Unusual - starting dry and ending sweet.

Medium body and gently carbonated
12 oz Bottle.  Pours a dark reddish color with a than head.  Lots of fruits in the aroma.  Taste is very sweet and coats the tongue, with a lgiht bite on the end.  Very nice.

750 ml bottle poured into a Duvel glass.  Dark cherry red with a tan head.  Plenty of lace.  Load of dark fruit aroma.  Bit O Honey, and Reisin candies.  Flavors of raisins and licorice cover the entire tongue.  Fairly soft palate with some tingly carbonation.  Really pretty damn good.
Clear brown color.  Fizzy white head.  Aroma of dark fruit and malt.  Medium/full bodied. Fizzy carbonation.  mellow dry finish.  possibly my favorite Abbey.

A very strong beer that pours with a nice head.  This rich, dark red bodied  beer has a nice fruit-like aroma and hints of chocolate and caramel on the palate.  One of the few abbey style beers that I really enjoy drinking.
Lots of fruit taste. Color of red wine. Good solid mouthfeel. Some sweetness, but reasonable. No hops.

Blend the label and bottle color together and thats the lovely deep ruby this pours into your glass.  Medium tan rocky head with sweet malty nose.  Chewy like the caramel but in liquid form nice mellow dry finish..........In fact a nice caramel with this after dinner (science project complete) makes this beer just explode your tastebuds.  Try it after a nice steak wrapped in bacon.  Homer says... MMMMM...bacony.
12oz bottle. Pours a cloudy copper/brown with a huge head. Fair lacing. Aroma of dark fruit and malt.  Taste brings in wood. Medium/full bodied. Fizzy carbonation. Finish is sweet with alcohol.

Corked bottle. Awesome abbey ale that is complex throughout and tastes better with each sip. The 8.5% is well hidden and the head retention is amazing. This brewery is worthy of being down the street from the Hall of Fame in Cooperstown!
750 ml bottle.  Cloudy dark amber color, a head that lasts forever, sweet with a wide variety of tastes and 8.5 ABV that will definitely do the trick.  Superb.

bottle . . pours dark/cloudy brown . . like a cloudy newcastle . . aroma is sweet nutty, alcohol, raisin, toffee . . taste is is sweet, raisin, popcorn, toffee, buttery, chewy . . GREAT body to this beer . . very complex . . NO bitter aftertaste . . GREAT beer . . i enjoyed it . . highly recomended!
lots of carbonation...ruby red...slightly murky...cherries, banana, raisins...tasty but not overpowering...yummy

Omme-DANG! This is good stuff. Exactly as it says on the tin, Belgian style but with a bit of a New World twist. Lots of great caramel, licorice, chocolate, dark fruit and chicory flavours abound, fierce carbonation but with a smooth palate, well-hidden alcohol levels and its all wrapped up in a neat-looking package. Aces.

Dark color with amber tint.  Think tan head.  Complex aroma.  Cola, Grape, citrus, wood and alcohol all noted.  Good lacing.  Medium-full body.  Milky, cherry-like with great balence.  Grape=-ike sweetness, with some marshmello(?) and almond.  Nice, complex, interesting.

Very strong aroma right out of the bottle.  Poured a deep burgandy with a medium off white head.  The impressive aroma is fruity, with yeast, malts a little sugar sweetness and wine notes as well.  A little alcohol in the aroma as well.  Aroma becomes richer as the beer warms.  Mouth is smooth and creamy.  The flavor is just as delicious as the aroma.  Caramel malts, dark fruits, yeast, brown sugar and some wine is all evident.  Finishes with a nice alcohol bitterness.  The flavor lingers on your tongue.  This is an excellent beer, I wish I had tried it sooner.
This is an elegant beer.  Surprisingly dark, it is very rich but lightened with vigorous carbonation.

Pours a deep dark brown brew with red hues (when held up to light). Aroma: Fruity/ripe fruit. The head is thick and tan. The flavor is complex, very Belgian, yeast, alcohol, earthy/funky. The finish is where you see most of the alcohol.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2007 Bottle. Tan head huge at first then dissapated kinda quickly.  Nutty honey and spice smell with strong berry and hot flavour.  Heavy feel in the mouth, not as light and lively as other Abbey style ales (Delerium, Duvel).  Packs a punch though and cost effective vs. Belgian Imports.  Horray for American Acheivers!

(750 ml bottle, cellared for 11 mos. after purchase) Malty and winey and good...Pours a clear dark brownish red color with two fingers of pillowy biege head that recedes to about 1/8" and stays. Nice looking beer and surprised how un-cloudy it is. Rich nose of malt, brown sugar, wine, yeast and fruit. Mouthfeel shows lots of soft bottle conditioning carbonation, feels light but full and has a bit of stickiness at the end.  Nice sheets of lacing on the goblet. Flavor is fairly rich brown sugary malt and wine-like (red I suppose) notes, some yeast and sometimes banana in finish. I think cellaring enriched this beer. Nice. Label says this is an abbey dubbel.
Seems like something is holding its full flavor potential back.  Still very nice but doesnt reach a level of elegance.  Decent for the $, too.
Dark red  hazy appearance. A multitude of heavily fruity and malty flavors.

Bottle. Pours dark ruby, off white head. Aroma is musty, fruity, grassy, malty. Flavor is fruit, caramel, grass, wheat. Ive drank this beer since it first came out and I always wanted to like it more, but I just cant.

Sweeet, spicy aroma.  Malty with raisins and plum notes. ..	Dark Brown with Ruby hints.  Rich tall tan head tha crawls out of the glass. .. 	Sweet, vinous, long lasting and complex. .. 	Medium/hvy body.. ..	Tasty Abbey Beer.  Fairly heavy, but quite yummy.
Brown with minimal tan head. Heavily carbonated. Vinious. Notes of cloves and bananas, cheeries, and other fruit. Sweet, then a slightly dry, slightly bitter finish.

Pours a dark red color with a thick tan head. Very pretty looking (gave it a 5). Smells spicy and yeasty with a bit of sweetness. Very sweet tasting in fact it tastes the exact reverse than how it smells. To me it smells much more spicy than sweet. Very fruity and yeasty in taste finishing with toffee. Good beer.
Deep ruby body with a large creamy tan head. Heavy spice and dark malt aroma. Sweet belgian spice flavor with a light fruity background and a touch of caramel.

Lovely garnet colour, a deep, deep ruby.  Thick rocky tan head.  Molasses fruit aroma with a tailend of spice.  A more pungent flavour of alcohol and funk is evident, but the molasses is still a strong foundation.
Fresh aroma. The perfect pint - sustained head untill the last sip, beautiful color.. good example of belgian style ale. Sweet palate, with nice tiny bubbles. Very solid.
Floral with Red Apple and pear aromas. Cloudy color and creamy flavors. Slightly bitter finish.
Unclear bown with fine large white head. Sweet aroma of malts, plums and spices. Sweetness. Rather thin body. Fine lacings on the side of the glass. Dry easy bitter finish
Bottle brewed in belgium.  Pours a clear dark red, with off-white head.  Sweet fruit and caramel aroma.  Flavors of sweet malt, belgian yeasts, fruit, honey, and spice.  Medium mouthfeel.
Deepn intens reddish amber with thick rocky light brown head. Spice, herbal, malt, caramel and yeast. A bit to sweet side, but still nice balance. Medium ti thin body!

12 oz bottle via RegallacMC (thanks!). Pours a dark reddish brown with a MASSIVE head. Nose is mostly fruity esters, strawberries, figs, toffee, and a spice that i cannot put my finger on. Taste is very yeasty, with a strong malt make-up, some figs, and a somewhat chalky sourish finish. it is REALLY hard to put the tadte of this into words...It is interesting and different but i do not think i will finsih the bottle...with the massive head and sourness..i think this bottle may have simply gone a bit bad? Will have to try another sometime...

750mL, no date.  Pours a cloudy reddish brown with a three finger beige head.  Aroma of yeast, powdered sugar, raisins, dust, and apples.  Flavor has the addition of some chocolate and caramel, maybe even a little graham crackers.  Quite well balanced, very little bitterness noted--leans more towards sweetness, for sure, though it has a dry finish.  Moderate carbonation, medium to full bodied.  Quite nice.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: I dont know what it is with the Ommegang brews, but theyve each held a bit of disappointment for me. Comparable to an Abbey dubbel, Ommegang was similar in every way to the style ... except the alcohol presence had a vaguely medinical quality to it that I found distasteful. Other than that, it was a pleasant enough brew.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2012 Deep red/amber pour with nice frothy head.  Aroma is full of honey with a little bit of caramel.  Flavor is nice and complex, some mild dark chocolate and sweetness.  Decent dry finish.  Very good Belgian!

12 oz. bottle at Flat Rock Saloon.  Pours deep ruby with thick beige head.  Surprisingly fruity aroma.  Malty, bready flavor with cloves and raisins also present.  No noticeable alcohol in the palate.  Well done, I continue to be impressed with Brewery Ommegang.

12oz bottle (bonus) courtesy of RagallachMC.  Thanks, Paul!  Pours a cloudy brownish-red appearance, topped by a fluffy tan head; good retention and lacing.  Nose is vinuous, but also smells strongly of green apples and candy sugar; overripe red-fruit sweetness.  Full, chewy mouthfeel: red fruits, candy sugar, licorice (as noted), red vinuous notes, and some roasted malt character; the sweetness is really a bit much, however - like boozy raisins.  The finish is much better: lengthy, balanced, with belgian sugars, wine, and spice.

Sampled at Real Beer Expo (Rochester).  Bottle.  Dark-reddish-brown colour with decent light beige head.  Sweet raisins, dates, and dried fruit on the nose.  Full bodied, a little syrupy.  Low-med. carbonation.  Lots of dried fruit, sweet and malty in the mouth.  A decent example of a style that I dont particularly like!

Great aroma of dark prune-like fruit and toffee sweetness with a touch of peaty earth.  Body is a hazy brown and head is a thick froth of tan.  Flavor is thick and fruity with a big sweet punch.  Alcohol is present but doesnt dominate... just provides a bit of warmth.  The fruit flavoring gives just a touch of a sour pucker midway through the development.  The malt presence has a bit of a smokey/peaty flavoring.  Nicely blended.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle. Light phenolic fruity nose. Cloudy red chestnut, creamy low head. Nutty and spicy base flavor, vineous, barrique, a bit gunpowder, dead yeast. Dry mouthfeel. Alcohols peek through in the aftertaste, fruity otherwise.

dark ass burgundy. beige head. smells fruity maybe overripe bananas. hints of blue cheese as well. taste like cinnamon  raisins honey no licorice or chocolate soem blue cheese in the finish as well a littel smokey taste the alcohol when i swallow but the finish dry.

Huge tannish brown head, like a toasted marshmallow.  Aroma of sugar and fruit.  Taste is a bit malty and spicy, with nutmeg and cloves.  My only complaint is that the alcohol is not well hidden; a bit overpowering.  Still, a good abbey-style dubbel.

750 ml cgaed /corked bottle. Says "Brewed and bottled exceptionally in Belgium"
Nice yeasty, dark overripened fruity aromas, caramel fudge like aromas from the malts.
Nice looking ale, handsome i would say, murky dense brown with a lovelly tight tan head.
very rich deep malty/fruity taste, followed by a very noticable alcoholic strength spicy with some citric aftertaste. Tastes also of darker autumnal berries..even redcurrants come to mind.
The palate was not the strongest part of this beer, though some may like the drying after glow, i did  not, its my preference but i like a slightly more flavourful and wet" finish.
Overall a good beer..i was going to say for an American Belgian style..but then its brewed in Belgium..whatever its a good beer and very good value at $4.50 a 750.

Bottle. Paired with a NY style pizza.; an unbeatable combination. Pours actually quite dark, with a nice head. The aromas are dominated by spices (cloves?) and yeast. Flavors of yeast, bread and malts. Quite complex.
dark beer with little ieces of sediment smells of malt and molassas. taste of dark chocolate a little bitter, yes that licorice is presant. maybe some anise, good beer

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2006 Pours a deep amber/brown with a nice tan head. Beautiful full fruity bouquet in the aroma of sweet dates and toffeeish malt. Full, creamy body. Fruity flavors of berries, raisins, prunes, toffeeish, dark caramel, yeast, slight nuttyness, wood and a peppery alcohol touch. Has the perfect bitterness in the finish. Nicely balanced, complex, well done Belgian style beer by Ommegang, right here in NY.
Corked 750 ml bottle. Dark brown color and mininal brown head. Malty smell an alcohol taste.

750. ENormous tan head towers over what little beer is visible during the pour. FInally makes way for a dark ruddy brown brew under a big, fluffy, rocky head. Gorgeous. Mild caramel sweet malty nose. Gentle attack, light-medium body with low-ish carb. Easy sweet malt flavor, too; everything about this beer is understated except for the head. No finish. Great stuff, light on the boldness.

Bottled. Thanks to Probiere. Dark amber coluored. Unclear. Dense light brown head. Sweetness, fruits, spices, alcohol and chocolate in the aroma. Quite intense. Flavour i s a bit more bland. øfuirts, vanilla, liqourice and dades. Light cocoanotes. Medium bodied. Alcohol and fruits in the end. Quite good.

The pour here is beautiful:  a fantastic deep red bordering on brown with a significant white head that lasts and lasts.  In the nose I get some dark fruits with a nice yeasty undertone, as well as a significant amount of spice.  Taste is much the same, with dark fruits making a first act appearance and then slowly fading way to candi sugars and Belgian spice. There is a subtle note of alcohol here but nothing you wouldnt expect from an 8.5. On the tongue this beer is surprisingly perky but still manages to have a richness to it.  Excellent ale.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2007 Re-Rate. Pours very dark ruby brown with a big creamy tan head. Aroma is full of dark fruit, hints of cherries, some nice spicy overtones, pronounced notes of caramel, and a bit of anise. Flavor is dryer than expected, and very pleasant.  Nice light fruit mingled with notes of chocolate and anise. Palate is medium, with a dry and slightly spicy feel. Great brew from Ommegang. Cant believe I didnt give this a higher rating the first time. Original Rating 5 4 6 3 16

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2006 750 mL bottle.  Poured a burgundy-brown color with moderate white head.  Aroma is yeasty and has winey presence.  Flavor has a wine/oak start and a dry, slightly sour finish.  For some reason, I remember being more into this when I had it in a 12 oz. bottle about a year ago, so Ill try it again to make sure.

If you like dark Belgians in general you will probably like this one. It is very typically Belgian-dark in its attributes (in my experience) yet above average as well. Pours out with a substantial tan colored head. In your glass it looks amber but when held to the light it has a ruby/copper glow to it. A great appearance. 

The smell instantly gave me raw sugar. It has (again Ill say) very Belgian strong, dark characteristics in the smell. It is that, somewhat sweet, sparkly light (champagne of beers) attribute. Second I got the smell of toffee and subtle fruit undertones.

The taste is malty fruity and light. This is a unique and confusing taste. I LIKE THAT! It tastes like sugar but it is not sweet. I concurred with another BA friend that it is the dryness of this beer that troughs you off. Similar to champagne (which may be sweet) the sweet taste is only right up front, and then its the dryness that you notice. So it does not drink like a very sweet beer. The mouthfeel is very light, and crispy with an intriguing fruity after taste. It is very carbonated so you feel the tiny bubbles on your tongue. It is a quite refreshing beer.

It is very guzzleable. Its remarkably easy to put down, maybe because of the light refreshing mouth feel or maybe because of how light the beer sits in your stomach. Regardless, if you are looking for a beer that youll hardly notice, that wont get you full or sit in your stomach this maybe the one you looking for. I would definitely consider this beer to be Recommended. 

Hope this is helpful. 
Cheers!

Auburn pour with froth billoy head that decides to hang around a bit afterwards. Tastes of a light dopplebock, with hints of raisins and prunes with a sweet finish. slight bitterness on the outside of the tongue, but a generally smooth mouthfeel. Some extraordinary malt character in that dark copper glass, with apple hints on the nose. Intentions on the tip of the tongue contain a sour bite, but rests in the mouth with subsequent sips. Not a bad belgian Strong, but I prefer their Rare Vos more-so. (Bottle Pour 9/1/2006)

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2007 Cold 750ml bottle:  Pours a clear dark reddish amber with a foamy light tan head.  Aroma is of of fruit and caramel. Very complex ale.  Fizzy on the tongue.  Taste is of sweet malt with notes of licorice and chocolate.  Long unpleasant aftertaste on the tongue.  Eh.

Poured burgundy with a pretty good sized white head. My first impression was a metallic aroma which turned me off and lingered in the back of my head the entire beer. The flavor was carmelly, a lot of fruity esters, and some alcohol. This wasnt bad, but definitely not one of my favorite belgians.

12oz bottle.  Aroma:  Dark fruits(currants and dried figs), great caramel aroma, yeastiness, anise, slight coffee, and a nice earthiness that blends with the yeast.  Appearance:  Deep copper bordering on brown and just slightly hazed.  Light tan head was full and looked like shaving cream.  Really nice lacing.  Flavor:  Lots of dark fruit, caramel, and candi sugar initially.  Melds into a sweet malt/bready flavor.  Some cherry, vanilla, anise, and wood right before the finish.  Alcohol also slips in as it finishes, but is not overpowering.  Palate:  Medium-full bodied.  Medium carbonation.  Finish was dry and pleasant.  Alcohol left nice warming sensation.  Overall:  Tons of fruit in this one.  Really well made and balanced.  Terrific.

750 ml bottle.  Deep, dark brown/burgundy in color.  thin head, but exceptional lacy vs. expectations.  Sugary, toffee/caramel taste . . . more aromatic than fulfilling to the taste.  Certainly a quality beer; somewhat disappointing though, vs. expectations

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2007 Draft and bottle. The alcohol hides so well here. Very smooth flavor with a fruity palate that is not dominated by the crisp flavor. Good abbey strong that would improve in 1-2 years of cellaring. !

Update The nose is just beautiful. Plum, raisin, and berry pastry dance creating a delightful aroma. Sweet taste, notes of honey, plum, dried fruit and berry. An absolute treasure of a beer.
