12 oz. Bottle: This is by far tied for first with Chimay Blue for my favorite Belgian strong ale!  It is murky brown with a fizzy, creamy, stiff head which is maintained throughout the time of consumption.  The head is off-white to tan and clings to the glass in big chunks like a fly to fly paper.  It boasts a strong spicy aroma along with ripe bananas and vanilla.  The taste was more delightfully interesting than the aroma.  I noticed a strong cherry flavor along with alcohol, yeast, prunes and bicycle tire (similar to a fat tire, but skinnier!).  The medium body is not too thick or too thin, just right.  And it leaves a great taste lingering in your mouth beckoning you to try another.  The only problem is, I only bought one!

Dark copper body, frothy tan head.
Rich malty fruit coming out of the Westy glass as I pour. 
Taste is minerally belgian spice, dark fruit, honey sweetness, stale yeast. 
Really good beer. This brewery does Belgian beer well.

Aroma was of sweet -darker fruits.  One of the most lovely pours Ive ever seen.  Id love to have a study done up in such a beautiful dark brown.

Flavour was strong with fruitiness and a nice sweet taste in the mix as well.  A bit dry on the finish.

From a 750 ml. caged corked brown bottle with a blurb along the left side of the front label and serving instructions on the right side, no bottling date I could find, sampled at cellar temperature in a Ommegang chalice.

Poured a elegant ruby hued brown with a foamy tan head that settled into a thin sudsy lacing, very minor amount of sticking.

Aromas of honey and caramel malts, fruity and spicy, with a touch of licorice.

Good carbonation and a crisp, dry, velvety smooth lightish medium bodied mouthfeel.

Delicious tasting and malty at first, caramelized sugar, honey with a light toffee, earthy spices, dark tropical fruits, a nice chocolate licorice flavor, the alcohol is well masked and provides a smooth warm in the palate, and a dry yeasty and malty finish with a flavorful licorice lingering in the palate.

This is a really nice Belgian dark ale, tasty and balanced, well worth trying.

Almost the best thing coming out of ommegang other than their three philos. The ommegang is a big ass load in my mouth. Its a complex fish with enough room to breath in a tiny fish bowl. I guess what I mean is the sweetness does not over power it full flavor, and at the same time the taste is not washed away by maltiness. I love you Ommegang Ommegang.
Dark rich black brown color with a beige long lasting creamy head. Deep sweet caramel toffee smell witha floral hint. Taste was sweet and full of caramel and chocolate flavor.

Poured from the bottle a rich mahogany with a big brown head. Aroma was sweet dark fruits, malts, yeast, and a touch of chocolate. Flavor was sweet malts, with some cherry and prune notes all of this finished up with some caramel/toffee flavors. A great beer.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2007 Dark molasses-brownish pour.  Nice smell of fruits and sweet malt.  Upfront taste is sweet and settles into a very wine-like sour taste that Im not a big fan of.  Not nearly as well balanced as other strong ales, but nice to try.

Really nice reddish mahogany color.  Generous foamy, frothy head.  Aroma of fresh strawberries, some maltiness, some general fruitiness.  Rich, predominantly fruity flavor, with undertones of malt, yeast, caramel, toffee, roasted nuts and grains.  A fizzy brew with a crisp and dry finish.  Solid beer, easy to get, easy to drink, awesome overall.

Bomber.  Pours very dark, with nary a head to speak of.  Aroma of molasses, plums, raisins, chocolate, and perhaps coffee.  An imperial stout keeps coming to mind.  Flavor is a bit sweet, with the dark fruits and molasses coming through.  The flavor seems to be a bit thin after the aroma - however, this could be that I was expecting imperial stout-like flavor after the aroma.

The first thing about this beer is the strong fruit smell, which is not appealing to me.  It hits you before you even pour.  It pours a deep dark brown with a thick sudsy tan head, that for me took forever to disappear.  But the flavor was great.  Tasted slightly sweet, with some subtle fruit undertones.  Had a marginally bitter end.  Couldnt pick out any alcohol flavor, which was noted in some other peoples comments.  Very good beer, even lacking the bitter hops

Deep brownish red with a thick tan head.  Aroma is sweet, chocalate, some vinous notes.  Flavor starts out with sweet, tofee flavors, and moves to more fruity raisin/ plum flavors as it warms.  bitterness is low but present, and the finish is long lasting.  nice warmth from the alcohol, a it thin on the palate.

Bottle (12 oz.) - Pours mahogany brown with thick foamy tan head.  Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of raisins, plums, and some cherry.  Palate is a touch on the thin side, but pretty smooth with a fair amount of carbonation.  Upfront taste is spicy with some subdued hoppiness and alcohol.  Follow through is much like the aroma with malt, raisins, plums, and some cherry without the sweetness.  Aftertaste is dry with notes of alcohol warming, malts and dark fruit sweetness balanced out by some spicy hoppiness.  Overall, a very complex beer with many layers and a lot of flavor.

Head is a frothy coca-cola color, which is average size and mostly diminishing.  Lacing is good, body is clear, dark raspberry/mahogany.  Aroma has roasty malts, estery(citrus, banana, cherry, plum), phenol(clove), with notes of alcohol, cherry, and plum.  Flavor and aroma are very complex.  A medley of esters(plum, artificial cherry, lemon), malt(bread, caramel, toffee), and alcohol warming.  Palates body is full, with a soft fizzy carbonation.  This beer has a bitter finish.  Overall I think this is a complex enjoyable beer, but would only appreciate it every once in a while.
Superb color.  Beautiful head, like warm coco.  Strong and complex.   A little  wine-like for my taste, but high quality.

I really got into this one last summer (2004) after a trip to the brewery in Cooperstown. Star anise. Lovely stuff. I even drank it up against the likes of the "so called" best Belgians... still like this one better.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with a medium brown head. Prun, vanilla, dark fruits aroma and taste. Medium to full body with a dry finish.

Poured from a 22 ounce bomber to a amber brown color with a thick tan head and great lacing. The aroma was that of malt and nut early, but as the glass watrmed, the aroma became more dark fruit and a more noticeable alcohol. I was not impressed with the finish at first, in that it was slightly watery. However, as beer warmed at mid-glass, palte was much more full and smooth, and the alcohol gave a warming sensation on the way down.

Bottle.
Cloudy red brown coloured with a beige head.
Sweet aroma of plums, dried fruits and spices.
Flavour of plums, dried fruits and spices.

Bottle, dark brown with red tones, aroma of malt and yeast, I get a strong taste of malt and alcohol with a with a soothing sweetness.  for its style its a good beer although im not a fan of a lot of malt or yeast.
Nice smell of fruits. Ok body, poor head. dry finish. Very disapointing considering the attractive bottle and description.

A Mes rate: 
Yet another bottle that Sim purchased in the states. Gouden Carolus type aroma. Sweet, fruity and alcoholic. Glorious appearance. Flavour is just like the nose. Reasonably complex and well balanced. Very spritzy palate. Bitter finish that doesnt quite live up to the rest but damn good stuff overall.

Sweet aroma, cereal, malt, some fruit and yeast.  Pours a very rich brown, a beautiful beer to look at.  Sweet, malty, notes of spice, caramel and brown sugar.  This bottle was actually brewed in Belgium, Moorgat Im assuming, but i will admit i do think the American version is a little more complex, both are excellent though!

Corked and caged 750. Brown-orange pour with a big foamy beige head. Sweet, yeasty malt nose, somewhat fruity. Caramel and brown sugar notes. Lightly sweet fruit and spice flavors transition to a peppercorn dry finish.

Ommegangs namesake beer is a good beer considering its made in the states.  Rich, subtle, and surprisingly good.  Ive had it twice now and it hold up to its imported cousins rather well.  I would definitely recommend it to any Belgian enthusiast for comparison.
Red-brown color with off white head. Not to much in the aroma. Carbonated. Alcohol is hidden well. Very complex taste

UPDATED: OCT 1, 2006 Burgundy, small off-white head, no lacing.  A rather complex beer despite its weak aroma.  At first its all about the caramel and candies sweetness, but soon spices and some sour notes (cherries) are added and then the caramel moves aside to leave room for the spices and it all ends with a peppery finish.  Highly carbonated.  The rich body and complex taste hide the alcohol very well.  When transferring my handwritten notes I wondered why I didnt rate it even higher.  Ah well, perfect excuse to try it again.
Dark amber with big head. Aroma is slight sugary with notes of dried fruits. Flavour has fruit, caramel and a touch of anise and choclate,  The finish is long and pleasant.

Bottle - 355ml. Cloudy brown body topped with an average beige frothy head. Wonderful malty aroma with vineous, plummy, and yeasty notes. Taste is robust and very well balanced. It is dominated by maltiness and fruitiness, but also carries nutty, toffee, and yeasty hints. Leaves a long, dry, and warming aftertaste. Wow!

Oh my gosh, Ommegang! 2 for 2 with this brewer. In fact, I liked this one as much as I liked the 3 Philosophers. Poured a dark ruby brown color with a large pillowy head (although the lacing was short lived after each sip, leaving behind a clear / clean glass). The flavor was spicey, sweet (candy sugar), malty, nutty, and banana-like. Dark fruits detectable in both the aroma and flavor. A very nice American version of a Belgian strong ale.
Bu au Mondial de la Bière sous le nom de "Abbey Ale". Rousse super foncée, beau collet. Arome légé dépice. Goût épicé réchaufant et légèerement caramelisé.

Spicey banana aroma, dark amber color,medium head, probaly the smallest Ive seen on a Belgian,malty slightly tart fruity taste, with some sweet carmel in the middle, and then a dry bitterish finish. Well made ,but pretty far down on my list of Belgian favorites
Lovely beer. Very Belgian.  The taste almost reminds me of candy circus peanuts.  One of my favorite easy access beers.
12 oz bottle - Pours a cloudy brown color with a nice off white head.  Aroma and flavor are spicey and fruity (apple).  Nice smooth bitter finish.  Medium body.  Good beer.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2006 12 oz bottle. Clear orange-brown color with thin off white head. Complex aroma. Suprising mix of molasses, anise, nutmeg, and raisins. Malty, slightly sweet, and effervescent with a touch of alcohol. Excellent beer.
Very nice aroma, hints of fruits and spices.  Strong ale but went down smoothly.  $5 for a 750ml bottle, will definitely get this again.

sweet fruity aroma, pours beautifully - nice off white head and deep leathery color.  Big flavor, very complex palate.  Good sipping beer, warming and bitter finishing dry and bitter.  this would have scored higher for me if the finish was half as good as the start.

Dark brown, cloudy body with some reddish highlights. Head is full and is a very, light-brown color. Its a typical abbey-style with sweet sugars, dates and yeast but there is also pineapple and spice in the nose. Taste is pleasantly balanced. Malty sweetness, a little chocolate, followed by generous hops. Mouthfeel is medium-thin and not silky. Aftertaste is raisin,  coffee and alcohol. This is a very good beer.  A must try.

Fruity aroma.  Dark , opaque.  Long lasting shaded dense head.  Fruity cherry like taste.  Smooth with just a slight bitter aftertaste.  Medium bodied with lively carbonation which belies its appearance.  A wonderful Belgian Ale brewed in the good old USA.

thick, tan head, good lacing. drying on the tongue. smooth with just a little weight. would prefer a touch more carbonation. raisiny, sweet flavor, hint of brown sugar & prunes. slightly sour at finish, beautiful claret color, warming by the fourth sip, alcohol well masked

aroma of carmel malt that smells rich, remenicent of barlywine.  deep burgundy color with light tan head.  Flavor was of rich malt, notes of chocolate, after taste of slight cheese, yeast is present.  Nice feel in the mouth, full with fine  bubbles.  Pretty decent beer and was only $3 at the pub

750 ml bottle obtained in a trade I think with Beeryum - Mine was cave aged in Howe Caverns according to the tag.   Not sure how much that helped but it was pretty good.  Poured dark copper with a big fluffy tan head that stayed pretty well.  Aromas of caramel, candi sugar, yeast, and raisins.  Flavor is caramel sweetness, earthy yeasty notes, raisins, plums, roasted malts, and sweet candi sugars.  Palate is smooth and creamy but oh so sticky sweet.  Delicious stuff.

Best beer Ive had the pleasure of enjoying in a long while.  Between the pop of the cork, the wonderful fruity aroma, and its beautiful color with a rich foamy head - I think I liked it before I even got to taste it.  Oh, but it doesnt stop there.  The flavor is where this beer really shines.  Very complex and distinct...but not in a "hey, lets try to make a complex beer" kind of way.  Every flavor perfectly complements the next.  I could drink this beer all day long.

Pours dark amber with a pillowy tan head that sticks around for some nice lacing.  Aroma has dark fruits, caramel, earthy yeast - overall a sweet rich impression.  Mouthfeel is thing and rich with frothy carbonation.  Taste has most of what was predicted from the aroma - dark fruits (black cherries / plums), the earthy yeast qualities and caramel malt.  Creaminess to the taste.  The finish has some sourness to it - that is my only problem with the beer.  Overall a very nice beer and an excellent value for the money.

Carmel colored head with good lace and tight foam.  It is more of a sipper, with the flavors capable of overloading your tongue.  A good beer for a cold day, drinking more like a red wine than an ale.
bottle .. ruby colored pour ,thick tan head with good lace . aroma of spices and citrus . pleasant fruit and a bit sour but smooth . medium mouthfeel and a dry finish ...nice brew
Color is more brownish with hints of burgundy with a huge, tan head.  Nice blend of spices, a bit of apple, chocolate, and toffee.  Finish is truly dry and balanced.
UPDATED: APR 27, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours  brown with an off white head. Aroma of citrus, spices, and fruit. Flavor is smooth, citrus, and maybe a little over carbonated.

A very good, fruity beer.  Dark color and powerful aroma.  I could taste the yeastyness mixed with the subtle overtones of apples and what seemed like grapes and pineapples.  I recommend this beer to anyone wishing to try a good belgian beer if chimay is not available in your area.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: Deep brown, opaque cloudy body with medium tan lacing head.  Vinuous caramel arona.  Flavor is OH, vinuous, light sour.  Medium palate.
A wonderful dark, rich and creamy head. Notes of caramel and dark fruit. A sublte hint of sourness but fades fast and finishes slightly dry.  A really nice beer that is very drinkable.

Subtle aroma of caramel and baking bread. Flavor is well balanced with no rough or sharp edges. Slightly sweet with warming alcohol and some grain flavor, like a touch of unfermented wort. Dangerously drinkable with a a dry finish and none fof that hop phlegm build-up common in other American beers of this style.
Very interesting ale.  Beautiful burgandy color and hints of cherry.  Similar in body to other belgian ales but has a unique flavor.

Aesthetically this is one of the too beers in the world I think.  Beautiful burnt orange ruby pour with a huge rocky head  that is still in the bottom of the glass when the beer is finished.  Slightly floral, slightly funky aroma.  Dry floral mouthfeel and medium bodied.  Yeast and some licorice flavor not as rich as I was expecting but still good and the whole bottle dissapeared fast.  At 4.79 a bottle this is an absolute value.

Bottle in the bar of the Back Bay Hilton Boston where we stopped Dec 05 there is a fantastic range of bottled beers in this hotel bar. This really was a superb beer dark deep reddy/brown colour med head loads of fruit and caramel and toffee tastes mmhhh smashing stuff this, wonderful.

This is a really good beer.  It reminds me of Duvel a LOT.  Its not as rich as Duvel, which may give it an edge.  It has the same caramel and toffee notes, which slam your tastebuds with ecstatic delights.  An ale among ales, this one should be drunk slowly and enjoyed.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2007 Same rating for cave aged and not. Pours mahogany into a tulip.  Well retained, medium-sized head.  Cherry and bread notes.  Full with spicy cherry/vanilla and fig flavors.  A dry, lingering hay finish.  "Burgundian" is a very good descriptor.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2011 12 oz bottle.  Dark garnet brown with a smooth, dirty-tan, custard head.  Settles to a skin.  Strong banana; mango, cereal, toffee and currants.  Smells good enough to drink.  Starts bitter with a good fizzy mouthfeel then smooths.  Just the slightest sweetness behind some lime.  Dry celery aftertaste.  7/30/11 - 25.4 oz bottle, cave aged March through September 2004 then to my cellar.  Nose is wet oak, cedar, pine and stale raisin.  Medium body with a tingle.  Taste is plum, portabellas, green olive and brown bread.  Richer with age but loses points for aroma.

Poured from bottle into shaker glass. This one had a cloudy caramel color with a profuse, dark, creamy head.  Aroma was yeasty, yummy, and of dark fruits.  Flavor was crisp and tangy, and hid the substantial alcohol well.

Very dark ruby. Thick, tan, cottage cheese head. Nose of rich malt, dark fruits, lively yeast, caramel, subtle alcohol. Same flavors joined by some roasty, bittersweet chocolate and licorice. Doughy, roasty, dry finish. Full body is a bit heavy on the carbonation. Great brew.
Great beer, and sold in Lake Placid at Rite Aid for $4. Yum It has a bit of bite mixed with a bit of sweetness. Has a pleasant aroma, although not among my favorites from this brewery.

Im starting to wonder about my rates.  i have had this several times and i know i have rated it, yet there is no check mark?  hmmm? if you ever get a chance go to cooperstown in the fall and check out this place, it is quite simply one of the most beautiful places beer is brewed.  this beer is a bit disapointing for me.  more of a rock candy gig that is overpowered by the malty side kicks of this fruity fig likness.  i have some aging so ill have to try it in a bit.

Dark red color.  Has a fluffy tan head.  This has a stron taste of plum and rasin.  A bit of dark candy sweetness.  I found this to be bold wit an alcohol dryness and some subtle hidden complexity.  Very suprising for an American microbrew.  I think Ill be sampleing this again in the near future.

This has an aroma infused with: fruit, yeast, roasted nuts/grain, caramel, malt, wheat, and toffee.  It is mahogany in color with a thick light brown head.  This rich beer moderately thick as it introduces itself with the tastes of wheat, yeast, and prunes/dates.  The palate is also able to detect hints of fruit and nuts just before swallowing.  The burnt biscuit aftertaste is mildly bitter.
Deep burgandy.  Big, off-white, almost tan, moussy head. Subdued, fruity, honeyed aromas.  Deep, dark malt tastes with chocolate overtones.  Relatively dry-finish and nice body.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2006 Re-rate (12-5-06):
Dark brown almost completel opaque body with three fingers of head that slowly dissipates.  Smells chocolatey with some fruit and alcohol notes.  Tastes fruity, maybe of grape with a little citrus with more chocolate at the finish.  Rather well-ballanced between the two.  Alcohol, while present, is not very noticeable.  On the higher end of medium-bodied, with a pleasant silky smooth texture.  Definitely a sipper, but very enjoyable, especially for cold late fall and winter nights like tonight. The alcohol is so well-hidden, it creeps up on you.  An excellent beer, and a steal at 5$ per 750ml bottle.  Fantastic, worthwhile ale.

Bottle poured a clear reddish brown with a lasting amber head. Aromas of dark fruit, molasses and a bit  vinous. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of spices, molasses, and some fruitiness with a smooth, lingering sweet finish.

Side by side tasting of fresh and cave aged.  Very little difference is noted with the fresh being slightly more carbonated with a bigger head and the aged being slightly sweeter.  Both were lovely in the glass with sky high heads.  Aroma was delightful, fruity and a bit smokey.  Taste was sweet and complex and as it warmed, became spicy and even more complex.  A fine example of an Ale.
Dark reddish brown.  Looked like deep wine in the dark, except it was bright in the room, it just looked dark.  Lots of sediment on the bottom.  Slightly thick mouthfeel.  Rich head.  Not too shabby.

25.4 oz bottle, corked.  Body a dark ruby brown with a big brown head.  Aroma of caramel and brown sugar with some fruit.  I tasted caramel, oak, and baking breads.  Very nice complex flavor.  Palate is smooth without being oily, medium thick.  A very nice beer.

Bottle enjoyed courtesy of Rob (Rooftoprogue). Thanks, Rob!  I liked this one quite a bit. Crimson meets brown in the color, and banana and clove meet caramel on the nose. Lots of spices and delicious malt tones in the mouth. Reminded me of a barleywine to some extent. Lots of fig and date notes. Great stuff, one of my favorite Belgians in awhile.

A hazy, burgandy pour with a nice, big-bubble head. Aroma was of apricots and oak. Eaten after an Ethiopian food meal, it battled with the spiciness, and didnt want to win. After some downtime, the ale revealed its toasty side. Stunning-looking in the glass, like a sunset through smog fumes.

Big frothy head with Mike Jordan hangtime. Just the site of it had me drooling.  A rich mahogany sunset that is almost hypnotising. I thought I was in Aruba on the beach at dusk. Has a ballanced flavor profile with slight earth and fruit. Nice dry finish. Alcohol is well hidden. A tasty ale indeed. I highly recommend.

Pours dark burgundy with a foamy tan head. Aroma of plums, caramel, and oak. Taste is yeasty, oak, toasted caramel malts, and rising bread dough. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with lush carbonation. Very nice Belgian style beer.

Pours brown, looks like an orange haze under the light though.  There is a thin but constant head.  There is a dark, fruity, toffee aroma.  It is full of flavor, very rich, tough for me to pinpoint anything really.

Bottle.  Malty belgian special aroma, a little on the nice spicy side. generous fluffy beige head on a super clean full semitranslucent brown beer.  Full of flavor, bittersweet, tangy spice - good and excellent for value.  I drink this on a regular basis now and its kinda sad I cant think of more descriptors, but for the price point and ease of finding it, one of the best things one can get in those parameters.

AWESOME BEER! burgundy to ruby  in color with a thick light brown head...aroma is huge and is of dark fruits, figs, raison, caramel, sugars and spices...flavor takes all of those elements and add many others to create a delicious treat (big in raison, nuts, caramels, spices, sugars, toffee, molasses, and yeast...); add an awesome palate to this great beer

From bottle.  Pours a deep ruby red with thick tan head, that laces quite nicely the whole way down.  Aroma is a nice mix of fruits, mostly cherry and prune.  Flavor follows the nose with some caramel as well, but falls a little short due to a too light body.  Very good for an American entry, and a good value as well.

Bottle.  Pours burgundy in color with a thick and creamy light brown head.  Good lacing all the way down.  Big aromas of dark fruit, some sour apple and some sugary sweetness.  Initial taste of apple juice, honey, then the malt kicks in and there is a richness that includes a little chocolate, caramel and something toasted.  Very dry finish, a little too dry for me.  Carbonated and medium bodied.
really appreciate this beer! a delicious taste that finishes nicely. a very delicate balance of goodness in every sip. to be enjoyed by every true beer lover. comparable to any belgium
[bottle] Pours out looking excellent.. with a wonderful, foamy head. Flavors are spicy, very fruity. Finishes off with a nice caramel and a dry, warming feeling. Very nice.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2006 Very Classy Strong Belgian. A wonderful Brew that you can enjoy all by its lonesome. This Beer has countless hidden flavorings that jump out at different times on your journey. Caramel, Honey, mixed fruit and a hint of chocolate round it off. Solid, a must sample.

The aroma has caramel, honey, plums, figs, raisins, malt, and some yeast. The appearance is a dark red brown with a huge head. The flavor has the above listed elements with cherry and licorice. The aftertaste is sweet and fruity. The palate is just about right. This is quality stuff.

Bottled.  Pours a mahogany color with a tan colored head.  Dark fruits and caramel meld together in the aroma.  Very clean flavor with a sweet, malty dominance.  Raisin notes.  Clean, fading sweet finish.

My first time with an Ommegang brew and they did not disappoint at all. Huge aromas of raisins, figs, plumbs and a spicy character that is near perfect. The first sip and I had a few thoughts of what I could taste and that was caramel, some toffe, said dark fruits and some yeast. Wonderful brew that I will buy again and again as long as its this high of quality.

Deep ruby with a slight brown tint.  It has a pleasant nose of sweet cherry cola, malt, and a little clove.  Crisp on the palate with carbonation and good acidity.  The first flavors to hit are cherry and malt almost like root beer.  The finish is hops with this earthy dankness that sticks on the back of my toungue.  It keeps the beer from being sweet, but is also a bit astringent.  Im going to go ahead and disregard that dank taste, as its a bit unpleasant and Ive had Ommegang several times before and its never been present then.

Thick fluffy head not unlike many in its style.  This one is very complex.  Many flavors hit you all at once.  Shared this with some non Big Beer Geek friends and it was too much for them.  For me though, this was extremely rich and inviting!  I love it!

First pour takes patience.  Head is massive and lasts but finally subsided enough to pour a little more.  In appearance it is such an inviting  and delicious looking beer.Very dark tan with a kind of dirty look to it.  Aroma is of raisen, toffee and a hint of malt.  Very complex and pleasant.  Alcohol content is significant.  Mix that with the size of the bottle (750 ml.) and this is a beer to either drink slowly (too good a beer to do that) or to share with.  My wife hates beer so I had to suffer through it.  I found it to be a wonderful beer, complex, interesting, and delicious.

Small bottle. Dark brown/red, murky thick beige head - looks great.  Nice slightly sweet, fruity, and spicy aroma.  Strong taste at first - some alcohol, some hops, much sweetness and some fruit (plum, cherry).  A hint of spice.  Full bodied, rich mouthfeel. Short dry finish, the first half of this beer is incredible, the second half ends too soon with little flavour.  But overall, a great Belgian Strong, this warming liquid treat was perfect after a long day at work.

Ommegang is an Abbey Dubble by style, and it is very interesting and delicious one. All of Brewery Ommegangs beers are brewed with spices, and Ommegang contains spices including coriander, star anise, and even the rare African spice grains of paradise. The brewery likes to call this a burgundian beer, as it shares many traits of burgundy wine, and works exceptionally well with red meats, game, cheeses, and a number of dishes you would match a good burgundy wine with. 
Ommegang pours to a beautiful, bright, burgundy red color with a thick and creamy white head, and a good bit of carbonation. The nose on this beer is very impressive with lots of aromas of chocolate, malt, estery aromas of fruit, yeast, and peppery alcohol. The palate on this beer is complex and layered with lots of good sweet malt and chocolate flavors, plummy fruit, and hints of toffee and raisin. Ommegang finishes with more of those complex and delicious malt and fruit flavors up front, then ends with some good yeasty and peppery alcohol flavors that linger. 

This is a complex, delicious, very well done example of an Abbey Dubble, from an outstanding NY brewery. At 8.5% abv, Ommegang is the type of beer to share and relax with. As stated, it is an excellent beer to pair with a number of dishes, ranging from a cheese course, to meats, to a rich desert. Marketed in 750ml caged and corked bottles and 12 oz 4 pack bottles, Ommegang is well worth seeking out in markets where it is sold. If you ever find yourself in and around Cooperstown, NY, a tour of this beautiful country brewery is well worth the time and effort to find.
Sharp tangy acidic aroma with a head that starts at about 90% of the volume of the glass.  A trappist ale for sure and quite good.  Finishes with a sour note.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text:
Pours a purplish/brownish (almos mauve) with a heavy haze and a quick but huge tan head. Last dregs of the bottle give the brew a septic look. Doppelesque aromas with rich malts, light sweat & alcohol with a spiciness that is invasive upon the sinus cavity. A fluffy, explosive mouth carries raisin and caramel to a sour, dirty finish.


<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Forest, IL 60452<font size=-1>

750mL bottle.  Deep purple-red with a large rocky tan head.  Biscuit, toffee, estery spiciness, and estery fruitiness in the aroma.  Figs, raisins, caramelized sugar flavors.  Alcohol, cloying malt, and residual spiciness in the finish.  Mouthfeel is medium heavy, rather wet.

"Pour a dark ruby color with a nice fluffy head. Aroma was of dark fruit and spice. Had a spicy taste to it, but still sweet with a little malty taste to it as well. This is the 3rd ommegang i have had and they have it together. what a good beer."
UPDATED: NOV 25, 2006 What a great beer Abbey style from a American Micro brew, Smells of dark fruit and even a little bit of Sake notes. Taste full malty with dark fruit and spices, great beer!!!
almost wine-like in complexity; good mouthfeel, lively carbonation and appealing deep copper/ruby color. Distinct alcohol finish. An excellent value as a US-produced Belgian.
For the price, this is a great value. It has a very complex taste that unfolds easily.  Its not the best Belgian available but it is still better than almost everything out there.

75 cl bottle. Dark ruby colour with a big head. Malty aroma with tones of hops, alcohol, chocolate and some spice. Nice flavour of yeast, spice and sweet maltness. Remind me of a Belgium beer, but I think it is missing something.

750ml bottle - Quality.  This beer poured up a huge, foamy, long lasting head and is a very good looking reddish brown color.  The aroma was sweet and good if a little light.  It tastes malty and fruity with light carbonation.  The finish is pleasantly bitter and crisp with a bit of nice, warming alcohol.  And at four bucks a bottle at my local World Market, its a great deal on a Belgian brew.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2006 A hazy deep red-brown beer with a nice brown head. The aroma is sweet with primary notes of berries, but also lighter notes of yeast and wood. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of yeast, but also notes of wood, prunes, and berries, as well as hints of the alcohol. It is very sparkling on the tongue due to the carbonation, and it ends of with a slight alcohol burn.

(Bottle 75 cl) Beautiful mahogany with a tint of red. Creamy, off-white head leaving some laces. Sophisticated, vinous aroma with distinct alcohol. The body is solid and full with plenty of roasted malt. Sweet, fruity notes - of dried fruit like raisins in particular. Also very warming alcohol in the finish. 291205

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2007 Pours a dark red/brown.  Fruity aroma.  You can taste a little alcohol.  Dry finish.  Reminds me a bit of wine.  Worth having again.

If you stop by the brewery pick up a bottle of the cave aged Ommegang.

750ml corked bottle. Reddish brown with big, offwhite head. Aromas of yeast, dark fruit, and brown sugar. Flavor is mainly subtle sweet dark fruit with a tangy, drying yeast bite throughout. Pleasant carbonation, but all in all the body is a bit thin. Nice, dry finish. Tasty stuff.

This bottled brew poured a very large sized head of foamy finely sized mostly lasting brown colored bubbles thick fair lacing.  The body contained no visible carbonation, was nearly opaque and dark brown in color.  Its aroma contained notes of strong vinous malts.  Its mouth feel had a mild vinous malty bite in the aftertaste.  Its flavor contained mild chocolate vinuous dark malty notes.

Quick falling head, dark red bordering on  brown, but transluscent.  Sweet aroma and not much of a hint of that 8.5% ABV.  Sharp on the tongue as the bubbles dissipate.  Taste is definitely alcoholic with a chocolaty after-taste.  Its a good beer, but doesnt stand up to the acclaim Ive seen heaped upon it.

Pours deep brown with a red tint and a thin tan head.  Malty aroma is weak and has notes of honey, caramel, dark fruits, floral hops.  Flavor is not as sweet as I was expecting - it starts wtih a honey sweetness, but finishes very dry.  Tastes of fig, apricot, cherry, several spices, licorice.  The finish is somewhat bitter and sour, but the texture is creamy  with lively carbonation.  Overall, you get what you pay for.  Its a decent Belgian imitation, but Ommegangs Three Philosophers is much better.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2006 Rerate 11/2006 - Poured from bottle, reddish dark brown with tan head.  I think a few months aging this stuff makes a difference.  Intersting aroma of burnt caramel and apricot.  Flavor bombards you from many angles - raisin, caramel, malt, pepper, molasses, something roasted (okra, maybe?). Alcohol evident in the back of the throat, giving this a brandy-ish feel.  Mellows nicely about halfway through.  No bad  aftertaste, as experienced in 1st review (aging?).  Lacing throughout.  Finished OK - I taste the honey on the last few sips.  This is a well made beer with a lot going for it.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: AUG 25, 2008 This is spot-on for a Strong Belgain style Dark ale or commonly known as a "Dubbel".  Chocolatey, smooth, nice dark fruittyness, and just the right amount of yeast flavors.  An EXCELLENT beer expecially for the $5.50 for the 750 ml bottle.  Half the price of Chimay Grand Reserve but darn near as good...not quite tho. However, I gave the Chimay Grand reserve the highest rating of any beer I have ever tried!!  This is so far the best Belgian Abby style dubbel from any American Micro-brewery except that from Avery known as " Collaboration Not Litigation", it is a tad better.  Ommegang Abby dubble ale competes very well with McChouffe brown , Corsendonk Brown, and just about any belgian dubbel.  MY HATS OFF to Ommegang Brewery!!

Pours dark caramel with moderate carbonation and an impressive, rocky, buttermilk head.

Suprisingly weak on the nose, but with spicy hints of cinammon and caramel malt.  Pretty mild for what Ive come to expect from a Belgian.

Medium heavy body, lightly carbonated, not a lot of kick going down.

Hopped spices and vague fruitiness with a faint hint of alcohol to finish it off.  Really pretty underwhelming for what I expect out of a Belgian.  Maybe Ive just had too many sterling examples recently to be impressed by something thats "only" Chimay caliber. Scored higher overall due to greater drinkability at this price, which can be fully half what youd pay for the average Belgian import

Aroma was unexpectedly subdued. Malt, cherries and other dark fruits. Dark red/brown color. Beautiful cramy, three finger thick head. Cherry in the fore...ever so slightly sour...I think it definitely needs to be served 55+ because the flavors are too subdued just out of the fridge.  Finish is desert dry. Has a nice flavor progession, but lacks flavor intensity and range.

From the bottle, pours a deep red with a thick, bubbly off-white head.  Smells a bit sour, some yeast, some light malts.  Tastes lightly sour at the beginning, some fruits.  Cherries are definitely in there.  Very smooth, and a little sweet at the end.  This is a keeper.

750 mL brown bottle  purchased from Home Service Beer Beverage Discount Center, Glenview, NY.  ABV 8.5%.  Hazy brown ale having a long lasting average tan head with good lacing.  No discernable carbonation. Nice fruity and sweet malt aroma.  Medium bodied that starts with a sweet malt with fruity and toffee flavors and finishes with a sweet malt flavor and tiny bitterness.  This is an excellent drinkable Belgium ale.
A nice reddish ale.  Smooth to drink, stays frech to the last drop,  best consumed at 58-63 deg f, but even room temperature is acceptable.  Will always fill by thirst

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2007 Large white head over ruby/burgundy ale.  Nose off alcohol and malt, and yep Im going with the whiteboard marker descrp. here too.  Taste is somewhat malty and sweet, but mainly astringent.  Smooth mouthfeel. The alcohol seems to dominate too much for its abv.  The palate isnt as weak w/ some cookie dough, more malt, and that damn dry, harsh, gas like linger.  Weird beer, too much hype.  Though might be better if less young, who knows? Besides I dont remember there being a date on my bottle or cork, and that shits just annoying. Unique.

Smells of..... Honey-Malt and sweet prune/raisin.  and some chocolate and cherry.

Has a rich brown and amber color with a light tan head.  The taste is sweet and fruity with a little alcohol kick.  The balance is nice.  it is drinkable.  not harsh and not heavy.  Some faint hop presence in the finish.  A very enjoyable ale.  Ive had better, but I like this.  Ommegang usually delivers
Another sub-par experience from Brewery Ommegang.  I must one of the few belgian fans who doesnt like this brewery.  Oh well, more for the rest of you I guess.

[750ml bottle, 8.0c]
Taste with the guys from Institut de la Bière.
Give me mmmmore! Deep rich burgundy color that begs drink me. Good head and awesome lacing. Chocolate, dark fruit, caramel aroma. A rich flavor of sweet fruits that proves gratitude from being drink. A rich bold taste with a very nice finish of toffee. A true Abbey-Style.
Pours out a deep murky amber color with a huge head.  Flavors is floral and fruity with a bit of sweetness.  Aroma is well... wonderful.  I throughly enjoyed this brew.

Poured from bottle

Pours amber brown with thick frothy white head.  Aroma is like flowers, Flavor has floral and fruit hints, with toffee, flavors. Very nice easy to drink, very smooth.

Pours a murky mahogany with a large white head. Nose is rich with sweet notes of fig and cherry followed by drier tones of butterscotch and toffee. Mouthfeel contains a lot of carbonation and strong alcohol presence. The flavor is very enjoyable with fluttering sweetness of changing character that is reined in a bit by the alcohol. Once again, a very nice Ommegang brew that succeeds in achieving the richness of Belgian masterworks if only to falter a little before a too noticeable alcohol content.

As we walk back from the liquor store, my friend and I often like to read off the label of our latest acquisition as we prepare for a rating session. This time it was long after we had gotten back and established ourselves at the bar of his kitchen, that we were finally ready to actually drink Ommegang. Indeed, the six pack and bottles feature more quotes, facts and stories than the Guinness book itself. I dont know how they managed to fit it all there, its really quite a feat. The pour was nice but nothing terribly exciting: a thick yellowish head towering over the reddish brown liquid. The aroma however was quite pleasant, blending dark fruits and malts. Port wine, plums, figs and licorice held a fine balance with the brown sugar and chocolate base. Some alcohol was noticeable but not overwhelmingly so. As I took my time to analyze the nose, my friend and I would take turns discovering new facts on every part of the packaging. As I finally took a sip, I was greeted with a metallic, salty, bitter flavor that I really was not expecting. I noticed a familiar flavor, reminding of a really bad Rochefort 8 - as if someone took a leak in my beer. I mean Rochefort is pretty amazing to begin with, so that was still quite good. However I resorted to take long sniffs before each tip of the glass as the aroma seems far more pleasurable than the taste. When I finally finished the six-pack I noticed a whole new chapter of text on the underside of the box... Its just too much.
Bottled.  Deep brown coloring with a moderate off-white head.  I got a lot of toffee and chocolate in the flavor with a big hop kick that warms and dries as it goes down.  Very good.

Pours a cloudy brown with a doughy yellowish head that disappears quickly but a foam layer stays til the end.  Taste is nicely balanced between heavy sweet flavors like raisin and somewhat bitter woody flavors.  Like others have said, similar to a dry wine, with some dried fruit sweetness.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2006 Pours a dark ruby color.  Large head that fades quickly resembly a glass of red win.  Aroma is of fig, plum, licorice, and alcohol.  Taste is dark fruit with a dry and spicy finish and a bit of wood taste in the swallow.  Not much alcohol taste but you do feel a bit of warmth.  Pretty taste but there are better BSAs out there.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2007 A warning before you pick up a bottle of Ommegang.  Get something to eat.  Anything, really, so long as you can chew it.  I dont think the Ommegang was made to be drunk by itself.  Having it without food just felt awkward, like the beer was embarrassed of me for having hands bereft of chips or nuts.  Also, you might want to get rid of all your reading material.  Books, magazines, journals, put them all away.  The Ommegang has enough writing on it to entertain you for weeks.  My personal goal, inspired by the loquacious label, is to write my college thesis on a six pack of beer bottles.  Chapter 1 through Chapter 6, legible, intelligent opinions filled with beer!  What professor would give me a bad grade?  We move on.
What is Ommegang like?  Im still asking myself, and havent come up with a good answer.  The beer is dark with a crimson glow, and the aroma has a lot of dark fruits inside, including grapes, plums and figs.  It also has a lot of alcohol in the smell.  Thats a trait off putting to me, but I know others like it.  The beer is probably the most similar flavor to a dry wine Ive yet had; its a strong dry alcohol taste with a beer feel.  Again, it felt uncomfortable, but I think some supplementary food would do the trick.  One of the numerous and elaborate volumes written on the label explains what comestibles go best with the Ommegang.  Id recommend following the instructions, partly because a brewer knows his beer the best of anyone, and also because something needs to tame that pungent wine flavor.  Happy drinking, happy reading.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2006 How funny!  This bottle is cave aged in Howe Cavern ... like the beer cares how the temperature is maintained?  Like it knows if the air is artificially or naturally maintained at a constant temperature?  Surprisingly, I did not enjoy the cave aged bottle as much as my earlier bottles, which seemed much more like a Chimay Blue; this is basically midway between the Chimay and a Belgian Brown.  Color is a dark reddish brown, not as opaque as I remember, with a huge tan head that vanishes without a trace.  Sweet malt, a little dark roast, a little toffee, a little coffee, a little dried fruit ... but somehow all of that is dominated by alcohol and bubblegum; less Bourbon and more barleywine.  This was not nearly as good as I remembered it from several happy previous occasions.  // Rerated, this time with the regular (not Howe Cavern aged) Ommegang.  No change in the review.  Yeah, this is a well made beer.  And yeah, it looks good, but would look better with a little less head.  But I dont get the complexity from this that I would find in a real Belgian.
I buy this once in a while and overall its pretty good...and has quite a wallop. Generally, a little to big for me.

750 ml bottle. Pours a rusty, cloudy color with a thick creamy head that disppeared a bit quickly. Super aromatic. Lots of honey, caramel, and bourbon flavors. There was a background fruit flavor that I could not identify, but one of the other reviewers got it - prunes.  Really good stuff!
bottle-750ml A deep dark red color with a small headthat din not seem to last.Fruity aromas and a sweet honey taste,with a nice finish.A good beer.

12 oz bottle.  Murky and dark burgundy.  Good head and lace.  Aroma starts off very vinous and somewhat metallic (and I sensed a little bit of vinyl), but as it warms, it becomes chocolatey with dark fruits (figs, prune, more grape).  Very vinous flavor, which starts to mingle with some chocolate as it warms.  Mouthfeel is sweet to start and dry with a slight tingle to finish.  Toward the end of the glass, it becomes sweeter and more enjoyable.  Its rather funny, I would never consider sitting down for a chocolate covered prune, but it seems to work in a beer.

Pours dark burgundy, almost opaque.  The head is huge and takes a while to settle.  Aroma of overripe apples and sugar.  Taste is sharp at first, then mellows into sweet malts and the baked apple and honey flavors.  Good enough.

Poured from 750ml bottle this beer appears a burgundy brown. Aromas of honey, "big apple" and caramel blends with a yeasty tone. Taste starts malty with candy sugars, caramel with layers of roastiness followed by a dryer balancing finish. The alcohol is blended well and gives a pleasant warming in the belly. Nice fizzy mouthfeel that is not too sharp. Smooth, aromatic and very belgian for a USA brew.
This stuff and its sister Hennepin is all over the place in NC now that the proverbial "cap" has been popped.  I just wish I liked Belgian style ales better.

750 mL bottle.  Pours mahagony with a fizzy frothy tan head and spotty lacing.  Caramel malt fruit hop nutty roasted malt and cellared yeast aromas with pear notes.  Caramel malt hoppy acidic start, fruit (pear) malt warming body with nutty roasted notes.  Medium bodied and fizzy, dry palate.

Bottle. Cloudy reddish color with a huge frothy off-white head that diminished very slowly leaving good lacing. Good complex fruit and wine aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Good fruity flavor with a sweet finish that had a moderate duration with no alcohol bite.  Very good brew for number 700.

Ruby red and fruity.  Id say more like a wine than a beer, but Id only be indulging wine aficionados.  This is clearly a stellar Belgian-style beer brewed in upstate New York.  Maybe Ive been drinking too many beers lately (if thats possible) but I smelled (among the many layers of honey and fruit sweetness) cherry-limeade.  This was smooth as silk and simply delightfully palatable.  Fantastic!

Revisited this beer last night and thoroughly enjoyed it, better than I remembered. maybe tweaked after the brewery sale?  Lovely looking deep red with inviting head. Bready malt with dark fruit and subtle banana.  A bit spicy and lively, late chocolate, warm, lingering finish. A  great value.

Cave Aged?  Wow!!!!  I think my bottle was refridgerator aged at Holiday Wine Cellars.  But it was still fantastic stuff.  Aromas of brown sugar, molassas, and fruit.  Flavors were very sweet with sugar cane and more maltiness like caramel.  Very tasty stuff.

Cave-aged 750ml. bottle. Cloudy reddish brown color with a nice thick tan head. Nice mold growing on the cork and label.
Fruity, spicy aroma with lots of fresh baked bread and caramel. Flavor was malty, bready goodness with dried fruits, caramel and pepper. While I doubt cave aging had anything to do with it, this beer was marvelous. The fact that it was a couple of years old probably made a big difference. Ive had this a few times in the past but for some reason never rated it. I dont remember it being nearly this good however. Maybe I should go and buy a bunch to sit on for a couple of years.
Lots of fig and overripe fruit flavors here, some spice and a slight metallic aftertaste.  Very smooth for the ABV, a good all around Belgian.

Aroma is the unique highlight here.  Not quite up to the standards of a Rochefort 12, but it is rich and fruity nonetheless.  This does improve somewhat as you reach the bottom of the 25-oz bottle; Im rating basically on the basis of the product in the middle portion.  Carbonation and brown-ale characteristics appear simultaneously.  Mild in flavor, with a soft finish.
UPDATED: JAN 8, 2006 Rich dark red color. Small head. Hoppy with citrus rind flavor and a hint of chocolate and toffee. A bit of a spicy aftertaste.

Small head that quickly dissapates. Very dark red color with a fruity aroma. Very complex flavor of fruit, roasted malt and alcohol.  The yeast doesnt seem as complex as in the abbey ales from Belgium.  Not the best ale in the Ommegang lineup, but good nonetheless
Sampled at Hop Leaf:   Mainly malt; caramel and toffee with a taste of citrus and dried fruit.  I get more honey flavor as it warms.   Alcohol well hidden, but lurking.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2005 This beer explodes out of the bottle -- literally, all over my floor. Before I get to my favorite thing about Ommegang, Ill quickly cover some details: Pours very dark red-brown with a huge, pillowy head, smells like belgian ale, quite carbonated, tastes good. Now, why I give it such a high score: The finish is pure butter toffee! Ive never tasted anything like it. A hint of dark chocoloate, too, but the toffee flavor fills my mouth. I LOVE butter toffee, and never buy it, cuz its bad for you, but beer is GOOD for you, so Ive got an outlet. And at $5 a bottle at Whole Foods, this beer is a steal.

I really like the reddish color and overall appearance of this one.  Malty caramel aroma.  Somewhat spicy, with some fruit and sweetness as well as some chocolate on the back end.  A little bit of alcohol as well, but not close to distracting.  I really dig the high carbonation as well... makes for an interesting drink.  Makes me want to go out and get a trappist glass as a standard pint glass does not do these belgians justice.
I absolutely enjoy this belgian style beer from New York.  It is now available at grocery stores around me!  Nice taste of fruityness.

Nat a bad drink, but I truly thought it was a dubbel until I sat down to rate it.  Cloudy brown with a creamy tan head, it smelled of caramel, brown sugar, and was lightly spiced.  The flavor of this medium-bodied ale  is toffee & caramel with white peppers and a suggestion of chocolate, all followed up by a surge of alcohol in the spicy finish.  Not a complex strong ale, but a good one.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Armanetti, Willowbrook, IL<font size=-1>

Pours a dark reddish brown with a thick two finger head that recedes to a thin layer with nice lacing.

Smell is fruity: plum, a little banana, and some mild cherry. I could smell the yeast a little, plus slightly sugary.

Taste is of dark fruits: plums/raisins, malt, and somewhat yeasty, and mildly sweet, but not too much. I could feel the alcohol much more than I could taste it. Has a very rich and smooth mouthfeel.

This is my third beer from Ommegang, and they are quickly becoming one of my favorite breweries.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: mmm this stuffs pretty good, kind of fruity, a nice red ale, didnt care for the yeasty dregs but read the label and knew not to pour them.

Soapy off-white head with deep burgundy color.  Sweet fruity aroma. Taste is sweet and fruity with a hint of chocolate and toffee.  Fruity cherry-like finish with a very slight hot edge.  This a magnificent beer!

If you like the abbey style ale, the winey taste of heavily fermented beers, then this is the top of the line.  The caramel, the toffee, the chocolate, and the fruity taste are all well represented as soon as you take a swig.  Its an awesome ale!

Reddish brown in color with a nice thick white head that lasts and lasts. Great lacing as well. Very nice aroma is full of fruits like cherry and raisins with only a hint of alcohol. Taste is fruity as well but with a sweet honey flavor and a hint of cherry and citrus. Really a fantastic beer that I can see myself picking up often.
A pepperish nut aroma with a dark burgandy appearance.  Has a bit of spice in front with a sour finish.
Bottled. Reddish brown coloured. Yeasty aroma with notes of fruits. Very sweet and yeasty flavour with loads of caramel and toffee. Extremely high carbonation level.

Bottle. Large fizzy tan head that was mostly lasting, fine-small sized bubbles, lacing was sparse, cloudy, carbonation, and a brown hue. Nose was malty, caramel, sweet, and alcohol. Flavor was sweet, malty, caramel, vinuous, and somewhat dry. Mouthfeel was dry, tingly and vinuous. Medium-full body. An outstanding BSA, very enjoyable and quaffable and the alcohol was not overdone IMO. Scrumptious! If you like this beer style, find it, buy it and enjoy every taste of it!

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2006 Had this one bottled from DeKalb, Illinois.  Cloudy, dark amber color with a thick tan head.  Very complex nose; hints of citrus and other fruits, pumpkin and melon.  Tastes equivalently complex, starts quite cidery and tart, quite hoppy but balanced bitterness, and finishes with bitter chocolate.  Alcoholic in the finish.  Outstanding.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2006 Let me start by saying that I bought a 750 ml bottle of this at Osco drugstore for $4.  Alright, you have to realize that this rating/review is relative.  For I just drank a Rochefort 10.  I know, they are different styles and all.  However, the good news is that I realize that the Rochefort is better than this.  Though, im still not a fan of any belgian beer.  Usually I like american versions of european beers so i hoped that id love this one.  dont get me wrong this one is better than most but it still has that bizarro wood chip taste.  it also has some alcohol taste.  RERATE: This smells like fucking turds.

Rusty orange, thin light tan fizzy head.  Good complexities in the nose with notes of golden raisin, plum, and musty caramel, with lighter notes of chocolate, cherry and spruce.  Rich flavors up front with rum raisin, plum, and caramel leading the way.  Balance comes around nicely late with a decent bittering hop addition.  Full bodied, moderate carbonation, fruity, bittersweet finish.  A top notch American style abbey ale.  A great price point on their brews certainly doesnt hurt either...
Brownish burgundy with a spicy fruity alcohol aroma. Malty spicy, with a good bubblyness but also a small bit metallic.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2007 Pours a dark reddish brown color with a creamy white head.  Smells of dark cherries,plums,spices,raisins,caramel,toffee and yeast.  Taste is faintly sweet toffee/caramel with strong dark fruity flavors.  Black cherries,honey and bread can be detected in the taste.  Excellent overall.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2007 pours a murky brow color with red hues and a large off white - tan head, aromas of citrus,belgian style spices and sweetness, the taste was smooth and sweet, citrusy, & carbonated, a good well rounded beer.

Poured dark brown with red tones and with large, tight, bubbly head. Smelled of citrus tones with just a bit of what I first thought was spice, but more likely astringency from the alcohol. The flavor has no indication of alcohol, just citrus, malts and a good dose of carbonation. It just begs to be picked up and sampled again. As mentioned, this bottle was priced very low compared to many of the specialty beers and it gets extra kudos from me on that point. Will be purchased again.

A muddy brown, opaque brewwith a big, light tan head. This one has been aging in my liquor locker for a couple of years. It was mellow, the flavors had melded to give a medium bodied mouthfeel and a multiple fruit like flavor. No bitterness, no identified taste of hops, the light sweetness is there but is balanced. Very smooth, pleasant with a short-lived aftertaste. When I first tried this brew years ago I was put off by a musty, earthy, mushroom flavor, that was not there at all this time. Perhaps aging greatly improves the quality.

Verre de dégustation (provenant dune bouteille de 750 ml) au Belgium Comes to Cooperstown 2005 (Cooperstown, NY). Arôme: Odeur de raisins, de prunes et de mocha. Apparence: Couleur ambrée foncée. Large col beige mousseux. Faible densité des bulles. Large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de fruits foncés et de caramel. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est plein et la texture mince. Arrière goût de caramel. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. (Rating #237)

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2006 I am growing ever fonder of this brewer. Sampled on draft at the State College beer festival this beer poured a ruby chestnut color with a huge red-tan head. There is a strong sweet candy scent. The body is thick and syrupy. The flavor has noted elements of vanilla, molasses and ripe fruits. There is a mild alcohol burn and a sweet finish.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry & GregClow at Le Select Bistro -- aged approx. 5 years. Pours a lightly cloudy dark red-ruby with a small diminishing off-white  head. Not that much sediment considering the age of the bottle. Complex aroma of fruit, caramel, wine, grain, raisin and much more. Smells wonderful. Very nice, surprisingly smooth, flavour of plum, raisins, spices, caramel and alcohol. This ages extremely well -- I look forward to trying a newer bottle to compare.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2005 Bottle (750ml) (possibly 5 years old) shared with blankboy and GregClow at Le Select Bistro  Poured a fairly dark, murky (almost muddy) peach-ruby with a quick-diminishing off-white head and spare lacing.  Quite a few small white floaties in the glass.  Aroma was intruguing - strong wine (sour), ferment raisins an other fruits dominated on first sniff, then fairly heavy malts, not much hop, heavy yeast - cheese? - and a tang of lime.  Flavour was attention-grabbing - very tart and musty, with strong off-sweet, almost sour malt, some hop and strong yeast bitterness, and evergreen sap in the background.  Very complex mouthfeel, hard to describe - slightly lively, oily and alcoholic, but not really.  The finish was very much of sour wine, but it worked - definitely a senior citizen, but carried its age well, despite the yeast and dregs.  I concur with Greg - I want to try this again with a bottle nearer its prime.

750 ml bottle at Le Select Bistro - shared with blankboy and HogTownHarry. Somewhere around 6 years old according to our server. Pours a dark, murky burgundy colour with lots of little floaties and not much head. Aroma of rich wine/port and fermented cherries. Body is initally fizzy, but softens quickly, and rolls over the tongue very nicely. Flavour starts with a muted caramel sweetness, followed by notes of tart fruit, and a hint of roasted coffee in the finish. Alcohol is really well hidden. Develops a musty, ash-like quality as it warms up. Could be a bit past its prime, but still pretty nice stuff. Id love to try a younger bottle for comparison.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2005 750ml bottle from the Brewery that was hidden (unintentionally) in the fridge since 2000, no lie.  This bottle aged well for 5 years, but I have to admit, I am no ommegang or belgian ale expert, so I dont have much to compare it to.  Very mellow and fruity, a bit flat I would suppose. (7/3/7/4/15)

Rerate (12oz bottle, 2005) -- Nice floral nose and deep brown color, sustainable head.  The beer looks better now than it did after 5 years of aging in my last tasting.  Still a big full beer yet lacking something...

Dark red. Aroma of raisins, fruit, alcohol. One tasty beer that keeps your buds hopping from one flavor to another - the malts, the raisins, the honey. Good balance of sweet and bitter. The 8.5% alcohol is nicely hidden.

Bottle. Dark ruby color, pillowy tan head left great lacing on my glass. One sniff and I get a lot of different aromas, dark fruits (plums and raisins mostly), then a bit of a toasty hint after that. Also a bit of cocoa or coffee, though very faint, hiding in there. Flavor starts out rather sweet, a lot of persistent action on the front of my tongue, kind of a honey sweetness to it. After that the fruitiness takes control, a bit of viniousness towards the middle. Mouthfeel is rich at first, then becomes very dry in the end, though overall the body seemed to be a bit lacking towards the end, the flavors hung around but they seemed a little faint for an ale of this strength. Fairly well rounded flavor makes this a good belgian style, its certainly a contrast in that respect to the Stone VE series (to compare it to a different American interpretation of the style) which are a lot bolder but rough around the edges. As the label on the bottle says, "good beer deserves good food," and it went well with some pork chops hot off the grill.

The cork finished bottle is a nice presentation for this belgian-esque beer, Someone must have been kind of rough with my bottle though. Cork shot out with a huge "pop!" and then foamed all over me, the carpet, et cetera. Once that excitement was over and I got some into the glass, it was a deep ruby/brown, with lots of tan head that seems to start out fairly course and settle into a nice fine skim. Aromas of brown sugar, molasses, figs, banana. Tawny port-like palate, and much chewier than I expect for a belgian-style ale. The sugar additions are  rather evident. Quite sweet toffee flavors. Is that diacetyl? Something there reminds me a bit of Samuel Smiths buttery taste.

This is quite an interesting and distinctive beer for the money, and I admire the enthusiasm of the Ommegang folks for making traditional Belgian styles in the US. To my tastes however, this particular beer was kind of rough. Much more residual sweetness than I like, becoming cloying after just half a glass and covering up any flavor subtleties. A year or two of aging might fix that, and I plan give that a try.
Forgot to rate this back from the Flour City Brewfest last summer.  A very dark brew with a mix hops and malt with a lot of sweet chocolate.  Very enjoyable.
A very nice inexpensive Belgian Style Brown Ale with less alcohol then its Belgian Brothers. HIghly recommended.
This is delicious ale.  A little bit of chocolate and yet fruity. This is a very smooth distintive taste. Dark in body but lighter in taste.  Very nice aroma that smells a good as its sweet taste.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2005 Tried this for the first time about 2 years ago before my palate was defined. Thought it sucked. But now its a favorite. Its highly carbonated, and has hints of dried cherries.

poured a dark fruity murky tannin color with fluffy light brown head.  the aroma explodes with sweet dried fruit and caramel.  the flavor is full of raisin and chocolate.  a wine like flavor character with added malty character.   nice mouth feel.  a great beer.

Mohogany red with a thick inch of head.  Stubborn lacing.  Aromas are nutty, with caramel and toffee as promised.  Fruit (raisin and cherry) and chocolate are more assertive on the tongue, with a lazy toffee finish.  Good long palate, but medium mouthfeel.  Pretty complex, good use of hops, and a malty depth from the brewmaster on this one.  Very interesting.

WTF? Yet another brew I have never rated yet have drank more than a few even before Ratebeer was around. Yo to PhillyBeer2112 who is the 2nd person to have rated it way back in August of 2000! 
From an two year old + bottle: Pours a deep rich multihued brown and copper with a small fading frothy head but good lace was noted. The aroma has notes licorice, currant, prune, hints of caramel and mocha, earthy yeast esters, and a light oxidition notes that works well. The taste starts quite fruity and scores an undertones of belgian sugar and sweet malts. The big part of the palate however is the strong earthy and woody notes that dominate midesection. It is a characteristics that has not changed since the first time I ever had it. The finish has that licorice twang and a bit of honey too. The feel is sharp and biting with the expected warming of the alcohol, always has tasted stronger than the 8.5% to me. While no longer a classic IMO since other American breweries has since brewed better Belgian Strongs, it is still a must try for all ratebeerians.

Bottled.
Hazy amber, large brownish head.
Toffe and chocolate.
A bit sourish, a bit sweetish.
Flavour from dried fruits and almond.
Sweet, tasty aroma of raisin and fruit.  Rich cinnamon red color. Malty taste with quite a bit of fizz and dryness.  Would definitely buy again.
Brown and fantastic.  Spicy, alcoholish, but fine in smell and appearance.  Ima big fan of this guy.  Who knew Yankees could make Belgian better than most Belgians, and at less cost?
Rich burgundy color with a nice tan head.  Aroma is malt, fruit (raisin, plum) and light spice.  Flavor is more rich malt and raisins.  Dry, yeasty finish.  Very nice and an excellent value.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2007 750 ml bottle, corked and caged.  Deep rich brown with ruby and copper tints.  Very malty and fruity aroma.  Toffee, caramel, biscuit malt, plummy fruit, light toastiness, some honey.  There is also some nice dark cherry aromas in here.  Some heavy sweaty spiciness, a little bit of dustiness with some lingering malt sweetness.  Toasty finish with a bit of light molasses and licorice.  Great complexity and well balanced.
Dark fruit aroma, like raisin or prunes.  Nice dark color with a creamy white head.  Flavor had sweetness of dried fruits to it, malt and some spice.  Very easy to drink, medium bodied.

Sampled at le Mondial de la bière 2005. Clear burgundy pour with an offwhite head. Appealing aroma of rich malt, caramel, fruits and spices. Very good flavor of rich malt, caramel, fruits, moka and spices. The body is light to medium with a dry mouthfeel. Excellent stuff.

bottled. 
Muddy, dark amber. Aroma is slight sugary with notes of dried fruits. Flavour has dried fruits, marzipan, residual sugars, has a slight sourish undertone that I fancy, and is a little buttery. The finish is long and pleasant.

Rouge aux reflets brun foncé.  Mousse beige persistante, moyen dégagement gazeux lors du service.  Arômes très levurés et herbacés.  La présence de levure semble assez typique de la signature belge mais possède aussi sa propre identité allant plutôt vers le vernis et le détergent à lessive.  Plus tard terreux, anisé, réglisse noire, poire william, crayon de cire et sucré.  Forte présence de cerises et de vernis en bouche, rappelant aussi une grosse croûte des pain brun biologique pour son côté levuré.  Épaisseur moyenne, carbonatation très active.  Échantillon, mondial de la bière, Juin 2005.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2006 6/9/06: Brown sugar and bready aroma, caramelly, and with a sweetness I asscociate with De Dolle. Kind of beety but sharp, alcoholic and slightly fruity but a very unique smell. The pour is a thick, dark brown with a nice head that fades into a wet foam cap. The taste is bitterly pungent, alcoholic up front, with that same yeasty sweetness mentioned before. It is vegetably and smooth, with a gushy, green, obtuse zucchini finish (I dont know how else to describe it!). Really, the taste is kind of bland and one-dimensional, which is funny as when I first rated this as only my 15th or so ratings I thought the flavor was great. Its interesting how things change and how much ones palate grows. 

6/6/05: Malt, maybe a little caramel in the aroma. Pours a nice full head that quickly deteriorates, but is wonderful and creamy in the mouth. The beer itself is full and enveloping. Chocolaty, dark malt, a bit of citrusy bitterness at the finish, maybe a touch of cherry, with a subtle but lingering warm, malty aftertaste. 5/3/9/5/17

First beer for me from this brewery.  Poured a dark rusty almost cherry juice color, with a dense head.  Smelt of wool, cherries,  and a slight bourbon aroma.  The taste is almost indescribable.  Sour cherries, earthy overtones, hints of alcohol and oak.

Hazy copper red/brown. Creamy yellow head. Aroma from almondpaste with yeasty and nutty hints. Nutty flavour as well, with some caramel notes. Acidic taste with chocolate hints. Thick mouthfeel. Medium to full bodied.
Hazy dark orange with a large tan head.  Aroma of bananas and spice.  Caramel in the palate, very sweet actually.  This is one of their better brews (along with 3 Philosophers of course).

Aromas of caramel, dried fruit (raisins) slightly vinous.  Rich brown color with a nice off-white head.  Sweet caramel, brown sugar, dried fruit, something seems a bit disheveled, tasty but not blended very well.  Creamy, medium full and sweet.
Cloudy reddish color.  Smells like kitty litter.  Fizzy like soda but a nice taste with malts and sweet stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2008 Sweet malty aroma with a hint of wet dog, this is a coudy red sauce with a large dimpled creme colored head. Taste is fizzy (with all that entails as a taste), somewhat bitter, and finishes with a bit of carraway seed, essence of beet, and a hint of chocolate. Not at the top of my list. $6/22oz

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2006 Picked this up at a 6 pack shop in PA in a 750 for $5.50 (which I thought was a good price since the place I got it from tends to be pricey).  The caramel really came through in the aroma on this one.  My brother in law had a Chimay Grand Reserve when I had this one and they were very similar in appearance. The Chimay was a little smoother. The Ommegang had a bit more fizz to it yet overall you could tell they were going for a similar thing. 7-4-7-4-17

Re-rate:  Pours a red amber with an average tan lacing head.  Aroma was vineous, caramel and dark fruits.  Flavors of the same, slightly bitter.

Christ,as soome as I opened this the aromas of Ripe bananas and spice bitch slapped me,Man awesome.Lots of candy in the buttery sugar form aka caramel.Heavy carbonation on the tongue which fizzles some of the flavor away but still this brew is pretty descent with the yeast strains and malts producing lotsa fruity sweetness.

750 ml fresh bottle. Cloudy amber color with a decent sized head. Nice aromas of dough, grape peel, toffee and caramel. Taste is smooth with the right amount of carbonation. Flavors of chocolate and banana, bubble gum and caramel. Wonderfully complex a much different beer fresh than aged. Both are good.

One of my favorite, easily accessable (at least in NY state) brews.
Looks beautiful, smells wonderful, tastes rich and lovely...
I always keep an eye out for this one.

750. Pours cloudy scarlet with a creamy, fluffy blonde head. Spicy, earthy aromas: lemon pepper, honey, clay dust, bubblegum, pipe tobacco, green bananas, and ...pomegranate maybe? Soft, spicy flavor starts with medicinal/smoky phenols and becomes ann odd cacophany of dried mint leaves, hay, freshly-dug earth, wood, apple seeds, and hot vinyl. Fluffy, cottony, and tingly in the mouth. Dry finish with aftertastes of anise and cantaloupe, and eventually low-fat milk. Far from "rich, fruity" as the label claims. Complex and strange. The more I drink, the less I like it.

750 mL.  Poured a cloudy burgandy color with a well-retained 1/4" head.  Beer was well-carbonated, and the flavor was composed of dark fruits and Belgian yeast.  Some other spices were definitely present, and the mouthfeel was lively.

Raisins and figs and lots of brown sugar/syrup flavors.  Some chocolate.  Rich cherry-brown with a voluminous head.  Yeast notes and malt dominate the nose.  A sweet, lush treat of a beer.  Cant believe I waited this long to try it.

Bottle: Poured a burgundy lightly hazy color ale with a huge light brown head with perfect retention. Aroma is malty with traces of spices (pepper with a touch of cinnamon?). Taste is very enjoyable with a mix between some nice floral malt and some sweet dry fruit (raisin). Body is full and alcohol is well hidden. Very enjoyable and probably the best I had from Ommegang.
Sweet aroma of licorice. Burgundy body color with a big tan head. Head settled to a small one on top of beer. A rich sweet flavor to it that was good on the palate. A good beer.

On second tasting, was very impressed with the depth and diversity of this beer.  It combines the coffee flavors of a good stout with fruity and malty overtones and solid flavor depth.  This stuff held up to buffalo wings and kept its personality intact.  An excellent job by the Belgians of Cooperstown.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2010 750ml. Served at 47° in my NB worthy glass. Dark red color with an off white head. Foam spots appear on the side of the glass and a swirl leaves a coating. The aroma is yeast, raisin, plums, some spice (cinnamon?). The beer has a very nice nose. The taste is dark fruits, spice, with some hops at the end and plenty of malt.  The mouthfeel is nice, but not great. I would have liked to see some more sediment and a little more complexity. I might have to cellar one for a while, and see how that changes it. RETASTED at 59.5° Like most big beers, better when a bit warmer.    ADDITIONAL NOTES. I rated this a 3.9 originally, but this is a beer I enjoy each time I have it. Lets give this beer the score it deserves.

750 ml bottle into tulip glass.  Rich murky golden/reddish brown in the glass with large dark taupe head thats rocky and fluffy.  Smells of yeast, banana, plum, sweaty socks.  Medium bubble lacing is not too sticky.  Prickly hops add nice counterpoint to the cookie malt flavors with notes of golden raisin, spiced apple, and dark cherry.  Finish is kind of lackluster, the flavors just trail off; its almost dry, with a distinctly spicy character (oregano, basil, black pepper).  Somewhat salty.  If the finish were better, this would be a great beer, but as it is, its just really good.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2005 Pours a deep auburn read with a huge amount of froathy tan head. Aroma is yeasty, apricote, and very sweet - almost caramely.  Flavor is sweet and smooth, with some creaminess to it with some fruit and alcohol undertones.  Warming slightly bitter finish.  Overall, I really really enjoyed this beer.  Price on it was very reasonable - under $5 a bottle for a 750ml.

pours a dark copper hugh w/ a large fluffy thick off white head carbonation
bubbles float slowly up the bottom.  head laces well
scent is initialy strong but fades smells of sweet sugars syrup maybe malts tiny hint of a weak bitterness.
palate is well carbonated coats ok mildly creamy
taste is very sweet typically belgian alcohol comes through clearly malt presence
A pretty decent beer but not the greatest.

Thanks Chuck!  I helped sample this sub $4 beer.  It has a thick bubbly tan head that doesnt disapate atop a dark brown/mahogany body that is rapidly bubbling like champagne.  I wished more beer looked like this.  The aroma is a bit light.  Hints of light toasted malts and lightly acedic (perhaps this is licorice).  Dates are hiding under there.  The flavor is of toasted malts, a little caskiness, some really ripe bananas.  The flavor lingers.  Medium bodied beer with a huge carbonation.  This carbonation kinda kills the flavor.  Perhaps I just wasnt in the mood for this beer or we got a bad bottle?  I thought the aroma just wasnt there.

(Bottled) Dark, opaque, reddish brown color with a medium, beige head. Very strong rye-pudding aroma with lots of dried fruit and a hint of alcohol, plus orange-peel and other spices. Very malty, somewhat anise-licoricey flavor with plums and spices. Initially sweetish and caramely, but dries out nicely towards the finish. Quite full-bodied palate with perfectly balanced carbonation. A really tasty, extremely balanced and strong dubbel brewed with taste (not overdone).

A deep brown beauty for color with copious foam in the trappist glass - thick and tan head, with wonderful lacing.  Aroma is licorice, toffee, caramel and milk chocolate.  Fizzy when it first hits the palate, but after letting it sit for about 15 minutes, the fizz subsided and the malts became superstars.  Flavor is toffee and licorice, caramel, fresh bread, tobacco leaves, figs and plantains.  Finish is tobacco and dry chocolate.  This is liquid candy.
750ml bottle had along with an Allagash Dubbel Reserve.  Allagash was a smoother, creamier drink.  Good flavor as it went across the palate, but didnt care for the finish/aftertaste.

Interesting beer.  Nice deep dark red colour, with a nice dark cream head which doesnt stay too think but does linger on the chalice.  This is a sweet beer with some nice fruity overtones.  Plenty of malt flavour and a touch of alcohol aroma but mostly just a good sweet belgian ale.  Great finish, very easy to drink the whole big bottle.

Though Im still getting acquainted with the Belgians, I really enjoyed this one.  A good full flavor with a velvety smooth and bubbly mouthfeel.  The flavor was first of several fruits - most notable to me was apple and berry with a hint of banana - then it becomes more sweet with the caramel notes and finishes with just a tingle of dry alcohol taste.  It leaves my mouth wanting more, so I succumb to my mouths desire and enjoy the rest of the bottle...  Still want more!  Ill be buying multiple bottles next time. [$3.99/25oz]
Heavy hazy ale. Pretty decent head. Alcohol wasnt too strong, simply just right. A nice "after meal treat" All in all, a very good belgian beer.
A SOLID ale! Had a dark amber color, with a nice thick head. Spices and Fruit radiate from this ale. A true pleasure for one to absorb!

Pours hazy brown/burgundy with thick frothy head. Aroma is mostly carmel and sweet. Flavor is very complex: first there is a dry earthiness, then comes the licorice, and finally a smooth slight alcohol finish. Nice. Goes great with a late breakfast of eggs and bacon.
Poured a dark amber color, with a nice thick head. Aroma was spices, fruit and caramel.  Had a thick, smmothflavor that was very true to the aroma.  Very enjoyable beer.
Deep rich burgundy color, some notes of cherries or currants noticed as well.  Quite frothy at first with subtle alcohol detection, rich semi-sweet complexity that became better as the ale warmed.
Excellent Belgian. Dark red appearance, sweet odors, rich tastes of caramel, chocolate, and slight fruitiness.  Smooth finish, sure didnt notice the alcohol.  Good stuff.

A very fruity beer, a complex taste.  It poured nicely from the bottle, with a large head.  The friut is evident in the aroma.  It may be a great example of the style, but I just dont care for it.  Its acidic, and very sweet, with a touch of chocolate on the finish.

Poured dark dark red, almost black with a good head and awesome lacing.
Aroma is chocolate, dark fruit, caramel.
